headline: For the Taliban, a New Era of Isolation Has Arrived
abstract: The group has promised moderation even while reinstituting its harsh rule of Afghanistan. Now, the revelation that the Taliban were sheltering Al Qaeda’s leader is likely to harden support for sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Hours after an American drone strike killed the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, in downtown Kabul, Taliban security forces rushed to seal off the site. Green tarps were thrown over destroyed windows. Checkpoints were put up, and shops were closed.

headline: Russia backs China’s stance on Taiwan, calling Pelosi’s visit ‘provocative.’
abstract: The Kremlin on Tuesday said Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan “provokes the situation” over the island, aligning Russia with China’s claims to Taiwan as its territory.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin on Tuesday said Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan “provokes the situation” over the island, aligning Russia with China’s claims to Taiwan as its territory.

headline: Trump Faces Questions About His Net Worth in Interview He Tried to Avoid
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has embraced the verbal sparring of legal depositions in the past, but now faces significant risk.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Donald J. Trump has boasted with impunity about a subject close to his heart and ego: his net worth.

headline: Nichelle Nichols Helped Show America a Different Future
abstract: As Lieutenant Uhura in “Star Trek” and an advocate for inclusiveness in the U.S. space program, Nichols made an indelible impact on our collective imagination.
lead_paragraph: “She walks in beauty like the night. …”

headline: Am I Mom?
abstract: The essayist Michelle Tea writes about queer parenting with frankness, humanity and verve.
lead_paragraph: We want things we know will hurt us. We chase happy endings we know are myths. And, sometimes, we look for wholeness in the very institutions and traditions we’ve built our identities in opposition to. Michelle Tea has devoted her career to chronicling the desires, fears and contradictions of contemporary urban American queer life, in genres as wide-ranging as memoir, picture books, the occult and fiction. Situating herself, her friends and her lovers against the dystopian realities of inequality, climate crisis and capitalism’s most interpersonal effects, Tea’s candid examinations of addiction, pleasure and belonging have embodied and nurtured a subculture.

headline: Profits Slump at CNN as Ratings Plummet
abstract: The network is on a pace to drop below $1 billion in profit for the first time in years, according to people familiar with its operations, amid steep declines in TV viewership.
lead_paragraph: One of the first moves the newly formed Warner Bros. Discovery made when it took over CNN was shutting down CNN+, the nascent streaming service that was touted as the network’s bridge to the future.

headline: ‘Own Every Dollar’ Gang Unleashed Havoc in Manhattan, U.S. Says
abstract: Members are responsible for killings, robberies and assaults in Washington Heights, officials said as they indicted 24 people.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 20, 2021, a man named Jeffrey Sanchez was walking toward his car in Upper Manhattan when members of a gang that calls itself Own Every Dollar rushed him. Mr. Sanchez fell, a gunshot wound in his back, said Manhattan’s district attorney, Alvin Bragg.

headline: Big Trouble in Little Loving County, Texas
abstract: Murdered cattle. Family feuds. People arrested when showing up for jury duty. In America’s least populated county, a bare-knuckle struggle for control may hold implications for Texas voters.
lead_paragraph: MENTONE, Texas — In America’s least populated county, the rusting ruins of houses, oil drilling operations and an old gas station interrupt the sun-blanched landscape. A hand-painted wood sign still promises good food at “Chuck’s Wagon” to drivers along State Highway 302, though the proprietor died months ago and the wagon is gone.

headline: Michael R. Jackson, in a Place All His Own in Washington Heights
abstract: The Tony- and Pulitzer-winning author of ‘A Strange Loop’ finally has an apartment to himself in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It had to be around here someplace, but Michael R. Jackson could not readily locate his Pulitzer Prize certificate when an importuning visitor asked for a look. He rummaged through piles of paper on a closet shelf. Not there. He inventoried the plastic storage boxes in that same closet, but came up empty again.

headline: Dozens protest in Pelosi’s home city, where attitudes toward Taiwan are shifting.
abstract: Dozens of people gathered in downtown San Francisco on Monday to protest Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s trip to Taiwan, arguing from her home district that the visit could inflame potential war with China.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people gathered in downtown San Francisco on Monday to protest Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s trip to Taiwan, arguing from her home district that the visit could inflame potential war with China.

headline: Over two dozen Republican senators laud the speaker’s Taiwan visit.
abstract: WASHINGTON — In the United States, the prospect of Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan during a diplomatic trip to Asia has been politically fraught.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the United States, the prospect of Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan during a diplomatic trip to Asia has been politically fraught.

headline: Key Themes From the 2022 Midterms
abstract: As the second half of the midterm primary season begins, some key themes have emerged. Here’s a look at what we know.
lead_paragraph: As the second half of the midterm primary season begins, some key themes have emerged. Here’s a look at what we know.

headline: Bernard Marson, a Catalyst for SoHo’s Renaissance, Dies at 91
abstract: An architect and developer, he helped pioneer the neighborhood’s transition from manufacturing into lofts where artists could work and live.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Marson, who as an architect and developer figured prominently in the transformation of a Lower Manhattan industrial district into SoHo, an affordable neighborhood for artists to work and live before it evolved into an enclave of chic boutiques, celebrity bars and overpriced apartments, died on July 9 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Dolphins Lose 2 Draft Picks; Owner Suspended for Tampering With Brady
abstract: An investigator also found no evidence that the Dolphins owner Stephen M. Ross seriously pressed his coach to deliberately lose games.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has suspended the Miami Dolphins owner Stephen M. Ross and taken away two draft picks after an investigator found the team violated the league’s anti-tampering policy by trying to lure quarterback Tom Brady and the coach Sean Payton to Miami.

headline: One Fifth, Serving Updated Italian Fare, Is Set to Open in Greenwich Village
abstract: A classic tavern in TriBeCa, a restaurant from two Momofuku Ko alumni, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: With a nearly 100-year history, this Art Deco-styled space, most recently the Batali and Bastianich team’s Otto, will reopen Aug. 9 with Marc Forgione and his Respect Hospitality running it in partnership with Apres Cru. Though the restaurant’s approach is Italian, like its predecessor, Mr. Forgione’s menu, executed with the chef Robert Zwirz, reinvents the standard repertoire. Consider dishes like squash blossom zeppole; sesame buns with lamb mortadella and pistachios; Roman-style pinsa (oval pizzas) with toppings like bottarga with fennel, and fromage blanc; smoked linguine with Manila clams and green garlic gremolata; and a Long Island cioppino. Italy and the United States are prominent on the wine list, developed by the beverage director Scott Woltz, who handles the wines for Mr. Forgione’s other restaurants, Peasant and Restaurant Marc Forgione. There’s also a hefty list of amaros. The original terrazzo floor and revolving door have been restored. The space has always been divided in two areas: Now, the bar in front offers a view of fresh pasta being made, while the main dining room beyond features old wooden tables, wall paneling made from salvaged wood and artwork that relates to the neighborhood. (Opens Aug. 9)

headline: Who’s Embargoing Whom?
abstract: Russia’s peculiar economic war with the West.
lead_paragraph: The other day, my CUNY and Stone Center colleague Branko Milanovic suggested that it would be interesting to “compare Napoleon’s continental blockade against Great Britain to the current sanctions against Russia.” As it happened, I was already on the topic. I had just read Andrew Roberts’s “Napoleon: A Life” and was thinking about the parallels.

headline: Pelosi trip could take U.S.-China acrimony to new heights, analysts say.
abstract: BRUSSELS — The visit to Taiwan by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the highest-ranking official to travel there in decades, could take the acrimony between the United States and China to new highs and leave U.S. allies in difficult positions.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The visit to Taiwan by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the highest-ranking official to travel there in decades, could take the acrimony between the United States and China to new highs and leave U.S. allies in difficult positions.

headline: The Al Qaeda That Ayman al-Zawahri Leaves Behind
abstract: The administration clearly misjudged Al Qaeda’s trajectory in Afghanistan and U.S. influence over the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden announced the withdrawal of U.S. forces from Afghanistan last year, one of his main justifications was that Al Qaeda had been so “degraded” that the United States no longer needed to maintain a military presence in a country once used as a Qaeda sanctuary. Mr. Biden also vowed to hold the Taliban to its pledge not to allow terrorists to threaten the United States from Afghan soil.

headline: Forbes Explores Sale After SPAC Deal Collapses
abstract: Forbes has tapped Citigroup to sell at a price of at least the $630 million valuation declared in its earlier plan to go public.
lead_paragraph: Forbes, the chronicler of the wealthy and powerful, announced on Tuesday that it was exploring a sale of its business after a previous deal to go public fell through.

headline: The Books Merger That’s About Amazon
abstract: The U.S. wants to stop Penguin Random House from buying Simon & Schuster. The elephant in the room is Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Amazon isn’t on trial in a big books lawsuit. But its power is.

headline: With Trade of Juan Soto, the Nationals Fire Sale Is Complete
abstract: A blockbuster trade between Washington and San Diego sends Soto and Josh Bell to the Padres, creating a potential World Series contender. It gutted the 2019 champions.
lead_paragraph: In one of the biggest deadline trades in baseball history, outfielder Juan Soto of the Washington Nationals is headed to the San Diego Padres in a blockbuster deal that was announced by both teams ahead of the 6 p.m. trade deadline on Tuesday.

headline: Dinner and Dancing in an Ivy-Laced Courtyard in Italy
abstract: On a warm summer evening, Isabel Wilkinson Schor hosted an event celebrating both her line, Attersee’s one-year anniversary and a recent collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Despite the grand surroundings, a recent dinner held in the ivy-accented courtyard of Milan’s 17th-century Palazzo Durini had a surprising sense of ease about it. This was by design. “Nothing should feel too precious,” the host, Isabel Wilkinson Schor, said of the gathering, though she could just as easily have been talking about Attersee, the New York-based clothing and accessories label she founded in June 2021 with the goal of offering versatile, high-quality clothing that wouldn’t need to be handled with kid gloves. “I found there was a disconnect between the pieces I thought were really beautiful and those I ended up wearing every day,” she said. Now, of course, she wears her own designs, which include cotton-linen pop-overs, shorts and caftans, tailored trousers and cashmere wrap coats with vintage velvet trim. She threw the dinner to celebrate her brand’s one-year anniversary, and its debut of shoes, which came in the form of a collaboration with Drogheria Crivellini, a family-run company that started selling furlanes, the round-toed slip-ons traditionally associated with Venetian gondoliers (the shoes’ soft rubber soles leave the boats’ wooden surfaces unscratched), in 1955.

headline: Another Major Heat Wave Sweeps the U.S.
abstract: After deaths in the Pacific Northwest, parts of the central United States will see record-breaking temperatures, with the Northeast broiling on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: After a miserably hot summer across much of the country, don’t expect August to bring relief.

headline: The Meridian Brothers’ Eccentric Mastermind Is Electrifying Roots Salsa
abstract: Eblis Álvarez’s albums are “collaborations” with fictional bands. His latest, with the imaginary El Grupo Renacimiento, is a psychedelic fever dream and a critique of technology’s encroachment.
lead_paragraph: One day Artemio Morelia, a singer and maracas player for an obscure Colombian salsa band called Grupo Renacimiento, awoke and found himself transformed into a robot. Haunted by visions of HAL 9000, he was suddenly acutely aware of the coldness and the distractions of a constantly plugged-in world. “Memory is dying,” he sings on his band’s new single, “Metamorfosis.” “They’ve already connected the internet to my lung/to my heart.”

headline: The U.S. imposes a new round of sanctions on Russians, including a woman close to Putin.
abstract: Many of the targets are already under sanctions imposed by the European Union and Britain. One is Alina Kabaeva, a former Olympic gymnast believed to be the romantic partner of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Tuesday announced a major new round of sanctions on dozens of Russian companies and individuals to further punish Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine, including oligarchs close to President Vladimir V. Putin and technology institutions with ties to Russia’s military.

headline: The Robust Return of Beyoncé
abstract: A deep dive on “Renaissance,” her relationship to queer music communities and her framing of authorship.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s seventh solo album, “Renaissance,” is a rich tribute to the long history of Black dance music, from disco up through ballroom house. It functions both as collage and history lesson, and also captures an evolution in her songwriting and personal presentation toward more modern directions.

headline: A Central Park Reservoir Nature Walk
abstract: An invitation to slow down and enjoy the natural beauty of New York's popular foot path.
lead_paragraph: An invitation to slow down and enjoy the natural beauty of New York's popular foot path.

headline: Review: In ‘The Butcher Boy,’ an Anti-Coming of Age Story
abstract: The new musical, based on the novel by Patrick McCabe, follows a boy in 1960s Ireland as he recounts a tale of childhood mischief and alienation.
lead_paragraph: They creep in from the shadows, snorting and snickering. The singing pigs that skulk and shimmy through “The Butcher Boy,” which opened on Monday at the Irish Repertory Theater, are silly but also half menacing. Below the neck, they’re dressed like townspeople in 1960s Ireland, where the new musical, written and composed by Asher Muldoon, is set. From the jowls up, however, their snout-nosed masks are eerily impassive.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Fond of the Little Fellow’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t want our first kiss to be in a parking lot. I told Rachel that at the end of our fourth date. She laughed and walked with me back to the water’s edge where she kissed me gently. Her tiny, rosebud shaped lips explored my big-Texas mouth. We held hands back to our cars. I breathed deeply as I watched her open her car door then turn around and walk over to mine. I rolled down my window and she put her hand around the back of my neck, giving me one more deep, incomparable kiss — in the parking lot. — Mandelyn Cloninger

headline: Don’t Call It a Swimming Pool
abstract: Plunge pools have become an alternative for homeowners who want a simple, less expensive way to cool off.
lead_paragraph: When Amy Holland bought her house in Austin, Texas, in 2020, she and her husband knew they wanted to have a pool in their backyard — but not just any pool.

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Idaho Over Its Abortion Restrictions
abstract: The Biden administration filed its first new litigation to protect access to abortion since the Supreme Court ruling in June that ended the constitutional right to terminate pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration sued Idaho on Tuesday over a strict state abortion law set to take effect this month that the Justice Department said would inhibit emergency room doctors from performing abortions that are necessary to stabilize the health of women facing medical emergencies.

headline: After Pelosi’s arrival, China announced military drills in nearby waters.
abstract: China planned live-fire drills that would take place partially inside Taiwan’s territorial waters, escalating already high tensions.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s plane touched down in Taiwan, China’s military said it would conduct drills that appeared to infringe on Taiwan’s territorial waters, setting the stage for a potential showdown over the self-governed island between China and the United States.

headline: Millions in Advertising Help Shape Closely Watched Abortion Vote in Kansas
abstract: Voters are considering amending the state Constitution in the country’s first electoral test case on abortion since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Kansas election results.

headline: Does Vitamin B6 Boost Mental Health?
abstract: Here’s what we know about this essential vitamin’s effects on well-being.
lead_paragraph: Q: Does vitamin B6 boost mental health?

headline: With New Targets, Jets Hope Zach Wilson Can Thrive Under Pressure
abstract: The Jets quarterback had little protection and few targets for his throws last season. Adding receiver Garrett Wilson and tight end C.J. Uzomah gives him better targets on broken plays.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — One scene grew more and more familiar as the second day of Jets training camp wore on last week: quarterback Zach Wilson’s scrambling.

headline: A Fed Pivot? Not Yet, Policymakers Suggest, as Rapid Inflation Lingers.
abstract: Stocks rose after the Federal Reserve’s recent meeting, with investors hoping the central bank would dial back rate increases. Not so soon, officials indicated on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials on Tuesday made clear that they expected to continue raising rates to try to choke off the most rapid inflation in decades, putting them at odds with investors who had become more sanguine about the outlook for interest rate moves.

headline: Five Years of the Second Avenue Subway
abstract: Journey to the Upper East Side for Thai specialties, “jewel” rice and South African wine.
lead_paragraph: A Gen Z friend and I shared an Uber a few months ago, and she asked me what New York was like 10 years ago. (“You should have seen it in the ’80s,” our snowy-haired driver interjected.)

headline: ‘What if This is My Destiny?’ Children of Alzheimer’s Patients Sometimes Fear Future Diagnosis
abstract: Watching a loved one’s decline can be heartbreaking, and can stoke concerns about potential memory loss.
lead_paragraph: At school pickup, Janet Perez always looks for the neon orange backpack that makes her 6-year-old son, Jayden, so easy to spot. But on a recent spring afternoon in Perris, Calif., she couldn’t find him. Her first response was primal: Someone had kidnapped him. Then she tried to remember what he had been wearing and realized she wasn’t sure if she had dropped him off that morning. A familiar dread washed over her: Was it happening? Was ‌her forgetfulness an early sign that she had her mother’s illness, Alzheimer’s disease?

headline: Here are the Republicans endorsed by Trump in Tuesday’s key races.
abstract: The former president has backed three candidates running against House Republicans who voted to impeach him, and there’s a long list of Trump-backed candidates in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s primaries in Arizona, Michigan and a handful of other states will be the latest test of former President Donald J. Trump’s long list of endorsements in competitive races.

headline: Matt Purdy, Shepherd of Investigations at The Times, Is Named Editor at Large
abstract: He has helped guide many of the newsroom’s most ambitious projects in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Matt Purdy, a top New York Times editor who has helped guide much of the paper’s Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative coverage over the past decade, will become an editor at large, The Times announced on Tuesday.

headline: Dentist Found Guilty of Murdering His Wife on a Hunting Trip
abstract: The jury in a federal court also found the dentist, Lawrence Rudolph, guilty of defrauding multiple life insurance companies when he collected nearly $4.9 million in benefits.
lead_paragraph: A dentist was found guilty by a federal jury on Monday of fatally shooting his wife in the heart on a big game hunting trip to Zambia in 2016 and then collecting nearly $4.9 million in insurance benefits.

headline: In Michigan, primary choices are defined by worries.
abstract: Voters in the Detroit suburbs said issues including the economy and bodily autonomy were driving their ballot decisions.
lead_paragraph: HAZEL PARK, Mich. — Ashley Polansky, a 34-year-old retail manager, hurried inside a polling place at a tiny church to vote on Tuesday morning with one issue foremost in her mind.

headline: The Taiwan Connection
abstract: How the war in Ukraine could affect the crisis over Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Stephen King Testifies That Merger Between Publishing Giants Would Hurt Writers.
abstract: “Consolidation is bad for competition,” Mr. King said in the trial that will determine whether Penguin Random House may acquire Simon & Schuster.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling author Stephen King testified on Tuesday in a suit filed by the Justice Department to block Penguin Random House from buying Simon & Schuster, saying the merger of two of the country’s largest publishers would make it harder for writers to earn a living.

headline: Farewell to Joey Gallo, the All-or-Nothing Yankee
abstract: The slugging outfielder known for walks, home runs and strikeouts lived up to his advance billing — in a sense. A trade to Los Angeles may set him free.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees knew what they were getting with Joey Gallo.

headline: Two More Die in McKinney Fire, Bringing Total to Four
abstract: The fire, which began Friday in the Klamath National Forest in Siskiyou County, Calif., has burned more than 56,000 acres and prompted evacuations for thousands of people.
lead_paragraph: Two more people have died in a fast-moving wildfire that has torn through more than 56,000 acres of dry timber, grass and brush in Northern California since Friday, bringing the total of those killed in the blaze to four.

headline: Robinhood lays off 23% of its staff, blaming crypto meltdown and inflation.
abstract: The trading app that helped drive the meme stock frenzy announced staff cuts for the second time this year.
lead_paragraph: Robinhood, the trading app that popularized one-click trading and helped fuel last year’s meme stock frenzy, said on Tuesday that it was laying off about 23 percent of its work force.

headline: Arizona Officials Warned Fake Electors Plan Could ‘Appear Treasonous’
abstract: Politicians involved in Donald Trump’s effort to put forth electors to falsely claim he had won Arizona said doing so without first filing a legal challenge could look like a crime.
lead_paragraph: Two Arizona Republicans recruited by allies of former President Donald J. Trump to join an effort to keep him in office after he lost the 2020 election grew so concerned about the plan that they told lawyers working on it that they feared their actions could be seen as treason, according to emails reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: China Plans Drills as Pelosi Arrives in Taiwan
abstract: Also, a U.S. strike kills Al Qaeda’s leader and Trump will face questions under oath.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi became the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit the island of Taiwan in 25 years. Her arrival set up a high-stakes standoff between the U.S. and China.

headline: Are Participles a Thing of the Past?
abstract: Our informal verbalization of verbs.
lead_paragraph: I want to follow up on the topic of language evolution that I took up in my previous newsletter about how the word “satisfying” has taken on a new meaning among many of today’s kids. The bigger theme is that we all know language inevitably changes; it’s the way we got from Latin to French or from Beowulf to Tom Wolfe. But while that change is happening, we tend to see it as decay, sloth, maybe even a scourge.

headline: Congress Clears Bill to Make Officer Suicides Eligible for Death Benefits
abstract: The bill would extend eligibility for the Public Safety Officers’ Benefits Program to families of officers who die by suicide after traumatic events on the job, including the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress has approved bipartisan legislation that would extend a benefits program for the families of public safety officers who are killed in the line of duty to officers who die by suicide as a result of a traumatic event on the job, including those who took their own lives after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: The Outdoor Cat: Neighborhood Mascot or Menace?
abstract: To some, letting cats roam is unthinkable. To others, so is keeping them inside.
lead_paragraph: Zeke, a white and gray short-haired cat with a penchant for taking down rats, is known in his Boston neighborhood as a fearless prowler.

headline: ‘Shalom Taiwan’ Review: Taking the Long Way Home
abstract: In this film, a rabbi from Buenos Aires hits the road in Taiwan to raise money for his community center.
lead_paragraph: A rabbi from Buenos Aires pounds the pavement to raise money for his community center in “Shalom Taiwan,” a film whose meager plot could use a bit of a boost itself. After finding little support on a fund-raising trip to New York, Rabbi Aaron (Fabián Rosenthal) ventures out to Taiwan on a hunch, and routine culture-clash content and sightseeing montages ensue.

headline: Boy, 14, Found Fatally Shot in a Queens Driveway, Police Say
abstract: The number of shootings in New York City has begun to subside, but the ages of some gun violence victims remain striking.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old boy was found fatally shot in a Queens driveway early Tuesday, and investigators were exploring whether the killing was connected to a shooting on a nearby block the night before, officials said.

headline: The Last Thing We Needed Was Pelosi Backing Down From a Bully
abstract: Bullies don’t usually read concessions as anything but signs of weakness.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan carries undeniable risks.

headline: ‘Exposing Muybridge’ Review: Putting a Cinematic Pioneer in Focus
abstract: A documentary of the 19th-century photographer Eadweard Muybridge’s legacy shows the enduring fascination of his work.
lead_paragraph: “Exposing Muybridge,” a documentary on the art and science of the pioneering photographer Eadweard Muybridge, trots into release less than two weeks after Jordan Peele’s “Nope” put a new spotlight on Muybridge’s proto-cinematic images of horses in motion.

headline: The Padres Go for Broke With a Roster of Superstars
abstract: San Diego has never won a World Series. By trading for Juan Soto, Josh Hader and other established stars, they are going for sensational rather than sustainable.
lead_paragraph: The franchise started in 1969, just another expansion team in funny uniforms that lost 110 games. Five decades passed, with a few Hall of Famers but no championships. Then, after years of aggressive spending and trading by the front office, Juan Soto led the team all the way.

headline: An Arbitrator Left Deshaun Watson’s Fate to the N.F.L. Commissioner
abstract: The league has until Thursday to appeal the six-game suspension of Watson recommended by hearing officer Sue L. Robinson. Legal experts said she gave Roger Goodell plenty of incentive to do so.
lead_paragraph: She called his conduct predatory and egregious, and said he expressed no remorse. Yet when it came to penalizing Deshaun Watson, the Cleveland Browns quarterback accused in lawsuits of sexual misconduct and harassment by two dozen women, Sue L. Robinson, the disciplinary officer hired by the N.F.L. and the players union, suspended him for just six games.

headline: Zelensky says Ukraine’s government may allow civil partnerships for same-sex couples.
abstract: The Ukrainian president said the constitution’s ban on same-sex marriage could not be changed during the war. Calls for equal rights have grown as L.G.B.T.Q. soldiers have joined the fight against Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky, responding on Tuesday to a citizen petition that called for the legalization of same-sex marriage in Ukraine, raised the prospect of “civil partnerships,” but said the Constitution’s definition of marriage as the union of one man and one woman could not be changed during wartime.

headline: Burt Metcalfe, Who Left His Mark on ‘M*A*S*H,’ Is Dead at 87
abstract: He was the showrunner of the classic Korean War sitcom for its last six seasons, notably casting David Ogden Stiers as the pompous surgeon Winchester.
lead_paragraph: Burt Metcalfe, who as the showrunner of “M*A*S*H” for the last six of its 11 seasons made a critical casting decision as he began his tenure and helped write the two-and-a-half-hour final episode, contributing ideas he had picked up on a trip to South Korea, died on July 27 in Los Angeles. He was 87.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Arrives in Taiwan, Drawing a Sharp Response From Beijing
abstract: China announced plans for live-fire military drills soon after Ms. Pelosi flew into Taiwan. Analysts said Beijing’s move seemed designed to project strength rather than serve as a precursor to an invasion.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday, casting aside private warnings from the Biden administration about the risk that her high-profile diplomatic visit could stoke a new crisis in Asia and immediately prompting a sharp response from the Chinese government, including new trade restrictions on Taiwan and an announcement of military exercises.

headline: Pelosi cites ‘America’s determination to preserve democracy.’
abstract: After weeks of silence ahead of a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was anything but understated on Wednesday during a day of high-profile meetings, in which she offered support for Taiwan and irked China.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of silence ahead of a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was anything but understated on Wednesday during a day of high-profile meetings, in which she offered support for Taiwan and irked China.

headline: David Axelrod on Biden, Karl Rove and What He’d Ask Trump
abstract: In a recent conversation over a Reuben and matzo ball soup, the strategist behind Barack Obama’s presidential campaigns veered from raconteur to philosopher to armchair psychologist to pundit.
lead_paragraph: Long before David Axelrod became a national figure as Barack Obama’s political guru and spinmeister — the bard of the future president’s pitch to voters on the campaign trail, and his “message maven” once in the White House — he was a working journalist in Chicago.

headline: Rugby’s Greatest Team Confronts a Worrisome Prospect: Decline
abstract: A series of defeats by New Zealand’s All Blacks has led to a humbling drop in the world rankings, and concern that the team might not have what it takes to bounce back this time.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — When New Zealand’s All Blacks face South Africa on Saturday in the opening match of the annual four-nation Rugby Championship, it will be one of the few times in their decorated history that they have played as underdogs.

headline: In Ukraine, Devastation Spreads as Russia Regroups for New Offensive
abstract: The U.S. has announced $550 million in additional arms for Ukraine as it gears up to defend its eastern regions, which Ukrainian officials have asked civilians to flee before winter.
lead_paragraph: At least 140,000 residential buildings in Ukraine destroyed or damaged. More than 3.5 million people left homeless. More than 12 million displaced. New tallies were added Tuesday to the merciless accounting that measures the losses from Russia’s invasion.

headline: Starbucks Reports Record Revenue, Driven Mostly by Gen Z’s Love of Iced Drinks
abstract: The largest coffee chain in the world said it saw no signs that consumers were giving up their nitro cold brews or iced espressos, despite higher prices.
lead_paragraph: Customers flocking to Starbucks and ordering Pineapple Passionfruit refreshers and Iced Shaken Espressos helped propel the coffee giant’s revenue to a record $8.2 billion in the latest quarter, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Several primaries are being decided Tuesday. Here’s when we might know results.
abstract: Pour a cup of coffee if you need to — this could go late.
lead_paragraph: Results from Tuesday’s elections are some of the most hotly anticipated of the midterm season, with two battleground states among the five hosting major primary contests, a spate of Trump-backed election deniers seeking their party’s nominations and the first post-Roe vote on abortion happening in Kansas.

headline: How the C.I.A. Tracked the Leader of Al Qaeda
abstract: The U.S. search for Ayman al-Zawahri had spanned decades. His presence on a balcony at a safe house in Kabul presented an opportunity to strike.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officers made a crucial discovery this spring after tracking Ayman al-Zawahri, the leader of Al Qaeda, to Kabul, Afghanistan: He liked to read alone on the balcony of his safe house early in the morning.

headline: In Visiting Taiwan, Pelosi Capped Three Decades of Challenging China
abstract: From her first days in Congress, the future speaker was willing to confront China’s leaders. As she looked toward her legacy, the California Democrat was not about to back down this time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1991, a trio of junior House members on a bipartisan trip to Asia was encouraged by a Chinese dissident they visited in Hong Kong to make a gesture of solidarity with government opponents and victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre when they reached Beijing.

headline: Eli N. Evans, Who Wrote About Jews in American South, Dies at 85
abstract: His book “The Provincials” mixed memoir, travelogue and history to tell the story of a culture that many people never knew existed.
lead_paragraph: Eli N. Evans, a courtly Carolina Tarheel who rose to the upper ranks of the New York philanthropic world, but who left his biggest mark as the author of three books exploring the culture and history of Jews in the American South, including his own family, died on July 26 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Trump tries to topple a powerful Wisconsin Republican in his futile quest to reverse his 2020 loss.
abstract: The former president endorsed a little-known challenger to Robin Vos, the Republican speaker of the Wisconsin Assembly, who has rejected attempts to overturn the state’s 2020 results.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Wis. — After months of toying with Robin Vos, who as the speaker of the Wisconsin Assembly is the most powerful Republican in state politics, former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Mr. Vos’s long-shot primary challenger on Tuesday in a futile effort to push the state’s Republicans to decertify the results of the 2020 election.

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Expand Benefits for Veterans Exposed to Burn Pits
abstract: Republicans who had blocked the bill, which would extend benefits to an estimated 3.5 million veterans, allowed it to pass after trying unsuccessfully to limit funding for the treatments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday approved a bill to create a new entitlement program to treat veterans who may have been exposed to toxic substances from burning trash pits on U.S. military bases, sending President Biden legislation that would expand medical care eligibility to an estimated 3.5 million people.

headline: Killing of Qaeda Leader Crystallizes Debate Over Biden’s Afghanistan Strategy
abstract: President Biden now confronts the question of what, if anything, he will do in response to the revelation that the Taliban were again sheltering a leader of Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sunrise missile strike that shredded the leader of Al Qaeda on the balcony of a house in Kabul finally validated President Biden’s decision to withdraw from Afghanistan. Or perhaps the strike discredited it. Or maybe some combination of both.

headline: Al-Zawahri’s Death Puts the Focus Back on Al Qaeda
abstract: The terrorist network has lost eight of its top leaders in recent years. But it has more total fighters than it did on Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No terrorist group, not even the Islamic State, has had the notoriety and immediate name recognition of Al Qaeda.

headline: Neon, Film Distributor of Indie Darlings Like ‘Parasite,’ Ponders Sale
abstract: It has tapped the investment bank Raine to assess its options, on the heels of a megadeal for another independent distributor, A24.
lead_paragraph: Neon, the independent distributor behind Academy Award-winning films such as “Parasite” and “I, Tonya,” has tapped the merchant bank Raine to explore a sale of some or all of its business, according to three people familiar with the process.

headline: Girl, 12, Escapes Captivity, Leading Alabama Authorities to Find 2 Bodies
abstract: José Paulino Pascual-Reyes, 37, was charged with capital murder and first-degree kidnapping after the authorities said they found two decomposing bodies inside his house.
lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old girl who had been held captive in a home in rural Alabama was found walking along a nearby road on Monday, which led the authorities to the bodies of her mother and brother inside the residence, the authorities said.

headline: A Battlefield From 1777 Yields a Dozen Mercenaries’ Remains
abstract: Archaeologists uncovered the remains of 13 Hessian soldiers killed by American forces in the bloody Battle of Red Bank near Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists working at Red Bank Battlefield, a site along the Delaware River south of Philadelphia, have uncovered the remains of 13 Hessian mercenaries who were killed during a bloody Revolutionary War battle.

headline: Tudor Dixon, a conservative commentator, will challenge Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in Michigan.
abstract: Ms. Dixon, who was backed by former President Donald J. Trump and Michigan’s powerful DeVos family, topped a field of relatively unknown Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: Tudor Dixon, a conservative media personality with the political backing of Michigan’s powerful DeVos family, won the state’s Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Nadler and Maloney Are Collegial at Debate. Their Rival Is Combative.
abstract: Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Carolyn Maloney touted their extensive political records while Suraj Patel highlighted his lack of one as a virtue.
lead_paragraph: After decades of working together as House colleagues and ultimately ascending to powerful committee leadership posts, Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Carolyn Maloney took the stage on Tuesday night as reluctant foes in a three-way Democratic debate.

headline: It’s Destiny!
abstract: Take a pop quiz with Daniel Bodily’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hoo boy, I have a feeling today’s puzzle is going to be a challenging one for solvers. I’ll keep this preamble short and sweet, but just know that if you had a tough time on this tricky puzzle by Daniel Bodily (his solo debut), you’re not alone. Mr. Bodily has collaborated on two New York Times crosswords in 2022, and with today’s puzzle he demonstrates his solo constructing chops and his creativity. I expect we’ll see plenty more good stuff from him in the future. It’s his destiny!

headline: Eric Schmitt defeats Eric Greitens to win Missouri’s G.O.P. Senate primary.
abstract: The victory by Mr. Schmitt, the state attorney general, was a relief for Republicans who wanted to stop Mr. Greitens, the scandal-plagued former governor, from securing the nomination.
lead_paragraph: Eric Schmitt, the Missouri attorney general, easily captured the Republican nomination for an open Senate seat on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. His decisive victory derailed the political comeback of former Gov. Eric Greitens, whose campaign had been clouded by allegations of domestic abuse, infidelity and corruption.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Johnson to Leave Office, But Keep the Spotlight
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Aug. 3, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “If you ask me, I would like to see my brother rest and write and paint and just regroup and just, you know, see what happens.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 3, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 3, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a promise from Democratic leaders and the White House to complete a highly contested 304-mile gas pipeline in West Virginia in exchange for Senator Joe Manchin III’s support of climate legislation misstated the timing of Mr. Manchin’s announcement on the agreement. It was Monday, not Tuesday.

headline: Kansas Votes to Preserve Abortion Rights Protections in Its Constitution
abstract: In the first election test after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, voters overwhelmingly rejected an amendment that would have allowed legislators to enact abortion restrictions.
lead_paragraph: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Kansas voters resoundingly decided against removing the right to abortion from the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press, a major victory for the abortion rights movement in one of America’s reliably conservative states.

headline: Taiwan’s leader, Tsai Ing-wen, has vowed to defend its sovereignty.
abstract: Taiwan’s leader, Tsai Ing-wen, owes her presidency to her pledge to preserve the island’s sovereignty. Her meeting with Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday, and Beijing’s response to the visit, are highlighting the complexity of that task.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s leader, Tsai Ing-wen, owes her presidency to her pledge to preserve the island’s sovereignty. Her meeting with Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday, and Beijing’s response to the visit, are highlighting the complexity of that task.

headline: DeGrom’s Return Makes the Mets Deadline Winners, Even in a Loss
abstract: After more than a year away, Jacob deGrom looked terrific. That the Mets lost the game, and didn’t make any significant trades, hardly seemed to matter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The buzz and clatter of baseball’s annual trading deadline drew most of the attention around the sport on Tuesday, and rightly so. Numerous players changed teams in a matter of hours, including Juan Soto, the devastating slugger for the Washington Nationals, whom some consider the best position player in the game.

headline: Senate Republicans in Support of Speaker’s Taiwan Visit
abstract: Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, and Senator Roy Blunt, Republican of Missouri, praised Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan during a diplomatic trip to Asia.
lead_paragraph: Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, and Senator Roy Blunt, Republican of Missouri, praised Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan during a diplomatic trip to Asia.

headline: ‘I Want You to Hear This’: A Sandy Hook Mother Confronts Alex Jones
abstract: Scarlett Lewis, whose son Jesse, 6, was killed in the elementary school shooting, rebuked the Infowars fabulist over his lies in a face-to-face courtroom confrontation.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the trial of Alex Jones.

headline: Vin Scully, Voice of the Dodgers for 67 Years, Dies at 94
abstract: The team has had many great players since World War II, but it was Mr. Scully, a gifted storyteller and a master of the graceful phrase, who became the enduring face of the franchise.
lead_paragraph: Vin Scully, who was celebrated for his mastery of the graceful phrase and his gift for storytelling during the 67 summers he served as the announcer for Dodgers baseball games, first in Brooklyn and then in Los Angeles, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: Senate Approves Bill to Provide Care for Veterans Exposed to Burn Pits
abstract: The Senate passed a bill to create a new entitlement program to treat veterans who may have been exposed to toxic substances from burning trash pits on U.S. military bases. It would expand medical care eligibility to an estimated 3.5 million people.
lead_paragraph: The Senate passed a bill to create a new entitlement program to treat veterans who may have been exposed to toxic substances from burning trash pits on U.S. military bases. It would expand medical care eligibility to an estimated 3.5 million people.

headline: Justice Dept. Subpoenas Pat Cipollone, Trump White House Counsel
abstract: Mr. Cipollone is the highest-ranking White House official in the lead-up to Jan. 6 who is known to have been called to testify by federal investigators.
lead_paragraph: Pat A. Cipollone, the White House counsel under former President Donald J. Trump who tried to stop some of his more extreme efforts to overturn the 2020 election, has been subpoenaed by a federal grand jury investigating activities in the lead-up to the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, a person familiar with the subpoena said.

headline: Fast-Moving California Wildfire Continues Path of Destruction
abstract: The death toll rose from the McKinney fire, which has torn through more than 56,000 acres of dry timber, grass and brush in Northern California.
lead_paragraph: The death toll rose from the McKinney fire, which has torn through more than 56,000 acres of dry timber, grass and brush in Northern California.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Nancy Pelosi meets with Taiwan’s president.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi met with Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan’s president, after visiting Taiwan’s Legislature earlier today.

headline: Pelosi’s Taiwan Visit Risks Undermining U.S. Efforts With Asian Allies
abstract: The Biden administration has built an economic and diplomatic strategy in Asia to counter China, assuring friendly countries that the U.S. is in the region for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has spent months building an economic and diplomatic strategy in Asia to counter China, shoring up its alliances and assuring friendly countries that the United States is in the region for the long haul.

headline: Here’s how abortion rights supporters won in conservative Kansas.
abstract: Turnout was high for a referendum that drew national attention.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of abortion rights won a huge and surprising victory on Tuesday in one of the most conservative states in the country, with Kansas voters resoundingly rejecting a constitutional amendment that would have let state legislators ban or significantly restrict abortion.

headline: Living side by side, Ukrainian and Russian sailors are tested by the war.
abstract: Commercial vessels have become some of the few places where Russians and Ukrainians, who make up 15 percent of the world’s 1.9 million sailors, still live side by side on routes around the world while their countries are at war. Some ships have become rare havens of understanding and forgiveness. On other ships, the mood has become tense and at times unbearable, upending the maritime tradition of sailors viewing each other as teammates, no matter their backgrounds.
lead_paragraph: Commercial vessels have become some of the few places where Russians and Ukrainians, who make up 15 percent of the world’s 1.9 million sailors, still live side by side on routes around the world while their countries are at war. Some ships have become rare havens of understanding and forgiveness. On other ships, the mood has become tense and at times unbearable, upending the maritime tradition of sailors viewing each other as teammates, no matter their backgrounds.

headline: Results from primaries in Arizona, Michigan, Kansas, Missouri and Washington.
abstract: Kansans defeated a constitutional amendment that would have enabled abortion restrictions, Missouri Republicans breathed a sigh of relief over their Senate nominee, and more results.
lead_paragraph: Voters in five states with major primary contests went to the polls on Tuesday. Here’s a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses so far.

headline: How New Yorkers Push the Limits
abstract: From speed zones to traffic crossings to parking rules, city residents try to get away with going a little faster, or cutting it close, or being a little later.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll take a quick look at limits — speed limits and time limits — prompted by the expanded operation of speed cameras in the city. We’ll also look at a book that’s finally permitted to be read in the place it’s about, except for two pages.

headline: Pelosi Vows ‘Ironclad’ Commitment in Meeting With Taiwan’s President
abstract: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, met with Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, and was presented with an award for outstanding contributions to Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, met with Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, and was presented with an award for outstanding contributions to Taiwan.

headline: Trevor Noah Weighs In on the Killing of Ayman al-Zawahri
abstract: Noah argued that safe houses should be called something different because “every terrorist gets killed in a safe house.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Chinese military drills circling Taiwan set up a potential standoff.
abstract: China’s plans to conduct live-fire drills into Taiwan’s territorial seas could mark a new stage of brinkmanship.
lead_paragraph: Although much attention has been on Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan, the real potential for a military showdown comes now that she has left.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A ‘Whisper’ Leads a Real Estate Reporter to Claims of Deed Theft
abstract: In an interview, Stefanos Chen, who covers tenants, owners and buildings in New York, discussed a recent investigation and his approach to the beat.
lead_paragraph: Last week, The New York Times published a front-page article by Stefanos Chen, Ted Clifford and Camellia Burris that examined a history of questionable dealings behind a New York real estate empire. Sanford Solny, who owns small residential buildings across the city, is accused by prosecutors of deed theft, a practice used to swindle homeowners out of their properties while leaving them stuck with the mortgage.

headline: Five of Vin Scully’s Most Memorable Calls
abstract: The longtime Dodgers announcer, who died Tuesday, narrated many of the greatest moments in baseball history.
lead_paragraph: The longtime Dodgers announcer, who died Tuesday, narrated many of the greatest moments in baseball history.

headline: Voters in Kansas Celebrate Preservation of Abortion Rights
abstract: In the first election test after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Kansas voters decided against removing the right to abortion from the State Constitution.
lead_paragraph: In the first election test after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Kansas voters decided against removing the right to abortion from the State Constitution.

headline: The Violent Fantasies of Blake Masters
abstract: His bizarre, menacing vision for American politics could well define the future of his party.
lead_paragraph: Blake Masters’s first campaign ad opens with a shot of the Sonoran Desert. A plaintive piano theme tinkles as Mr. Masters, a 35-year-old venture capitalist and, as of early Wednesday morning, the Republican nominee for Senate in Arizona, delivers a monologue in voice-over. “The truth is, we can’t take America for granted,” he says. “And if we want to keep it, we’ve got to fight for it.”

headline: Meijer’s Defeat Shows Republican Intolerance for Trump’s Antagonists
abstract: In Michigan, primary voters rejected the young conservative who voted to impeach Trump, while two other Republicans who did so fought for political survival in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The defeat on Tuesday of Representative Peter Meijer of Michigan, the young conservative scion of a supermarket empire who voted to impeach President Donald J. Trump, was another sign that the party’s conservative core is bent on casting out those who have dared to break with Mr. Trump, who has embarked on a revenge tour aimed at punishing his adversaries.

headline: OPEC Plus members agree to a small increase in oil production.
abstract: Politically, the paltry increase would appear to be a snub of President Biden, who went to Saudi Arabia seeking assurances from big producers that they would act to cool oil markets.
lead_paragraph: The group of oil producers known as OPEC Plus approved a small increase in production on Wednesday, just over two weeks after President Biden visited Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to seek assurances that the group would act to cool oil markets.

headline: Pelosi draws crowds as she moves through Taiwan’s capital.
abstract: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As Speaker Nancy Pelosi moved around Taiwan’s capital with her entourage on Wednesday, taking one meeting after another, the people of Taiwan shadowed her nearly every step of the way.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As Speaker Nancy Pelosi moved around Taiwan’s capital with her entourage on Wednesday, taking one meeting after another, the people of Taiwan shadowed her nearly every step of the way.

headline: ‘Mothercare’ Takes a Hard Look at What Happens When Duty Outlives Love
abstract: In her new book, the novelist and critic Lynne Tillman writes unsentimentally about the years she spent attending to her mother’s failing health.
lead_paragraph: Care work — tending to the sick, the very young or the very old — has long been denied the kind of recognition (and remuneration) that such essential labor deserves. Activists have argued that society should treat it as a social good, affording people the time and the resources to attend to loved ones as needed.

headline: A Creamy, Spicy Dip Unlike Any Other
abstract: The Houston chef Dawn Burrell brings her biography to everything she cooks, like her creamed collard greens spiked with chile sauce.
lead_paragraph: Dawn Burrell couldn’t be busier. When we spoke several weeks ago, the chef was in the midst of planning a Juneteenth event, preparing for the opening of a restaurant in Houston and organizing her many advocacy projects — but this workload, it seems, was a regular day.

headline: How ‘The Bear’ Captures the Panic of Modern Work
abstract: You don’t have to work in a kitchen to recognize the chaos and precarity the show depicts.
lead_paragraph: The Original Beef of Chicagoland is the fitting name of the restaurant at the heart of the acclaimed FX series “The Bear,” which stars Jeremy Allen White as Carmy, a world-class chef who returns home to run his family’s sandwich shop after his older brother’s suicide. Of all American cities, Chicago is the one whose mythos is most closely associated with a particular kind of work: honest, meaty, broad-shouldered labor that forges you into something bigger, nobler. Like the city it’s set in, the restaurant in “The Bear” is an unpretentious place, humbly catering to “the working man.” But “the working man,” we soon learn — as a young, Black, female sous-chef mocks an older, white, male manager’s use of the label — is a contested term, especially in an environment where nobody does anything but work, and pretty much nobody has anything to show for it.

headline: I Was a Lesbian Until This Summer. What Happened?
abstract: A reader worries about a summer romance that may alter her social life when she returns to college.
lead_paragraph: I am 20 years old, about to start my junior year in college and need your help ASAP! I thought I had a handle on who I am: I’ve always dated women (since I started dating two years ago), and the lesbians on campus have always been my people. I hung out with an amazing woman last year. But I met a guy at my internship this summer. Over a month, we became good friends, then we started a romantic relationship. I really like him and our sexual connection, but I have no idea what to do when I go back to school. What’s wrong with me?

headline: What’s God Got to Do With It? The Rise of Christian Nationalism in American Politics.
abstract: Esau McCaulley and Katherine Stewart on how the G.O.P. weaponized Christianity — and where we go from here.
lead_paragraph: Christian nationalism has been empowered in American politics since the rise of Donald Trump. From “Stop the Steal” to the storming of the U.S. Capitol and now, the overturn of Roe v. Wade — Christian nationalist rhetoric has undergirded it all. But given that a majority of Americans identify as Christian, faith also isn’t going anywhere in our politics. So what would a better relationship between church and state look like?

headline: When White People Become People of Color
abstract: In Mohsin Hamid’s new novel, “The Last White Man,” the white protagonist awakes to find he has turned brown.
lead_paragraph: The opening sentence of “The Last White Man,” the latest novel by the Pakistani writer Mohsin Hamid, may sound overfamiliar — “One morning Anders, a white man, woke up to find he had turned a deep and undeniable brown” — but who wouldn’t read on? A protagonist as erudite as his creator might have been grateful not to turn into a giant bug; Anders, who works in a gym and seems as aliterate as he is inarticulate, feels only rage at losing his whiteness: “He wanted to kill the colored man who confronted him here in his home, to extinguish the life animating this other’s body, to leave nothing standing but himself, as he was before.” But the self-divided Anders — could he have a more Nordic name? — calms down when he learns there’s a pandemic of changelings; the formerly white come to include his yoga-teacher girlfriend, Oona; Oona’s racist mother; and, eventually, everybody who was born white. (All except Anders’s dying father, a secondary character who gives the book its catchy, if misleading, title.) By the end, a pulp-magazine premise has metamorphosed into a vision of humanity unvexed by racial animosities.

headline: Five Minutes That Will Make You Love Duke Ellington
abstract: We asked jazz musicians, writers and others to tell us what moves them. Listen to their choices.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Zachary Woolfe, a New York Times critic and editor, posed a question: What are the five minutes or so that you would play for a friend to convince them to fall in love with classical music? How about Mozart? Or the violin? Or opera?

headline: Trump Has Big Plans for 2025, and He Doesn’t Care Whether You Think He’ll Win
abstract: Ignore them at your peril.
lead_paragraph: As he contemplates a third straight run for the presidency, Donald Trump has a multimillion-dollar political machine and a network of tax-exempt advocacy groups at his disposal. He also has a plan. The plan is to wrest control of the federal government from what he sees as a policy apparatus dominated by “radical left-wing Democrats.”

headline: This Is How the U.S. Will Stand With Taiwan
abstract: If we do nothing, then we must be comfortable with effectively ceding Taiwan by letting China continue its unabated bullying campaign.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s brutal attack on his Ukrainian neighbors has sparked global outrage — and forged unprecedented unity — among the democratic nations of the world. Not so with Xi Jinping, the hypernationalist president of the People’s Republic of China. Rather, he is no doubt taking notes and learning lessons from Russia’s unprovoked attack on Ukraine to apply to his plans for Taiwan.

headline: The Mother of South Korean Men’s Wear Rides the K-Wave
abstract: People told Woo Youngmi a war-torn country couldn’t produce luxury fashion. She proved them wrong.
lead_paragraph: Her garments are worn by stars like Lee Jung-Jae of “Squid Games,” Choi Woo-Shik of “Parasite” and members of the K-pop sensation BTS. But when the South Korean fashion designer Woo Young-mi made her international debut in 2002, few people believed high-end fashion could come out of a country known for its war-torn history.

headline: Five Takeaways From Tuesday’s Elections
abstract: Voters in deep-red Kansas delivered a loud warning shot to Republicans, and Arizona Republicans nominated a 2020 conspiracy theorist to be the state’s top election official.
lead_paragraph: While Donald J. Trump’s wing of the Republican Party flexed its muscle in primaries across the country on Tuesday, a remarkable victory for abortion rights in Kansas, coupled with a couple of defeats for Trump-styled candidates, suggest this year’s midterms are a trickier environment for uncompromising conservatives than Republicans once believed.

headline: How the Claremont Institute Became a Nerve Center of the American Right
abstract: They made the intellectual case for Trump. Now they believe the country is in a cultural civil war.
lead_paragraph: “All weak sisters on the right must be called out,” wrote the editors of The American Mind on Nov. 5, 2020, in the uncertain days after the election. Their editorial, titled “The Fight Is Now,” warned that Democrats were all but declaring themselves the winners “before the votes are counted,” making a mockery of the law and trying to “demoralize half the country,” just as they had for the “last damned century.” But the 2020 election — like the contest for America’s future — was not yet over, they vowed. “The fight has just begun,” The American Mind declared. “This is the moment that decides everything.”

headline: Kenya’s Elite Talk About American Power in the Past Tense
abstract: At a garden party I attended in a wealthy Nairobi suburb, the guests talked global politics and the upcoming presidential election in Kenya.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A Kenyan friend of mine who graduated from Harvard Business School recently told me that the United States is a good place to get an education, but “it is no longer a leading light.”

headline: You, Too, Can Strike It Rich on YouTube!
abstract: A cottage industry is persuading people to spend thousands to create video businesses on YouTube. Disclaimer: It is harder than it looks.

headline: Jennette McCurdy Is Ready to Move Forward, and to Look Back
abstract: In her memoir, “I’m Glad My Mom Died,” McCurdy, best known for her role in“iCarly,” reflects on her time as a child actor and on her troubled relationship with her mother.
lead_paragraph: When Jennette McCurdy was 16, she was in her third year on “iCarly,” the hit teen sitcom on Nickelodeon. Millions of young viewers admired her for her comic portrayal of Sam Puckett, the wisecracking pal of its title character, and she was proud that her lucrative work was helping to support her family.

headline: Giuliani Is Unlikely to Face Criminal Charges in Lobbying Inquiry
abstract: A federal investigation into Donald Trump’s former lawyer over his work in Ukraine during the 2020 campaign is winding down with no indictment expected.
lead_paragraph: As Rudolph W. Giuliani comes under intensifying scrutiny for his efforts to overturn the 2020 election results, another legal threat is quietly fading: the criminal inquiry into his ties to Ukraine during the presidential campaign.

headline: Golden Sand, Calm Waters and Dramatic Dunes: 5 Family Beaches in Europe
abstract: From the calm, clear waters of Ålbæk, Denmark, to the soft, sandy shores of Spain’s Balearic Islands, a selection of favorite beaches that both children and their parents will love.
lead_paragraph: What makes a great family beach? Clean water for swimming, clean sand for sitting, sunning, playing or walking, and naturally occurring amusements like gullies, tide pools or rocks for climbing. Access to decent food and bathrooms and even showers are also a plus and, thankfully, relatively common in Europe, where I’m based. And, of course, stunning scenery and nearby towns with lots of activities certainly help.

headline: Footprints Discovery Suggests Ancient Tracks May Cover the West
abstract: The set of 88 prints is about 12,000 years old, scientists say, and was found in the military’s Utah Test and Training Range.

headline: In the Late ’70s, Teen Punks Ruled New York. These Are Their Stories.

The thrash of hardcore was still a few years down the pike. Yet the storied music venues of Manhattan were alive and aloud with excited, underage patrons.

headline: 4 Helpful iPhone and Android Tricks You May Not Know About

But China experts predict more fallout may be ahead for businesses and investors from a trip that tested China’s appetite for confrontation.

headline: Read Your Way Through Cairo
abstract: Yasmine El Rashidi, a journalist and novelist, guides readers through Cairo, a city whose presence is so powerful it is “the subject, the object and the main character” of many of its writers.
lead_paragraph: The face of my city is changing fast. Highways are replacing centuries-old cemeteries with their mazes of alleys, old neighborhoods are being razed to make way for shiny new skyscrapers, and, on the banks of the Nile, concrete walkways and flashy cafes are uprooting the gardens and trees that have long framed the river.

headline: Russia is preparing its forces for an attack on the southern battlefront, Ukraine says.

In her book, out this month, Vitali explains that Klobuchar, the Minnesota senator, was kicked out of the hospital just a day after giving birth to her daughter. This was a not-uncommon cost-cutting measure for insurance companies in the past, and Klobuchar was sent home even though her baby had to stay because of complications.

headline: ‘This is America’s fight’: Europe largely stays out of the fray on Pelosi’s trip.

For The Times this week, Elyse Inamine wrote about the complicated relationship Korean adoptees in America have with Korean food, particularly among those who’ve become chefs. “They’re coming to terms with a heritage they didn’t grow up with,” she wrote, “and enthusiastically expressing it through the vulnerable, public act of cooking for others.”

headline: A ‘Reversible’ Form of Death? Scientists Revive Cells in Dead Pigs’ Organs.
abstract: Researchers who previously revived some brain cells in dead pigs succeeded in repeating the process in more organs.
lead_paragraph: The pigs had been lying dead in the lab for an hour — no blood was circulating in their bodies, their hearts were still, their brain waves flat. Then a group of Yale scientists pumped a custom-made solution into the dead pigs’ bodies with a device similar to a heart-lung machine.

Swiveling my head to the left, I saw what it was. The woman in the row behind me had somehow wedged her toes into the seat crevice alongside my ear.

Stretching the electric guitar across his tiny knees for the first time, using a D-cell battery as his slide, he traced the hymns his mother sang.

headline: How the Indian Action Spectacular ‘RRR’ Became a Smash in America

Now in its 10th week, it’s the rare Indian hit to catch on with American viewers outside the Indian diaspora, thanks to the unusual decision to relaunch the film weeks after it had already played across the country on 1,200 screens.
