headline: Heard the One About the Hole That Swallowed Part of Chicago?
abstract: “Mount Chicago,” Adam Levin’s new novel, is an absurdist epic for an age of disasters.
lead_paragraph: Adam Levin’s expansive new novel begins with a high-concept catastrophe. One day in November 2021, a crater opens up in Chicago and swallows a swath of Michigan Avenue, along with many thousands of people. It’s a timely setup in this age of disasters beyond parody, and Levin homes in hilariously on the lame official response. The mayor and his P.R. people call the inexplicable disaster a “terrestrial anomaly,” since the euphemism seismic event has “earthquakian overtones” and the term sinkhole is too reminiscent of Florida: Sinkholes “made you think of swamps and they made you think of armpits. Swampy armpits. Meth, opossums, thrush. … People in mourning did not need that.”

headline: 20 Years at 30,000 Feet: A Flight Attendant Answers Readers’ Questions
abstract: Does the cabin crew ever get scared in the air? Is there a secret flight attendant code? How do I survive a flight with my toddler? An industry insider answers.
lead_paragraph: As a flight attendant who has been on the job for 20 years, it’s easy to take my travel insights for granted — the little tips and tricks that make the journey smoother.

headline: In ‘A League of Their Own,’ Abbi Jacobson Makes the Team
abstract: Jacobson cocreated and stars in this new Amazon series, which expands the story told in Penny Marshall’s 1992 film.
lead_paragraph: Abbi Jacobson really can play baseball, she insisted. Just not when the cameras are rolling. “I fully get the yips when someone is watching me,” she told me.

headline: After Losing Favor to Electric Cars, Plug-In Hybrids Gain Ground
abstract: There has been a surge in the sales of cars that can travel short distances on just electricity and have a gasoline engine for longer trips.
lead_paragraph: In late 2010, General Motors sought to seize the high ground from Toyota’s successful Prius hybrid with the Volt plug-in hybrid — a car that could drive short distances on only electricity and fire up a gasoline engine for long trips.

headline: In a House Race With Big Names, 2 Women With Local Ties Rise
abstract: Carlina Rivera, a Manhattan councilwoman, and Yuh-Line Niou, a state assemblywoman, are vying to defeat rivals who include current and former members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, the megawatt contest for a rare open House seat in New York City seemed destined to be shaped by one of a handful of nationally known candidates.

headline: Amtrak Rewarded Executives With Six-Figure Bonuses as Rail Service Struggled
abstract: Most of the top leaders received bonuses above $200,000 in the last fiscal year, as Amtrak worked to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Amtrak’s top executives received six-figure incentive bonuses in 2021, their biggest payouts in years, despite the service’s lackluster financial performance and weak ridership caused by the pandemic, according to data obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Republicans Begin Adjusting to a Fierce Abortion Backlash
abstract: After Kansans voted to preserve abortion access, Republicans who once said the economy reigns supreme are acknowledging the issue will be a centerpiece in the fall campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Republican candidates, facing a stark reality check from Kansas voters, are softening their once-uncompromising stands against abortion as they move toward the general election, recognizing that strict bans are unpopular and that the issue may be a major driver in the fall campaigns.

headline: Who Killed Tair Rada? Inside Israel’s True Crime Obsession
abstract: A TV documentary upended a murder case and captivated the nation. But its sensational theories might also be distorting justice.
lead_paragraph: There is little about the limestone courthouse in Nazareth, a predominantly Arab town in northern Israel, to suggest that it would be the setting of Israel’s most-talked-about trial.

headline: ‘Something Is Wrong Here.’ More Than 100 Local Residents Had Brain Tumors, but What Was the Cause?
abstract: The complicated nature of cancer cluster investigations.
lead_paragraph: Al Lupiano, his wife and his sister all had brain tumors.

headline: Kylie Minogue Mixes Her Signature Cocktail
abstract: The pop star returned to the Carlyle Hotel after celebrating her wine collection there.
lead_paragraph: Kylie Minogue’s early experiences of alcohol were not especially glamorous — canned drinks with teenage friends, boxed wine at family barbecues. But Ms. Minogue, 54, the only female artist to have topped music charts in five consecutive decades, has refined her relationship to liquor since.

headline: ‘Captain Condom’ Turned the Tide in Thailand’s War on AIDS and Overpopulation
abstract: At a time when most Thais avoided discussing safe sex and family planning, Mechai Viravaidya promoted condom use with spectacle and humor, saving millions of lives.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Mechai Viravaidya twice saw Thailand in desperate trouble — first from a ruinous population explosion and then from the AIDS epidemic — and he responded to both crises the same way: with condoms and his own considerable charisma.

headline: Mitch Epstein’s America: Funny, Nostalgic — and a Bit Lonely
abstract: Between the 1970s and 1990s, the photographer captured a nation at leisure.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, the American photographer Mitch Epstein published a book of photographs of American people, from New York to Los Angeles, Dallas to Gary, Ind., between the early 1970s and the early 1990s. A new, updated edition of RECREATION (Steidl, $85), edited by Susan Bell and Ryan Spencer, includes 34 previously unseen images, creating an expanded portrait of a nation at various forms of leisure.

headline: Jacques Pépin, in Search of Lost Cars and Cuisine
abstract: Have France’s distinctive food and automobiles slipped in their cultural cachet? The celebrity chef and serial owner of French cars has opinions on the matter.
lead_paragraph: While the French famously obsess about the dilution of their culture at home, it is not unfair to say that their great nation’s cultural sway appears to have dwindled in the larger world as well. To give two examples that touch me where I live, the primacy of French cuisine — once regarded as the world’s best — is finis. No longer is the cozy French bistro a staple of every American city.

headline: A Mother on a Mission: World-Class Music for Everyone
abstract: Community Concerts aimed for “a Carnegie Hall in every town.” Its adherents, including the author’s mother, were devoted to the cause. For decades, the experiment worked.
lead_paragraph: After Don Shirley performed with his trio before an appreciative audience in the Putnam High School auditorium in November 1965, he did not go back to his lonely motel room and hit the Cutty Sark, the way he did in the movie “Green Book” — at least not right away. Thanks largely to my mother, he came to our house first.

headline: The Mysterious Dance of the Cricket Embryos
abstract: A team of biologists and mathematicians studied hours of video to learn how insects take shape in the egg. The secret is geometry.
lead_paragraph: In June, 100 fruit fly scientists gathered on the Greek island of Crete for their biennial meeting. Among them was Cassandra Extavour, a Canadian geneticist at Harvard University. Her lab works with fruit flies to study evolution and development — “evo devo.” Most often, such scientists choose as their “model organism” the species Drosophila melanogaster — a winged workhorse that has served as an insect collaborator on at least a few Nobel Prizes in physiology and medicine.

headline: Jim Steinman’s ‘Cottage to Compound’ in Connecticut
abstract: The Ridgefield home of songwriter Jim Steinman, who died last year, is going on the market with all of his personal belongings still inside.
lead_paragraph: The Ridgefield home of songwriter Jim Steinman, who died last year, is going on the market with all of his personal belongings still inside.

headline: A Gothic Rock Cottage Fit for a Bat Out of Hell
abstract: Jim Steinman spent years transforming his Connecticut house into a kind of rock ‘n’ roll museum. Now his friends are trying to sell it — with his belongings intact.
lead_paragraph: Jim Steinman, who died last year at 73, left behind one of the most distinctive catalogs of music in history, filled with chart-topping hits written for the likes of Meat Loaf, Bonnie Tyler and Celine Dion. With songs ranging from the restless (“All Revved Up With No Place To Go”) to the wrenching (“For Crying Out Loud”), Mr. Steinman spent decades establishing himself as a sophisticated songwriter with the spirit of a teenager.

headline: With Surge in July, U.S. Recovers the Jobs Lost in the Pandemic
abstract: The increase of 528,000 outstripped expectations, and the gains were spread widely across industries. The jobless rate fell to 3.5 percent.
lead_paragraph: U.S. job growth accelerated in July across nearly all industries, restoring nationwide employment to its prepandemic level, despite widespread expectations of a slowdown as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to fight inflation.

headline: Gloomy about the economy and inflation, Americans remain upbeat about jobs.
abstract: In a survey, most say that it is a good time to find work and that the labor market favors employees. They see little change ahead for at least six months.
lead_paragraph: Americans are worried about inflation, pessimistic about the economy overall and upset about the way their leaders are handling it. But they still feel pretty good about the job market.

headline: Amid the Pandemic, the Rise of the Single-Issue Parent: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Welcome to Soccer’s Strangest Season
abstract: The World Cup will split seasons in two in much of the world, including the Premier League campaign that opens this weekend. What is revealed could be fascinating.
lead_paragraph: Gian Piero Ventrone surveyed his handiwork with just the hint of a smile. A few minutes earlier, Ventrone, Tottenham Hotspur’s fitness coach, had gathered the club’s players together on the turf at the Seoul World Cup stadium and informed them of their next assignment.

headline: Fight or Surrender: Taiwan’s Generational Divide on China’s Threats
abstract: In areas close to the military drills, younger Taiwanese worried about the future, while older residents looked back to a harsher past to find hope.
lead_paragraph: KINMEN COUNTY, Taiwan — The San Jiao Fort cafe on Kinmen Island may well be the best place in Taiwan to watch for the threat of invasion by China. Boasting a direct view of the Chinese city of Xiamen just six miles away, it is built atop an old military bunker, festooned with camouflage netting, and serves hot and cold beverages.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Reassure Asian Allies as China’s Military Grows Bolder
abstract: The Biden administration says its commitment to the region has only deepened, but critics say the tensions over Taiwan show that Washington needs stronger military and economic strategies.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Just a few hours after five Chinese missiles blasted into Japanese waters near Taiwan, the foreign ministers of China and Japan found themselves uncomfortably close together, in the holding room for a gala dinner on Thursday night at a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

headline: Vacationing in the Time of Covid
abstract: The story of one man’s determination to resume traveling — despite the particular risks to his health.
lead_paragraph: Charles Falls Jr., known as Chillie, loves to take cruises. But Covid, as it has done for so many, left him marooned at home in Virginia.

headline: Coal vs. Wall Street
abstract: Republican state officials have found a new way to push back against “woke capitalism”— by punishing companies that distance themselves from fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: Climate change isn’t a partisan issue in many countries. Both right-leaning and left-leaning parties favor policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, even if they fight over the specifics of those policies. This consensus allowed the European Union to cut emissions sharply over the past few decades, as the threat of global warming became clearer.

headline: Lessons From the ’80s, When Volcker Reigned and Rates Were High
abstract: When inflation was soaring 40 years ago and the economy slowed, short-term investing was perilous. But people with patience and long horizons came out fine.
lead_paragraph: The cost of living is sky-high, and the chair of the Federal Reserve says that battling it is his highest priority. Financial markets don’t know quite how to react.

headline: Spain Limits Air-Conditioning to Save Energy
abstract: The country this week became the latest to announce restrictions, in part to promote energy efficiency but also to reduce consumption of Russian gas.
lead_paragraph: Public buildings in Spain will be cooled to no less than 27 degrees Celsius (81 Fahrenheit) in the summer, and heated to no more than 19 degrees Celsius (66 Fahrenheit) in the winter as part of a plan to save energy, the government said this week.

headline: Facing Energy Crisis, Germans, Warily, Give Nuclear a Second Look
abstract: For three decades, nuclear power was one of Germany’s most divisive debates. But with Russia cutting gas, Germans are revisiting their political energy taboos.
lead_paragraph: LANDSHUT, Germany — When Angela Merkel pulled the plug on nuclear power after the Fukushima meltdown, she put Germany back on course to become the only leading industrial nation to abandon atomic energy in the world. The economic engine of Europe planned instead to fuel itself through a transition to renewable energies with cheap Russian gas.

headline: Sri Lankan Family Wins a Long Battle to Stay in Australia
abstract: Rights groups say they do not expect Australian immigration policy to change significantly with its new government, but the decision raised hopes for a more tolerant approach.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Four years ago, immigration officers arrived at dawn to rip a Sri Lankan family away from the life they had built in the tiny Australian town of Biloela.

headline: Fire at Thailand Nightclub Kills at Least 13
abstract: Witnesses said the flames spread rapidly. A video showed victims running from the building with their clothes ablaze.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A fire broke out in a crowded music pub in Thailand’s eastern Chonburi Province early Friday morning and spread quickly, killing at least 13 people and injuring about three dozen, the authorities said.

headline: 3 Downpours in 8 Days: How Extreme Rain Soaked the Midwest
abstract: Back-to-back deluges swamped Kentucky, Missouri and Illinois. These types of storms are expected to be more frequent and more intense as the planet warms, climate experts say.
lead_paragraph: Three separate downpours across three states over a span of eight days this summer swept away homes, destroyed crops and left at least 39 people dead.

headline: Why College Students May Need Renter’s Insurance
abstract: The insurance can help pay for property damaged in a fire or stolen. And replacing clothes, furniture and electronic gadgets adds up.
lead_paragraph: College students who are already shopping for laptops, textbooks and other campus gear may want to add something else to their list: renter’s insurance.

headline: Pregnant Men Were a Movie Punchline. Now They’re Horror Villains.
abstract: The idea of the pregnant man has long been mined for Hollywood comedy. This summer, he becomes a menace.
lead_paragraph: When I was four months pregnant, just as my midsection had grown vast enough to convert my pregnancy into a public event, I escaped to the movies. I saw “Men,” Alex Garland’s May horror film about the young widow Harper (Jessie Buckley), who sets out on a restorative countryside getaway only to be terrorized by a village full of unsavory male archetypes — pervy vicar, passive-aggressive nice guy, condescending cop — all played by Rory Kinnear.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 12 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 23.
lead_paragraph: Aug. 23 update: This week’s winners have been announced!

headline: A Tax Loophole’s Powerful Defender
abstract: Senator Kyrsten Sinema had one main request before she would support a key spending bill: Preserve a tax loophole that mainly benefits people in private equity.
lead_paragraph: Sinema is in. But a plan to close a big tax loophole is out.

headline: In Chinatown and the Bay Area, Residents React to Pelosi’s Trip
abstract: Chinese and Taiwanese Americans offer varying thoughts on the House speaker’s visit.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan this week drew concern from U.S. allies in Asia, support from Republican senators and sharp criticism from China.

headline: The jobs report suggests President Biden is right about a recession.
abstract: But the unexpectedly strong employment growth reported for July also appeared to contradict forecasts that the economy was cooling off.
lead_paragraph: The strong jobs report was welcome news for President Biden, who has insisted in recent weeks that the United States is not in recession, even though it has suffered two consecutive quarters of economic contraction.

headline: 6 Practical Alternatives to Pro Kitchen Tools
abstract: No, you don't need kitchen tweezers.
lead_paragraph: No, you don't need kitchen tweezers.

headline: Iran Targets Its Baha’i Community With Arrests and Home Demolitions
abstract: Representatives of the religious minority said that the crackdown was the latest chapter in a long history of persecution. The authorities accused those detained of being spies with links to Israel.
lead_paragraph: Iran has begun a sweeping crackdown on its Baha’i community, a long-persecuted religious minority, arresting dozens of people and destroying property belonging to members of the group, according to accounts this week from the government, residents and rights groups.

headline: The Home Runs Kept Coming, but It Wasn’t Enough
abstract: Los Angeles went deep seven times on Thursday — with Shohei Ohtani hitting two — but managed to lose anyway. For better or worse, that is the Angels’ way.
lead_paragraph: For a team that boasts Mike Trout and Shohei Ohtani, the Los Angeles Angels sure lose a lot of games: 61 so far, with only 44 wins.

headline: She’s the Secret Weapon in a Film About the Thai Cave Rescue
abstract: For Ron Howard’s retelling of the 2018 ordeal, Pattrakorn Tungsupakul not only played the mother of a stranded boy, she also made key script contributions.
lead_paragraph: When Ron Howard set out to retell the story of the dramatic 2018 rescue of a young soccer team from a flooded cave in northern Thailand, he knew he would have to grapple with underwater photography, hordes of extras and a handful of surly protagonists in the form of the British divers who successfully saved the boys through extraordinary methods. But he also knew that, as an American director tackling a specifically Thai story, authenticity would be crucial — and that any deviation from verisimilitude would come at his peril.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kathryn Bond Stockton
abstract: A conversation with the queer theorist
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kathryn Bond Stockton. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: A.I. Is Not Sentient. Why Do People Say It Is?
abstract: Robots can’t think or feel, despite what the researchers who build them want to believe.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Grilled shrimp with chile, a classic Denver omelet and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I once had a fantastic wood-fired seafood pizza at the Seaside Café in Key West, Fla.: sweet and salty, luxurious with lobster meat, cream sauce, fontina and puréed garlic. The meat was plush, pillowy, perfectly cooked, and I wondered about that. If I put knuckles of cooked lobster on a pizza in a 1,000-degree wood oven, they’d turn into rubber chew toys.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Apocalyptic photographers, amnesiac killers and dueling Karen Gillans make up this month’s sci-fi selections.
lead_paragraph: Just a few minutes into this new South Korean import, it’s obvious we are in for a completely bonkers ride. Shortly after waking up with amnesia and a cross-shaped incision on the back of his neck, Carter (Joo Won, the star of the original Korean version of “The Good Doctor”) has recovered enough to brutally dispatch dozens of half-naked foes in a blood-soaked melee inside a bath house. He hears a woman’s voice in his head that informs him that a spreading virus is turning people into bald zombielike maniacs, and he must deliver the antidote to North Korea. Should Carter, a rogue former C.I.A. operative, trust a disembodied voice from North Korea to begin with? You have one guess.

headline: Questioning the Place of Black Art in a White Man’s Collection
abstract: Isaac Julien’s installation at the Barnes Foundation highlights the museum’s African sculptures even as it questions the ethics of their acquisition.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Dazzled by the iconic Cézanne, Matisse and Seurat paintings, most visitors to the Barnes Foundation overlook the African sculptures. Yet to Albert C. Barnes, who founded the collection, they were central. He started acquiring African sculpture in 1922, the year he set up the foundation, because it had inspired Picasso, Modigliani and many other artists in France he supported. “When the Foundation opens, Negro art will have a place among the great art manifestations of all times,” he wrote to his Parisian dealer in 1923.

headline: A Road Trip to Sample America’s Many, Many Music Festivals
abstract: With a minivan and a three small children in tow, a critic spent 12 days discovering classical music offerings among the Rocky Mountains.
lead_paragraph: Four classical music festivals. Three children. Two exhausted parents, with a brave grandfather in tow. One bedraggled minivan.

headline: What I’m reading
abstract: The seismic shifts of the 1960s are still reverberating in the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written a lot lately about America in the 1960s  and the way that the backlash to civil rights paved the way for the modern Republican Party’s hard-line positions on gun control and abortion bans. But I haven’t spent as much time looking at what happened within the Democratic Party that enabled that seismic shift to happen. So this week I’ve been remedying that with a giant stack of vacation reading:

headline: How Much Do You Know About “The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love”?
abstract: Do you know the answers to five trivia questions about this award-winning novel?
lead_paragraph: Do you know the answers to five trivia questions about this award-winning novel?

headline: How floods become human catastrophes
abstract: Parts of the South and Midwest are cleaning up from deadly flooding. We explain the factors that sharply increased the risks.
lead_paragraph: The greatest hazard of the climate-changed era is often just the hard fact of being poor.

headline: Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: This week, the late-night hosts discussed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan, a surprising abortion-rights win in Kansas and Brittney Griner’s sentencing in Russia.
lead_paragraph: This week, the late-night hosts discussed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan, a surprising abortion-rights win in Kansas and Brittney Griner’s sentencing in Russia.

headline: Carried Interest Is Back in the Headlines. Why It’s Not Going Away.
abstract: Changes demanded by Senator Kyrsten Sinema will preserve a tax loophole that Democrats have complained about for years.
lead_paragraph: For years, Democrats and even some Republicans such as former President Donald J. Trump have called for closing the so-called carried interest loophole that allows wealthy hedge fund managers and private equity executives to pay lower tax rates than entry-level employees.

headline: They Got to the Premier League. Staying? That’s the Hard Part.
abstract: Fulham has made a habit of bouncing in and out of the world’s richest soccer competition in recent years. Is there a business model in being almost good enough?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The thing about Aleksandar Mitrovic is that he is not just a striker, barrel-chested and shaven-headed and keen-eyed. He is not simply a Serbian international, a fairly constant presence for his country for the better part of a decade. Nor is he merely something of a national hero, scorer of the goal that sent his country to the World Cup.

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen’s Brand-New Boy Problems, and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by DJ Khaled featuring Drake and Lil Baby, Panda Bear & Sonic Boom, the 1975 and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Arming Teachers: A Misguided ‘Solution’
abstract: Teachers with guns? Readers don’t think much of the idea. Also: Analyzing Russia and Putin; G.O.P. governors; Kentucky heartbreak; mixed martial arts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jurors in the Alex Jones Trial Get to Pose Questions to Witnesses — and They Are Revealing.
abstract: After Mr. Jones cast jurors on his broadcast as ignorant “blue-collar” people handpicked by his political enemies, they asked for his definition of “blue collar.”
lead_paragraph: Judge Maya Guerra Gamble of the Travis County District Court employed an unusual practice during the Alex Jones defamation trial: She allowed the jury to ask written questions of all witnesses.

headline: Overlooked No More: Alda Merini, Poet Who Wrote of Life’s Joys and Struggles
abstract: Countless fans have been intrigued by her verses carrying erotic and sacred imagery, and by her life, from her childhood in Milan to her time spent in asylums.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: ‘Easter Sunday’ Review: A Feel-Good Filipino Family Comedy
abstract: Jo Koy stars as a struggling comedian who is balancing his acting career with the demands of his son and mother.
lead_paragraph: “Easter Sunday” has all the makings of a rollicking family comedy: The protagonist is a struggling actor and comedian with wacky relatives and a rocky relationship with his son. The film features mostly Filipino actors, with wonderful, culturally specific jokes and a cast of characters that fit into stereotypical, but no less true, immigrant archetypes. Not only Filipino viewers will see their families represented here; much of it rang true to this Dominican reviewer, as well.

headline: ‘This Broke Me’: Parkland Trial Reveals Depths of Families’ Sorrow
abstract: The rare trial of a gunman in a mass shooting has underscored how massacres shatter families and communities over time.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Peter Wang’s mother has four tattoos memorializing her 15-year-old son, one inked on Feb. 14 each year since he was killed. Carmen Schentrup’s parents find sleep elusive. Nicholas Dworet’s mother hesitates every time someone asks her, “How many kids do you have?”

headline: The Carried Interest Loophole Survives Another Political Battle
abstract: The latest effort to narrow the preferential tax treatment used by private equity executives failed after Senator Kyrsten Sinema objected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Once again, carried interest carried the day.

headline: ‘Most Severe’ Drought Grips France as Extreme Heat Persists in Europe
abstract: A lack of rain and a string of heat waves have caused devastating wildfires and left farmland parched in the country and much of the continent.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France declared Friday that it was in the grip of its “most severe” drought, one that has also desiccated large areas of Europe this summer, causing wildfires and imperiling crops as temperature records shatter across the continent.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: These titles by Colson Whitehead, Spencer Ackerman and Olivia Laing offer a range of narratives for any reader.
lead_paragraph: These titles by Colson Whitehead, Spencer Ackerman and Olivia Laing offer a range of narratives for any reader.

headline: The Humbling of Coinbase
abstract: In just over a year, the United States’ largest cryptocurrency exchange went from a triumphant public offering to a “crypto winter” of cost cutting and layoffs.
lead_paragraph: Brian Armstrong, the chief executive of the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the United States, traveled across the world to make an announcement in early April: Coinbase was bringing crypto to India.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The Webb telescope’s new cosmic snapshot. Also in this edition: illegal airstrips in Brazil and the wild life of a bishop robbed at the pulpit.
lead_paragraph: The Webb telescope’s new cosmic snapshot. Also in this edition: illegal airstrips in Brazil and the wild life of a bishop robbed at the pulpit.

headline: Why Monkeypox Vaccine Shortage May Threaten the Immunocompromised
abstract: People with H.I.V. and other immune-system problems may need the full two-dose regimen, researchers say. But the shots, particularly second doses, are hard to come by.
lead_paragraph: The shortfall of monkeypox vaccine doses in the United States, expected to last for months, is raising urgent questions about how well and for how long a single shot may protect against the virus.

headline: The Republican National Convention Will Be Held in Milwaukee in 2024
abstract: In choosing Milwaukee, Republicans picked an overwhelmingly Democratic city in America’s pre-eminent battleground state.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee will hold its 2024 convention in Milwaukee, Ronna McDaniel, the party’s chairwoman, announced Friday.

headline: Corny on Main
abstract: Sometimes you just can’t get enough of those sweet, fresh summer cobs.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I told you I was in full tomato mode. Which is true. But it’s not the whole story.

headline: Amazon to Buy Maker of the Roomba for $1.7 Billion
abstract: The acquisition of iRobot Corp., maker of the robot vacuum, will add to Amazon’s roster of smart home devices, which includes the Alexa virtual assistant and Ring doorbells.
lead_paragraph: Hey, Alexa, tell Roomba to vacuum the bedroom.

headline: Premier League Preview: Has Arsenal Pulled It Together? Will United Fall Apart?
abstract: Six contenders (more or less) and five story lines (plus a few extra) as the new season kicks off with everyone chasing Manchester City (again).
lead_paragraph: Somehow, it is that time again. Cue the dramatic music, crank up the content generator and get ready to absorb the hottest takes around: the Premier League season is upon us once again.

headline: Wonking Out: The Meaning of Falling Inflation
abstract: Don’t get carried away, but do accept the good news.
lead_paragraph: Inflation is coming down — fast.

headline: Fetterman Plans His Return to Campaign Trail in Pennsylvania Senate Race
abstract: Mr. Fetterman has been criticized by his opponent, Dr. Mehmet Oz, over his absence from in-person campaigning since he suffered a stroke in May.
lead_paragraph: Three months after John Fetterman, Pennsylvania’s Democratic Senate nominee, was sidelined by a stroke, he is planning to return to the campaign trail with a rally next Friday.

headline: The Composer Huang Ruo on Illusion and Betrayal in ‘M. Butterfly’
abstract: Huang, who wrote the music for the operatic adaptation of David Henry Hwang’s play, says its exploration of race, gender and power still resonates today.
lead_paragraph: The question from the Chinese-born composer Huang Ruo came out of the blue: Would David Henry Hwang, the American playwright, consider adapting his Broadway hit “M. Butterfly” for the opera stage?

headline: A Town in Washington State Is Evacuated as a Wildfire Burns Six Houses
abstract: The fire also destroyed eight other structures as it burned about 2,500 acres in and around the town of Lind, Wash., on Thursday, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A small town in Washington state was temporarily evacuated on Thursday after a fast-moving wildfire destroyed at least six homes, the authorities said.

headline: Slow-Cooked Lamb That Can Stand the Heat
abstract: A meaty main, cooked indoors or out, anchors David Tanis’s August menu, book-ended by a light tomato-eggplant salad and an effervescent fruit compote.
lead_paragraph: Speaking of summer weather, or weren’t we? I pronounce it “exceedingly hot and humid.” While that’s not true of everywhere, of course, I know many people who would emphatically answer yes when asked, “Hot enough for you?” And emphatically no when asked, “Are you going to cook?” Some won’t even turn on the oven or boil a pot of water from June to October.

headline: The Sandy Hook defamation cases have put Alex Jones’s finances under scrutiny.
abstract: The conspiracy theorist filed for bankruptcy for Infowars’ parent company, but lawyers for parents of the school shooting victims called it a ploy to shield him from paying damages.
lead_paragraph: Alex Jones’s attempts to shield his fortune from legal threats drew a warning this week from a Texas judge and new revelations about the finances of his misinformation operation.

headline: Russia and Ukraine trade accusations of terrorism after blasts at a giant nuclear complex.
abstract: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Ukrainian officials have been raising alarms for months. The world’s nuclear watchdog agency warned of the extraordinary risks just this week. Then on Friday, artillery duels near a giant nuclear power plant on the Dnipro River in southern Ukraine created new safety risks.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Ukrainian officials have been raising alarms for months. The world’s nuclear watchdog agency warned of the extraordinary risks just this week. Then on Friday, artillery duels near a giant nuclear power plant on the Dnipro River in southern Ukraine created new safety risks.

headline: Coco Gauff vs. Naomi Osaka Could Be a (Friendly) Rivalry in the Making
abstract: Gauff, 18, and Osaka, 24, played a cracker of a match Thursday night in San Jose, Calif., as they prepared for the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Maybe, some years in the future, if Coco Gauff goes on to fulfill the destiny that some have predicted for her, her win over Naomi Osaka, 6-4, 6-4, on Thursday night will serve as a torch-passing moment.

headline: Democrats’ Long-Sought Plan for Lowering Drug Costs Is at Hand
abstract: Empowering Medicare to negotiate prices directly with drug makers has been a Democratic goal for 30 years, one the pharmaceutical industry has fought ferociously.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, as prescription drug costs have soared, Democrats have battled with the pharmaceutical industry in pursuit of an elusive goal: legislation that could drive down prices by allowing Medicare to negotiate directly with drug makers.

headline: Poems in Practice and in Theory
abstract: Elisa Gabbert talks about her poetry criticism and her own poems, and Ian Johnson discusses Wang Xiaobo’s novel “Golden Age.”
lead_paragraph: Elisa Gabbert, the Book Review's On Poetry columnist, visits the podcast this week to discuss writing about poetry and her own forthcoming collection of poems, her fourth, “Normal Distance.”

headline: ‘Nope’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Jordan Peele narrates a sequence from “Nope,” starring Daniel Kaluuya.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Peele narrates a sequence from “Nope,” starring Daniel Kaluuya.

headline: Watch Daniel Kaluuya Face a U.F.O. in ‘Nope’
abstract: The writer-director Jordan Peele narrates a harrowing sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Love Letter: ‘Don’t Start Anything’
abstract: Scrolling through Instagram, a formerly ultra-Orthodox Jewish woman wonders what happened and what could have been.
lead_paragraph: I’ve read many Modern Love submissions about encountering old crushes and high school flames online. (First love never dies, right? Especially in the digital age.)

headline: What Was Revealed About Alex Jones’s Net Worth and More in His Trial
abstract: The closely watched proceedings delved into Mr. Jones’s finances and included text messages that his lawyers had accidentally sent to attorneys for the families of Sandy Hook victims.
lead_paragraph: The trial this week for damages that the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones must pay to the parents of a child killed in the 2012 mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School has revealed interesting details about Mr. Jones and his Infowars media company, which he used to spread lies about the shooting.

headline: A U.S. diplomat warns African countries against buying anything from Russia except grain and fertilizer.
abstract: “We caution countries not to break those sanctions,” the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield said, warning of that they stood the chance “of having actions taken against them.”
lead_paragraph: Ahead of a trip to Uganda and Ghana this week, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, said in an interview that it would be a “listening tour” and that she wanted to find solutions, not assign blame, over a food insecurity crisis intensifying on the African continent since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Dee Hock, Credit Card Visionary, Is Dead at 93
abstract: As chief executive of Visa, he transformed a struggling company into a global powerhouse and the world’s leading credit card network.
lead_paragraph: Dee Hock, a banker with a junior college degree who shaped the Visa credit card into a global financial behemoth, died on July 16 at his home in Olympia, Wash. He was 93.

headline: Griner’s Sentence Renews Pressure on President Biden
abstract: The basketball star’s supporters are pressing for action. But critics of any possible deal are already fuming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Immediately after a Moscow judge handed down Brittney Griner’s nine-year prison sentence on Thursday, calls grew louder for President Biden to find a way to bring her home.

headline: Dick Cheney excoriates Trump in an ad for his daughter Liz Cheney.
abstract: The one-minute ad landed with a bang on social media, but in Wyoming, it is highly unlikely to sway any significant number of voters in Ms. Cheney’s favor.
lead_paragraph: A new advertisement for Representative Liz Cheney’s re-election campaign features a leader of a bygone era in the Republican Party excoriating the leader of the current one.

headline: Amber Midthunder Has a New Action Hero for You
abstract: She is gaining a reputation for such roles with films like “The Ice Road” and her latest, “Prey.” She’s the rare Native American actress to star in the genre.
lead_paragraph: It was the day a grand showdown fight in “Prey” was to be shot, and Amber Midthunder felt awful.

headline: South Korea Is Scouting Out the Moon, With More Missions to Come
abstract: The Danuri spacecraft, which launched on Thursday, aims to provide a lunar scientific bounty while preparing the country’s small space program for future exploration.
lead_paragraph: South Korea set off for the moon on Thursday. But it doesn’t want to stop there.

headline: Clock Running Out on Antitrust Bill Targeting Big Tech
abstract: A sweeping bill that would enact the strongest restrictions on Big Tech companies in the United States has been stalled in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Critics of the country’s largest tech companies branded the last few months “Hot Antitrust Summer” because they hoped that Congress would vote on new regulations for Amazon, Apple, Google and Facebook.

headline: Man Charged With Killing Worker Over Duck Sauce Found Dead, Police Say
abstract: Authorities were checking on the man, Glenn Hirsch, after he failed to appear in court. He died after shooting himself, according to the New York City medical examiner’s office.
lead_paragraph: A man charged with murder last month in the killing of a Chinese food delivery worker amid a dispute over duck sauce was found dead on Friday after shooting himself in his Queens apartment, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Mary Ellin Barrett, Daughter and Defender of Irving Berlin, Dies at 95
abstract: When the great American songwriter’s character came under attack after his death, Ms. Barrett sought to correct the record with a candid but tender memoir.
lead_paragraph: The songwriter Irving Berlin defined a very American style of sunniness. “Anything You Can Do (I Can Do Better)” delighted in competition. “Puttin’ On the Ritz” made social mobility silly. “White Christmas” exalted innocence. With “God Bless America,” Berlin, an immigrant from Russia, wrote the unofficial second national anthem of his adopted home.

headline: Good News on Jobs May Mean Bad News Later as Hiring Spree Defies Fed
abstract: Employers hired rapidly and paid more in July, suggesting the Federal Reserve may have to remain aggressive in its effort to cool the economy.
lead_paragraph: America’s job market is remarkably strong, a report on Friday made clear, with unemployment at the lowest rate in half a century, wages rising fast and companies hiring at a breakneck pace.

headline: 10 Dead in Fast-Moving Pennsylvania Fire, Officials Say
abstract: Among those killed in the blaze, at a home in Nescopeck in the northeastern part of the state, were several relatives of a firefighter who was at the scene.
lead_paragraph: A fire described as “violent” and “forceful” swept through a home in Northeastern Pennsylvania early on Friday morning, killing 10 people, including several relatives of a firefighter who responded to the blaze, according to the authorities and the firefighter.

headline: A Nuclear U-Turn
abstract: Russian gas cuts force Germany to reconsider shutting its atomic power plants.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Ronald J. Sider, 82, Who Urged Evangelicals to Social Action, Dies
abstract: He often bucked the rightward trend among some Christians, and in a popular 1977 book he argued that faith meant more than just personal salvation.
lead_paragraph: Ronald J. Sider, an evangelical Christian author and speaker who, in an era when evangelicals increasingly aligned themselves with the political right, argued that Christ called the faithful to attend to social justice issues like racism and poverty, died on July 27 at his home in Lansdale, Pa., near Philadelphia. He was 82.

headline: A New National Health Emergency
abstract: And the new rules of travel.
lead_paragraph: We’re taking a detour from our regular Covid coverage to keep you up to speed on the monkeypox outbreak.

headline: Melissa Bank, Author Whose ‘Girls’ Guide’ Was a Phenomenon, Dies at 61
abstract: Her story collection “The Girls’ Guide to Hunting and Fishing,” her first book, has been translated into dozens of languages and has sold more than 1.5 million copies.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Bank, a witty, acerbic writer whose first book, “The Girls’ Guide to Hunting and Fishing,” became a global publishing phenomenon in 1999, died on Tuesday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 61.

headline: Leon E. Rosenberg, Geneticist Who Wrote of His Depression, Dies at 89
abstract: After years of pioneering research into inherited disorders, mostly in children, he spoke openly about his struggle with mental illness.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Leon E. Rosenberg, who after spending decades as a pioneer in the field of medical genetics revealed that he had spent just as long struggling with manic depression, and who then urged doctors to be more open about their own mental health, died on July 22 at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 89.

headline: Israel Hits Gaza, Prompting Rocket Barrage and Ending Relative Calm
abstract: In by far the biggest escalation of violence in Gaza since the end of a war in May 2021, Israeli airstrikes killed a militant leader and at least nine others, according to Palestinian officials.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israeli airstrikes hit several targets in the Gaza Strip on Friday, prompting Palestinian militants to return fire with scores of rockets, in the deadliest escalation of violence in the territory since an 11-day war last year.

headline: For Alex Jones, a Moment of Truth in a Flood of Lies
abstract: Nothing about his apology merits forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: In America’s clash between information and disinformation, the facts just won a rare round: Alex Jones has conceded that the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., on Dec. 14, 2012, which he had repeatedly told millions of readers of his alt-right website Infowars was “a hoax” perpetrated by “actors,” was, in point of fact, “100 percent real.”

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bill Gates: We’re on the Verge of a Remarkable Moment for Congress and the Country
abstract: The Inflation Reduction Act may be the single most important piece of climate legislation in American history.
lead_paragraph: Turn on the evening news, and it immediately becomes clear that Americans are experiencing the effects of climate change. Extreme heat and drought are affecting tens of millions of people as floods and wildfires ravage communities from Appalachia to California. In the coming days, Congress has the opportunity to face the climate crisis while strengthening our country’s energy security, creating opportunities for businesses and improving the lives of Americans. We can’t afford to miss it.

headline: Albert Woodfox, Survivor of 42 Years in Solitary Confinement, Dies at 75
abstract: His term in solitary was perhaps the longest in American history. He described how he kept his sanity, and dignity, in an acclaimed memoir.
lead_paragraph: Albert Woodfox, who spent 42 years in solitary confinement — possibly more time than any other prisoner in all of American history — yet emerged to win acclaim with a memoir that declared his spirit unbroken, died on Thursday in New Orleans. He was 75.

headline: How Arizona Became an Abyss of Election Conspiracy Theories
abstract: This week’s primaries showed how Donald Trump’s lies about the 2020 election have gripped Arizona Republicans. To learn why, we spoke with a reporter who has deeply covered the state.
lead_paragraph: Of the roughly three dozen states that have held primary elections this year, Arizona is where Donald Trump’s conspiratorial fantasies about the 2020 election seem to have gained the most purchase.

headline: U.S. and Russia Ready to Negotiate Griner’s Release
abstract: The countries’ top envoys made separate announcements after a meeting where they sat close together — without talking.
lead_paragraph: On the day after Brittney Griner was sentenced to a Russian penal colony, the top diplomats of the United States and Russia said on Friday that their governments were ready to negotiate for the release of both the American basketball star and Paul N. Whelan, who is also imprisoned by Russia.

headline: 3 Days. 68 Kids. Snapshots of Summer on Coney Island.
abstract: The New York Times for Kids visited the quirky but classic destination.
lead_paragraph: What would summer be without a little heat? A little adventure? A little mischief? Last month, The New York Times for Kids visited Coney Island to get all three. Along the beach, in the maze of rides at Luna Park and on the sandy boardwalk, we found and spoke to more than 50 kids to find out what they love most about this quirky but classic New York destination. For some kids, it was the roller coasters. For others, it was just being with their friends when school’s out. Yet one thing seemed to be true among the kids we met: There’s no better place to stay cool.

headline: Progressives Embrace Climate and Tax Deal, Despite Disappointments
abstract: Liberal Democrats who once demanded a far more ambitious plan appear ready to support a climate, health and tax package that could be their party’s last chance to enact some of its agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With enactment of a major piece of Democrats’ domestic agenda in sight within days, progressives in Congress are rallying, grudgingly but decisively, around a climate, health and tax package that is a shadow of the ambitious cradle-to-grave social policy overhaul they once demanded.

headline: Jury Orders Alex Jones to Pay $45.2 Million in Sandy Hook Case
abstract: The parents of a child killed in the school shooting were awarded the punitive damages at the conclusion of the defamation trial against the conspiracy theorist.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — A Texas jury ordered the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones on Friday to pay the parents of a child killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting $45.2 million in punitive damages for spreading the lie that they helped stage the massacre.

headline: Dan Newhouse, who voted to impeach Trump, wins his primary in Washington.
abstract: Mr. Newhouse beat back multiple right-wing challengers, including Loren Culp, who was endorsed by the former president.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dan Newhouse of Washington, one of 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach President Donald J. Trump for inciting the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, will advance to the November general election to seek a fifth term after finishing in the top two in a crowded primary, according to The Associated Press. He will face Doug White, a Democratic businessman, who narrowly trailed him as of Friday night.

headline: California Regulator Accuses Tesla of Falsely Advertising Autopilot
abstract: A state agency said the electric carmaker had misled the public in describing its driver-assistance service as autonomous.
lead_paragraph: California’s Department of Motor Vehicles has accused Tesla of falsely advertising its driver-assistance technology in two complaints that could affect the company’s ability to sell cars in the state.

headline: Why Australia’s Climate Bill Matters
abstract: After years of inaction, the world’s third largest exporter of fossil fuels decides to get serious about global warming
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — For as long as I’ve been in Australia, climate change policy has stymied governments, leading to division, inaction and embarrassment, most recently as the country became a global laggard at last year’s international climate conference in Copenhagen.

headline: Place to Get a Smoothie
abstract: Byron Walden is here to make you furrow your brow.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Byron Walden is a prolific weekend constructor; we last solved a puzzle of his on a Sunday in April, and this is his 66th Saturday grid. You can count on a thicket of debuts — 12 today — and clues that will make you do a double take, or triple take, or even need to take a break to think things over.

headline: Indiana Governor Signs First Post-Roe Abortion Ban, With Limited Exceptions
abstract: The law passed despite dividing Republicans. Some of them said the measure was too restrictive; others objected to limited exceptions for rape and incest.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Indiana lawmakers passed and the governor signed a near-total ban on abortion on Friday, overcoming division among Republicans and protests from Democrats to become the first state to draw up and approve sweeping new limits on the procedure since Roe v. Wade was struck down in June.

headline: Ukrainian Grandmaster Bids to Unseat Russian Head of World Chess Body
abstract: Hoping to end Russia’s domination of the International Chess Federation, Andrii Baryshpolets is running for the presidency of the powerful governing organization.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia’s war against Ukraine has permeated even the seemingly sedate world of chess, where a Ukrainian grandmaster is bidding to unseat the powerful Russian president of the International Chess Federation.

headline: Chinese Military Drills Aim to Awe, Both Abroad and at Home
abstract: As China staged its third day of war exercises, state media was also working hard to shape the narrative, in what seemed a response to earlier public discontent.
lead_paragraph: China’s military continued on Saturday to menace Taiwan with a series of drills, a show of force intended not only to intimidate Taiwan and the United States, but also to appease a domestic audience that had seemed disappointed by what it perceived as an insufficiently bellicose posture.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Parkland Trial, Families Lay Bare Shattered Lives and Anguish
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 6, 2022
lead_paragraph: “I have a box over my heart with a lid so tightly closed, trying to keep all my emotions under control. But today, I’m taking the lid off that box.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 6, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 9 this weekend about six podcasts about political scandals and upheaval refers incorrectly to the producers of “The Fault Line: Bush, Blair and Iraq.” They are Somethin’ Else and Sony Music Entertainment, not the BBC.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Breonna Taylor Raid Puts Focus on Officers Who Lie for Search Warrants
abstract: When warrants are based on misstated evidence or outright lies, the consequences can be disastrous. Prosecutors say that’s what happened in Ms. Taylor’s case.
lead_paragraph: On the day before police officers shot and killed Breonna Taylor in her apartment in Louisville, Ky., a detective tried to persuade a judge that a former boyfriend of Ms. Taylor’s could be using her home to stash money and drugs.

headline: City’s Admissions That It Can’t Care for Rikers Detainees May Propel Suits
abstract: The family of Herman Diaz, who choked to death on an orange, filed the first case relying on the documents. Dozens more may follow.
lead_paragraph: The security-camera images tell a remarkable story: A man being held on Rikers Island collapses and is carried to a medical clinic — not by the correction officer outside his housing unit but by other detainees. The man, Herman Diaz, 52, who had choked on an orange slice, did not survive.

headline: The Companies That Take Money Straight From Your Paycheck
abstract: Some lenders and retailers have a pretty neat business model: You pay them before your wages ever hit your bank account. And sometimes they give you no choice.
lead_paragraph: At any given time, millions of workers are overdue on at least one bill. But it is the rare employer that is late in cutting its paychecks or that bounces them altogether.

headline: Graywolf Press’s New Publisher is Looking for Talent in New Places
abstract: Carmen Giménez, Graywolf’s new executive director, wants to search for writers wherever “people are talking or thinking, or being creative or having a voice.”
lead_paragraph: When Carmen Giménez, then a young poet in San Francisco’s vibrant literary scene, walked into one of the city’s bookstores in 1999, she was dazzled by its selection of chapbooks: short and often handmade, the booklets came in all sizes, textures, and materials.

headline: How Can I Add My Partner to a Rent-Stabilized Lease?
abstract: The law makes it possible for relatives and domestic partners to be added to leases. But there are some hoops to jump through.
lead_paragraph: Q: My partner and I both are senior citizens. We have decided to live together in my rent-stabilized New York apartment, where I currently live alone. I want to know: If something happens to me as the tenant of record, will he be able to stay in the apartment? We are considering registering as domestic partners. Would this help in an effort to get him added to the lease as an additional tenant of record?

headline: Democrats Eye a Major Shift in How Corporations Are Taxed
abstract: With a new corporate minimum tax, Democrats would be adding complexity to an already byzantine tax system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the center of the new climate and tax package that Democrats appear to be on the verge of passing is one of the most significant changes to America’s tax code in decades: a new corporate minimum tax that could reshape how the federal government collects revenue and alter how the nation’s most profitable companies invest in their businesses.

headline: Baseball Buys In on the Digital Age. But at What Cost?
abstract: A sport that struggles with change has mixed opinions about PitchCom and other new technologies. But everyone seems to agree that the systems work.
lead_paragraph: Baseball and technology have always made for wary partners.

headline: How New York City Hopes to Win Its Long, Losing War on Trash
abstract: Can social media and rat-resistant receptacles help clean up the city?
lead_paragraph: “Did you get that?”

headline: Seeking Asylum in Texas; Sent to New York to Make a Political Point
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott chartered a bus to send a group of migrants to New York, where Mayor Eric Adams said asylum seekers were overwhelming the city’s homeless shelters.
lead_paragraph: The first 3,500 miles of Jose Rodríguez’s journey from Venezuela to New York took nearly two months.

headline: Don’t Expect Alex Jones’s Comeuppance to Stop Lies
abstract: His success has inspired a new generation of conspiracy theorists, who have learned how to stay away from legal trouble.
lead_paragraph: If it hadn’t been so excruciatingly sad, Alex Jones’s defamation trial might have been cathartic.

headline: In Senate Battle, Democrats Defy Biden’s Low Standing (for Now)
abstract: “The billion-dollar question,” as one Republican pollster put it, is whether Democratic candidates in crucial Senate races can continue to outpace the president’s unpopularity.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In a Senate split 50-50, Democrats on the campaign trail and in Congress have zero margin for error as the party tries to navigate a hostile political environment defined chiefly by President Biden’s albatross-like approval ratings.

headline: Would You Go Back to the Office for an Eames Chair?
abstract: Ben Watson is overseeing the merger of Herman Miller and Knoll, with the belief that good design means good business.
lead_paragraph: Ben Watson was in his happy place.

headline: How a Couple Who Started a Food Bank Spend Their Sundays
abstract: The founders of EV Loves NYC, which kicked off during the pandemic, oversee the making and distribution of 2,000 meals every weekend.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic caused food banks to shut down in March 2020, two soup kitchen volunteers, Mammad Mahmoodi and Sasha Allenby, borrowed a baker friend’s kitchen to make hot meals for people in need.

headline: There’s Just One Drug to Treat Monkeypox. Good Luck Getting It.
abstract: Doctors who want to prescribe tecovirimat, or Tpoxx, must navigate a gantlet of bureaucratic hurdles that experts say could be quickly lifted.
lead_paragraph: The only drug available to treat monkeypox is so difficult to access that just a fraction of the nearly 7,000 patients in the United States have been given it.

headline: Drop Box for Babies: Conservatives Promote a Way to Give Up Newborns Anonymously
abstract: After Roe, groups are seeking to expand safe haven laws, which allow women to surrender babies with minimal interference. But these laws pose their own problems.

headline: How This Economic Moment Rewrites the Rules
abstract: Jobs aplenty. Sizzling demand. If the United States is headed into a recession, it is taking an unusual route, with many markers of a boom.
lead_paragraph: To understand the strange, conflicting signals being sent by the U.S. economy right now, it helps to look at Williston, N.D., in about 2010.

headline: An Afrocentric Fashion Boom in the Streets and Presidential Palace
abstract: The wardrobe of Francia Márquez, Colombia’s first Black vice president, is the creation of a young designer at the center of an Afro-Colombian fashion explosion.
lead_paragraph: CALI, Colombia — At a premier fashion event in the coastal city of Buenaventura this year, a pair of towering models strutted down the boardwalk, one in a red minidress with a fluted top inspired by an open seashell and the other wearing a blue-and-gold gown fit for a modern queen.

headline: In Turbulent Times, Xi Builds a Security Fortress for China, and Himself
abstract: Taiwan, Covid, “color revolutions,” the classroom: everywhere, China’s leader sees threats that foreign forces can exploit, and he has enlisted the whole nation to defend against them.
lead_paragraph: Over informal, private meals with American leaders, China’s Xi Jinping let his guard down a little. It was a decade ago, relations were less strained, and Mr. Xi, still cementing his power, hinted he worried about the Chinese Communist Party’s grip.

headline: Think 9% Inflation Is Bad? Try 90%.
abstract: With the world grappling with rising prices, a tour through Argentina reveals that years of inflation can give rise to a truly bizarre economy.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Eduardo Rabuffetti is an Argentine who has been to the United States once, his 1999 honeymoon in Miami. Yet he probably knows the $100 bill better than most Americans.

headline: For Instant Happiness, Grab a Book and Head Outside
abstract: Photographers from The New York Times visited beaches, parks and cafes to capture readers indulging in a timeless pleasure.
lead_paragraph: Enjoying a book alfresco is one of summer’s simple, iconic joys, right up there with running through a sprinkler, spotting the evening’s first firefly or scraping a flat wooden spoon across a freezer-burned cup of Italian ice.

headline: A Time for War, a Time for Play
abstract: Summer for Ukraine’s children means sunshine and swimming, but also long hours in bomb shelters and mine-safety training. A photographer captured their days in Kyiv for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A late-July morning, and the sounds of the summer camp were the sounds of summer camps everywhere as children raced from activity to activity.

headline: In the Philippines, Blinken Vows to Strengthen Military Ties
abstract: Against a backdrop of rising regional tensions with China, the U.S. secretary of state reaffirmed Washington’s commitment to defending Manila.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Saturday that their nations were committed to strengthening their military alliance, and that their governments would need to deal with rising tensions in Asia, including those involving China and Taiwan.

headline: A Photographer Who Has Always Worked on a Large Scale Goes Even Bigger
abstract: Edward Burtynsky has turned his 40 years spent documenting humanity’s effects on the planet into a multimedia show.
lead_paragraph: Long before the climate crisis was the focus of global concern Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky was traveling the world documenting what people have inflicted on the environment and, by extension themselves.

headline: Reading Outdoors
abstract: Grab a book and read outside this weekend, if you can. Here’s some inspiration.
lead_paragraph: What is the best setup for serious outdoor reading? I propose it’s in a chair, sitting upright, in the shade of a tree or umbrella, comfortable but not too comfortable. A beach towel or picnic blanket works, but the sun moves, your back or neck gets stiff, it’s not a sure thing. My friend Avi insists you need to be in one of those zero-gravity recliners that I’m positive would function as an adult cradle and instantly lull me to sleep.

headline: The Fight to Lead Kenya: ‘Hustler Nation’ vs. Allied Scions
abstract: Kenyans vote for a new president on Tuesday, ending a heated race that shows why, in a troubled region, the East African nation matters more than ever.
lead_paragraph: KANGARI, Kenya — The helicopter swooped over the lush tea and coffee fields flanking Mount Kenya, Africa’s second highest peak, and touched down outside a small highland town where William Ruto, the self-proclaimed leader of Kenya’s “hustler nation,” stepped out.

headline: The Search for a Meaningful Clue to the Mystery of an Enslaved Ancestor
abstract: Old newspaper ads are serving as a window into the hopes and histories of hundreds of individuals who were newly emancipated.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Aug. 1, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Archie Battersbee, Gravely Ill 12-Year-Old, Dies After Removal of Life Support
abstract: The boy’s family had made several legal appeals to keep him on a ventilator, but judges in Britain sided with doctors in finding that he had no hope of recovery.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Archie Battersbee, a 12-year-old British boy whose life support was withdrawn after a legal battle between his parents and his doctors, died on Saturday, bringing to an end another wrenching case over who makes life and death decisions for a seriously ill child.

headline: Dolphin Strangers Met in the Bahamas. Things Went Swimmingly.
abstract: Two research teams found that dolphins could forge strong social bonds with outsiders within a few years
lead_paragraph: In 2013, a group of 52 Atlantic spotted dolphins, driven to migrate by unknown forces, left their home on the Little Bahama Bank in the northern Bahamas. They traveled 100 miles south to the island chain of Bimini, a destination already inhabited by a community of 120 Atlantic spotted dolphins.

headline: Republicans Should Pay a Political Price for Abortion Bans
abstract: Kansas voters point the way for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The right to an abortion is protected in the Kansas State Constitution and on Tuesday, a decisive majority of voters kept it there. Fifty-nine percent of Kansans who went to the polls voted to reject a constitutional amendment that would have opened the door to full abortion bans of the kind that exist in neighboring states like Missouri and Oklahoma.

headline: Fighting Around Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Heightens Safety Fears
abstract: A series of blasts Friday at the plant, which the Russian military is using as cover for artillery attacks, renewed concerns of a radiation catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine —  Fighting raged on Saturday near a sprawling nuclear power plant in the south of Ukraine, despite warnings from nuclear safety watchdogs earlier this week that conditions there were posing risks and “out of control.”

headline: Winds of Change
abstract: Helping my son feel safe in a scary world.
lead_paragraph: Helping my son feel safe in a scary world.

headline: Hey, Joe, Don’t Give It a Go
abstract: Rest on your laurels, and don’t run for re-election, Mr. President.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ruth Bader Ginsburg is a cautionary tale.

headline: After Chadwick Boseman’s Iconic Black Panther, Should King T’Challa Be Recast?
abstract: The #RecastTChalla movement argues that many white superheroes have been recast again and again — and that the king of Wakanda’s adventures shouldn’t end.
lead_paragraph: The actor Chadwick Boseman’s death, from cancer in August 2020, was a breathtaking shock. With his performance as Marvel’s Black Panther, Mr. Boseman became a towering figure, particularly for Black people, who rarely get to see themselves depicted as heroes on the screen.

headline: The U.S. Relationship With China Does Not Need to Be So Tense
abstract: Tensions over Taiwan underscore the need for the United States to engage more deeply with China on more than just trade.
lead_paragraph: China, economically ascendant, has become increasingly assertive in pressing its economic, political and territorial claims. The United States, which long treated the country as something of a charity case, now regards it as a rival and, increasingly, as a threat. While some tension is inevitable, the rhetoric in both nations has taken a bellicose turn. There is little trust or cooperation even on issues of clear mutual interest, like combating the Covid-19 pandemic or addressing climate change.

headline: Don’t Return to the Office for Your Boss. Go Back for Yourself.
abstract: Many offices are desolate, open plan landscapes dotted with individuals staring at screens, headphones on. It doesn’t have to be that way.
lead_paragraph: In the conversation about returning to in-person office work, it sometimes seems like bosses and workers are operating in different realities.

headline: Sid Jacobson, Comic Book Writer With Range, Dies at 92
abstract: His portfolio included the adventures of Richie Rich and graphic treatments of 9/11 and torture by the C.I.A. He also wrote dozens of songs.
lead_paragraph: Sid Jacobson, a veteran comic book writer and editor whose work took him from the opulent, fanciful world of Richie Rich to the real-life terrorist attacks of 9/11, died on July 23 in San Francisco. He was 92.

headline: Is Homework Necessary for Student Success?

headline: We Went on a Lanternfly-Killing Rampage. They’re Still Here.
abstract: The spotted lanternfly, an invasive pest that ecologists have urged the populace to squish on sight, is back, infesting the New York City area.

headline: Even the Idea of Motherhood Is Lonely
abstract: In “Diary of a Void,” Emi Yagi unravels the limitless ironies of maternity.
lead_paragraph: Blame it on social media, on synoptic attention spans, whatever: The speculative conceit reigns in contemporary publishing, where few novels live up to their promise of revelatory social commentary. But a particularly good one can still tempt even the most cynical of readers. In the Japanese author Emi Yagi’s prizewinning debut, “Diary of a Void,” a single woman in her mid-30s, frustrated by her stupefying job at a company that manufactures cardboard cores for paper products, spontaneously decides to feign pregnancy in order to get out of menial tasks like making coffee and cleaning up after meetings — the stench of unappreciated labor aggravates her morning sickness. Over the course of the novel, she carries the lie to term.

Part of her said go home. The race wasn’t what it used to be. She didn’t feel wanted anyway. She loved this race. She hated this race. She revolved her entire life around this race.

lead_paragraph: Clu Gulager, a rugged character actor who appeared in critically acclaimed films like “The Last Picture Show” as well as low-budget horror movies, and who memorably portrayed gunslingers on two television westerns, died on Friday at his son John’s home in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: The Week in Business: Blistering Job Growth
abstract: Elon Musk countersues Twitter. The Walt Disney Company’s bold subscriber ambitions may get a check in its quarterly earnings report. And the latest inflation number comes out.
lead_paragraph: Analysts had forecast an increase of 250,000 jobs in July. And so it was a shock when the Department of Labor’s report showed that more than twice that number — 528,000 —  were added last month. The blistering pace of growth brought total employment back to prepandemic levels, a befuddling benchmark considering other recent signs of a slowing economy, including a falling gross domestic product and a more sedate housing market. Indeed, this latest jobs report provides more questions than answers about the state of the U.S. economy: What is the cause of employers’ confidence in hiring if many fear a recession? Why is the job market so resilient if the economy seems to be more depressed? These are apparent contradictions that Federal Reserve officials will weigh as they think about what path to take.

headline: A Model for an Evangelical Christianity Committed to Justice

I was taking a class on poverty in the United States and another course taught by an avowed socialist passionately committed to radical politics. I was volunteering with a ministry that worked with undocumented immigrants and among the economically disadvantaged. I felt increasingly disconnected from my evangelical community on issues of nonviolence and social and economic justice.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. Senate Passes Major Legislation
abstract: Also, China’s military exercises could alienate Taiwan and rockets strike near a Ukrainian nuclear power plant.
lead_paragraph: Congress edged closer to realizing a slew of Democratic priorities when the Senate passed the climate and tax bill after an all-night legislative bender known as a vote-a-rama.

headline: The Way I See It
abstract: Get back together with Kathy Lowden’s Monday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The constructor of today’s puzzle, Kathy Lowden, is making her second appearance in the New York Times Crossword today, after debuting in a 2020 collaboration with her daughter. It’s a welcome return — Ms. Lowden’s puzzle is a perfectly executed example of what an associate puzzle editor, Tracy Bennett, calls a “sum of the parts” theme, in which “one part of a multiword phrase is in a category that’s revealed punnily in a final entry.”

headline: Israel and Palestinian Militants Reach a Cease-Fire
abstract: The truce appeared to end a three-day conflict in Gaza that barely changed the status quo in Israel and the occupied territories, but  revealed splits among rival Palestinian militias.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza agreed to a cease-fire late on Sunday night, in a move that was expected to end a three-day conflict that killed dozens of Palestinians, including militant commanders, but which did little to change the status quo in Israel and the occupied territories.

headline: Yankees Show Flaws and Get a First Look at Frankie Montas
abstract: The Yankees were swept in a three-game series for the first time this season and extended their losing streak to a season-worst five games.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Slipping of late but still holding a slight edge for the best record in the American League, the Yankees took action last Monday ahead of the Major League Baseball trade deadline. They sent two of their top 10 prospects and two other minor league players to the Oakland Athletics in exchange for the relief pitcher Lou Trivino and the starting pitcher Frankie Montas.

headline: Killings of 4 Men in Albuquerque Leave Muslim Community in Fear
abstract: As the authorities appeal to the public for help in their investigation, many Muslim residents are experiencing a “managed panic.”
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Imtiaz Hussain is afraid to step outside his home in Albuquerque to water his plants. Or retrieve books from his car. Or even venture out onto his balcony.

headline: New Jersey Man Gets 5 Years in Prison in GoFundMe Fraud Case
abstract: Prosecutors said Mark D’Amico and his then-girlfriend made up a heartwarming tale of a homeless man to help raise more than $400,000.
lead_paragraph: Mark D’Amico and his girlfriend said they wanted to reward a homeless man who had spent his last $20 to help her after she ran out of gas on a highway in Philadelphia in November 2017. The couple started a GoFundMe campaign that sought $10,000 to provide rent, a reliable vehicle and some living expenses for the man.

headline: Mets Strengthen Their N.L. East Lead
abstract: The Mets won four of five games in a crucial series with the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: The Mets won four of five games in a crucial series with the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.

headline: Ex-Officer to Serve Time for Failing to Act in Excessive Force Arrest
abstract: The sentencing of Daria Jalali over her failure to intervene comes two years after a woman with dementia was mistreated by another officer in the Loveland Police Dept. in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: A former Colorado police officer was sentenced to 45 days in jail and three years of probation on Friday for failing to intervene during the arrest of a 73-year-old woman with dementia who was assaulted by a different police officer in June 2020, a law firm representing the officer confirmed on Sunday.

headline: ‘Why Do I Have to Work Twice as Hard Just to Get Noticed?’
abstract: Sylvia Fowles has been as dominant on the court as Sue Bird, but only one of them is a household name, our columnist writes.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Fowles is one of the most successful American athletes ever.

headline: In My Homeland, the Smell of Death on a Summer Afternoon
abstract: In Ukraine, tragedies are a backdrop to everyday existence, piling up in numbers that seem inconceivable, an inescapable reality that feels like the very air in your lungs.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Muslims in New Mexico Are Shaken by Possible Targeted Killings
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 8, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Now, I look outside the window and think, ‘Oh, this is the place where my brother was killed. Should we move?’”

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 8, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 8, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A cease-fire in Gaza.
