lead_paragraph: Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza agreed to a cease-fire late last night, which appeared to hold as of this morning. The move is expected to end a three-day conflict that has killed dozens of Palestinians, destroyed buildings and resulted in the deaths of two key leaders of Islamic Jihad, Gaza’s second-largest militia.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Princess’ and ‘Password’
abstract: HBO airs a new documentary on the life and death of Princess Diana. And NBC brings back a game show.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 8 — 14. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: For Ukrainians in Donbas, tragedy is the backdrop to everyday existence.
abstract: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.
lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.

headline: Authorities Seek Public’s Help in Investigation of Albuquerque Killings
abstract: The authorities appealed to the public for help as they sought the person or people who killed four Muslim men in Albuquerque.
lead_paragraph: The authorities appealed to the public for help as they sought the person or people who killed four Muslim men in Albuquerque.

headline: Why the Rent Is So High
abstract: New York City faces a housing crisis that’s making it harder for middle- and low-income people to live here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at why affordable apartments are in such short supply in New York. We’ll also look at a new player in the Mets’ lineup who’s hard to miss — and who, in only two weeks, has become a fan favorite.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Along a Subway Line’s 31 Miles, Nagging Crime Fears Test Riders’ Resolve
abstract: Ridership is down, even though crime levels have stayed the same. Some New Yorkers who ply the longest subway route say the city feels unmoored.
lead_paragraph: At 31 miles long, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s A train traverses New York City, from the thriving Dominican enclave of Washington Heights to the Financial District, from rugged East New York to beachy Far Rockaway.

headline: In an Unequal Economy, the Poor Face Inflation Now and Job Loss Later
abstract: Americans with low incomes are pulling back from buying even as their richer counterparts keep spending — with potentially big consequences.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Heady Nihilism of Kotaro Isaka
abstract: In “Three Assassins,” the Japanese author’s latest thriller to be translated into English, a corporate assassin isn’t far from a corporate automaton.
lead_paragraph: The killings that take place in “Three Assassins” — and there are many — are disarmingly mundane. Kotaro Isaka describes murder the way a doctor would a surgery: meticulous, but numbly pragmatic. He fixates on the pulpy, tangible procedure of death, the blood, spittle, clatter of knife point against bone. The novel’s central enigma, the Pusher, is defined by his method of pushing his victims in front of moving cars and then vanishing, making the scene look like an accident. But a method quickly becomes a routine, which becomes a straitjacket. And when your clients are a rogues’ gallery of conniving politicians and wealthy dirtbags, a corporate assassin isn’t far from a corporate automaton.

headline: I Love My Students, but I Won’t Use a Gun to Protect Them
abstract: It is difficult to learn when one is always listening for a bullet.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — Before classes start Aug. 22 at the university where I teach English, I’ll locate my new classroom, slip inside and conduct a ritual inspection. It has a practical purpose: ensuring that the chalk board has chalk, the AV has cords, and the desks and chairs are in neat rows.

headline: Exercise Was the Perfect Coping Mechanism, Until It Wasn’t
abstract: I believed I’d found the cure for the depression and trauma that had plagued me for years: Start running and just don’t stop.
lead_paragraph: When I was a junior in college, I joined the rowing team. The unthinkably expensive boats gliding down the Charles River enchanted me. But I was also drawn to something else: I’d heard crew was brutal. In the aftermath of a chaotic adolescence, I felt constantly on edge. What more wholesome way was there to burn off the feeling of hot poison in my veins than with a movie montage of fitness, pounding up stadium stairs while wearing a visor? In a tunnel of fire, I hoped to find relief.

headline: We Will All End Up Paying for Someone Else’s Beach House
abstract: As extreme weather events compound, the obvious perils of waterfront living are growing both more obvious and more perilous.
lead_paragraph: A video of a North Carolina beach house being dismembered by a voracious ocean was a viral hit this spring. But it won’t be long before the novelty wears off. As sea level rises and storm surges grow more intense, beach towns on every coast of the United States will soon be sacrificing more real estate to Poseidon. A 2018 study by the Union of Concerned Scientists found that more than 300,000 coastal homes, currently worth well over $100 billion, are at risk of “chronic inundation” by 2045.

headline: Your Pandemic Puppy Was Not a Mistake
abstract: Living with an animal of another species has never been trouble-free. But the rewards are extravagant.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It was a Saturday night, close to midnight, when the weird little cough erupting from our dog Rascal’s mouth stopped being a cough and turned into dramatic hacking. My husband and I looked at each other.

headline: A Sparsely Populated Island, a Marital Spat and a Missing Husband
abstract: Johanna Mo’s new novel, “The Shadow Lily,” is a solid police procedural that brims with twists, turns and surprising revelations.
lead_paragraph: The mark of a promising series is that each installment can stand alone, and readers can begin with any book. It’s too early to say if this will hold for Johanna Mo’s Island Murders cycle, just two books strong, but THE SHADOW LILY (Penguin Books, 418 pp., paper, $16.99) is a solid police procedural that invited me onto the sparsely populated Baltic island of Öland, where nights are pitch-black and villages “sometimes consisted of no more than a few houses.” Like the first book in the series, “The Night Singer,” it’s capably translated from the Swedish by Alice Menzies.

headline: Bolsonaro Is Afraid of Going to Prison, and He’s Right to Be
abstract: It’s getting hard to keep track of all the charges against Brazil’s president.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — “I’m letting the scoundrels know,” President Jair Bolsonaro told supporters last year, “I’ll never be imprisoned!”

headline: Subverting a Preppy Classic
abstract: Customized L.L. Bean tote bags have become blank canvases for a contemporary sense of humor.
lead_paragraph: When Gracie Wiener ordered a canvas Boat and Tote bag through the L.L. Bean website in July 2021, she filled out the “add monogram” field with the word “psycho” instead of her initials. “I think it’s funny to wear your best, or worst, qualities on your sleeve,” she said.

headline: Mandela Barnes Is Already Looking Past Wisconsin’s Democratic Primary
abstract: Mr. Barnes, Wisconsin’s lieutenant governor, consolidated his party’s support in his bid to take on Ron Johnson, one of the most vulnerable Republicans in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes of Wisconsin is entering Tuesday’s Democratic primary for a Senate seat as the clear favorite to take on Senator Ron Johnson and is already sharpening his attacks against the Republican incumbent.

headline: Shopping for Laundry Hampers
abstract: The best ones make dealing with dirty laundry a whole lot easier.
lead_paragraph: How crucial is your laundry hamper? It can make or break your plans to control clutter.

headline: ‘No Drama’ Compost? N.Y.C. Is Expanding Food and Yard Waste Pickup
abstract: The city will pilot automatic, optional curbside pickup across Queens after lagging behind promises to collect compost.
lead_paragraph: What happens to food scraps in the garbage is both gross (rats, garbage juice) and weighty (methane emissions, climate crisis). In New York, the fate of old food has recently inflamed passions and caused a political stink.

headline: U.S. Open Commits to Fund-Raising Exhibition Match and $2 Million for Ukraine
abstract: Unlike at Wimbledon, players from Russia and Belarus will be allowed to compete at the U.S. Open. Whether they play in an exhibition to support relief efforts in Ukraine is another question.
lead_paragraph: For weeks this spring, the leaders of the United States Tennis Association debated whether to allow Russian and Belarusian players to participate in the U.S. Open.

headline: In Wisconsin, G.O.P. Voters Demand the Impossible: Decertifying 2020
abstract: Donald Trump’s supporters have turned anger over his defeat two years ago, and the false notion that it can still be reversed, into central campaign issues ahead of the battleground state’s primary.
lead_paragraph: SHEBOYGAN, Wis. — When she started her campaign for governor of Wisconsin, former Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch, a Republican, acknowledged that President Biden had been legitimately elected.

headline: Maps in Four States Were Ruled Illegal Gerrymanders. They’re Being Used Anyway.
abstract: A Supreme Court shift, frowning on changes close to elections, gives House Republicans a big advantage in November.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since January, judges in Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana and Ohio have found that Republican legislators illegally drew those states’ congressional maps along racial or partisan lines, or that a trial very likely would conclude that they did. In years past, judges who have reached similar findings have ordered new maps, or had an expert draw them, to ensure that coming elections were fair.

headline: Biden Appeared to Overstate the Role of Al Qaeda’s Leader
abstract: Terrorism experts were surprised by the president’s descriptions of Ayman al-Zawahri, who was killed in a U.S. drone strike.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In announcing last week that the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, had been killed in a U.S. drone strike in Kabul, Afghanistan, President Biden described the long-sought terrorist as “a mastermind” behind the U.S.S. Cole bombing in 2000.

headline: Freed From Prison in China, Taiwan Activist Urges Resistance to Beijing’s Threats
abstract: Li Ming-che and his wife, who met with Speaker Nancy Pelosi in Taiwan last week, have sought to inspire others not to be intimidated into silence by Beijing.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Li Ching-yu was desperate to send her husband a message.

headline: The Taliban’s Dangerous Collision Course With the West
abstract: After barring girls from high school — and harboring an Al-Qaeda leader — the regime now risks jeopardizing the billions of dollars of global aid that still keeps Afghans alive.
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan’s ministry of education sits on a chaotic thoroughfare in downtown Kabul, not far from the presidential palace. When I visited this May, I was able to walk straight into the main building without having to state my business or undergo more than a light frisk. The country’s four-​decade civil war is at its lowest ebb in years, and many of the capital’s draconian security measures have been scaled back by the new Taliban government. The crowds of petitioners inside the ministries have changed, as well: Women are seldom seen, and the traditional garb of robe and trousers has become nearly ubiquitous among men.

headline: Can Global Shipping Be Fixed? One Regulator Will Try.
abstract: The Federal Maritime Commission, traditionally obscure, has been cast by Congress and the administration to help lead the campaign to tame inflation.
lead_paragraph: Daniel B. Maffei is at once a crucial player in the campaign to subdue inflation, and a figure virtually unknown outside the confines of his wonky Washington domain.

headline: ‘What a Horrible Place This Would Have Been’
abstract: Archaeologists found the remains of 14 soldiers who died in a pivotal Revolutionary War battle — a fresh reminder of the violence of war.
lead_paragraph: This spring, a team of archaeologists and volunteers began painstakingly digging into the history of Fort Mercer, a Revolutionary War fortification on the Delaware River that is now the centerpiece of Red Bank Battlefield Park in National Park, N.J.

headline: What You Get for $4 Million in California
abstract: A Spanish-style retreat in Santa Barbara, a grand 1933 home in the Hollywood Hills and a Mediterranean-style house in Long Beach.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish-style retreat in Santa Barbara, a grand 1933 home in the Hollywood Hills and a Mediterranean-style house in Long Beach.

headline: $4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Spanish-style retreat in Santa Barbara, a grand 1933 home in the Hollywood Hills and a Mediterranean-style house in Long Beach.
lead_paragraph: The recent renovation of this house was inspired by traditional Spanish-style construction and by the site, where 100-year-old oaks and drought-tolerant plants grow.

headline: Embarrassing, Uncomfortable and Risky: What Flying Is Like for Passengers Who Use Wheelchairs
abstract: To better understand the obstacles faced by wheelchair users, The Times sent a reporter and a photographer to document one man’s plane trip. Here’s what they saw.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: China’s Military Drills and Other Tensions With Taiwan, Explained
abstract: China’s military announced new exercises near Taiwan, a day after concluding four days of drills that simulated a blockade of the island.
lead_paragraph: China said on Monday that it would hold new drills near Taiwan, a sign that Beijing may keep up a drumbeat of military pressure on the island after conducting its largest-ever exercises in the area in retaliation for Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit last week.

headline: The Alex Jones Verdict and the Fight Against Disinformation
abstract: What is the significance of the defamation case against America’s most prominent conspiracy theorist?
lead_paragraph: This episode contains descriptions of distressing scenes.

headline: Rumors spread quickly in wartime Ukraine.
abstract: While seemingly harmless, these tales may have their origins in Russian propaganda, according to analysts monitoring Russian disinformation campaigns in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: They lived in an abandoned house in a forest next to a small village. They survived on mushrooms and berries. And it took months after the Russian Army retreated for the Ukrainian police to finally capture them.

headline: A Drop in Murders
abstract: Despite the grim headlines, 2022 is less violent so far than last year.
lead_paragraph: Crime, murder and mass shootings have dominated headlines this year. Just over the weekend, a shooting in Cincinnati wounded nine people, and another in Detroit killed one and wounded four.

headline: People Flock to South Korean Crypto Event Despite Market Turmoil
abstract: Falling prices and upheaval in the industry do not appear to have curbed Koreans’ appetite for crypto, blockchain and all things web3.
lead_paragraph: When the South Korean cryptocurrencies Luna and TerraUSD collapsed in May, their failures contributed to a $300 billion loss across the crypto economy; public outcries for Do Kwon, the cryptocurrencies’ creator, to go to jail; and multiple investigations. But that, and a broader “crypto winter” dragging down prices across the industry, do not appear to have curbed South Korea’s appetite for all things web3.

headline: SoftBank Reports $23 Billion Loss as Tech Investments Plummet
abstract: Masayoshi Son, the Japanese conglomerate’s founder, said SoftBank would take fewer big risks in the future.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese conglomerate SoftBank reported on Monday its largest-ever quarterly loss, $23.4 billion, driven by poor performance of its flagship tech investments and a weak yen.

headline: Trump Asked Aide Why His Generals Couldn’t Be Like Hitler’s, Book Says
abstract: The former president once asked his chief of staff why his military leadership couldn’t be more like the German generals who had reported to Adolf Hitler, according to an excerpt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Donald J. Trump told his top White House aide that he wished he had generals like the ones who had reported to Adolf Hitler, saying they were “totally loyal” to the leader of the Nazi regime, according to a forthcoming book about the 45th president.

headline: California Fire and Floods Turn a River to ‘Sludge,’ Killing Thousands of Fish
abstract: Flash floods last week pushed burned soil, rocks and downed timber into the river, killing off, according to local tribal leaders, thousands of fish.
lead_paragraph: As a deadly fire continued to burn last week in the Klamath National Forest in Northern California, Kenneth Brink, a local fisherman, counted dead fish in a river that had turned to the consistency of “chocolate milk.”

headline: A Cease-Fire Holds After a 3-Day Gaza Conflict: Key Takeaways
abstract: The conflict may have dealt a severe blow to Palestinian Islamic Jihad, the Gaza militant group, and strengthened the hand of Israel’s interim prime minister, Yair Lapid.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A cease-fire ending three days of fierce cross-border attacks between Israel and a Palestinian militant group in Gaza appeared to be holding on Monday, and life on both sides of the lines began to return to normal.

headline: Sacramento Savors Its Underdog Moment
abstract: The capital city, often overshadowed by San Francisco and Los Angeles, is taking pride in the success of its lower-tier Sacramento Republic F.C. over Major League Soccer teams.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — A veteran of international soccer, Mark Briggs did not need to be told that his second-division Sacramento Republic Football Club had done something significant, shocking three straight Major League Soccer opponents to advance to the finals of the all-comers U.S. Open Cup.

headline: Fashion Suited for Surreal Times
abstract: Strange proportions, odd materials and clothing shaped like a car — this season, nothing is as it seems.

headline: Rescuing Art in Ukraine with Foam, Crates and Cries for Help
abstract: Many cultural institutions were not prepared to protect their collections and buildings before the Russian invasion, so ad hoc groups of arts workers and leaders stepped in to fill the breach.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — A month after the Russian army invaded Ukraine, the photographer Roman Metelskiy stood on the platform of this western city’s domed Art Nouveau railway station, watching trains full of women and children evacuating from the east. But he was waiting for a carriage from the other direction. This one, from the west, was full of Bubble Wrap.

headline: Axios Agrees to Sell Itself to Cox Enterprises for $525 Million
abstract: The digital media company’s founders, Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen and Roy Schwartz, will continue to run the company.
lead_paragraph: Axios, the digital media company that quickly gained traction since its founding five years ago with its distinctive bulletin-style scoops on the realms of politics, business and technology, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell itself to Cox Enterprises.

headline: $15 French Fries and $18 Sandwiches: Inflation Hits New York
abstract: As food prices rise at the fastest rate in decades, it’s become more expensive to eat and drink in New York City.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be a summer of long-awaited celebrations in New York City, the return of a packed calendar full of birthday dinners and happy hours. But New Yorkers are confronting sticker shock everywhere they look, whether they’re shopping for barbecue supplies at the grocery store, ordering a beer after work or grabbing a late-night slice of pizza.

headline: ‘A Slow Death’: Egypt’s Political Prisoners Recount Horrific Conditions
abstract: Many are held in filthy cells, subjected to routine torture and denied lifesaving medications, according to former inmates, their families and lawyers, and rights groups. Some never leave.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Every time he appeared before Egyptian prosecutors during his 21 months in detention, Ahmed Abdelnabi, a 61-year-old print shop owner from Alexandria, had a more disturbing story to tell.

headline: Pete Rose Dismisses Questions About Sexual Misconduct
abstract: After attending an on-field celebration of the 1980 Phillies, Rose refused to answer questions about allegations from a 2017 lawsuit. “It was 55 years ago, babe.”
lead_paragraph: Pete Rose was dismissive Sunday when asked about an accusation that he had sex with a girl under 16 in the 1970s.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Melissa Clark brought us four recipes for upside-down cake, perfect for overripe fruit from the market.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Melissa Clark recently went big on upside-down cakes  in The Times, and now that’s all I want to make: peach upside-down cake (above); pineapple upside-down cake with pecans; berry upside-down cake; banana upside-down cake. They’re relatively easy to put together and are perfect for those of us who buy too much at the farmers’ market and wince at the sight of aging fruit on the counter.

headline: Decorative Bowls for Odds and Ends
abstract: Vessels that lessen clutter and bring style to any space.

headline: The U.N. secretary general warns that attacks on the Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex could be ‘suicidal.’
abstract: The remarks by António Guterres came two days after he called for global nuclear disarmament at a commemoration of the 77th anniversary of the U.S. nuclear bombing of Hiroshima.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, on Monday condemned the fighting around the vast Zaporizhzhia nuclear power complex in southern Ukraine, saying that any attack on a nuclear facility is “suicidal.”

headline: In Search of Mexican Pizza
abstract: Taco Bell may have made the name famous, but this pizza — made with leavened dough and traditional Mexican ingredients — has become a genre all its own.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — On a sticky day in late June, Margarita Jeronimo and Aaron Del Rosario assembled a feast on a picnic table outside Rosario’s, their restaurant on a quiet corner in South Philadelphia. The procession started with tamarind and hibiscus aguas frescas, followed by tortilla chips and hand-painted bowls filled with green and red salsas, and finally, pizza.

headline: Two in Arbery Case Sentenced Again to Life in Prison; Third Man Gets 35 Years
abstract: The men were convicted of federal hate crimes after state murder convictions in 2021. Their lawyers tried without success to have part of their sentences served in federal prison.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Before the three men convicted of murdering Ahmaud Arbery were sentenced on Monday on federal hate crime charges, they asked a judge to consider not only the length of the sentences, but also the location, with one lawyer arguing that if her client went straight to Georgia’s dangerous state prison system, he would be subject to “vigilante justice.”

headline: What’s Your Breastfeeding Story? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: If you’re a parent trying to breastfeed — with all the highs and lows that brings — we want to hear your story.
lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Pediatrics recently issued new breastfeeding recommendations encouraging women to breastfeed for two years or beyond, if doing so is “mutually desired” by moms and their babies.

headline: Biden Is on a Roll That Any President Would Relish. Is It a Turning Point?
abstract: White House aides say the string of victories compares favorably to the two-year legislative record of most any other modern president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden arrived at Air Force One on Monday with a jaunty step, a playful manner and a huge grin. “Feeling great,” he declared. He meant physically, having finally ended his lengthy bout with Covid-19, but he could have been talking about his presidency writ large.

headline: Michigan Officials Detail a Brazen Voting Machine Scheme by Trump Supporters
abstract: Revelations of possible meddling have set off a political tsunami in a critical battleground state, as the attorney general seeks an independent inquiry into her likely rival on the ballot this fall.
lead_paragraph: In early 2021, with the turmoil of a bitterly contested presidential contest still fresh, several election clerks in Michigan received strange phone calls.

headline: David McCullough, Best-Selling Explorer of America’s Past, Dies at 89
abstract: His research — on Adams, Truman and so much more — was deep, his writing was lively, and his narrator’s voice in documentary films was familiar to millions.
lead_paragraph: David McCullough, who was known to millions as an award-winning, best-selling author and an appealing television host and narrator with a rare gift for recreating the great events and characters of America’s past, died on Sunday at his home in Hingham, Mass., southeast of Boston. He was 89.

headline: Bert Fields, Lawyer to the Hollywood Elite, Dies at 93
abstract: A master dealmaker, he had as clients Madonna, Michael Jackson, Tom Cruise, the Beatles and many others, becoming something of a celebrity himself.
lead_paragraph: Bert Fields, the colorful and canny dean of Hollywood lawyers whose services were called on by superstars and studios alike knowing they would get a no-holds-barred defense and all but assured of some measure of victory, died on Sunday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Electric Cars Too Costly for Many, Even With Aid in Climate Bill
abstract: Battery-powered vehicles are considered essential to the fight against climate change, but most models are aimed at the affluent.
lead_paragraph: Policymakers in Washington are promoting electric vehicles as a solution to climate change. But an uncomfortable truth remains: Battery-powered cars are much too expensive for a vast majority of Americans.

headline: In Lawsuits, Ex-Employees Offer Harsh Portrait of Project Veritas
abstract: One former employee described the conservative group as having a “highly sexualized” atmosphere where drinking and drug use were commonplace.
lead_paragraph: The conservative group Project Veritas has for years sought to embarrass political opponents and members of media organizations by surreptitiously recording them and publicizing their private communications.

headline: Chad’s Military Junta and Rebels Sign a Deal, but a Main Player Is Missing
abstract: The accord paves the way for national reconciliation talks and democratic elections. However, it was snubbed by the main rebel group responsible for the death of Chad’s previous leader.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Chad’s military government and more than 40 rebel groups signed a cease-fire agreement on Monday in Qatar, paving the way for reconciliation talks later this month as the Central African nation seeks a way out of a troubled political transition.

headline: Blinken says it will be ‘open season’ around the world if Russia’s aggression in Ukraine is not stopped.
abstract: PRETORIA, South Africa — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned on Monday that if countries don’t stand up to Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, that would give a green light for similar aggressions worldwide.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned on Monday that if countries don’t stand up to Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, that would give a green light for similar aggressions worldwide.

headline: The Perfect S’more Is Practically Burned and a Little Salty
abstract: Potato chips, Nutella and even Peeps can step into this campfire classic, but success lies in its balance of flavors and a healthy char.
lead_paragraph: The campfire s’more is a gooey mess: saccharine, certainly, but also sentimental, stuffed with childhood memories.

headline: Investigators Say Collector Had Suspect Art and Lots of Chutzpah
abstract: The investigators say Georges Lotfi invited them to his storage space because he did not think they would suspect that the antiquities he kept there were stolen, an accusation he denies.
lead_paragraph: For years, Georges Lotfi made himself a valuable source of information to prosecutors investigating the global trafficking of looted antiquities.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ Dominates the Album and Singles Charts
abstract: The pop star’s seventh album debuts at No. 1 with the second-biggest opening week of the year, while her song “Break My Soul” climbs to the top of the Hot 100.
lead_paragraph: For her last two solo albums, Beyoncé turned the music business on its head by rewriting the standard marketing playbook. “Beyoncé” (2013) came without warning and had a music video for every song; for “Lemonade” (2016), she teamed with HBO for an hourlong film. Each went straight to No. 1 and became an instant pop-culture moment.

headline: A Climate Bill, No Thanks to the G.O.P.
abstract: Readers decry the united Republican opposition and “deal making behind closed doors.” Also: A new “axis of evil”; nuclear dangers; an Idaho housing crisis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Scenes From the Chess Olympiad: Magnus Carlsen Is Still on Top of His Game
abstract: And the election for president of the International Chess Federation carried overtones of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The chess world was left reeling by the surprise announcement last month that its biggest star, Magnus Carlsen, would surrender his world title, citing a lack of motivation.

headline: How New York City Got Its Fresh Water
abstract: In “Nineteen Reservoirs,” Lucy Sante recounts the history of a vast network that supplies more than a billion gallons of water a day.
lead_paragraph: Every morning in this newspaper you can, if you dare, check the level of New York City’s reservoir system, which supplies our fresh water, more than a billion gallons a day.

headline: Blinken Details Push to Bolster Democracy in Africa
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the United States would collaborate with African nations to promote democratic governance across the continent.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the United States would collaborate with African nations to promote democratic governance across the continent.

headline: Another Gaza Conflict, but With a Difference: Hamas Sat It Out.
abstract: In the weekend battle with Israel, Hamas left the fighting to Islamic Jihad, another militant group, highlighting differences between them over how best to combat Israel.
lead_paragraph: The brief weekend conflict over Gaza had a grimly familiar outcome: dozens of Palestinians killed, including militant leaders as well as children, and scores of homes damaged or destroyed, most by Israeli airstrikes but some from Palestinian misfires.

headline: In war-battered Mykolaiv, the authorities search for informers helping the Russians.
abstract: As the city emerged from a 54-hour lockdown, the governor of the Mykolaiv region declared the operation a success, saying that five people had been arrested.
lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — The embattled city of Mykolaiv emerged on Monday from a 54-hour lockdown during which officers went door to door in search of collaborators who officials say are responsible for helping Russian forces identify targets for the rockets that pound the city daily.

headline: ‘The Devil Wears Prada’ Review: An Adaptation That Needs Tailoring
abstract: The new Elton John-Shaina Taub musical, based on the popular film about a fashion-world ingénue and her demanding boss, isn’t yet ready-to-wear.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A movie-to-musical that wants to have its cake and eat it, too, and still fit into a sample size, “The Devil Wears Prada,” opened at the James M. Nederlander Theater here on Sunday. With music by the rock god Elton John and lyrics by the Off-Broadway sweetheart Shaina Taub (“Suffs”), it had seemed poised to set a trend or two.

headline: Treasury Dept. blacklists crypto platform used in money laundering.
abstract: The crackdown was the government’s latest effort to rein in the crypto industry.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department on Monday prohibited Americans from using the cryptocurrency platform Tornado Cash, saying the service has helped criminals launder more than $7 billion of virtual currencies.

headline: In War-Torn Mykolaiv, Ukrainians Search for Informers
abstract: As the city emerged from a 54-hour lockdown, the governor of the Mykolaiv region declared the operation a success, saying that five people had been arrested.
lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — The embattled city of Mykolaiv emerged on Monday from a 54-hour lockdown during which officers went door to door in search of collaborators who officials say are responsible for helping Russian forces identify targets for the rockets that pound the city daily.

headline: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles History (in a Half-Shell)
abstract: After nearly 40 years and a new Netflix film, a look at what continues to make these cartoon heroes so appealing.
lead_paragraph: There’s a great episode of “The Simpsons” in which Roger Myers Jr., a cartoon producer who runs the hit show “Itchy & Scratchy,” attempts to introduce a new character into the series to rejuvenate declining ratings. Poochie, the sunglasses-wearing, surfboard-carrying dog the studio comes up with, is “a dog with attitude,” explains one of the network executives pushing the idea. “He’s edgy, he’s in your face. You’ve heard the expression ‘let’s get busy’? Well, this is a dog who gets biz-zay. Consistently and thoroughly.”

headline: Do Spiders Dream of Eight-Legged Sheep?
abstract: Researchers found jumping spiders, known for their acrobatic hunting, exhibiting signs of R.E.M. sleep, but it is unknown whether they dream, or even sleep.
lead_paragraph: By day, jumping spiders hunt their prey, stalking and pouncing like cats. When the lights go down, these pea-sized predators hang out — and maybe their minds spin dreams.

headline: At Mostly Mozart Concerts, Casual Vibes and High Musical Values
abstract: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra offered a series of breezy but focused programs at Lincoln Center, filled with treats big and small.
lead_paragraph: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra bears the name of a festival that no longer exists, but over the last three weeks, it played 12 concerts that showed it still has a place in the new creative landscape at Lincoln Center.

headline: An Argument for Calling Your Mother
abstract: Lynne Tillman’s taut memoir of caring for an aging parent runs an emotional gamut.
lead_paragraph: With the rights of mothers and would-be mothers and would-rather-not-be mothers first under threat, and now under open ambush, who can blame writers and publishers for voting with their offerings? Mothers are having a moment. Novels about mothers, memoirs by and about them, essays on mothering with and without trauma, with or without dollops of white space between paragraphs. Mothers for most every palate. Yet the observant reader will probably have noticed that mothers have never been in short supply. Every idiot seems to have one.

headline: The U.S. Will Send Another $1 Billion in Aid to Ukraine.
abstract: The latest round of aid includes rockets credited with destroying Russian command posts and ammunition depots.
lead_paragraph: The United States will send more ammunition to Ukraine, including rockets for the HIMARS launchers that have been credited with destroying Russian command posts and ammunition depots, the Pentagon said Monday.

headline: Olivia Newton-John, Pop Singer and ‘Grease’ Star, Dies at 73
abstract: She amassed No. 1 hits, chart-topping albums and four records that sold more than two million copies each. More than anything else, she was likable, even beloved.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Newton-John, who sang some of the biggest hits of the 1970s and ’80s while recasting her image as the virginal girl next door into a spandex-clad vixen — a transformation reflected in miniature by her starring role in “Grease,” one of the most popular movie musicals of its era — died on Monday at her ranch in Southern California. She was 73.

headline: A Chaotic Sprint to the Finish for the W.N.B.A. Season
abstract: Six teams are fighting for the final three playoff spots with only one week left.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Sky, the reigning champions, are assured of one of the top two spots in the upcoming W.N.B.A. playoffs. The rebuilding Indiana Fever are the only team out of contention. Everything else is up for grabs.

headline: Strip-Searches of Children by London Police Are Called ‘Deeply Concerning’
abstract: A report from England’s children’s commissioner on Monday found that 650 children, including a disproportionate number of young Black boys, were subjected to the practice.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Hundreds of children were strip-searched in London by the police over a three-year period, according to a report released on Monday by Britain’s top official for children, who said she was “unconvinced” that the authorities were sufficiently judicious in employing the invasive practice in light of the potential harm.

headline: U.S. Promotes Democracy in Africa as Rival Nations Expand Influence
abstract: The Biden administration says the push will bolster African and American interests, including the ability of the United States to compete against China and Russia.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — The United States has been grappling with the growing influence of China, Russia and Middle Eastern nations across Africa, a situation made more acute in recent months by the competition to win partners in the war in Ukraine.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: China’s New Military Drills Near Taiwan
abstract: Also, a moving dispatch from Ukraine and the dire outlook for Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Just a day after ending its largest-ever military exercises near Taiwan, China announced new operations in the area.

headline: ‘Cheers, Virginia!’ Takes a Boozy Tour Through History
abstract: The exhibit at the Virginia Museum of History & Culture displays artifacts like George Washington’s fluted drinking glasses, a liquor taxation stamp from 1916 and more.
lead_paragraph: Alcoholic beverages, as they have been woven into the fabric of life in Virginia since the early European settlements, are the subject of a new exhibition at the Virginia Museum of History & Culture in Richmond. Historic details are illustrated by artifacts on display, exploring the need to drink alcoholic beverages because water was unsafe, George Washington’s contribution to American spirits, Prohibition, and modern craft brewing, distilling and winemaking. Among them are George Washington’s fluted drinking glasses, an early 18th century sherry glass, a liquor taxation stamp from 1916, an anti-Prohibition scarf and a 19th century copper still.

headline: The Guessing Game on the Front
abstract: Ukraine and Russia are in a quandary over where to concentrate their forces.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: A Choice of Mooncakes for the Mid-Autumn Festival
abstract: Try Chinese mooncakes in a gift set from Lady M, or Taiwanese-style versions from Té Company in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good month before the Mid-Autumn Festival (Sept. 10), also called the Moon Festival, is celebrated in Asia‌n communities. But to avoid less than a full mooncake supply for the occasion, observers often gather theirs in advance. Lady M, the bakery known for elaborate pastries, is ready with Chinese-style mooncakes in a new Glowing Lights Mooncake Gift Set, made in collaboration with Kee Wah Bakery in Los Angeles, a specialist. The set has six cakes in three flavors: Earl Grey, caramel-coffee‌, ‌and purple yam custard. In Taiwan the mooncakes are often different, pale and domed with a red stamp on top. At Té Company, which serves Taiwanese teas, they’re made to order with a filling of mung bean paste, sold in a package of six.

headline: ‘Tito’s in a Can,’ Just Add Vodka
abstract: A portion of the price of Tito’s Handmade Vodka’s stainless steel, 16-ounce can will be donated to charity.
lead_paragraph: With all the canned hard seltzers and ready-to-drink cocktails lining store shelves, Tito’s Handmade Vodka, a corn-based cult favorite from Austin, Texas, has taken a D.I.Y. route with a charity angle. It has introduced a sturdy, fairly slim stainless steel double-walled 16-ounce can containing no drink, with net proceeds donated to charities the company supports. (At checkout you can select one of five charities, like American Farmland Trust and Meals on Wheels America, that will receive at least 25 percent of the price.) We’re long past April 1 but yes, it’s empty, ready for anyone’s preferred libation — presumably made with Tito’s, as suggested on the can.

headline: An Italian Newcomer for Murray’s Cheese Shop
abstract: Cossanella, with an orange-streaked rind, comes from the Piedmont region and has the consistency of soft serve.
lead_paragraph: The bulging orange-streaked rind suggests Époisses from France, but Cossanella, newly imported by Murray’s Cheese Shop, is more delicate. It’s a product of the Alta Langa in the Piedmont region of Italy, an area known for top-flight wines and cheeses like La Tur and Robiola. Cossanella’s rind is washed with annatto — a condiment used for coloring made from the seeds of the achiote tree — providing its rusty hue. The ivory interior has subtle hints of mushroom and verbena, with a satin sheen and the consistency of soft serve. It’s a delectable partner for one of the Alta Langa’s spumantes.

headline: Follow the Scent of Cardamom to Smor Bakery
abstract: Near the restaurant Smor in the East Village, this bakery offers pastries, packaged goods and sandwiches.
lead_paragraph: Smor, a bright little Scandinavian-inspired restaurant in the East Village, now has its own bakery a few steps away. The Danish owners of both, Sebastian Perez and Sebastian Bangsgaard, had plans for it all along but the pandemic interfered. Their baker is Rowan Gill from Bien Cuit and Leo. The new bakery adds to New York’s growing supply of Nordic bakeries and their wealth of fragrant cardamom buns. It also offers cinnamon buns, swirled Danish tebirkes poppy seed rolls and breads like a dense rye loaf, a savory bread studded with Castelvetrano olives, and sourdough rolls that are the foundations for assorted sandwiches. There are 15 seats, and shelves laden with packaged goods like tinned fish, jams and homemade sauces and mustard herring.

headline: Anne Saxelby Remembered With a Legacy Fund
abstract: The owner of Saxelby Cheesemongers was a champion of American-made cheeses. Now her memory will help young people experience sustainable farming.
lead_paragraph: Anne Saxelby, the downtown cheesemonger and promoter of American cheeses who died last year, has been remembered with a fund that offers monthlong paid apprenticeships for young adults to live on sustainable farms. Next month, that organization, the Anne Saxelby Legacy Fund, will host a fund-raiser at the Chelsea Market, featuring 60 of Ms. Saxelby’s favorite chefs, such as Riad Nasr and Lee Hanson of Frenchette, Michael Anthony of Gramercy Tavern, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi of Carbone, Lena Ciardullo of Union Square Cafe and Max Ng of Momofuku. Ms. Saxelby, who opened Saxelby Cheesemongers in 2006 and later another store in the Chelsea Market, died in October of a heart condition. She was 40.

headline: It’s Never Too Late to Take Up Water Polo
abstract: Mark Braly, 86, has spent the last decade playing a particularly challenging team sport. Is he good? No — but that’s not the point.
lead_paragraph: It’s Never Too Late is a series about people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.

headline: A Health Care Bill, Minus Covid
abstract: The new climate and health legislation does not significantly address the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, after months of painful negotiations, Senate Democrats muscled through a $370 billion climate, tax and health care package.

headline: How Are You Feeling About Back-to-School This Year?
abstract: Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: As summer begins to wind down, many families across the U.S. are preparing for a new school year. Some students have already returned to class.

headline: Alex Jones’s Text Messages Turned Over to House Jan. 6 Committee
abstract: The messages only cover a period up to mid-2020, disappointing investigators who hoped they would shed light on the conspiracy theorist’s role in the events leading to the attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for plaintiffs who are suing the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones on Monday turned over more than two years’ worth of text messages from Mr. Jones’s phone to the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, including messages that show Mr. Jones was in touch with allies of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Biden Promises Federal Aid to Rebuild After Flooding in Kentucky
abstract: President Biden toured parts of Kentucky hit by some of the worst flooding in the state’s history, pledging federal resources toward rebuilding efforts and to families who lost their homes.
lead_paragraph: President Biden toured parts of Kentucky hit by some of the worst flooding in the state’s history, pledging federal resources toward rebuilding efforts and to families who lost their homes.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Biden Tours ‘Heartbreaking’ Kentucky Flood Damage
abstract: The president said he wanted to ensure the area was rebuilt in a way that made it more resilient to natural disasters that he described as a consequence of climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During his first official trip after recovering from the coronavirus, President Biden flew to eastern Kentucky on Monday and committed federal resources to families whose homes had been condemned or washed away by some of the worst flooding in the state’s history.

headline: Ukraine Disowns an Olympic Champion Who Skated in Russia
abstract: Viktor Petrenko, who won a gold medal at the 1992 Winter Games, has been shunned by Ukrainian figure skating officials — and by President Volodymyr Zelensky — after performing in Sochi, Russia.
lead_paragraph: As Russia began its invasion of Ukraine in February, Viktor Petrenko, one of Ukraine’s most visible Olympic champions, posted the message “NO WAR” to his Instagram account. Days later, Petrenko’s daughter said her father had been stranded in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, where he was taking shelter after returning from a commemoration of his 1992 Olympic figure skating title that had been held in his hometown, Odesa.

headline: U.S. Returns 30 Looted Antiquities to Cambodia
abstract: At a ceremony in Manhattan, federal officials said the artifacts had been stolen by organized looters who sold them through an art dealer who was later indicted on smuggling charges.
lead_paragraph: American and Cambodian officials urged museums and private collectors on Monday to investigate the origins of their Khmer art to determine whether it had been looted, and the officials demonstrated the pervasiveness of such thefts at an event that celebrated the return of 30 antiquities to Cambodia.

headline: How a Last-Minute Lobbying Blitz Watered Down a Climate Bill Tax
abstract: The new corporate minimum tax is not law yet and is already rife with exceptions for the businesses that might have to pay it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An hour after Democrats released the text of their climate and tax legislation, Washington lobbyists for the private equity industry sprang into action.

headline: Did Democrats Just Save Civilization?
abstract: On climate, Biden got almost everything he wanted.
lead_paragraph: They really did it. The Inflation Reduction Act, which is mainly a climate change bill with a side helping of health reform, passed the Senate on Sunday; by all accounts, it will easily pass the House, so it’s about to become law.

headline: When Sexual Liberation Is Oppressive
abstract: On Nona Willis Aronowitz’s “Bad Sex: Truth, Pleasure and an Unfinished Revolution.”
lead_paragraph: The conclusion of Louise Perry’s “The Case Against the Sexual Revolution: A New Guide to Sex in the 21st Century,” which was published in Britain in June and will arrive here next month, is titled “Listen to Your Mother.” Arguing that young women need to protect themselves from a sexual culture that treats them as disposable, Perry urges them to draw from the accumulated wisdom of previous generations. Feminism, she writes, “needs to rediscover the mother, in every sense.”

headline: Why the Soothsayers Are So Puzzled by This Year’s Midterms
abstract: People who have predicted election after election are scratching their heads about this one, as Election Day approaches.
lead_paragraph: Doug Sosnik is the kind of political analyst who likes to figure out the results of the next election well in advance — it’s just how he’s wired.

headline: In a Summer of Feints, Russia and Ukraine Try to Predict Enemy’s Next Move
abstract: Ukraine says that announcing a planned offensive on the southern front has paid off in the eastern Donbas region, as both sides deploy forces based on guessing each other’s next moves.
lead_paragraph: SLOVIANSK, Ukraine — At one point on the front line, Ukrainian soldiers advanced by creeping on their bellies 50 yards at a time, digging new trenches at every stop. Elsewhere, soldiers with the 93rd Brigade captured about three miles of wheat fields — and a Russian tank. Another unit liberated a village last week.

headline: F.B.I. Searches Trump’s Florida Home, Signaling Escalation of Inquiries
abstract: The focus appeared to be on material that the former president had brought to Mar-a-Lago when he left the White House.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Monday that the F.B.I. had searched his Palm Beach, Fla., home and had broken open a safe — an account signaling a major escalation in the various investigations into the final stages of his presidency.

headline: The search came as Trump is weighing another run for the presidency.
abstract: The F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago came as former President Donald J. Trump weighs an increasingly likely third White House bid. He has considered making an unusually early announcement this year, a move designed in part to shield himself from a stream of damaging revelations emerging from congressional and criminal investigations into his attempts to cling to power after losing the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago came as former President Donald J. Trump weighs an increasingly likely third White House bid. He has considered making an unusually early announcement this year, a move designed in part to shield himself from a stream of damaging revelations emerging from congressional and criminal investigations into his attempts to cling to power after losing the 2020 election.

headline: G.O.P. Group Targets Herschel Walker With Ad on Domestic Abuse Accusations
abstract: The anti-Trump group’s commercial in Georgia’s Senate race features Mr. Walker’s ex-wife describing his threats with a gun.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In his campaign for the Senate, Herschel Walker has not hidden his past struggles with mental illness and violence in past relationships, aspects of his background that he outlined in a 2009 memoir and that his campaign sought to address in its earliest days.

headline: From the archives: A look at the inquiry that led to the F.B.I. search of Trump’s Florida home.
abstract: The National Archives discovered in January that at the end of his term, former President Donald J. Trump had taken to his home at the Mar-a-Lago resort 15 boxes from the White House that contained government documents, mementos, gifts and letters. The boxes included material subject to the Presidential Records Act, which requires that all documents and records pertaining to official business be turned over to the archives.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives discovered in January that at the end of his term, former President Donald J. Trump had taken to his home at the Mar-a-Lago resort 15 boxes from the White House that contained government documents, mementos, gifts and letters. The boxes included material subject to the Presidential Records Act, which requires that all documents and records pertaining to official business be turned over to the archives.

headline: What is a federal search warrant?
abstract: Federal law enforcement officials’ use of a warrant does not indicate guilt, but it does indicate a sense of prosecutorial urgency.
lead_paragraph: Federal law enforcement officials obtain search warrants when they need to move quickly on a criminal investigation, or are concerned that sensitive materials they need might be in danger of being moved, concealed, altered or destroyed.

headline: Maryland Towns to Pay $5 Million in Black Teen’s Death in Police Encounter
abstract: The family of Anton Black, who died after being held face down for about six minutes during a 2018 encounter, partly settled their lawsuit against three Eastern Shore Police Departments.
lead_paragraph: Three towns on Maryland’s Eastern Shore have agreed to pay $5 million to the family of a Black teenager who was killed in an encounter with police officers in 2018, lawyers for the family said on Monday.

headline: A Florida political website lands a scoop.
abstract: News that the F.B.I. had searched Mar-a-Lago appeared to have been first reported Monday by Peter Schorsch, the publisher of FloridaPolitics.com.
lead_paragraph: News that the F.B.I. had searched Mar-a-Lago appeared to have been first reported Monday by Peter Schorsch, the publisher of FloridaPolitics.com.

headline: U.S. Moves to Stretch Out Monkeypox Vaccine Supply
abstract: The approach, which would require a new emergency authorization, would involve injecting one-fifth of the current dose into the skin instead of a full dose into underlying fat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has decided to stretch out its limited supply of monkeypox vaccine by allowing a different method of injection that uses one-fifth as much per shot, according to people familiar with the discussions.

headline: I Get Up and Nothin' Gets Me Down
abstract: Bruce Haight offers a puzzling twist on a classic tale.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Hello, Wordplay! I hope you are all ready to get up and let nothin’ get you down as we tackle Bruce Haight’s artistic Tuesday puzzle (his 60th New York Times Crossword!).

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 12 Recap: Hit the Road
abstract: Kim would like to make a confession, Gene has a new problem, and Jeff has car trouble.
lead_paragraph: After years of blending in and keeping low in Omaha, Gene Takavic, a.k.a. Saul Goodman, is about to lam it. In the closing moments of this episode, he is outed for good by a terrified but determined Marion, who has discovered the truth about her overly helpful pal. All it took was a computer, Ask Jeeves and a few key words: “Con man” and “Albuquerque.”

headline: Nets Owner Backs Team Leaders Amid Durant’s Reported Ultimatum
abstract: “Our front office and coaching staff have my support,” Joe Tsai said on Twitter just hours after a report that Kevin Durant wants the team to choose between keeping him or the coach and G.M.
lead_paragraph: Joe Tsai, the owner of the Nets, issued a statement of support for the team’s front office and coaching staff on Twitter Monday evening and added, “We will make decisions in the best interest of the Brooklyn Nets.”

headline: Heavy Rain Floods Streets in South Korea, Leaving Several Dead
abstract: A record-breaking storm hit Seoul and surrounding provinces in South Korea, causing deaths. More rainfall is expected.
lead_paragraph: A record-breaking storm hit Seoul and surrounding provinces in South Korea, causing deaths. More rainfall is expected.

headline: Republican officials reacted with fury to news of the search.
abstract: One Florida lawmaker suggested amending state laws regarding federal agencies.
lead_paragraph: Top Republicans and prominent conservatives reacted with outrage on Monday night to the news that the F.B.I. had searched the private residence of former President Donald J. Trump, with some suggesting that federal agents should be arrested and others hinting that the court-approved law-enforcement action against Mr. Trump was pushing the country toward political chaos.

headline: The House Jan. 6 panel is scheduled to interview Pompeo and Mastriano on Tuesday.
abstract: Douglas V. Mastriano, a point person in Pennsylvania for a plan to fake electors to keep Donald J. Trump in power, plans to object to the panel’s rules about video recording.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the F.B.I. search of former President Donald J. Trump’s property in Florida, the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is gearing up to meet with two potentially key witnesses in its separate inquiry on Tuesday.

headline: Republican governors criticize the Mar-a-Lago search as ‘unprecedented’ and ‘un-American.’
abstract: Several Trump allies echoed the former president’s claims that the Justice Department was being used as a weapon against Trump.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago home in Florida drew swift condemnation on Monday evening from some Republican governors who quickly backed Mr. Trump’s message that the Justice Department was being used against him.

headline: Law Enforcement Personnel Outside Trump’s Florida Residence
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump said that the F.B.I. had searched Mar-a-Lago, his Palm Beach, Fla., home, and had broken open a safe.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said that the F.B.I. had searched Mar-a-Lago, his Palm Beach, Fla., home, and had broken open a safe.

headline: Record-Setting Rainfall Inundates Seoul, Killing at Least 9
abstract: The South Korean capital saw some of its heaviest rainfall in decades. Drivers abandoned cars in the upscale Gangnam district as roads became impassable.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Some of the heaviest rainfall in decades struck the Seoul area overnight, flooding homes, streets and subway stations, and killing at least nine people, South Korean officials said on Tuesday.

headline: For Ukrainians Abroad, War Has Also Meant a Flowering of Identity
abstract: Italy already had the biggest Ukrainian community in Western Europe before the war, but in recent months the diaspora has taken on new prominence and visibility.
lead_paragraph: PADOVA, Italy — The Ukrainian gymnastics star leaped and pirouetted across the floor of a sports hall in northern Italy to the rhythm of a popular Ukrainian war song, as dozens of young Italian girls in chignons watched in awe.

headline: Snapchat Introduces Its First Parental Controls
abstract: The messaging app, which is popular with teenagers, has faced legal pressure to roll out tools so parents can keep an eye on their children’s social media activity.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Snapchat, the ephemeral messaging app, introduced its first parental controls on Tuesday, as social media platforms face increasing scrutiny for exposing young users to potentially harmful content.

headline: A Dry Summer Doesn’t Mean Serious Drought in New York
abstract: Rain has been scarce in recent weeks, but forecasters think a busy hurricane season is on the way.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Scroll down for trash talk with a reporter — that is, a Q. and A. about trash in the city. But first, is New York City in danger of a drought?

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘We Have Reached a Situation of Parity’ in the East, Ukraine Says
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “The first time I heard a HIMARS launch it was like music to my ears. It is the most beautiful music for Ukrainian soldiers.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 9, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about safety fears over fighting around a nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine misspelled the name of the Ukrainian state nuclear company. It is Energoatom, not Enerhoatam.

headline: After being trapped for months, ships loaded with grain have left Ukraine. Where are they going?
abstract: Two of the ships that have left ports in Ukraine after months of being trapped there are going to Turkey, carrying corn. One is going to England. One to Ireland. Others are headed to Italy and China.
lead_paragraph: Two of the ships that have left ports in Ukraine after months of being trapped there are going to Turkey, carrying corn. One is going to England. One to Ireland. Others are headed to Italy and China.

headline: Why China’s People No Longer Look Up to America
abstract: The U.S. should stop branding China as a threat and look in the mirror.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — My generation of Chinese looked up to the United States.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: An F.B.I. raid on the home of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. searched Donald Trump’s Palm Beach, Fla., home, including a safe that agents broke open, the former U.S. president said yesterday — an account signaling a dramatic escalation in the various investigations into the final stages of his presidency. The search appeared to be focused on files that Trump had brought to Florida when he left the White House.

headline: A View From China on How Perceptions of America Have Changed
abstract: A member of the Communist Party talks about how his country used to admire the United States.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning and on Saturdays.

headline: Will the fifth time be the charm for Raila Odinga?
abstract: Since his first presidential run three decades ago, Mr. Odinga has been at the center of most of Kenya’s elections.
lead_paragraph: Raila Odinga, the smiling eminence of Kenyan politics, has an admirable record of contesting national elections and a miserable record of winning them. Since his first presidential run 30 years ago, Mr. Odinga, 77, has been at the center of nearly every election, mostly as the aggrieved loser claiming to have been cheated of his rightful victory.

headline: William Ruto, the self-proclaimed champion of Kenya’s ‘hustler nation’
abstract: The candidate’s electoral pitch focuses on hard-working and ambitious young people.
lead_paragraph: William Ruto loves to tell of his humble origins — his barefoot childhood in the Rift Valley; his first pair of shoes at age 15; the time he scraped by selling chickens and ground nuts on the side of a busy highway.

headline: Stephen Colbert Taunts Trump for Bad Bathroom Behavior
abstract: “To be fair, it’s unclear if those are official White House documents or his toilet’s suicide note,” Colbert said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Here’s how Kenyan elections work.
abstract: The electoral commission has one week to declare the results of the vote.
lead_paragraph: Elections in Kenya have been passionately fought, and turnout has been high. Up to 80 percent of voters cast their ballots in the elections in August 2017. This election, too, has galvanized the country.

headline: Unai Emery Is Back for More
abstract: Fired after falling short at P.S.G. and in the Premier League, Emery has rebuilt his coaching reputation at Villarreal. It may not be long before his phone is ringing again.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — It has been more than three years now, but Unai Emery still remembers the moment as if he had just witnessed it. When he brings it up, all the frustration he felt on that day in March 2019 comes rushing back.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Long, Long Wait for a Diabetes Cure
abstract: A documentary captures the desperation and frustration of Type 1 diabetes patients in a clinical trial.
lead_paragraph: In the three decades since she was first diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes, Lisa Hepner has clung to a vague promise she often heard from doctors convinced medical science was on the cusp of making her body whole again. “Stay strong,” they would say. “A cure is just five years away.”

headline: Anxious New Yorkers Worry Whether Eric Adams Is the Man for the Moment
abstract: City residents are concerned about violent crime, housing costs, school budget cuts and homelessness. Some believe that the mayor has not met the challenge.
lead_paragraph: Outside Liberty Pool in Jamaica, Queens, near the home where Mayor Eric Adams was raised, Rosa Soriano watched her 6-year-old son play in the swelter of a midsummer heat wave.

headline: The troubles of Kenya’s China-funded train.
abstract: MOMBASA, Kenya — Fireworks popped and confetti rained down in the seaside city of Mombasa when Kenya’s president inaugurated the country’s new railway — designed, funded and built by China.
lead_paragraph: MOMBASA, Kenya — Fireworks popped and confetti rained down in the seaside city of Mombasa when Kenya’s president inaugurated the country’s new railway — designed, funded and built by China.

headline: How to Fall Out of Love With Your Lawn
abstract: Lawns are bad for you, your pets and the planet. It’s time to move on to greener pastures.
lead_paragraph: Lawns are bad for you, your pets and the planet. It’s time to move on to greener pastures.

headline: That Dinner Tab Has Soared. Here Are All the Reasons.
abstract: As diners everywhere suffer the shock of inflation, we tally up the many costs and forces driving up menu prices at a single restaurant.
lead_paragraph: As diners everywhere suffer the shock of inflation, we tally up the many costs and forces driving up menu prices at a single restaurant.

headline: How Russia Took Over Ukraine’s Internet in Occupied Territories
abstract: Diverting traffic through Russian networks makes it easier to censor, surveil and digitally wall off the invaded population.
lead_paragraph: Diverting traffic through Russian networks makes it easier to censor, surveil and digitally wall off the invaded population.

headline: Want to Stay Cool? Try Ankara Hand Fans.
abstract: Inspired by West African designs and very effective, they’re a stylish way to refute fictions of authenticity.
lead_paragraph: The subway was an oven. Humid air engulfed my mother, sister and me as we stood waiting for the train to take us to Times Square to see “The Lion King” musical. It was the first 90-degree day of the year, and I had forgotten what such heat felt like. Instinctively, my sister and I both reached for our African hand fans and began cooling our mother.

headline: Three Sentences That Could Change the World — and Your Life
abstract: The philosopher William MacAskill lays out the case for longtermism: “Future people count. There could be a lot of them. And we can make their lives better.”
lead_paragraph: Today’s show is built around three simple sentences: “Future people count. There could be a lot of them. And we can make their lives better.” Those sentences form the foundation of an ethical framework known as “longtermism.” They might sound obvious, but to take them seriously is a truly radical endeavor — one with the power to change the world and even your life.

headline: New York’s Hottest Club Is the Catholic Church
abstract: Catholicism is the new hip thing, partly as a rejection of progressive morality, partly as an aesthetic posture among the fashionable New Right.
lead_paragraph: As senior churchmen seek to make Catholicism palatable to modernity, members of a small but significant scene are turning to the ancient faith in defiance of liberal pieties. The scene is often associated with “Dimes Square,” a downtown Manhattan neighborhood popular with a pandemic-weary Generation Z — or Zoomer — crowd, but it has spread across a network of podcasts and upstart publications. Its sensibility is more transgressive than progressive. Many of its denizens profess to be apolitical. Others hold outré opinions, whether sincerely or as fashion statements. Reactionary motifs are chic: Trump hats and “tradwife” frocks, monarchist and anti-feminist sentiments. Perhaps the ultimate expression of this contrarian aesthetic is its embrace of Catholicism.

headline: The Cruelty Is Coming From Inside the House
abstract: Two eerie story collections depict the mundanity of human suffering.
lead_paragraph: Virgil, Emily Dickinson, Franz Kafka: It has become something of a cliché, authors on their deathbeds requesting that their unpublished works be destroyed (requests that literary executors have a fortunate habit of betraying). But the prolific 20th-century French writer Barbara Molinard was unwilling to take any such chances, tearing her short stories to shreds as soon as she wrote them. The malevolent and disorienting tales in her 1969 collection, “Panics,” represent her only surviving work. Saved from destruction by Molinard’s friend Marguerite Duras, who estimated that these 14 stories represent “maybe a hundredth” of what Molinard wrote, they have been translated for the first time into English, by Emma Ramadan.

headline: A Big TV Hit Is a Conservative Fantasy Liberals Should Watch
abstract: America is as divided over its favorite prestige television shows as news sources.
lead_paragraph: We may vote once a year, but most of us watch television every day.

headline: More Than a Muse
abstract: Mark Braude’s biography of a bohemian icon makes a case for Kiki de Montparnasse as an artist in her own right.
lead_paragraph: We open just as Kiki de Montparnasse begins to sing. It’s a scene narrated in the present tense, stitched together from a patchwork of memories — for who didn’t leave a record of their time in 1920s Paris? Especially if they’d managed to elbow their way into the Jockey, with its sticky floors, graffitied walls and stiff cocktails, where Kiki — queen of the neighborhood — purred her nostalgic songs. If you could smell it, said one contemporary, her voice would be “garlic hitting a pan’s hot butter and wine”: pungent, irresistible and impossible to recapture once it’s gone.

headline: Guatemala’s Corrupt Officials Train Their Sights on the Press
abstract: The arrest of José Rubén Zamora, an award-winning journalist and president of the elPeriódico newspaper, marks an escalation of the government’s assault on democratic values.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When I last saw José Rubén Zamora, the owner and director of Guatemala’s leading investigative newspaper, elPeriódico, in early June, he told me he suspected that the government was cooking up a case against him. His fears were not unfounded.

headline: Should I Tell My Elderly Turkish Dad That His Grandchild Is Trans?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on considerations when delivering news that will be shocking to a loved one.
lead_paragraph: We have a trans son who came out to us four and a half years ago. At first our focus was on his well-being, because we found out that he was self-harming. Immediately, we found a gender clinic in our area. As we sought to understand the struggles of our child and worked to get him the mental-health services that he needed, other issues started to pop up, like our child’s social transitioning.

headline: Kill Your Lawn, Before It Kills You
abstract: Lawns are bad for you, your pets and the planet. It’s time to move on to greener pastures.
lead_paragraph: Seen from above, it’s not the undulating rows of square houses that make American suburbia so recognizable. It’s the wide rivers of lush, almost neon-green grass that cut through the landscape. And on long, hot summer days, the lawn is where suburban living reaches its idyllic peak.

headline: Criminal Background Checks May Be Banned in N.Y.C. Housing Applications
abstract: The city could join New Jersey, Seattle and San Francisco in curtailing the ability of landlords to vet applicants’ criminal histories.
lead_paragraph: After she was released from prison in 2011, Kandra Clark spent five years sleeping on friends’ couches while searching for a new home in New York City.

headline: Crazy Eddie’s Life Was Insane!
abstract: In “Retail Gangster,” Gary Weiss explores the life and sketchy business practices of Eddie Antar, whose commercials are the stuff of legend.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: How Russian Propaganda Is Reaching Beyond English Speakers
abstract: Social media companies have taken steps to restrict Russian state media accounts. But posts from those accounts still spread in Spanish, Arabic and other languages and in places outside the West.
lead_paragraph: The day after a missile struck a shopping mall in central Ukraine in June, killing at least 18 people, the Spanish-language arm of Russia’s global television network, RT en Español, took to Facebook to challenge the facts of the attack.

headline: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About ‘Bad Sex’ but Were Afraid to Ask
abstract: In a quest to explore her own sexuality, Nona Willis Aronowitz hit the sheets — and the books.
lead_paragraph: “Bad sex” has become a catchphrase in recent years, shorthand for the ways that sex can still be unequal and sometimes not-quite-consensual. When I picked up “Bad Sex,” Nona Willis Aronowitz’s new book, I was prepared for an analysis of sexual politics post-#MeToo.

headline: She’s at Brown. Her Heart’s Still in Kabul.
abstract: In their first year at U.S. universities, women who escaped the Taliban are struggling to adjust — and to reckon with what they left behind.
lead_paragraph: It was late February when Suhaila Hashimi slid into one of the last available seats in the front row of her philosophy class, “The Place of Persons,” an intro-level course at Brown University about the moral and metaphysical status of personhood. Even though she was 23, and this was a class mostly for students who were several years younger, Hashimi fit in with them, her dark brown hair pulled into a messy ponytail, eyeliner darkening her lower lids, an oversize hoodie with Brown’s emblem on the front, black jeans tucked into black combat boots.

headline: With Deal in Hand, Democrats Enter the Fall Armed With Something New: Hope
abstract: Democrats say the climate and tax bill will help win over a skeptical electorate in November, as Republicans try to galvanize their base against a progressive wish list.
lead_paragraph: Vulnerable incumbent Democratic senators like Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire are holding events promoting the landmark legislation they passed over the weekend. Democratic ad makers are busily preparing a barrage of commercials about it across key battlegrounds. And the White House is set to deploy Cabinet members on a nationwide sales pitch.

headline: Admiring the Trees of Paris
abstract: From the dramatic weeping willows along the Seine to the London plane trees that line the Champs-Élysées, trees play a supporting role in the city’s inimitable elegance and grandeur.
lead_paragraph: As a Paris resident, I scarcely paid attention to the city’s tree-scape until a few years ago, when I stumbled upon an arresting scene of a young man stretched out in the elbow of a low-lying branch of a Japanese pagoda tree, its leaves skimming the pond at Buttes-Chaumont Park in the 19th arrondissement.

headline: Albuquerque Police Detain Suspect in Killings of Muslim Men
abstract: The shootings of four Muslim men since November may be connected, the police have said, raising fears in a place where many immigrants and refugees had felt at home.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — For days, the news that someone might be killing Muslim men in Albuquerque spread fear among the city’s Muslim residents, some of whom were so afraid of becoming the next target that they fled town or hunkered down in their homes.

headline: Mexico City Declared Police Abuse Over. Reports of Misconduct Kept Rising.
abstract: The police and city officials have turned a blind eye to misconduct, current and former police officials say — leaving victims of abuse, many of them poor, with little recourse.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Juan Carlos García Cortés was running errands in Mexico City on his moped when a taxi cut him off and two men jumped out. They shoved him in the back, threw a jacket over his head and began beating him.

headline: A Brother-and-Sister Renovation in the Hollywood Hills
abstract: When your sister is a real estate agent and an interior designer, why would you work with anyone else?
lead_paragraph: When your sister is a real estate agent and an interior designer, why would you work with anyone else?

headline: A Songwriter and His Sister Take on a Hollywood Hills Fixer-Upper
abstract: When your sibling is a real estate agent and an interior designer, why would you work with anyone else?
lead_paragraph: CJ Baran needed a new home in Los Angeles for personal and professional reasons. After living in an apartment for years, Mr. Baran, 32, a songwriter and music producer, longed for a house with a view and outdoor space. But he was also desperately in need of a home where he could make some noise.
