headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews William MacAskill
abstract: A covnersation with philosopher William MacAskill.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with William MacAskill. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Why China’s Confidence Could Turn Out to Be a Weakness
abstract: State propaganda about China’s rise is stoking extreme nationalism. That could blind China to its problems, and could lead to conflict — perhaps over Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: In his decade of ruling China, Xi Jinping has tried to imbue its people with confidence, telling them that the country is doing very well compared with the chaotic West.

headline: Issey Miyake, Who Opened a Door for Japanese Fashion, Dies at 84
abstract: The first Japanese designer to show in Paris, he was known for his origami-like designs, creating pleated skirts, dresses and trousers that afforded freedom.
lead_paragraph: Issey Miyake, one of the first Japanese designers to show in Paris, whose pleated style of clothing allowed for freedom of movement and whose name became a global byword for cutting-edge fashion in the 1980s, died on Friday in Tokyo. He was 84.

headline: How Democrats Salvaged a History-Making Bill
abstract: The climate change and prescription drug law has revived a set of party goals that were widely thought to be dead.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, Democrats passed legislation that would make historic investments to fight climate change and lower the cost of prescription drugs — paid for by raising taxes on businesses.

headline: Overlooked Provisions
abstract: Climate has received most of the attention. But the Senate bill brings big changes to health care, too.
lead_paragraph: The climate provisions in the bill that the Senate passed this weekend are likely to be more consequential than anything else in the bill. They will lead to a sharp reduction in U.S. greenhouse gas emissions, experts say, and help address arguably the world’s most pressing crisis.

headline: For an Article on ‘Ice Mermaids,’ Taking the (Very Cold) Plunge
abstract: To document the practice of cold-water plunging in the near-freezing waters of Maine, a photojournalist took to the ice, then under it.
lead_paragraph: Being a photojournalist means perpetually job shadowing; being a forever beginner; and a regular visitor. Each day, we learn how to navigate the world from the people willing to invite us into theirs.

headline: Russia helps Iran launch a satellite, a sign of closer cooperation.
abstract: A Russian rocket launched an Iranian satellite into orbit on Tuesday, a tangible sign of the expanding cooperation between the two countries in the face of stringent Western sanctions imposed on both.
lead_paragraph: A Russian rocket launched an Iranian satellite into orbit on Tuesday, a tangible sign of the expanding cooperation between the two countries in the face of stringent Western sanctions imposed on both.

headline: How We Mourn Covid’s Victims
abstract: In Britain, artists lit a structure aflame. At the Jersey Shore, names were carved on shells and rocks. With more than six million dead, memorials have evolved along the way.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Piece by piece, the Covid-19 sanctuary was born on a hilltop in the town of Bedworth in central England. The process was meant to be a metaphor for a human life. Like bones fused over time, it grew taller as the memorial’s creators spent months joining intricate pieces of wood into a skeletal structure that finally stood on its own, 65 feet high.

headline: Britain Faces More Extreme Heat
abstract: Temperatures were expected to reach 35 degrees Celsius (95 Fahrenheit) in some parts of the country, which largely lacks air-conditioning and set a record high last month.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Weeks after recording its highest-ever temperature, Britain was preparing for another unsettling stretch of hot weather, as officials said an extreme heat warning would be in place for much of the southern half of England and parts of Wales from Thursday through the weekend.

headline: Former Basketball Player Finds His Niche in Hollywood
abstract: Dane DiLiegro found his theatrical calling playing monsters onscreen and dreams of more in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles, like its signature art form, is constantly evolving, but some L.A. stories don’t change.

headline: A Painter’s Home That Celebrates Hawaii
abstract: The Honolulu home of Jean Charlot, a French expatriate artist, embodies his appreciation for the surrounding landscape.
lead_paragraph: WHEN THE FRENCH American muralist Jean Charlot arrived in postwar Hawaii in 1949 on a commission to paint a fresco in the foyer of a newly built administration building at the University of Hawaii at Manoa in Honolulu, he had no intention of making the islands his home. The 51-year-old artist’s goal was to complete a lush 10-by-29-foot depiction of ancient Hawaiian life, replete with poi pounding, spearfishing and seated hula dancing, set during the inauspicious moment right before Captain Cook’s approaching Resolution was sighted offshore by the natives.

headline: Serena Williams Says She Will Retire From Tennis Sometime After U.S. Open
abstract: In a cover story for Vogue, Williams said she was “evolving away from tennis, toward other things that are important to me.”
lead_paragraph: The world first came to know Serena Williams as a 17-year-old with beaded braids, overwhelming power and precocious intelligence and poise when she stunned her sport by winning the first of her 23 Grand Slam singles titles at the 1999 U.S. Open.

headline: Tell Us About Your Experience With Mental Health Apps
abstract: The Times wants to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: When many retreated into their homes at the start of the pandemic, virtual mental health start-ups positioned themselves as antidotes to emotional distress. Psychoanalysis went from the couch to the camera; psychologists found new ways to communicate with patients; and some psychiatrists issued more prescriptions online. For many, these services were a lifeline during the despair of lockdowns, and as life outside the home resumed, virtual therapy persisted. But some therapy app users and employees have spoken out about alleged wrongdoing in the world of online mental health, making claims about companies that are improperly prescribing psychiatric medications and infringing on consumer privacy.

headline: Does Wildfire Smoke Cause Lung Cancer?
abstract: And how does the risk compare with inhaling smoke from cigarettes?
lead_paragraph: Q: How does wildfire smoke affect the risk of lung cancer? And how does this compare to things like secondhand cigarette smoke?

headline: Lamont Dozier, Writer of Numerous Motown Hits, Dies at 81
abstract: With the brothers Brian and Eddie Holland, Mr. Dozier wrote dozens of singles that reached the pop or R&B charts, including “You Can’t Hurry Love,” by the Supremes.
lead_paragraph: Lamont Dozier, the prolific songwriter and producer who was crucial to the success of Motown Records as one-third of the Holland-Dozier-Holland team, died on Monday at his home near Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.

headline: A Gratin Worth Naming a Restaurant After
abstract: The gratin dauphinois is one of the stars of Le Gratin, the latest place from the chef Daniel Boulud.
lead_paragraph: The gratin dauphinois is one of the stars of Le Gratin, the latest place from the chef Daniel Boulud.

headline: Restaurant Review: Searching for Signs of Lyon at Daniel Boulud’s Le Gratin
abstract: The chef’s latest restaurant is billed as a “bouchon Lyonnais.” So where are the intestine sausages?
lead_paragraph: Right up until the moment he actually opened one, nobody appeared more qualified to run a Lyon-style bouchon in New York City than Daniel Boulud. Then along came Le Gratin, and it became clear that he wasn’t the right person for the job at all.

headline: Vermont: Here’s how to vote, where to vote and what’s on the ballot.
abstract: If you need to take advantage of same-day registration, do it in person. Here’s what else to know.
lead_paragraph: Vermonters head to the polls Tuesday to choose nominees for the state’s lone House seat as well as the Senate seat being vacated by Senator Patrick Leahy, a Democrat who is retiring.

headline: Russia says oil flows to three European Union members have been halted.
abstract: A state-owned operator of a Russian pipeline to Europe said its payment to the Ukrainian operator of the pipeline had been returned, blaming issues linked to European sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: In another sign of the fragility of Europe’s supply, flows of oil from Russia to Central Europe have halted over a pipeline payments dispute, raising fears that an “energy war” between Moscow and its European oil customers could escalate.

headline: Matt Carpenter’s Dream Season for Yankees Is in Jeopardy
abstract: The resurgent Carpenter fractured his left foot on a foul tip. No timetable has been given for his return.
lead_paragraph: If Matt Carpenter’s season is over after he fractured his foot on Monday in Seattle, he at least joined some elite company. His shocking resurgence at age 36 has put his name alongside some of the best hitters in franchise history.

headline: The Princess and the Poconos
abstract: In this excerpt from “Shy: The Alarmingly Outspoken Memoirs of Mary Rodgers,” a Broadway musical is born at a summer camp.
lead_paragraph: A hundred-mile drive from New York City, on the fringe of the Pocono Mountains, Tamiment was for much of the last midcentury a resort for singles and a summer intensive for emerging theatrical talent. During the first half of each season, writers assembled an original musical revue every week; in the second half, if they were interested in cranking out a show with a story — and if Moe Hack, the barky, crusty, cigar-smoking sweetheart who ran the place, thought it was a good idea — they would be free to try.

headline: Minnesota: Here’s how to vote, where to vote and what’s on the ballot.
abstract: The state has same-day registration, and voters in one district will decide on a special election that overlaps a House primary.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota voters in the First Congressional District will see some names on the ballot twice on Tuesday. It is not a mistake.

headline: From Pittsburgh to New Orleans, on a 19th-Century-Style Flatboat
abstract: In “Life on the Mississippi,” Rinker Buck takes a lengthy river trip to examine a uniquely American history.
lead_paragraph: A dry cleaner in Yankton, S.D., once told me that he had spied so many fussily costumed boaters from the banks of the nearby Missouri River that he’d grown weary of new arrivals. “People are recreating Lewis and Clark,” he said. “It happens here all the time.” He loved the river, for its waterfowl and promise of imaginative escape, but not always its thru-traveling flock, who, if not reprising the migration of previous generations, often seemed to be proselytizing for one thing or another: energy independence, say, or sobriety. “Some of these people are a little on their high horse, you know?” he said. To meet a waterborne voyager whose only cause was wanderlust: That was novel.

headline: Connecticut: Here’s how to vote, where to vote and what’s on the ballot.
abstract: Here is a refresher on the rules for voting and what’s at stake in Connecticut on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut might be known as a campaign fund-raising powerhouse that rarely deviates from electing Democrats statewide, but even its primary on Tuesday is drawing the attention of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Sheida Soleimani’s Art Is for the Birds
abstract: The artist’s home and studio in Providence, R.I., is, among other things, a wildlife clinic.
lead_paragraph: Sheida Soleimani speaks the language of birds, deftly contorting her lips and breath to recite lilting sounds with distinct avian fluency. As far as the Iranian American artist is concerned, it’s her second language after Farsi. “Before I could speak English, I used to listen to bird sounds on tape,” says Soleimani, 32. She would spend hours playing recordings in her childhood bedroom, specifically bird sounds from North America. “I didn’t really have friends at the time,” she adds.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 7: On ‘Is the World Really Falling Apart, or Does It Just Feel That Way?’
abstract: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Ivy Qin, as well as to our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: We received 1,315 entries from students from around the world for the seventh week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Ivy Qin, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.

headline: This Fall, Outerwear Will Be Furry, Fluffy and Wild
abstract: With an array of textures, these styles bring a spirit of adventure.

headline: The F.B.I. search ignited the language of violence and civil war on the far right.
abstract: Pro-Trump influencers, figures in the media and even some Republican candidates for office employed the language to rally opposition.
lead_paragraph: For the past six years, Donald J. Trump’s most loyal backers have, as though by reflex, attacked federal law-enforcement officials whenever they have sought to investigate the former president or his allies.

headline: Fighting inflation with climate action
abstract: Here’s how policies to slow global warming can also shield consumers from rising prices.
lead_paragraph: Democrats this weekend muscled through what would be the biggest expenditure ever by the United States to slow global warming, but you wouldn’t necessarily know from the name of the measure that it had anything to do with climate.

headline: Wisconsin: Here’s how to vote, where to vote and what’s on the ballot.
abstract: The deadline to register to vote for Tuesday’s primary has passed.
lead_paragraph: Republican voters in Wisconsin will pick who will get to challenge Gov. Tony Evers this fall in what has become Tuesday’s most closely watched race in the state.

headline: Demand for Italian Beef Is Booming. Thank ‘The Bear.’
abstract: The FX series has fueled a spike in sales of the sandwich at Chicago-specialty restaurants across the country.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Dan Michaels, an owner of Gino’s East of Chicago in Los Angeles, watched as orders for Italian beef — the classic Chicago sandwich of thinly sliced roast beef and tangy giardiniera piled on a roll — suddenly soared to 300 a day, from 150 a day in June.

headline: The Fed Is Cooling Down the Economy, but Stocks Are Hot. What Gives?
abstract: Investors are pinning their hopes on a rosy outcome for inflation and growth, driving the S&P 500 up 12 percent in the past two months.
lead_paragraph: Stocks have roared back from their low in June, as investors bet that inflation has peaked, even as the Federal Reserve signals that its campaign to cool the economy by raising interest rates isn’t over.

headline: Walmart Ponders Streaming Deal With Paramount, Disney and Comcast
abstract: The retail giant is exploring bundling a streaming service into its Walmart+ membership program.
lead_paragraph: Walmart has held discussions with major media companies about including streaming entertainment in its membership service, according to three people with knowledge of the conversations, part of an effort to extend its relationship with customers beyond its brick-and-mortar stores.

headline: How do you manage Omicron BA.5 symptoms, including a sore throat?
abstract: The longtime symptom of Covid is becoming more common, and sometimes more severe, with the dominant BA.5 subvariant.
lead_paragraph: While a sore throat has always been a symptom of Covid, experts said that it is becoming more common, and sometimes more severe, with the BA.5 subvariant of Omicron — now, the dominant strain of Covid in the United States.

headline: Was There a Biden Boom?
abstract: And if so, why aren’t people feeling it?
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I wrote a newsletter that I foolishly considered somewhat anodyne, not likely to get much reaction. It seemed probable that the initial estimate for G.D.P. growth in the second quarter would be negative and that many people would declare that this meant the United States was in a recession. So I spent some time pedantically explaining why we don’t actually use “two negative quarters” to define recessions and why, given other data, America probably wasn’t in one.

headline: In This Novel, Witchcraft Makes Women Powerful, and Vulnerable
abstract: In “The Women Could Fly,” women are uniquely capable of magic, which leads the government to strictly monitor and regulate them.
lead_paragraph: In the world of “The Women Could Fly,” Megan Giddings’s second novel, the government mandates that women marry by age 30; by age 28, unmarried women must enroll in a registry. Those who resist should gear up for a future post-carceral in its complexion. The justification? Women are uniquely capable of witchcraft. What in another world might be called miracles are, here, baleful strangenesses. More quotidian phenomena are attributed to women and witchcraft too. If you’ve come down with a fever that won’t go away, a witch did it. If your husband cheats on you, a witch made him do it. “Witch” is an epithet, and witches are still burned at the stake, women a danger to be corralled.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Team Protests After Church Production Adds Christian Themes
abstract: A church in Texas changed several lyrics in its unauthorized staging of the megahit musical, softening language and inserting religious messages.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the creators of “Hamilton,” the record-setting musical that remains a worldwide draw seven years after its Broadway debut, protested after a Texas church put on an unauthorized production this weekend. Church performers changed some lyrics and introduced Christian themes that were not part of the original.

headline: Sandro’s, From a Restaurant Veteran, Opens on the Upper East Side
abstract: A Beijing chain opens its first New York location, a Shelter Island spot with rustic elegance, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The chef Sandro Fioriti has owned a restaurant bearing his name in New York since 1985. Now, at 74, he’s still tossing pasta, in a new location. He opened his first with the help of Tony May at 420 East 59th Street, previously occupied by the super-luxe Palace. (It is now Pino Luongo’s Morso.) Then, in 2006, after a few interim gigs, he opened his spot on the Upper East Side, at 306 East 81st Street. That restaurant closed in February, and he has relocated to East 86th Street, in the former Little Frog. Throughout he was noted for his cuisine, inspired by his native Umbria and Rome, where he trained, long before Roman food achieved its current prominence in New York. He is now joined by his son, Sandro Fioriti Jr., who runs the restaurant, with his father in the kitchen turning out his well-regarded spaghetti al limone, rigatoni amatriciana, cacio e pepe, fried artichokes and pollo cacciatora alla romana. The younger Mr. Fioriti, who has been involved for the past eight years, said that the menu was essentially the same as it was on 81st Street, and that the kitchen and dining room staff also made the move. There are 56 seats in a somewhat formal room with a big bar, white napery and white brick walls.

headline: Olivia Newton-John: That Headband Was a Crown
abstract: When the singer smudged her classy image, she “unlocked something new that shot her to the top of pop’s Olympus,” our critic writes: “The vestal vamp.”
lead_paragraph: We would’ve just called her ONJ now. But part of the appeal, I think, was all of that name, the possible royalty of it. Nobody wanted to waste a syllable. Olivia Newton-John. Just saying it might bestow a crown. The rest of her allure sprang from that classiness: She was neither queen nor first lady of anything, yet she seemed, ultimately, like … a lady. And that was something she could have some fun with, a category she could smudge. Eventually. I mean, this was a person who, at the heights of funk, disco and glam rock, recorded six country-esque albums, throw pillows for your ears. And most of their singles topped what was once known as Billboard’s easy listening chart. (So maybe she was the queen of that.)

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Couple With Nothing to Talk About’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: One recent summer evening, my husband and I were sitting by the fire pit at our home north of Chicago, watching the flames dance, feeling tired but content. If someone had been watching us, they may have thought, “Now there’s a couple with nothing to talk about.” But, after 38 years of marriage — and a day biking and working in the backyard — I thought, “Who else could I do this with? Who else would I want to do this with?” Hours later, we checked the embers, covered the pit and headed wordlessly up to bed. — Ellen Blum Barish

headline: F.B.I. Search Ignited Violent Rhetoric on the Far Right
abstract: Some pro-Trump media figures reacted to the search at Mar-a-Lago with talk of ‘war,’ the clearest outburst of such language since the days leading up to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: For the past six years, Donald J. Trump’s most loyal supporters have gone on the attack against federal law-enforcement officials whenever they have sought to investigate the former president or his allies.

headline: Republicans Rally Behind Trump, Who Reprises Favored Role: Victim
abstract: Arguments used against Hillary Clinton in the 2016 email inquiry are long forgotten as G.O.P. officials rush to condemn the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans sought Tuesday to turn the F.B.I.’s search of Donald J. Trump’s Florida home into a rallying point, positioning the former president in his political comfort zone as a partisan target and victim, while effectively suspending the party’s efforts to focus on other issues heading into the midterm elections.

headline: PGA Tour Can Bar LIV Golfers From Playoff, Judge Rules
abstract: The narrow ruling came less than 48 hours before the start of the FedEx Cup playoffs in Memphis, but the broader turmoil could last for years.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday rebuffed an effort by three LIV Golf players to compete in this week’s FedEx Cup playoffs, giving the PGA Tour interim support as it faces an uprising over the invitational series financed by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Serena Williams Forced Her Way Into the Tennis History Books
abstract: With her dominant strokes and smart moves off the court, Williams helped redefine how to be a superstar athlete.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams’s fellow tennis professionals already know what their sport is like without her.

headline: U.S. Is Urgently Seeking a Country to Resettle a Qaeda Informant
abstract: Government lawyers said the transfer of Majid Khan was a high priority because he pleaded guilty to war crimes and his sentence at Guantánamo Bay had ended.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — U.S. diplomats have asked 11 countries if they would be willing to take in a former courier for Al Qaeda who was tortured by the C.I.A. and became a government informant, Justice Department lawyers said in a court filing on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. and Iran Weighing ‘Final’ E.U. Offer on Nuclear Deal
abstract: Tehran has dropped a key demand that stalled the talks for months, but it now has a new one.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen months after the United States and Iran began negotiating a possible return to the 2015 Iran nuclear deal abandoned by President Donald J. Trump, the European Union has presented a “final” proposal for the two sides to consider before the talks collapse for good, Western officials said.

headline: Serena Williams Leaves Tennis Just as She Played: On Her Own Terms
abstract: Williams brought her own distinctive flair to tennis, challenging norms that governed fashion, power, decorum, race and gender. By being herself, Williams’s reach far exceeded the game.
lead_paragraph: She is a symbol. A persona. An athlete who has gone far beyond the footsteps of her trailblazing sister and came to rule a cloistered, mostly white sport. She refuses to stop there.

headline: The Politics of Searching a Former President’s Home
abstract: Experts on high-wire investigations say that the Justice Department would have carefully weighed the decision to poke around Mar-a-Lago — and that it might want to tell the public why it was necessary.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. does not take a decision like searching the private home of a former president lightly.

headline: Explosions Rip Through Russian Base on Crimea
abstract: A senior Ukrainian official said his country’s forces were responsible, which Ukraine did not publicly confirm or deny. Russian officials said only that munitions had detonated.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — A series of explosions rocked a key Russian air base in Kremlin-occupied Crimea on Tuesday, killing at least one person and sowing confusion among local officials about the cause and whether Ukraine’s military could threaten targets on the peninsula.

headline: The Lawless G.O.P. Response to the Raid at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: Being seen to be persecuted by federal officers is now a badge of honor in the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: With the disclosure that the F.B.I. searched his winter palace at Mar-a-Lago, Donald Trump has doubled down on his attacks on law enforcement and on law itself. And many in the G.O.P. establishment are backing him up — not necessarily because they truly believe him to be innocent but because being seen to be persecuted by federal officers is now a badge of honor in the Republican Party.

headline: Biden Officials Change Monkeypox Dosing Regimen to Conserve Limited Supply
abstract: The development suggests that the United States may be able to vaccinate hundreds of thousands more people than anticipated by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After two months of a vaccine shortage that has undermined its response to the monkeypox outbreak, the Biden administration on Tuesday moved to stretch its limited supplies by authorizing a different injection method that will use one-fifth of the current dose.

headline: Employee Kept Arsenal, Including Assault Rifle, at Hospital, Police Say
abstract: A police dog led investigators to the cache after a bomb threat was called into the hospital last month, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey hospital’s marketing director stockpiled an assault rifle fitted with a high-capacity magazine along with dozens of other guns and ammunition in an unlocked closet at his workplace, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Here’s a look at Trump’s endorsement record in Republican primaries.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has endorsed more than 200 Republicans this year, many of whom ran unopposed or faced little-known, poorly funded opponents.
lead_paragraph: As the midterm primary season enters the homestretch, the candidates endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump continue to rack up primary wins.

headline: Garland Becomes Trump’s Target After F.B.I.’s Mar-a-Lago Search
abstract: The attorney general has not commented on the search at Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida, and the former president and his allies are filling the void with vitriol.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. had scarcely decamped from Mar-a-Lago when former President Donald J. Trump’s allies, led by Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, began a bombardment of vitriol and threats against the man they see as a foe and foil: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland.

headline: Justice Dept. Said to Conduct New Interviews in Inquiry Into Google’s Ad Tech
abstract: The Justice Department for more than a year has investigated whether Google abuses its dominance over the interlocking technologies that deliver ads online.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has in recent weeks conducted new interviews for its investigation into Google’s ad technology, a sign it may be moving closer to filing its second antitrust case against the company, said three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Ilhan Omar faces a primary challenge in her Minnesota House district.
abstract: Four opponents, including the former Minneapolis city councilman Don Samuels, are competing to unseat the incumbent.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ilhan Omar, one of Congress’s most prominent lawmakers, is facing four Democratic primary challengers in Minnesota as she seeks her third term, making her the latest member of the progressive group known as the “squad” to defend her seat this year.

headline: Representative Scott Perry says the F.B.I. seized his cellphone.
abstract: Mr. Perry compared the seizure of his phone to the F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago property.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. on Tuesday seized the cellphone of Representative Scott Perry, Republican of Pennsylvania and the chairman of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus, according to the congressman’s office.

headline: Never Before in American History: The F.B.I. Searches a Former President’s Home
abstract: The search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate is a high-risk gamble by the Justice Department, but Mr. Trump faces risks of his own.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight between former President Donald J. Trump and the National Archives that burst into the open when F.B.I. agents searched Mr. Trump’s Palm Beach estate has no precedent in American presidential history.

headline: F.B.I. Search of Trump’s Home Pushes Long Conflict Into Public View
abstract: Justice Department officials were worried that the former president had not fully complied with requests to return material taken from the White House that included possible classified information.
lead_paragraph: The search carried out on Monday by the F.B.I. at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home, a law enforcement action with explosive legal and political implications, was the culmination of a lengthy conflict between a president proud of his disdain for rules and officials charged with protecting the nation’s records and secrets.

headline: Jury Acquits Truck Driver of All Charges in Crash That Left 7 Bikers Dead
abstract: Volodymyr Zhukovskyy, 26, was facing 15 charges after being accused of causing a collision that killed a group of motorcyclists on a rural road in Randolph, N.H.
lead_paragraph: A jury in New Hampshire on Tuesday acquitted a commercial truck driver of all charges in connection with a 2019 crash on a rural highway that killed seven members of a motorcycle club and shocked the state.

headline: Becca Balint wins a Vermont House primary, with the backing of Senator Bernie Sanders.
abstract: She is expected to prevail in November and become the first woman the state has sent to Congress.
lead_paragraph: Becca Balint, a progressive leader in the Vermont Legislature who had the support of the state’s most influential political figure, Senator Bernie Sanders, won the Democratic primary for the state’s lone seat in Congress, according to The Associated Press.

headline: A House Republican who voted to impeach Trump loses her race in Washington State.
abstract: Marie Perez, a Democrat, and Joe Kent, a Trump-backed Republican, will face off in November after winning their “jungle primary” against Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler, who criticized Trump after Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler of Washington, a Republican who voted to impeach former President Donald J. Trump and sharply criticized his actions leading up to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, conceded her primary Tuesday in a crowded race that included a Trump-backed challenger and other 2020 election deniers.

headline: Meet Mandela Barnes, the 35-Year-Old Candidate Working to Oust Ron Johnson
abstract: Wisconsin’s lieutenant governor embodies both the flaws and the promise of his generation.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Millennials came of age at a time of crisis. They are the first generation in American history positioned to be worse off than their parents, their economic trajectory forever altered by the economic meltdown of the late 2000s, as the ladders to the middle class were pulled up or broken by the crushing burden of student debt, the decline of unions and skyrocketing health care and housing costs, and as rapid technological changes proved more calamitous than democratizing.

headline: Get It? Got It!
abstract: Karen Lurie’s puzzle is a bit pedantic.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations and a welcome back to the constructor Karen Lurie, who is making her second appearance in the New York Times Crossword, following up on her hilarious SPOILER ALERT puzzle from earlier this year. Between that puzzle and this one, Ms. Lurie has firmly established herself as a constructor who makes funny puzzles.

headline: Falling Tree Kills 2 Soldiers During Storm in Georgia
abstract: Three others service members were treated by Army medics and taken to a hospital.
lead_paragraph: Two U.S. Army soldiers were struck by a falling tree and killed on Tuesday while sheltering near Yonah Mountain in northern Georgia, where they had been training before a severe thunderstorm blasted the area with strong winds, Army officials said. Three other service members were injured.

headline: The Lycra Legacy of Olivia Newton-John’s ‘Physical’
abstract: Athleisure, leggings, shapewear owe a debt of gratitude to the iconic video.
lead_paragraph: A funny thing happened when Kameron Lennox revisited the music video for “Physical,” the 1981 pop megahit by Olivia Newton-John, who died on Monday.

headline: Tim Michels, with Trump’s backing, is Wisconsin Republicans’ choice for governor.
abstract: He has contemplated trying to overturn the 2020 election, a legal impossibility that is a popular cause among Wisconsin Republicans.
lead_paragraph: KAUKAUNA, Wis. — Tim Michels, a millionaire construction magnate endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, won Wisconsin’s Republican primary for governor, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Wisconsin Republicans Embrace Trump in a Race Defined by 2020 Grievances
abstract: Tim Michels, the former president’s choice in the primary for governor, beat an establishment-backed rival to set up a closely watched November race against Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Republican primary voters upended their party’s establishment in Wisconsin on Tuesday, choosing a Trump-backed candidate for governor who has entertained overturning the 2020 election results to take on Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat, in one of the country’s most consequential November contests.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Final’ Nuclear Deal on Table for Iran and U.S. to Weigh
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “This is their style: moving toward an agreement but at the moment of agreement saying, ‘There’s just one more thing.’”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 10, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: A profile on Saturday about Mechai Viravaidya, known as “Captain Condom” for his campaigns to promote safe sex and family planning, misstated the average number of children a Thai family had in the early 1970s. It was five, not seven.

headline: From the Workshop to the War: Creative Use of Drones Lifts Ukraine
abstract: While Russia lacks an effective long-range strike drone, Ukraine’s experimentation has produced an array of inexpensive, plastic aircraft, jury-rigged to drop grenades or other munitions.
lead_paragraph: POKROVSKE, Ukraine — A private in the Ukrainian army unfolded the rotors of a common hobby drone and, with practiced calm, attached a grenade to a device that can drop objects and was designed for commercial drone deliveries.

headline: The Greenest Block Grows in Brooklyn
abstract: A block of Lincoln Place in Crown Heights is the winner of an urban gardening award. Its trees lower temperatures, one of the gardeners says.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out why a block in Crown Heights is Brooklyn’s greenest. And, how much has inflation driven up food prices in New York? Scroll down for a sample of New York staples that cost more.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Russia’s grip on Ukrainian cyberspace.
lead_paragraph: In parts of Russian-occupied Ukraine, Russia has also begun occupying cyberspace. It has cleaved off Ukrainians in Kherson, Melitopol and Mariupol from the rest of the country, limiting access to news about the war and communication with loved ones. In some territories, the internet and cellular networks have been shut down altogether.

headline: Who Won and Who Lost in Primary Elections in Wisconsin and Elsewhere
abstract: Republicans chose Tim Michels to challenge Gov. Tony Evers in Wisconsin, and Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes will take on Senator Ron Johnson. In Washington State, a House Republican who voted for impeachment conceded her race.
lead_paragraph: Four states held primary elections on Tuesday — and we got a concession in one of last week’s House races in Washington State. Here’s a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses.

headline: A tally of damage near a Crimean air base contradicts the Kremlin’s assertions.
abstract: ODESA, Ukraine — Damage from a series of explosions at a Russian air base in Crimea appeared to be greater than the Kremlin has described, as officials on the Russia-occupied peninsula on Wednesday declared a state of emergency and said that dozens of nearby homes and commercial structures had been hit.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — Damage from a series of explosions at a Russian air base in Crimea appeared to be greater than the Kremlin has described, as officials on the Russia-occupied peninsula on Wednesday declared a state of emergency and said that dozens of nearby homes and commercial structures had been hit.

headline: Tim Michels Is Wisconsin Republicans’ Choice for Governor
abstract: Tim Michels, a Wisconsin native who inherited an infrastructure company from his father and was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, won Wisconsin’s Republican primary for governor.
lead_paragraph: Tim Michels, a Wisconsin native who inherited an infrastructure company from his father and was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, won Wisconsin’s Republican primary for governor.

headline: What Martial Law? Marcoses Get Star Treatment in New Film.
abstract: A big-budget production depicts the family as victims of a political vendetta, a popular narrative during the recent presidential election in the Philippines.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: For Older Americans, Health Bill Will Bring Savings and ‘Peace of Mind’
abstract: Starting in 2025, Medicare recipients with prescription drug coverage will not have to pay more than $2,000 annually for medications, a significant savings for some.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Pete Spring was diagnosed with dementia in 2016, he and his wife emptied their checking account in part to pay for his prescription drugs, then ran through $60,000 in pension payments before resorting to a charge card to help make sure Mr. Spring had the heart and Alzheimer’s medications he needed to survive — just two of the 11 drugs he took.

headline: ‘We Couldn’t Do Anything’: Family Drowns in Seoul Basement During Floods
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of poor people live in semi-underground homes around the city. The death of a family of three showed ​how vulnerable they are to flooding.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — At 4:40 p.m. on Monday, the 13-year-old girl texted her ​72-year-old ​grandmother ​who was ​in the hospital, wishing her well and saying that she was praying for her quick recovery.

headline: Newly Published, From Japanese Myths to African Fashion
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: THE JAPANESE MYTHS: A Guide to Gods, Heroes and Spirits, by Joshua Frydman. (Thames & Hudson, $24.95.) A professor of Japanese literature ushers readers through the country’s mythology from the earliest written stories to the rise of the manga industry and situates Japan’s rich cultural tradition within religious and historical developments.

headline: What Does ‘Vex Money’ Do to Love?
abstract: We Black women and girls must protect ourselves. Still, I wish I could relax into the plush comfort of a relationship.
lead_paragraph: Vex money. Noun. Origin: Anglophone Caribbean. Meaning: money stashed on your person or in a secret place (a brassiere, a bank account, your grandmother’s Bible, your sneakers). To be spent only in case of emergency brought upon by a once stable situation suddenly becoming vexed — usually but not always because of a man. See: the need for a swift exit in response to the threat of sexual assault. See also: the dissolution of a relationship, the loss of a job or being displaced from your home. Related to but not the same as the threat often uttered by an Afro-Caribbean woman: “Don’t get me vex.” Or “She/he/they get me vex, get me on my nerves.”

headline: The Greatest Athlete of All Time? Jim Thorpe.
abstract: In the new biography “Path Lit by Lightning,” David Maraniss details the enormous odds that a Native American hero had to overcome.
lead_paragraph: Forty summers ago, a man wearing a tracksuit stepped out onto Fifth Avenue to celebrate his 90th birthday by running down the sidewalk in front of the Guggenheim Museum. He was there to publicize the New York City Marathon because in those days the New York City Marathon still needed the help. But, as nearly always happened to Abel Kiviat, the talk quickly turned to Jim Thorpe because there is a convincing argument to be made that Thorpe was the greatest athlete of all time. And 70 years earlier, Abel Kiviat had been Jim Thorpe’s roommate at the 1912 Olympics.

headline: Why Isn’t Biden Ever on TV?
abstract: Americans are seeing a lot less of the president than they did of his predecessor. That’s partly by design.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering day last month, President Biden traveled to Somerset, Mass. Appearing on a bulldozed patch of land where a coal-fired power plant recently stood, and where a substation for an offshore wind farm eventually will, Biden delivered what the White House press office billed as remarks on “actions to tackle the climate crisis.” The previous week, Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia seemingly torpedoed Biden’s ambitious climate package (though Manchin would soon resurrect it). In the meantime, much of the country was suffering from extreme weather: wildfires, floods, record heat. Now Biden, sporting Ray-Bans and forgoing a tie in the blistering heat, looked out at the crowd and the cameras. “Let me be clear,” he declared. “Climate change is an emergency.”

headline: Your Blue State Won’t Save You: Why State Politics Is National Politics
abstract: Zack Beauchamp and Nicole Hemmer on why state-level politics is more important than ever.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Kansans voted in overwhelming numbers to protect abortion rights in their State Constitution — the first instance since the overruling of Roe v. Wade in which voters have been able to weigh in on the issue directly. But local battles aren’t just limited to abortion. There’s guns. There’s school curriculums. Most crucially, there’s voting rights. As national politics becomes increasingly polarized, how we live is going to be decided by local legislation. It’s time we step into the state houses and see what’s happening there.

headline: Yotam Ottolenghi Has Made Thousands of Meringues. This Is His Favorite.
abstract: There are many variations of the simple, elegant sweet — but pavlova with seasonal fruit is among the best.
lead_paragraph: My professional encounters with meringue happened to follow a trajectory that took me from very small to extra-large.

headline: How We Think About Politics Changes What We Think About Politics
abstract: We are pulling apart from each other, and it’s making our problems worse.
lead_paragraph: When so many voters — a majority, in fact — say that they prefer consensus to conflict, why does polarization continue to intensify?

headline: Can ‘House of the Dragon’ Be HBO’s Next ‘Game of Thrones’?
abstract: The stakes are high for the first “Thrones” spinoff, which could determine nothing less than the future of the franchise.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — George R.R. Martin has seen the comments, and he’s read the emails.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Is Coming. Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: HBO’s new “Game of Thrones” prequel takes us back to the land of Westeros, hundreds of years earlier. We’ve got your cheat sheet.
lead_paragraph: In the final episodes of HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” the mad queen Daenerys Targaryen incinerated most of the capital city of King’s Landing. But what was it like when it was all still standing, and the Targaryen dynasty ruled with an iron fist — er, throne?

headline: These Groups Want Disruptive Climate Protests. Oil Heirs Are Funding Them.
abstract: Beneficiaries of two American oil fortunes are supporting groups trying to block fossil fuel projects. One donor said he felt a “moral obligation.”
lead_paragraph: They’ve taken hammers to gas pumps and glued themselves to museum masterpieces and busy roadways. They’ve chained themselves to banks, rushed onto a GrandPrix racetrack and tethered themselves to goal posts as tens of thousands of British soccer fans jeered.

headline: Foundation Is Dead
abstract: Gone are the days of full-coverage foundation that conceals all of skin’s flaws. A new era is ushering in a wave of self-acceptance.
lead_paragraph: Donni Davy, the “Euphoria” makeup artist, doesn’t use foundation or powder on the cast. And when she introduced her own beauty line earlier this year, Half Magic, she chose to focus on eye shadows, lip liners and lipsticks, hybrid blush-highlighters and adhesive crystals — but no concealer or foundation. For the line’s ad campaign, she used minimal watered-down foundation for spot treatments, and she insisted that images show skin’s pores, texture and bumps.

headline: We Are Still in a Race Against the Coronavirus
abstract: Human ingenuity must keep up with the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic has been a lesson in speed — the speed at which a novel virus among humans can spread, the speed at which it can rack up fatalities and cripple economies, the speed at which vaccines can be designed and produced, the speed at which misinformation can undermine public health. Amid all that rapidity is a different kind of speed, which drives the rest, like an engine spinning the cars on a nauseating carnival ride: the speed of viral evolution.

headline: ‘Dangerous Road. No Cell Service. Drive at Own Risk.’
abstract: Elizabeth Hand’s “Hokuloa Road” brims with menace: vine-choked cliff-top highways, aviaries filled with strange birds, tanks of poisonous sea urchins.
lead_paragraph: Gillian McAllister’s tense new book begins as a woman waits for her beloved teenage son to come home late one night. But then she sees something inexplicable: the boy, Todd, running toward a stranger on the darkened suburban street — and stabbing him to death. “I had to,” he says cryptically as he is led away in handcuffs. “There was no choice.”

headline: When America Joined the Cult of the Confederacy
abstract: By renaming military bases, the Defense Department dismantles an enduring legacy of the Lost Cause.
lead_paragraph: President Woodrow Wilson transformed government into an engine of white supremacy when he took office in 1913. His administration segregated a federal work force that had been integrated for 50 years and imposed separate white and “colored” bathrooms in federal buildings. As the historian Eric S. Yellin shows in his iconic book “Racism in the Nation’s Service,” segregation was just a prelude. The goal was to drive African Americans from influential jobs and confine them to a “controlled and exploitable class of laborers.”

headline: The Russian Filmmaker Trapped Between Hollywood and Moscow
abstract: As boycotts of Russia expand to include cultural exports, artists like Kirill Serebrennikov must prove they are dissident enough to enjoy a Western audience.
lead_paragraph: Last December, a few months before Russia invaded Ukraine, Kirill Serebrennikov, the film and theater director, applied for parole on the basis of good behavior. Serebrennikov was arrested in 2017 on embezzlement charges, though it was widely understood that his real offense was producing work that irritated the Kremlin. He spent 20 months on house arrest and another year standing trial, before being sentenced to three years’ probation. In late March, a Russian court suspended his remaining sentence, and the very next day, he fled to Germany. By May, he was at the Cannes Film Festival, in the south of France, for the premiere of his new film, “Tchaikovsky’s Wife.” When Serebrennikov emerged in a small room at the Palais des Festivals for a news conference, the moderator introduced him as “someone who we’ve eagerly awaited for three years.”

headline: Change These Default Settings and Be Happier With Your Tech
abstract: Simple steps can make your smartphone, computer and TV work better for you.
lead_paragraph: Many default settings buried deep inside our technology make us share superfluous amounts of data with tech companies. In my last column, I went over how to shut those off.

headline: Tracking Ships (and Sharks) and Tying Knots: Apps to Enrich Your Seaside Vacation
abstract: With the right software on your phone you can turn a getaway on the water into an opportunity for discovery, from deciphering signal flags to forecasting tides.
lead_paragraph: Of all summer’s pleasures, few are as irresistible as a getaway by the water, be it an ocean, lake or city harbor. You can swim, sail, fish and partake of the age-old tradition of lazing around.

headline: Hunting for Voter Fraud, Conspiracy Theorists Organize ‘Stakeouts’
abstract: A nascent effort to surveil drop boxes for potential fraud is taking shape in at least 10 states, worrying election officials and law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: One night last month, on the recommendation of a man known online as Captain K, a small group gathered in an Arizona parking lot and waited in folding chairs, hoping to catch the people they believed were trying to destroy American democracy by submitting fake early voting ballots.

headline: Arizonans Trusted Kari Lake to Tell It Straight on TV. Will They Trust Her as Governor?
abstract: The former news anchor is running on falsehoods about the 2020 election. She is undeterred about her chances in November: ‘I am beloved by people.’
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Kari Lake worked her way through television interviews at her election night party, fielding a barrage of questions about her bid to be Arizona’s next governor. Votes were still being counted, and she’d been up all night. But Ms. Lake, a first-time candidate, didn’t flinch.

headline: U.S. Insists It Will Operate Around Taiwan, Despite China’s Pressure
abstract: The confrontation threatens to overwhelm President Biden’s efforts to find a series of issues in which the United States and China can work together.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is vowing to continue sailing warships through the Taiwan Strait and to conduct air operations in the region in response to Chinese military drills that U.S. officials say are evolving into a long-term strategy of heightened military pressure on the island.

headline: In the Amazon, a U.N. Agency Has a Green Mission, but Dirty Partners
abstract: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
lead_paragraph: RESGUARDO BUENAVISTA, Colombia — At the edge of the Colombian Amazon, in an Indigenous village surrounded by oil rigs, the Siona people faced a dilemma.

headline: The Magical Rooms of Sakonnet Garden
abstract: Want to create outdoor rooms in your garden? At Sakonnet, in coastal Rhode Island, you can learn from the masters.
lead_paragraph: Want to create outdoor rooms in your garden? At Sakonnet, in coastal Rhode Island, you can learn from the masters.

headline: The Art of Making Garden Rooms
abstract: Want to create outdoor rooms in your garden? At Sakonnet, a magical landscape in coastal Rhode Island, you can learn from the masters.
lead_paragraph: It’s the key question in making any garden: How do you get all the plants you can’t resist and the ideas insistently flooding your imagination to coalesce on common ground?

headline: Five Takeaways From Tuesday’s Elections
abstract: In a series of primaries in Wisconsin and a handful of other states, the power of a Trump endorsement resonated.
lead_paragraph: The day after F.B.I. agents searched his home in Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump yet again illustrated his electoral pull on the Republican Party.

headline: In ‘House of the Dragon,’ Paddy Considine Claims the Crown
abstract: A string of critically acclaimed roles has made him many British actors’ favorite actor. It has also lifted him from hardscrabble roots to a seat on the Iron Throne.
lead_paragraph: WINSHILL, England — On a blindingly sunny June afternoon, Paddy Considine whipped his sedan through a working-class neighborhood in this suburb in the West Midlands, pointing out the stolid taverns, churches and council houses that combine to cast the long shadows of his childhood.

headline: The poor face a one-two punch: inflation now and job loss later.
abstract: Higher-income households built up savings and wealth during the early stages of the pandemic as they stayed at home and their stocks, houses and other assets rose in value, The New York Times’s Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman report. Between those stockpiles and solid wage growth, many have been able to keep spending even as costs climb.
lead_paragraph: Higher-income households built up savings and wealth during the early stages of the pandemic as they stayed at home and their stocks, houses and other assets rose in value, The New York Times’s Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman report. Between those stockpiles and solid wage growth, many have been able to keep spending even as costs climb.

headline: Gas Prices Have Fallen 57 Straight Days
abstract: The decline in the cost of filling up at the pump has been a big factor in easing inflation.
lead_paragraph: Gasoline prices in the United States have fallen for 57 consecutive days since reaching a high of more than $5 a gallon in June.

headline: Takeaways from the July inflation report.
abstract: Inflation slowed to 8.5 percent as fuel costs cooled, but price increases on many other goods and services remain rapid.
lead_paragraph: Inflation cooled in July as gas prices and airfares fell, a welcome reprieve for consumers and economic policymakers but not yet a conclusive sign that price increases are turning a corner.

headline: The F.B.I. Search of Trump’s Home
abstract: What have we learned about the agency’s unprecedented decision to enter Mar-a-Lago?
lead_paragraph: On Monday, federal agents descended on Mar-a-Lago, the private club and Florida home of former President Donald J. Trump, reportedly looking for classified documents and presidential papers.

headline: Living In ... Peekskill, N.Y.
abstract: Newcomers praise this diverse Westchester city for its galleries, art studios and welcoming vibe: ‘It’s easy to be part of the community.’
lead_paragraph: Newcomers praise this diverse Westchester city for its galleries, art studios and welcoming vibe: ‘It’s easy to be part of the community.’

headline: Peekskill, N.Y.: An ‘Artist’s Paradise’ on the Hudson River
abstract: Newcomers praise this diverse Westchester city for its galleries, art studios and welcoming vibe: ‘It’s easy to be part of the community.’
lead_paragraph: With its industrial roots and lively art scene, Peekskill — or “PK,” as some call it — is considered a “mini Beacon,” a reference to the art-centric city in upstate New York.

headline: Two Trump Scenarios

lead_paragraph: Perhaps the central question about the F.B.I.’s search of Donald Trump’s Florida home is whether it is a relatively narrow attempt to recover classified documents — or much more than that.

headline: FIFA Seeks Last-Minute Change to World Cup Schedule
abstract: In a letter sent only months before the tournament, organizers have requested that the World Cup start one day earlier and allow Qatar, the host nation, to feature in its first match.
lead_paragraph: Qatar has had 12 years to plan for the World Cup. Now, with the first games of the tournament just over 100 days away and the intricate match schedule announced months ago, organizers have requested changes that would make the event start a day earlier so the host nation can have a featured place in the opening game.

headline: Russian propaganda is spreading in Spanish and Arabic and in places outside the West.
abstract: When Russia’s war in Ukraine began, Facebook, Twitter and other social media giants moved to block or limit the reach of the accounts of the Kremlin’s propaganda machine in the West. The effort, though, has been limited by geography and language, creating a patchwork of restrictions rather than a blanket ban.
lead_paragraph: When Russia’s war in Ukraine began, Facebook, Twitter and other social media giants moved to block or limit the reach of the accounts of the Kremlin’s propaganda machine in the West. headline: Raymond Briggs, Who Drew a Wordless ‘Snowman,’ Dies at 88
abstract: An author and illustrator of children’s books sensitive to emotions, he used comic-strip-like panels to explore the joys and struggles of workaday British life.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Briggs, the children’s author whose cheeky illustrations dignified workaday British life and an audacious breadth of emotions, most prominently in the wordless escapades of “The Snowman,” died on Tuesday in Brighton, England. He was 88.

abstract: An eight-bedroom Edwardian house in Springfield, Mass.; a 1913 home in New Orleans; and a three-bedroom bungalow in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: An eight-bedroom Edwardian house in Springfield, Mass.; a 1913 home in New Orleans; and a three-bedroom bungalow in Atlanta.

lead_paragraph: This house is in the Forest Park Heights Historic District, added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982. It was designed by G. Wood Taylor, the architect of a number of grand estates in the area, for Frank L. Brigham, the president of a clothing company.

headline: Months after Russian soldiers withdrew, Bucha begins to bury its unidentified dead.
abstract: BUCHA, Ukraine — The city of Bucha has begun burying the unidentified victims of the Russian occupation, despite months of research aimed at identifying the dead, reuniting them with family and giving them proper burials.
lead_paragraph: BUCHA, Ukraine — The city of Bucha has begun burying the unidentified victims of the Russian occupation, despite months of research aimed at identifying the dead, reuniting them with family and giving them proper burials.

abstract: The famous midtown property, an official city landmark, is opening a new sports and leisure lounge.
lead_paragraph: The famous midtown property, an official city landmark, is opening a new sports and leisure lounge.

headline: What Today’s Inflation Report Means for the Federal Reserve
abstract: Fed officials are waiting for an inflation slowdown, and economists have predicted that this could signal the start of a deceleration.
lead_paragraph: Consumer Price Index inflation cooled meaningfully in July as gas prices declined, which is good news for the Federal Reserve, though not yet enough for policymakers to conclude that America is through the worst of its burst of rapid price increases.

headline: Los Angeles Bans Encampments Near Schools
abstract: The City Council voted on Tuesday to prohibit homeless people from setting up tents within 500 feet of public and private schools and day care centers.
lead_paragraph: In a highly contested move, Los Angeles this week significantly expanded restrictions on where homeless people can sleep as the city, the nation’s second largest, grapples with its housing crisis.

headline: Beluga Whale Dies in France During Last-Ditch Rescue Mission
abstract: The 13-foot, 1,800-pound animal had been removed from the Seine river where it had been stranded for days, but it was later euthanized after experiencing difficulty breathing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A malnourished beluga whale that had been stranded in the Seine river for several days, causing its health to deteriorate rapidly, died on Wednesday a few hours after being removed from the water in a last-ditch rescue operation.

headline: Why Does My Grandson Think I Should Pay Him for Missing Our Family Vacation?
abstract: A reader is stunned by a grandson’s request for the cash value of a trip he’s unable to attend.
lead_paragraph: I am treating my family to a special vacation in Alaska. My grandson, 28, and his wife are unable to join us; they are expecting a baby soon. I’m sorry they can’t come, but I was shocked when my grandson asked me for a cash gift equal to what I would have spent for them to join us on the trip. He suggested I donate the money to the baby’s college fund. I am stunned! I was happy to help them with wedding expenses and part of the down payment on their first home. But I told him this is not how life works. Was I wrong?

headline: In Lima, a Home and Studio That Remains a Work in Progress
abstract: Amid the grayness of Peru’s capital, a multidisciplinary artist creates a place that illuminates both his practice and the city that informs it.
lead_paragraph: WHEN THE LIMA, Peru-based artist Miguel Andrade Valdez started sketching designs for a home and studio in the bohemian district of Barranco, his primary obsession was not the building’s form but how it might give shape to his native city’s stark, paralyzing light. Throughout its austral winter, banks of fog shroud the escarpment that separates the Peruvian capital from the Pacific, turning the sky into a blank, dimensionless field: “Six in the morning looks just like 6 in the evening — there’s nothing to mark the horizon,” says Andrade, 43. Herman Melville, who docked in the city as a 19th-century seaman, devotes a paragraph of “Moby-Dick” (1851) to Lima’s “white veil,” which, he writes, “spreads over her broken ramparts the rigid pallor of an apoplexy that fixes its own distortions.” Many of the city’s 10 million residents call it Lima la Gris — Lima the Gray — others, simply, La Horrible.

headline: Mountainside Modern in South Africa
abstract: This modern five-bedroom home, which backs onto the slopes of Table Mountain in the suburbs of Cape Town, South Africa, is for sale for $4.7 million.
lead_paragraph: This modern five-bedroom home, which backs onto the slopes of Table Mountain in the suburbs of Cape Town, South Africa, is for sale for $4.7 million.

headline: House Hunting in South Africa: Carved Into a Mountain in Cape Town
abstract: On the Western Cape, South Africa’s most active market, sales are booming, driven largely by European buyers seeking safe investments.
lead_paragraph: This five-bedroom home backs onto the slopes of Table Mountain in Oranjezicht, a suburb of Cape Town, South Africa. Set on about three quarters of an acre, the home is designed to mimic the landscape of the mountain, a prominent landmark, with a wavy concrete roof and ample use of wood and stone.

headline: The Author of ‘Dopesick’ Returns to Familiar Ground
abstract: In “Raising Lazarus,” Beth Macy considers how — or whether — we will ever be able to put the overdose epidemic behind us.
lead_paragraph: “Dopesick,” Beth Macy’s deeply reported account of how opioids came to savage so many Appalachian families, concludes with a wrenching image of Patricia Mehrmann tenderly preparing her 28-year-old daughter, Tess Henry, for burial. Tess is a major figure in the book, with Macy detailing how, for nearly two years, the author herself would even ferry Tess to rehab support groups, hold her infant during sessions and visit her in psych wards.

headline: Brad Finstad wins a special election to fill the seat of Rep. Jim Hagedorn, who died in February.
abstract: Mr. Finstad, a Republican, will complete the final four months remaining in the term of Mr. Hagedorn, also a Republican.
lead_paragraph: Brad Finstad, a Republican former state lawmaker in Minnesota, won a special election for a U.S. House seat, according to The Associated Press. He will complete the final four months remaining in the term of Representative Jim Hagedorn, a Republican, who died from cancer in February.

headline: Displaced by War, Ukrainians Open a New Front as Entrepreneurs
abstract: Ukrainians forced from their hometowns by Russia’s invasion find some solace, and success, setting up shop in a new city.
lead_paragraph: Oksana Dudyk scanned a small selection of ornamental plants lining the shelves of her new florist shop, recently opened in this city on Ukraine’s western frontier. Her eye landed on the perfect bloom for a new customer: fuchsia-colored primroses, vivid and lush, ideal for brightening an austere corner.

headline: Airfares tumbled as jet fuel prices fell.
abstract: Fares fell nearly 8 percent in July from June, a drop that helped to bring down overall inflation.
lead_paragraph: Airline ticket prices fell sharply in July after peaking in recent months, fueled by high costs, high demand and a limited number of flights.

headline: Astronomers May Have Found the Galaxy’s Youngest Planet
abstract: The Webb telescope soon will help measure the world, which may offer insights into how our own formed.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 30 years, astronomers have found more than 5,000 exoplanets, an eclectic menagerie of worlds far from our stellar neighborhood. The latest may be a mere infant.

headline: Classic Pumps Stage a Comeback
abstract: This season’s heels come in a range of heights and finishes.

headline: Trump Invokes Fifth Amendment, Attacking Legal System as Troubles Mount
abstract: The former president declined to answer questions from the office of the New York State attorney general, Letitia James, who leads one of a number of inquiries swirling around him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has long derided public figures who invoke their constitutional right against self incrimination, but on Wednesday he took full advantage of the Fifth Amendment.

headline: The Mets Make Their Case as New York’s Best Team
abstract: A run of 15 wins in 17 games has catapulted the Mets past the Yankees. With the second-best record in the majors and a big division lead, things are looking good.
lead_paragraph: With talk earlier this year about this possibly being the best New York baseball season ever, it had seemed clear that there was at least a small divide between the city’s major league teams.

headline: Slowing Inflation Gives Biden Respite, but High Prices Remain a Problem
abstract: Speaking at the White House, the president declared that his “economic plan is working.”
lead_paragraph: Signs that inflation eased in July offered a political reprieve for President Biden, who has spent months on the defensive as prices climbed to 40-year highs.

headline: Elon Musk sells nearly $7 billion in Tesla shares to finance his Twitter deal.
abstract: The billionaire entrepreneur said he wanted “to avoid an emergency sale of Tesla stock” if he was forced to complete the buyout of the social media company.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of the electric vehicle maker Tesla, has sold about $7 billion worth of the company’s stock, a move he said on Twitter was an effort to raise cash in case he was forced to complete his $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter.

headline: Scatter Your Sushi
abstract: Try a no-recipe recipe for chirashi, or Kay Chun’s recipe for sesame salmon bowls.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I love Kay Chun’s recipe for sesame salmon bowls (above), inspired by the sushi dish known as chirashi, which comes from the Japanese word for “scattered.” It’s fast and flavorful. You make a version of sushi rice, the grains cooked in water and vinegar, then steam salmon on top and serve it with a soy-sesame dressing and one of my favorite supermarket-ingredient short cuts: bagged, pre-cut coleslaw.

headline: Prentiss, 15 and Feeling Deeply
abstract: The dream-pop singer and songwriter from Jackson, Miss., tries out a range of sounds and speaks from the heart on his upcoming debut album, “Crescent.”
lead_paragraph: In his music videos, several of which have lately become tastemaker manna, Prentiss looks more like a kid brother than a rock-star rebel. Many show him out in nature wearing hippie-ish hand-me-downs and singing sweetly heartbroken lyrics that sometimes come from poems he writes on his phone. “I try not to overthink it,” he said on a recent video call from his Jackson, Miss., home just after his daily workout, his hair a bounteous bushel of curls. “My purest emotion comes from my first thought.”

headline: 92NY’s New Season Includes Ian McEwan and Tom Stoppard
abstract: The fall season also features Ralph Fiennes, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Katie Couric and Ken Burns.
lead_paragraph: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Katie Couric and Ralph Fiennes are among the array of actors, authors and dancers who will feature in the 92nd Street Y, New York's upcoming fall season.

headline: Sneeze by Sneeze, Sponges Fill the Seas With Their Mucus
abstract: You might be tempted to say “gesundheit,” but the sea creature’s snot helps feed other marine organisms.
lead_paragraph: Sneezing is far from a uniquely human behavior. Maybe you’ve seen your dog or cat do it, or watched a YouTube video of a giraffe sneezing on an unsuspecting toddler at the zoo. In fact, sneezing doesn’t even require a nervous system, let alone a nose, and dates back to some of the first multicellular animals: sponges.

headline: New York City Can Reinstate School Budget Cuts, Court Rules
abstract: With the first day of school in New York less than a month away, the city is caught up in a contentious legal battle over whether to cut school funding.
lead_paragraph: More than $200 million in cuts to the New York City public school budget are back in effect, at least temporarily, after a state appeals court on Tuesday put a hold on a lower court’s ruling requiring the city to redo the budget.

headline: Boston School Dean Recruited Students for Latin Kings, U.S. Says
abstract: Prosecutors said Shaun Harrison, 63, lived a “double life” as a leader of the drug gang while working at a public high school.
lead_paragraph: A former Boston public school official who recruited at-risk students into the Latin Kings gang and had the students distribute drugs on campus pleaded guilty to racketeering charges on Tuesday, the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the District of Massachusetts said.

headline: Gary Schroen, Who Led the C.I.A. Into Afghanistan, Dies at 80
abstract: Weeks before the troops arrived, he took a small team into the country to prepare for an invasion and begin the hunt for Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: Gary C. Schroen, a veteran C.I.A. operative who, just weeks after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, led the first team of agents into Afghanistan to prepare for an invasion and begin the hunt for Osama bin Laden and his top lieutenants, died at his home in Alexandria, Va., on Aug. 1, one day after an American missile killed one of the last of those men, Ayman al-Zawahri. He was 80.

headline: Trump is baselessly suggesting that the F.B.I. may have planted evidence during its search.

Trump invoked the Fifth Amendment in a New York inquiry into his business practices, he and his allies began an effort to discredit another investigation, suggesting without evidence that federal agents may have planted incriminating materials before searching his residence in Florida on Monday.

headline: Blinken Presses Congo Leaders to Slow Oil-and-Gas Push in Rainforests
abstract: The secretary of state’s efforts led to the U.S. and the Democratic Republic of Congo agreeing to have a team look at environmental conservation.
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Pushing for a reconsideration of plans by the Democratic Republic of Congo to auction parts of its vast rainforests and peatlands, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken announced that American and Congolese officials would form a team to examine proposed oil-and-gas extraction in those areas.

headline: Justice Dept. Charges Iranian in Plot to Kill John Bolton
abstract: Prosecutors said a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps sought the murder of the former national security adviser in retaliation for the killing of a top Iranian official.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department charged a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps on Wednesday with planning to assassinate John R. Bolton, who served as the national security adviser to President Donald J. Trump, as payback for the killing of a senior Iranian official.

headline: London Children Offered Polio Vaccine Booster as More Virus Is Found in Sewage
abstract: Children of ages 1 to 9 in the city will be offered a booster after signs that the virus was turning up more frequently in samples. No cases have so far been reported.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Every child in London age 1 to 9 should be offered a booster dose of polio vaccine, the British health authorities said on Wednesday, after traces of the virus turned up in sewage samples across a quarter of the city’s boroughs, though no individual cases of the disease have been reported.

headline: Hungary Settles Russia’s Bill With Ukraine to Restore Oil Flows
abstract: Hungary’s energy conglomerate, MOL, paid Russia’s transit fees to Ukraine, ensuring that oil keeps flowing through an overland pipeline that remains crucial for Central Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Hungary’s main oil conglomerate said on Wednesday that it would pay an outstanding bill owed by Russia’s oil pipeline operator to the Ukrainian authorities, clearing the way for Russian oil deliveries to resume to three Central European countries.

headline: Julia Lester on Her ‘More Knowing’ Little Red Riding Hood

headline: Biden Signs Bill to Help Veterans Who Were Exposed to Toxic Burn Pits
abstract: President Biden, who has long advocated the expanded benefits, has speculated that his son Beau developed brain cancer because of exposure to burn pits when he served in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday signed into law a bill that expands medical benefits for veterans who were exposed to toxins from burning pits of trash on military bases, ending a yearslong quest for support by veterans and their families.

headline: Serena Williams Bids Farewell to Canadian Tennis Fans

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Karl Hale has been the tournament director at the National Bank Open since 2006 and had never seen anything like the 24 hours after Serena Williams said she was winding down her professional tennis career.

headline: 24 Freezer-Friendly Recipes to Cook for New (and Tired) Parents
abstract: A collection of ready-to-eat meals is almost as good as a full night’s sleep.
lead_paragraph: Nothing can prepare someone for the level of exhaustion and elation that accompanies the early days of parenthood. But helping stock a friend’s freezer with delicious, nourishing dishes that need just a few minutes in the oven or microwave can certainly help.

headline: Sentence of American Lawyer Held in U.A.E. Is Overturned

headline: Sean Patrick Maloney Wins a Clinton Endorsement (Bill, Not Hillary)
abstract: The former president said he would vote for and endorse Mr. Maloney over a challenger from the left, State Senator Alessandra Biaggi.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton waded into one of New York’s most contentious Democratic primaries on Wednesday, saying that he would cast his vote for Representative Sean Patrick Maloney in a newly redrawn suburban district that includes his Chappaqua home and “urge all my neighbors to do the same.”

headline: Taxpayers for U.S. Chips
