headline: Yaqub Talib, Brother of Former N.F.L. Star, Killed Youth Coach, Police Say
abstract: He is accused of fatally shooting the coach after an argument at a game in Lancaster, Texas, the police said. His brother, the retired Super Bowl champion Aqib Talib, was also there, a witness said.
lead_paragraph: A brother of the former N.F.L. cornerback Aqib Talib is facing a murder charge after he fatally shot a youth football coach during an argument at a game in Lancaster, Texas, last weekend, the authorities said.

headline: Monkeypox Vaccine Plan Prods Cities and States to Adopt New Dosing Regimen
abstract: The Biden administration will distribute monkeypox vaccine to jurisdictions that adopt a new protocol using one-fifth the regular dose. Critics called the plan “unscientific.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House, under pressure to contain a growing monkeypox outbreak, announced on Thursday that it was sending 1.8 million vaccine doses to jurisdictions that agree to use a new vaccination protocol, as public health officials prepare for Gay Pride events and the return to college campuses, which they fear could hasten spread of the virus.

headline: Three Men Charged in Prison Killing of Whitey Bulger
abstract: The men were incarcerated alongside the notorious Boston crime boss when he was beaten to death in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Three men were indicted in the death of the notorious gangster James (Whitey) Bulger, who was beaten to death four years ago in a West Virginia federal prison where he was serving a sentence for crimes that terrorized Boston in the 1970s and ’80s, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Why the I.R.S. Is at the Center of a Political Firestorm
abstract: Republicans have zeroed in on Democrats’ plan to strengthen the agency. We checked in with two reporters covering the politics of tax law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, Republican politicians and operatives have attacked the Biden administration’s $80 billion plan to beef up the Internal Revenue Service’s capacity to audit wealthy Americans.

headline: What Biden Has — and Hasn’t — Done
abstract: Good stuff, but don’t call it “massive.”
lead_paragraph: There’s something strange in the D.C. air these days. It smells a bit like … competence.

headline: The Man Who Found His Inner Depths
abstract: How Frederick Buechner learned to listen to his life.
lead_paragraph: One morning in the fall of 1936, 10-year-old Frederick Buechner and his younger brother were playing in their room. Their father opened the door, checked on them, and then went down into the family garage, turned on the engine of the car and waited for the exhaust to kill him.

headline: Ukraine and Russia Accuse Each Other of Plotting Attack on Nuclear Plant
abstract: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, the largest in Europe, has already been hit by shelling, and the United Nations chief, warning of disaster, called for a demilitarized zone around it.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Tensions around the nuclear power plant on the front lines of the war in Ukraine escalated sharply on Thursday, as the Russian and Ukrainian militaries traded charges that each was preparing to stage an attack on the plant in coming days, risking a catastrophic release of radiation.

headline: Bruce Reinhart, the Magistrate Judge Who Approved the Mar-a-Lago Search
abstract: Judge Reinhart has faced a wave of criticism, disinformation and online threats over his involvement in the F.B.I.’s search.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the F.B.I. searched the Mar-a-Lago estate of former President Donald J. Trump for classified documents, the federal judge in Florida who signed the warrant authorizing the move, Bruce E. Reinhart, has been thrust into the spotlight.

headline: Remains of 2 Children Are Found in Suitcases Bought at New Zealand Auction
abstract: The police did not immediately release the precise ages of the children, their genders, or whether they might have been related. “We still have a lot of unanswered questions,” a detective said.
lead_paragraph: The remains of two young children were found in two suitcases that were purchased along with other household items in an online auction in New Zealand, prompting the police there to begin a homicide investigation, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Mexico Says Disappearance of 43 Students Was a ‘Crime of the State’
abstract: The authorities said for the first time that the state had been a key player in the likely massacre of students from a teachers’ college in 2014.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The disappearance of 43 Mexican students in 2014 was a “crime of the state” involving every layer of government, an official inquiry reported on Thursday, in the most profound admission to date of government responsibility for one of the most notorious atrocities in Mexico’s modern history.

headline: DeSantis Hails Voter Fraud Crackdown, but Start Is Slow
abstract: The 17 arrests announced on Thursday were the first by a new office dedicated to pursuing election crimes. The suspects were said to be former felons who had voted illegally.
lead_paragraph: Seven weeks after Florida’s state government opened a new office of election crimes and security, Gov. Ron DeSantis said on Thursday that 17 people had been charged with casting illegal ballots in the 2020 election, in which 11.1 million Floridians voted.

headline: How to Cope With Fall Anxiety
abstract: As the most carefree weeks of the year draw to a close, pay close attention to your emotions. They might be telling you something useful.
lead_paragraph: As August passes its halfway point, I find myself feeling a duo of unpleasant emotions: sadness that the summer is almost over, and dread over having to face a busy fall schedule soon. I’m rarely ready for the annual transition to pumpkin spice lattes and cooler weather, but this year, the shift feels especially unwelcome — perhaps because this has been the first somewhat normal summer in more than two years, and I’m not ready for it to end.

headline: Woman Testifies R. Kelly Sexually Abused Her on Video When She Was 14
abstract: The woman testified at the singer’s federal trial in Chicago that she had been persuaded not to testify against him at his 2008 state trial, which ended in his acquittal.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In 2008, a jury in Chicago declared the singer R. Kelly not guilty of producing child sexual abuse imagery after seeing a videotape that prosecutors said showed the R&B singer engaging in sex acts with an underage girl. The defense team had argued that the identities of the people in the tape were in question, and several jurors said the lack of testimony from the victim was a significant barrier to convicting Mr. Kelly.

headline: Brain-Eating Amoeba Caused Nebraska Child’s Death, Health Officials Say
abstract: Such infections are rare. From 2012 to 2021, only 31 cases were reported in the U.S., according to federal data.
lead_paragraph: An infection caused by a brain-eating amoeba killed a child who swam in a Nebraska river over the weekend, health officials said Friday. It was the first such death in the state’s history and the second in the Midwest this summer.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Researchers Alter Genes To Refine Photosynthesis And Improve Crop’s Yield
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Aug. 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I always wonder. Why are we missing the elephants in the room while chasing the mice?”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 19, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about Mary Peltola, who could become the first Alaska Native in Congress, misstated Ms. Peltola’s tenure in the Alaska Legislature. She served from 1999 to 2009, not from 2009 to 2019.

headline: The Drinks Are on Me!
abstract: Patrick John Duggan treats us to a puzzle that is delightfully rich with wordplay.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Have you ever stopped in the middle of solving a crossword and smiled at it with admiration? I have, and that’s what happened while I solved Patrick John Duggan’s puzzle.

headline: Variety: Extreme Wordle
abstract: Feast your wordling minds on Alex Kolker’s letter-picking extravaganza!
lead_paragraph: EXTREME WORDLE — Here’s a fever dream for everyone who complains that wordle happens but once a day, and for everyone who strategizes to solve their puzzle by the second turn (I am never so ambitious). How about a set of 25 words, each with at least two letters as hints, and a challenge issued: Can you get the right word in the next move? The only rules are that each answer is a very common English word, italics not mine, and that none are plurals or verbs formed by adding -s (for example, loves, meaning dear ones as a noun, or adores as a verb).

headline: An Invitation to Dinner Through Interoffice Mail
abstract: Andrew Dietz and Philip Melanson met seven years ago while both were in the Los Angeles page program of NBC Universal.
lead_paragraph: When Andrew Alan Dietz stumbled across the Tinder profile of Philip George Melanson in June 2015, he instantly recognized him as a colleague in the Los Angeles page program at NBC Universal. Then Mr. Dietz froze.

headline: On the Crosstown Bus, a Dramatic Meet Cute
abstract: Patrick Straub asked for Chelsea Toder’s number after they assisted a man who passed out on the M14 bus. Years later, they fell in love.
lead_paragraph: Patrick William Straub was commuting to his office on a packed M14 bus in Manhattan when an older man standing near him collapsed in December 2013.

headline: After She Gave an Inch, He Took Her Heart
abstract: Denise Pyfrom matched with Daniel White on Hinge only after lowering her minimum height preference on the dating app, but they connected over his service in the military.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t long after Denise Nicole Pyfrom gave an inch, so to speak, that she came across Daniel Evan White on Hinge in January 2019. The two, then living in Manhattan, matched on the dating app once Ms. Pyfrom changed her preferences from a minimum height of 6 feet to 5 feet 11 inches.

headline: Finding Common Ground in Their Childhoods on Farms
abstract: Midwestern roots, pumpkin pie and a prizewinning pig helped seal the deal for Sara Bunting and Adam Rouse.
lead_paragraph: Before they even met, Adam Gene Rouse had begun to master Sara Nicole Bunting’s love language.

headline: A Stitch in Time, With His Help
abstract: Naomi Mishkin brought out the creative side of Graham Lazar, who even helped her make her wedding dress.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Ariela Mishkin arrived with plaster falling from her hair when she met Graham Henry Lazar for a drink in May 2014 in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. It didn’t bother him one bit.

headline: ‘A Last Act of Intimate Kindness’
abstract: I had barely seen my brother in decades, but when time was short, he let me in.
lead_paragraph: The message I had dreaded for years appeared on my phone: “Looking to find the sister of my patient, Jay Friedman.”

headline: He Wanted Out of the ‘Friend Zone’, but She Took the Lead
abstract: When Andrew Zbihley first met Olivia Pura at Northwestern, he thought that Ms. Pura, a beauty queen, was out of his league. Years later, she made the first move.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2016, Andrew John Zbihley was scrolling through the Northwestern Class of 2020 Facebook page looking for a roommate when a photo of his future classmate, Olivia Natalia Pura, caught his eye.

headline: Odesa Is Defiant. It’s Also Putin’s Ultimate Target.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin knows that Ukraine’s fate, its access to the sea and its grain exports hinge on Odesa. Without it, the country shrivels to a landlocked rump state.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — The Odesa Fine Arts Museum, a colonnaded early-19th-century palace, stands almost empty. Early in Russia’s war on Ukraine, its staff removed more than 12,000 works for safe keeping. One large portrait remained, depicting Catherine the Great, the Russian empress and founder of Odesa, as a just and victorious goddess.

headline: There Are Good Dining Sheds and Bad Ones, Adams Says
abstract: The mayor is a fan of outdoor dining but plans to clean up the ones that aren’t enhancing the city.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s assault on those outdoor restaurant sheds that have become eyesores. We’ll also meet the artist commissioned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to do an installation around an escalator.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: A scorching European summer has affected nearly every part of the economy and even its normally cool regions, a phenomenon aggravated by human-caused climate change. Across the continent, people have experienced wildfires, harvest-threatening drought and extreme heat.

headline: Trevor Noah on Trump’s Jailbird Friends
abstract: “Look, if we had more time we could talk about how Trump pretends to be the candidate of law and order. Meanwhile, his friends can fill up an entire prison wing,” Noah joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: U.N. Chief, Visiting Odesa, Lauds Progress on Grain Deal but Urges Rich Nations to Do More
abstract: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, witnessed grain shipments, one of his organization’s most concrete achievements.
lead_paragraph: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, said during a visit to Odesa, Ukraine, on Friday that the port — where shipments of grain have begun departing under an international deal in recent days — stood as a symbol of what the world can achieve when countries work together for the common good.

headline: Louis’s Little Brother Rocks On
abstract: Fanny Britt and Isabelle Arsenault’s sequel to their graphic novel “Louis Undercover” turns the music up a notch.
lead_paragraph: As in music, sometimes you get a combination of artists working together so seamlessly it’s like a single creator. Fanny Britt and Isabelle Arsenault previously collaborated on “Jane, the Fox and Me,” a plaintive story of a lonely girl struggling to find connection, which won both the Governor General’s Award and a New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books Award. Their new graphic novel, “Forever Truffle,” is a joyful ode to love, and warrants a look back at 2017’s “Louis Undercover,” their earlier, less joyful book about the same family.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Review: Domesticating ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: HBO’s long-awaited prequel series has the swords and the dragon flame, the Hand and the Iron Throne. But something’s missing.
lead_paragraph: Gusts of dragon fire. Unseemly violence at a lavish wedding. A touch of incest. Is “Game of Thrones” back?

headline: More Money for I.R.S. Spurs Conspiracy Theories of ‘Shadow Army’
abstract: The agency will receive $80 billion to hire new agents, modernize technology and expand enforcement as part of the new climate, health and tax law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been called President Biden’s “shadow army,” described as a strike force to shake down small businesses with assault rifles and likened to a militia of auditors on search-and-destroy missions.

headline: Don’t Worry, We’re Not Actually Monitoring Your Productivity
abstract: Across the country, companies are using tracking software to monitor their employees. A recent Times investigation simulated how the software works — and how it feels to be watched.
lead_paragraph: Scrolling through a recent New York Times interactive article evoked anxiety — panic, even — for some online readers. That’s by design: The article, which explores how many U.S. companies now measure worker productivity with monitoring software, uses a tracking simulation built by Times journalists to mirror the experience for readers. As you scroll through the article (or worse, stop scrolling), pop-ups not-so-gently check in on your reading progress. “We can tell you’re idling,” one notification says if you are reading too slowly.

headline: Could New Zealand Change Its Name?
abstract: A petition before Parliament asks that the country be called “Aotearoa,” which loosely translates from Maori as the “land of the long white cloud.”
lead_paragraph: The connection between New Zealand, the Pacific archipelago  east of Australia, and Zeeland, the windmill-flecked Dutch province from which it takes its name, seems tenuous. That’s because it is.

headline: Drink Up, Japan Tells Young People. I’ll Pass, Many Reply.
abstract: The country’s tax agency, hoping to reverse the alcohol industry’s pandemic doldrums, is holding a contest to encourage more drinking among the young.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Among the casualties of the pandemic is one that many young people in Japan say they do not miss: the drinking culture.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's roundup includes titles by Salman Rushdie, Natsuo Kirino and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's roundup includes titles by Salman Rushdie, Natsuo Kirino and more.

headline: It Was a Mystery in the Desert for 50 Years
abstract: In a remote Nevada valley, the artist Michael Heizer’s astonishing megasculpture is finally revealed.
lead_paragraph: In a remote Nevada valley, the artist Michael Heizer’s astonishing megasculpture is finally revealed.

abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "House of the Dragon," a "Game of Thrones" prequel.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "House of the Dragon," a "Game of Thrones" prequel.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 19, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Constitution Is Broken and Should Not Be Reclaimed
abstract: Liberals need to radically change the rules of our politics.
lead_paragraph: When liberals lose in the Supreme Court — as they increasingly have over the past half-century — they usually say that the justices got the Constitution wrong. But struggling over the Constitution has proved a dead end. The real need is not to reclaim the Constitution, as many would have it, but instead to reclaim America from constitutionalism.

headline: Why Are C.E.O.s Suddenly Obsessed With ‘Elasticity’?
abstract: The economic concept, which describes consumers’ sensitivity to prices, is a hot topic as inflation soars and executives fret about profits.
lead_paragraph: From McDonald’s to Coca-Cola to Hershey, corporate executives lately are preoccupied with inflation and what it means to the bottom line. And on calls in the past few weeks with investors about their financial results, conversations have dwelled on a peculiar way of talking about it: “elasticity.”

headline: Kyrsten Sinema Has Made Sure the New Tax Bill Doesn’t Go Near the Wealthy
abstract: Without one intransigent Democratic senator and a significant political misjudgment by the Biden administration, we would have had an even more consequential package in the Inflation Reduction Act.
lead_paragraph: Early in my deal-making career, a Wall Street veteran counseled me to “never let the perfect be the enemy of the good.”

headline: The Mysteries of Mar-a-Lago
abstract: What is in those files? Where did they come from? And who shows up on the surveillance tapes from the Trump mansion?
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump loves to attack the “deep state” — the imaginary cabal of soldiers, spies and secret agents seeking to destroy him from within the government. In the last year of his presidency, he aimed to slay that mythical beast.

headline: Once Alarmed, Mainstream Pennsylvania Republicans Unite Around Mastriano
abstract: Doug Mastriano, the far-right state senator, has shored up his party’s support, but has done little to broaden his reach. Democrats have painted him as an extremist, but remain concerned in a tricky election year.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Before Pennsylvania’s primary, much of the state’s Republican establishment agreed that Doug Mastriano would be a disaster as the nominee for governor.

headline: The Juicy Secrets of Stars That Eat Their Planets
abstract: As scientists study thousands of planets around the galaxy, they are learning more about worlds that get swallowed up by their stars.
lead_paragraph: The sun has nourished life on Earth, but it will not be so hospitable forever. Five billion years into the future, our solar system’s star will grow so immense that Mercury, Venus and, possibly, Earth will be swallowed whole.

headline: Mohammed Amer Is a Salad Bowl
abstract: Melting pot? The Houston comedian prefers a different analogy for himself. His new Netflix series, “Mo,” cocreated by Ramy Youssef, should help clarify.
lead_paragraph: ALIEF, Texas — Mohammed Amer started up his black Mercedes and pointed to a corner across from Alief Middle School. The location was laden with meaning.

headline: Help! I’m 93, My Postponed Cruise Has Been Postponed Again, and I’d Like My Money Back.
abstract: A cruise company keeps pushing back its planned journeys, offering credits instead of a refund, and a passenger feels like the ship has sailed on her ability to enjoy a boat trip. Our columnist tries to get her the cash.
lead_paragraph: My travel companion and I booked a river cruise and tour to Portugal and Spain for this past July with Vantage Deluxe World Travel. We paid in full, and bought insurance against trip interruption or cancellation through Vantage from TripMate. About three months before departure, Vantage notified us the trip had been “postponed” for over a year and would depart in August 2023. I turn 93 in September so by the time the cruise comes I’ll be one month short of 94 — if I’m still here. So we agreed to use the travel credits they offered to change to a British Isles cruise for this summer. Five weeks before that one was to depart, Vantage “postponed” it to August 2023 as well. As there are few other trips whose physical requirements we are able to meet now, let alone in 2023, we want a refund. They say we are stuck with the credits — in my case worth nearly $20,000. Can you help? — Bernice, New York

headline: The West Is Kidding Itself About Women’s Freedom in Saudi Arabia
abstract: The West can’t admit that morals are a luxury it can no longer afford with Saudi Arabia, so it points to social reforms that are not all they seem.
lead_paragraph: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia is officially back in good standing, having spent his summer putting the finishing touches on a wildly successful reputation rehabilitation. The kingdom’s de facto ruler bumped fists with President Biden, who not long ago accused him of heading a “pariah” state; basked in the sycophantic praise of Greek officials in the birthplace of Western democracy; and feasted at the Élysée Palace with President Emmanuel Macron.

headline: After 19 Years of ‘Managing,’ He Finally Gets to Be a Manager
abstract: When Yadier Molina’s playing career ends this fall, he’ll head to Venezuela to coach. His qualifications? “I’ve managed for 19 years in the big leagues.”
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — After 19 years in the majors, and more than 18,000 innings crouched behind the plate, the old catcher has two World Series rings and has earned more than $170 million. After all of that, what is the next step? Traveling the world? Building a beach home? Plopping down in front of a television and disappearing from the limelight?

headline: Outside Money Floods New York Congressional Races
abstract: Super PACs have spent about $9 million to try to influence the Aug. 23 congressional primaries in New York, more than three times the amount spent in 2018.
lead_paragraph: In a feverish House race across Manhattan, a dark-money super PAC has spent more than $200,000 reminding voters that an incumbent congresswoman, Carolyn Maloney, once indulged doubts about vaccines.

headline: The True Legacy of Michael K. Williams
abstract: The actor set out to save his Brooklyn neighborhood. Here’s how he’s doing it, even in death.
lead_paragraph: Three months before he died, the actor Michael K. Williams spent all day at a block party in the Brownsville neighborhood of Brooklyn. In some ways it had the vibe of any block party — a D.J. making people move, kids riding bikes in the street, smoke billowing out of an oil-drum grill. But this wasn’t just another summer day in Brownsville. Mr. Williams and a group of community activists had persuaded seven of the politicians hoping to be New York’s next mayor to show up, granting them a forum to explain why they deserved the support of a Black community that was used to being ignored.

headline: Trouble in Paradise: Chinese Tourists Left Stranded During Lockdowns
abstract: Tens of thousands of domestic travelers were stuck at their summer vacation destinations after local outbreaks forced them into quarantine.
lead_paragraph: A few days into a two-week tour through the island province of Hainan — known as the Hawaii of China — Nicole Chan received a message from local authorities that no traveler in the country wants to see in the pandemic.

headline: Workers in the Catskills Can’t Find Housing. Bosses Are Trying to Help.
abstract: Business owners are building employee housing after an influx of transplants from New York City made a tight rental market even tighter.
lead_paragraph: Cooped up in the city during the pandemic, New Yorkers flocked to Hudson Valley for the fresh air, spacious yards and idyllic lifestyles. The urban dwellers quickly learned that they missed the convenience of 24-hour bodegas and live-in supers and had to contend with the drawbacks of rural life, including pesky beavers. There has been no shortage of complaints.

headline: For Former Rebel in West Africa, Her Allegiance Still Lies With Russia
abstract: The Kremlin armed a generation of freedom fighters in Africa, like Joana Gomes, who helped Guinea-Bissau win liberation. So her decision to take Moscow’s side in its war with Ukraine was never in doubt.
lead_paragraph: BISSAU, Guinea-Bissau — When her country needed arms to fight its bitter liberation war against its colonizer, it was the Soviet Union that provided them.

headline: Cosmic Questions
abstract: Conversations about the big, dreamy, existential questions we don’t have all the answers to.
lead_paragraph: What is a black hole? Why do we remember the past but not the future? If time had a beginning, does it have an end?

headline: A bridge to Crimea is a vital Russian link, and a potential Ukrainian target.
abstract: After overnight blasts into Friday, the Kerch Strait bridge appeared undamaged.
lead_paragraph: When explosions rang out over the Kerch Strait bridge overnight into Friday, the social media accounts of people closely tracking the war lit up in a frenzy of activity.

headline: Chinese Canadian Billionaire Sentenced to 13 Years for Financial Crimes
abstract: Five years after being grabbed from a Hong Kong hotel, Xiao Jianhua, who came to symbolize China’s corporate excess, also faces a hefty fine, as does his company.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Xiao Jianhua, the Chinese Canadian billionaire and onetime trusted financier to China’s ruling elite, was sentenced to 13 years in prison on Friday, and his company fined $8 billion, after he pleaded guilty to bribery and other crimes that the authorities said had “seriously jeopardized” the country’s financial security.

headline: Russia’s Struggles
abstract: We explain why the last several weeks of the war in Ukraine have gone poorly for Russia.
lead_paragraph: When we last updated you on the war in Ukraine, we laid out three possible scenarios for the near future. This morning, we’ll explain how the events of the past six weeks have affected the war, with help from our colleagues who are covering it from Ukraine, Washington and elsewhere.

headline: She Had an AirTag in Her Lost Luggage. It Led Police to a Baggage Handler’s Home.
abstract: An airport worker in Florida was charged with two counts of grand theft after a tracking device aided a sheriff’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: A traveler who put a tracking device in her bag helped sheriff’s deputies in Florida identify an airport worker who was accused of stealing more than $16,000 in goods from passengers’ luggage, the authorities said.

headline: 1972: Greece Grants Political Asylum to 6 Russian Sailors
abstract: The men asked for asylum after their trawler sailed into a bay near Piraeus harbor.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) — A Greek government spokesman said here last night that six Russian seamen who arrived in Piraeus on a Soviet trawler Monday would be granted political asylum.

headline: Himesh Patel on the Pandemic, Fatherhood and ‘Station Eleven’
abstract: The British actor received an Emmy nod for his role as a freelance writer who takes in a young actress as the world succumbs to a deadly virus.
lead_paragraph: Voting is underway for the 74th Primetime Emmys, and this week we’re talking to several acting nominees. The awards will be presented on Sept. 12 on NBC.

headline: We’ve Added More Songs to the California Soundtrack
abstract: Our reader-built playlist continues to grow.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re planning a road trip along the length of the California coast, from Imperial Beach to Crescent City.

headline: Overlooked No More: Regina Jonas, Upon Whose Shoulders ‘All Female Rabbis Stand’
abstract: Jonas was officially ordained as a rabbi in Germany in 1935, just as conditions were worsening for Jews. She was killed at Auschwitz when she was 42.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Florida’s ‘Stop WOKE’ Act Gets Pushback in Court
abstract: A federal judge blocked a key provision of the state’s law aimed at private businesses, calling it something you might find in an alternate universe.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge late yesterday blocked a key provision of Florida’s “Stop WOKE” Act aimed at private businesses. The ruling came in a case brought by two Florida companies, honeymoon registry company Honeyfund.com and a Ben & Jerry’s franchisee Primo Partners, as well as a diversity consultant Collective Concepts. They argue that the law, which limits discussion of “white man’s privilege” and other racial bias issues during diversity training offered by private employers, was an infringement of free speech.

headline: Think the Economy Is Hard to Predict? Try the Midterms.
abstract: The overturning of political norms is testing the limits of an established and generally dependable forecasting model that relies solely on economics.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: This Fall’s Fashion Is a Study in Contrasts
abstract: At once playful and serious, colorful and severe, clingy and boxy — this season, divergent styles come together.

headline: Junk Bonds Stage a Comeback as Investors Regain Risk Appetite
abstract: Borrowing by the riskiest companies was higher this week than in all of July, but some warn that the window may not be open for long.
lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, trying to cool the economy by increasing borrowing costs, companies that are considered risky have found it harder to raise debt. But firms with low credit ratings, whose debt is often referred to as “junk,” are now taking advantage of a window of opportunity to borrow more cash.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Will Revisit Westeros, Not Reinvent It
abstract: Ryan Condal and Miguel Sapochnik, the showrunners of the “Game of Thrones” prequel, discuss its fealty to the original and the new politics of brothel scenes.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Miguel Sapochnik thought he was done with “Game of Thrones.”

headline: T Process | Ottelien Huckin
abstract: The London-based artist updates traditional blue-and-white Delft tiles with erotic motifs.
lead_paragraph: The London-based artist updates traditional blue-and-white Delft tiles with erotic motifs.

headline: Delft Tiles Get a Playful, and Sometimes Raunchy, Update
abstract: A new generation of artisans are paying homage to the centuries-old craft even as they subvert it.
lead_paragraph: A broad-shouldered farmer, scythe in hand, gazes out over a field of asparagus. At first, the young man, subtly veined with craquelure and rendered in cobalt blue on a tin-glazed ceramic Delft tile, appears to have come from the 17th or 18th century, when more than 800 million such tiles, often bearing similar pastoral sketches, were produced in Holland. But on closer inspection, there are differences: This cropper is shirtless, his backside a bit too pert, and the stalks of asparagus growing from the ground are, in fact, penises. Made in 2019 by the 54-year-old British artist Paul Bommer — who has also worked phallic imagery into tiles variously depicting what might be initially mistaken for a kite in ancient China, a prize squash and chickens being fed by an old lady — the provocative scene reflects a larger rediscovery of Delft-style tiles by a new generation of history-upending ceramists.

headline: Europeans Debate Barring Russian Tourists Over the Invasion of Ukraine
abstract: A proposed visa ban has divided many Europeans, with some arguing it would increase pressure inside Russia and others questioning whether it plays into Kremlin claims of persecution by the West.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A proposal that the European Union ban visas for all Russian tourists because of the Ukraine invasion has set off a debate in the continent’s capitals about morality, legality, collective guilt and the use of power.

headline: How Heat Waves Take a Toll on Mental Health
abstract: Extreme heat can influence mood and raise the likelihood of a more serious mental health issue. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of people across the United States have been enduring heat wave after heat wave this summer, in what feels like an unrelenting succession of humid days and scorching temperatures. While there’s no denying that extreme heat and humidity can be physically uncomfortable, research suggests that such conditions can be trying on your psychological well-being, too.

headline: In Deep Red Texas, Beto O’Rourke Takes On Guns and Abortion
abstract: “I can’t win this with Democrats alone,” Mr. O’Rourke said during a 49-day drive across Texas that has included deeply Republican towns.
lead_paragraph: WHITESBORO, Texas — As supporters of Beto O’Rourke, the Democratic candidate for Texas governor, emerged from a crowded campaign event in a quaint, conservative bastion north of Dallas, Treva Sanges was there to protest them.

headline: A Trial Put Publishing’s Inner Workings on Display. What Did We Learn?
abstract: The book world can be opaque to outsiders. A case offered an unusual glimpse into it, revealing curiosities about the business and details about book deals.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Department of Justice and for Penguin Random House delivered their closing argument on Friday in a case that will determine whether the publisher, the country’s largest, can buy one of its rivals, Simon & Schuster.

headline: Marcy Kaptur, a Veteran Democrat, Breaks with Biden in New TV Ad
abstract: Ms. Kaptur is the most prominent Democrat to break with President Biden as she seeks re-election in a Toledo-area seat that was redrawn to be sharply more Republican.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marcy Kaptur of Ohio, the second-most tenured woman in congressional history, has released a new television ad explicitly breaking with President Biden, the most prominent Democrat to do so, as she seeks re-election in a Toledo-area seat that was redrawn to be sharply more Republican.

headline: Will the F.B.I. Search Give Trump a Boost?
abstract: Readers discuss a David Brooks column about the political fallout. Also: Honoring the victims of the 1972 Olympic massacre in Munich; economic illusions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Inside Salvage Food Stores and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: How Democracy Is Under Threat Across the Globe
abstract: The United States is far from alone in facing pressure on its democratic norms and institutions.
lead_paragraph: The United States is far from alone in facing pressure on its democratic norms and institutions. According to data from V-Dem, a monitoring institute based in Sweden, more democracies are declining, and even sliding into autocracy, today than at any point in the last century. This trend, continuing for over a decade, appears to be accelerating, data shows, affecting established and fragile democracies alike across the globe.

headline: Four Ways to Think About Wine
abstract: You can improve your drinking experience by taking a more thoughtful approach to the bottles you choose and how you judge what’s in your glass.
lead_paragraph: Drinking is thinking. That is, the way you think about wine affects what you choose to drink and how you generally approach wine.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Eric Kim brings us a pasta al pomodoro recipe inspired by a trip to Italy and, of course, “Eat, Pray, Love.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Eric Kim is in The New York Times Magazine this weekend with an excellent column about the perfection of late-summer pasta al pomodoro and a terrific recipe (above) to go along with it. The recipe is based on his memories of a meal he ate in Como, in northern Italy, and advice he received from the food stylist Susan Spungen, who made a beautiful plate of pasta al pomodoro for the 2010 film “Eat, Pray, Love.” Julia Roberts’s character eats a plate of it in a pivotal scene.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include three found-footage oddities and thrillers about a contagion and a kidnapping that are not what they seem.
lead_paragraph: The gods of experimental horror have been generous this year. First came the sublimely unsettling “We’re All Going to the World’s Fair.” Now comes this singular found-footage art film, made during the coronavirus pandemic lockdown by the writer-director-cinematographer Jacob Aaron Estes (“Don’t Let Go”) at his own home.

headline: A Cartier Watch, Ready for Its Closeup
abstract: Inspired by the bracelets worn by the Hollywood star Gloria Swanson, this intricate and reversible accessory can transform from a bangle into a timepiece.
lead_paragraph: In 1912, Cartier introduced its first mystery clock. The hands seemed to float magically around the dial as if without anchor but were, in fact, attached to two disks of transparent rock crystal. The object’s popularity coincided with the return to fashion of the translucent crystal, a fixture of the house’s haute joaillerie innovations of the time. Two decades later, Gloria Swanson — one of the biggest movie stars of the 1920s — purchased a pair of Cartier rock crystal and diamond bracelets. Crafted with an expandable row of carved hemispherical half-disks, the bangles had no clasp, and their monochromatic, oversize bombé shape stood out on the black-and-white screen when she wore them alongside Laurence Olivier in her 1933 film, “Perfect Understanding.” An extravagant woman (she had a 24-room Beverly Hills estate), Swanson adopted the Cartier bracelets as one of her trademarks both on- and offscreen, wearing them in publicity stills and at awards ceremonies. Later, she incorporated them into her wardrobe when she made her comeback in 1950 as Norma Desmond in Billy Wilder’s “Sunset Boulevard.”

headline: In Two London Plays, Being Black Means Looking From the Outside In
abstract: Black characters in “Mad House” and “The Southbury Child” endure microaggressions and aspersions. The familiar scenarios hit home for our critic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was my second time here, and I kept trying to remember if I had felt as conspicuous during my first visit. I could count the number of other Black women I spotted during my five days here: the hotel receptionist with the French braid, whom I spoke with when I stopped in to ask to use the bathroom, the long-haired woman at my own hotel’s front desk, the woman talking rapidly into her cellphone outside a Starbucks, the two women (clearly tourists) with matching backpacks near the British Museum, and the young woman with the short, relaxed hair, who was clutching a shopping bag as she walked briskly down the street. That list isn’t comprehensive. But it’s not far off.

headline: What Remains to Be Said About World War II? Plenty, These Authors Suggest
abstract: Four new books take another look at a conflict that changed history.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it seems as if half the books of military history being published are about some aspect of World War II. I generally try to avoid these works because there are so many other conflicts to discuss. But on occasion I give up and try to pick out a few good books from the incoming flood.

headline: All You Need for This Crisp-Tender Skillet Cake Is Rice and a Little Time
abstract: A gorgeous snack drizzled with honey or a way to shuttle soups, stews or grilled meat from plate to mouth, this simple dish is the best kind of exercise in patience, Yewande Komolafe writes.
lead_paragraph: Fermentation, to me, is like a dance with my environment, at times loose and improvisational, but always measured and contained. What better way to cook is there than to rely on nature to alter an ingredient, at its own pace?

headline: What the U.S. climate law means for the world
abstract: The effects will be felt far beyond America’s borders. We explain.
lead_paragraph: The Inflation Reduction Act is a very big deal for the United States. It’s the biggest climate law in the country’s history. It’s a lot of money, nearly $370 billion, for all kinds of tax incentives for American consumers and businesses. We’ve explained that from several different angles and we’ll continue to explore the package in the coming weeks.

headline: Fact-Checking Health Claims About the Inflation Reduction Act
abstract: A provision in the law seeking to drive down drug prices has become fodder for misleading claims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Critics of the climate change, health and tax law enacted this week have seized on a provision addressing high drug prices to make inaccurate claims.

headline: Putin offers his first public remarks on the nuclear complex since the most recent tensions began.
abstract: The remarks came during a telephone call initiated by President Emmanuel Macron of France.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in his first public remarks about the battles raging in the vicinity of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine, accused the Ukrainian military on Friday of risking a “large-scale catastrophe” by shelling the plant.

headline: She Made Glimmerglass a True Festival. Now She’s Moving On.
abstract: During Francesca Zambello’s 12 years as the festival’s leader, she did what she set out to do: took on “complex issues through storytelling and music making.”
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — Before every opera performance at the Glimmerglass Festival, Francesca Zambello, its artistic and general director, cruises around its bucolic campus in a golf cart that she calls “Grane” after Brünnhilde’s trusty steed. Zambello greets audience members, gives welcome lifts to some older patrons, and gets out regularly to mingle. That a leader should be the festival’s public face is something Zambello takes seriously.

headline: Survivor of White House Lightning Strike Embraces Third Chance at Life
abstract: On her 28th birthday, Amber Escudero-Kontostathis was struck by lightning in Lafayette Square. Three other people died. Her heart stopped twice, but she lived.
lead_paragraph: When Amber Escudero-Kontostathis, 28, drifts into a light sleep, she is frequently awakened by a feeling similar to a dream of falling, except the thing that jolts her is a glowing ball of light the size of a playground ball speeding toward her face.

headline: A judge blocks the workplace provision of Florida’s ‘Stop WOKE Act.’
abstract: The law seeks to determine how all sorts of organizations, including private businesses, can address race, gender and nationality.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday blocked a key provision of Florida’s “Stop WOKE Act” aimed at private businesses.

headline: Lit Trivia: Do You Know These Authors’ First Novels?
abstract: Can you guess the title and author of these classic literary debuts?
lead_paragraph: Can you guess the title and author of these classic literary debuts?

headline: Review: A Ukrainian Orchestra Speaks With Quiet Intensity
abstract: The Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra, convened just a month ago, shows its defiance with sophistication, craft, rigor and subtlety.
lead_paragraph: Brahms’s Fourth Symphony doesn’t mean anything. Like much of the classical music repertory, it has no text, no plot. It elicits emotions, but not in a rigidly defined way. At a concert, your neighbor’s experience of it, her explanation of its impact, will almost certainly be different from yours.

headline: This Easy One-Pan Chicken Recipe Has a Trick Up Its Sleeve
abstract: If you’re not already trimming your corn kernels off the cob this way, you should be, Melissa Clark writes.
lead_paragraph: Because of my daughter’s braces, our family’s summer corn-on-the-cob-palooza has been temporarily nixed. Corn is still on the menu — thank goodness — but the kernels need to be cut off the cob, lest any gnawing ravage the delicate infrastructure of modern orthodontics.

headline: Manchester United and the Mounting Cost of Failure
abstract: The problem at United is not, and never has been, a lack of money. It is the lack of a plan.
lead_paragraph: Manchester United’s problem has never been money. Not a dearth of it, anyway. Even now, in what may prove to be the twilight of the Glazer family’s 17-year ownership of the club, as prospective suitors and self-appointed saviors circle, great torrents of money continue to flow through Old Trafford.

headline: Political Test for Gavin Newsom: Whether to Sign Injection-Site Bill
abstract: California’s Democratic governor has backed progressive causes before, but he faces a tougher call on the bill if national aspirations are on his mind.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gavin Newsom, the governor of California, hasn’t been shy about testing his power to advance progressive causes, most notably in 2004 when, as mayor of San Francisco, he allowed same-sex marriages in defiance of a voter-approved ban.

headline: Nafis Sadik, U.N. Official and ‘Proud Champion of Choice,’ Dies at 92
abstract: An obstetrician, she led a groundbreaking effort to put women’s rights to control all aspects of their lives at the heart of the global population debate.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Nafis Sadik, a Pakistani obstetrician who as a top United Nations official ensured that women’s rights — not least the right to choose whether to get pregnant — were at the heart of the global population debate, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

headline: Islamic State Militant Sentenced to 8 Life Terms in Killing of U.S. Hostages
abstract: In April, a jury found El Shafee Elsheikh guilty on four counts of hostage-taking and four counts of conspiracy after a two-week trial.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A key member of an Islamic State cell known as the Beatles was sentenced to life in prison on Friday for his role in the abduction, abuse and deaths of four Americans in Syria, ending a long and wrenching effort by their families to bring him to justice.

headline: Tuesday Fancy Mussels
abstract: Jazz up any ol’ Tuesday with a 15-minute pot of shellfish.
lead_paragraph: Howdy, I’m Tanya, a New York Times Cooking editor and Emily’s gracious understudy this week. You should know that there are a few hills I’d die on: The “Star Wars” prequels weren’t as bad as everyone said they were, the best s’mores are deeply charred and a little salty, and we should all be making weeknight mussels.

headline: 14 Easy 15-Minute Dinners for When There Aren’t Enough Hours in the Day
abstract: Snuggle with your dog, call your mom, go for a walk. These quick meals let you get on with your lovely life.
lead_paragraph: “Brevity is the soul of wit,” wrote William Shakespeare, and the same could be said of a good recipe. Weekend cooking projects and three-hour braises are all well and good, but an exceedingly delicious meal — the sort that makes you do a little chair dance when you take your first bite — ready in just a handful of minutes brings a deep sense of satisfaction and delight.

headline: Supreme Court Temporarily Blocks Georgia Election Law Said to Harm Black Voters
abstract: A federal judge had ruled that election regulations for a state commission violated the Voting Rights Act by diluting the power of Black voters to elect their preferred candidates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court temporarily halted an election in Georgia on Friday, reviving a federal judge’s ruling that the state had adopted voting rules that disadvantaged Black voters in violation of a federal civil rights law.

headline: What Goes Into an E.V. Battery?
abstract: Electric vehicle batteries are composed of hundreds or thousands of individual lithium-ion cells or pouches.
lead_paragraph: Electric vehicle batteries are composed of hundreds or thousands of individual lithium-ion cells or pouches.

headline: Blackpink’s Genre-Hopping Return, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Blake Shelton, Chloe Moriondo and Madonna.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: ‘Bodies Bodies Bodies’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Halina Reijn narrates a sequence from her film.
lead_paragraph: The director Halina Reijn narrates a sequence from her film.

headline: Walmart Expands Employee Abortion Coverage and Will Include Travel Expenses
abstract: The Arkansas-based retailer, the country’s largest employer, said its health plans would cover abortions in specific cases and related travel expenses.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, the country’s largest private employer, with over 1.6 million workers in the United States, said on Friday it would expand the coverage of abortions and related travel expenses in its health care plans.

headline: Watch a Tense Pool Scene From ‘Bodies Bodies Bodies’
abstract: The director Halina Reijn narrates a sequence from her thriller featuring Amandla Stenberg and Maria Bakalova.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Retailers Stumble Adjusting to More Selective Shoppers
abstract: In earnings reports this week, companies showed it has been a struggle to adapt to a consumer mind-set that is vastly different from what it was during much of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This hasn’t been the year retailers planned for.

headline: ‘I’m Carrying This Baby Just to Bury It’: The Struggle to Decode Abortion Laws
abstract: At a Louisiana hospital, concerns about complying with new abortion bans in post-Roe America left a pregnant woman with a devastating diagnosis, but not an abortion.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Davis says that when she learned this month that the fetus she was carrying had a rare and fatal condition, she and her partner were devastated.

headline: ‘Bad Sisters’ Review: The Family That Kills Together (Maybe)
abstract: Sharon Horgan headlines a twisty, comic take on the avenging-women thriller for Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: A despicable male is found dead, and the prime suspects are a group of women who wanted to protect one of their number from his constant oppression. The killer or killers are eventually revealed; a lot of driving is done up and down a picturesque coastline. It’s the “Big Little Lies” scenario, but “Bad Sisters,” premiering Friday on Apple TV+, adds something new and refreshing to the formula: a sense of humor.

headline: Usyk and Joshua to Resettle Heavyweight Picture With Saudi Arabia as Backdrop
abstract: Oleksandr Usyk surprised the boxing world when he upset Anthony Joshua in their first bout. Then, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and maneuvering within boxing led to a rematch in Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: When Oleksandr Usyk upset the incumbent heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua in London last September, his win triggered speculation that a rematch could take place in early 2022 in Ukraine, Usyk’s native country.

headline: Rewriting Women Back Into Film History
abstract: In shorts from the early 20th century, the stars defy gender stereotypes that would later be standard in Hollywood, as a museum series and box set make clear.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made of cinema’s recent vanguard of female superheroes, the crusading women who give as good as they take. But long before Wonder Woman and her Amazonian sisters charged the big screen, long before feminist scholars began calling out the film industry’s inequities and long before talking movies became the norm, women ran wild in movies. And I mean, really wild. They riotously schemed, fought and defied convention, racing and laughing their way to liberation — or something like it.

headline: TikTok Browser Can Track Users’ Keystrokes, According to New Research
abstract: In the web browser used within the TikTok app, supplementary code lets the company track every character typed by users. The company said the capability was for troubleshooting.
lead_paragraph: The web browser used within the TikTok app can track every keystroke made by its users, according to new research that is surfacing as the Chinese-owned video app grapples with U.S. lawmakers’ concerns over its data practices.

headline: A Famous Walrus Is Killed, and Norwegians Are Divided
abstract: The killing of Freya has polarized Oslo and threatens to blight the image of a country more commonly associated with diplomatic good deeds than mob-like hits.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — It was another good day for Freya, the 1,300-pound walrus named for the Norse goddess of love, beauty and war, who had become a beloved and feel-good international media sensation, the frolicking mascot of the long Oslo summer.

headline: DeSantis, Eyeing 2024, Rallies With the Trump-Backed Far Right
abstract: Appearing with right-wing candidates in Pennsylvania and Ohio, the Florida governor signaled his desire to take over Donald Trump’s political movement. Whether Republican voters want that to happen remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, widely seen as the Republican who poses the biggest threat to Donald J. Trump if they both run for president in 2024, blitzed through Pennsylvania and Ohio on Friday during a national tour with hard-right candidates that was clearly intended to elevate his standing and earn political capital with potential future leaders in battleground states.

headline: Democrats Have Embraced Economics. Too Much?
abstract: In her recent book, the sociologist Elizabeth Popp Berman says economists have too much influence.
lead_paragraph: I love this sentence in a recent book by Elizabeth Popp Berman: “For Republicans, economic reasoning remained a means to an end; for Democrats, the values of economics became an end in themselves.”

headline: Community Filmmaking in the Amazon
abstract: Five questions for Alex Pritz about his documentary “The Territory,” about the fight to preserve the Amazon rainforest.
lead_paragraph: Alex Pritz’s documentary “The Territory” drops us right onto the front lines of the battle to preserve the Amazon rainforest in Brazil. Pritz embeds us with both an Indigenous community under threat, the Uru Eu Wau Wau, and the farmers who seize Indigenous lands with apparent impunity. That on-the-ground approach brings a visceral suspense to global environmental issues and gives a firsthand view of a local community (numbering less than 200) as they fight for survival in new ways.

headline: Weed Drinks Are a Buzzy Alcohol Substitute. But Are They Safe?
abstract: Business is booming for cannabis-infused beverages. Experts still know very little about their health effects.
lead_paragraph: The mid-2010s were an era of ready-to-drink cocktails, which were eclipsed in more recent years by hard seltzers, those fruit-flavored fizzes perfect for barbecues and beaches. Now, weed drinks may be having their moment.

headline: Vanessa Bryant Testifies in Trial Over Kobe Bryant Crash Photos
abstract: The widow of the N.B.A. star described her pain after learning Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputies and firefighters shared crash site photos.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Vanessa Bryant had found a measure of closure in February 2020 after the emotional, tribute-rich memorial for her late husband, the basketball star Kobe Bryant.

headline: Russia’s Gazprom announces another halt to Germany’s gas flow.
abstract: A three-day shutdown of the Nord Stream pipeline, which the company attributed to repairs, is likely to cause jitters in Europe’s largest economy.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Gazprom, the Kremlin-controlled energy giant, says it will temporarily shut down its gas pipeline to Germany at the end of the month for repairs, a move likely to trigger more uncertainty in Europe as countries struggle to compensate for cuts in Russian fossil fuels.

headline: Love Letter: What We Do in the End
abstract: Losing a sibling, but choosing to be present and brave for the end.
lead_paragraph: This week’s staggering Modern Love essay, “A Last Act of Intimate Kindness,” reminded me of a powerful Tiny Love Story we published years ago, “What We Do in the End”:

headline: Odesa, the Big Prize
abstract: The port city is a personal obsession for President Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Meme stocks are back. Here’s why wild trading may be here to stay.
abstract: Turbulent trading in shares of companies like AMC Entertainment and Bed Bath & Beyond can no longer be explained as simply a pandemic phenomenon, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Once thought to be a short-lived phenomenon, it appears the wild trading in so-called meme stocks is here to stay.

headline: Wonking Out: Virginia Woolf and Core Inflation
abstract: How should the Fed think about surging rents?
lead_paragraph: If you or someone you know has been looking for a place to live recently, you’re aware that the housing market has gone wild over the past two and a half years. House prices have soared; so have rents.

headline: The Best of Late Night 🌙
abstract: This week, the F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald Trump’s Florida estate, Mar-a-Lago, was a favorite topic for the late-night hosts. Here's what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: This week, the F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald Trump’s Florida estate, Mar-a-Lago, was a favorite topic for the late-night hosts. Here's what they had to say.

headline: Wayfair will lay off 870 workers after a drop in sales.
abstract: The online furniture retailer boomed in the early months of the pandemic, but it has failed to maintain that momentum.
lead_paragraph: The online furniture retailer Wayfair, which has struggled to maintain momentum after experiencing a surge in sales in the early months of the pandemic, said on Friday that it was laying off about 870 employees, about 5 percent of its global work force and 10 percent of its corporate team.

headline: Robert Caro on ‘Working’
abstract: The acclaimed biographer of Lyndon B. Johnson and Robert Moses talks about his methods.
lead_paragraph: For the next few months, we’re sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcast’s archives. This one was originally published on April 19, 2019.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway cleared to buy up to 50% of Occidental Petroleum.
abstract: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved a request from Warren Buffett’s company to take a bigger stake in the oil company.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway on Friday received authorization from federal energy regulators to acquire up to 50 percent of Occidental Petroleum, one of country’s largest oil and natural gas producers.

headline: Graham Ordered to Appear Before Atlanta Grand Jury Investigating Trump
abstract: A federal judge declined to stay her order that Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina appear on Tuesday before a special grand jury in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Friday turned down a request by Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina to avoid testifying next week before a special grand jury investigating attempts by former President Trump and his allies to overturn his November 2020 election loss in Georgia.

headline: Dmitri Vrubel, Who Planted a Kiss on the Berlin Wall, Dies at 62
abstract: A Russian-born painter, he created a mural of the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev smooching the East German leader Erich Honecker — and with it a tourist attraction.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Dmitri Vrubel, a Russian artist-provocateur best known for a startling mural on the Berlin Wall depicting the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev laying a fat kiss on the mouth of the East German leader Erich Honecker, died on Saturday in Berlin. He was 62.

headline: How a Kenyan Power Broker Lost His Stronghold, Then the Presidency
abstract: In his fifth, and possibly last, bid for president, Raila Odinga failed to enthuse a crucial bloc of voters in his own backyard that would have catapulted him to the top job.
lead_paragraph: KISUMU, Kenya — For decades, Kenya’s veteran opposition politician Raila Odinga has been the chief political power broker in the western counties around Lake Victoria, relying on his fellow Luo ethnic voters to back him in five successive elections for president.

headline: Gene LeBell, 89, Judo Champion, Wrestler and Star Stuntman, Dies
abstract: A tough guy who got beaten up by the likes of John Wayne, he had a bottom-line view of his job: “The more you get hit in the nose, the richer you are.”
lead_paragraph: One day in 1966, the stuntman Gene LeBell was called to the set of the television series “The Green Hornet” to deal with Bruce Lee, the future martial arts superstar, who played Kato, the crime-fighting Hornet’s sidekick. Mr. Lee, it seems, was hurting the other stuntmen.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Herd Mentality Is All Around Us. I Still See Hope for Diversity of Thought.
abstract: Moral courage (and the word “like”) can help us grapple with uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: There are times when things really throw you a curve as to what you thought human nature was. For me, one of them was when carrying mobile phones became the default. It would never have occurred to me before then that so many people would want to talk and text in their spare moments as much as they do.

headline: The Simple Yet Precise Legacy of Carril’s Princeton Offense
abstract: Carril, who died this week at 92, built teams that stymied bigger powerhouses during the games that mattered each March.
lead_paragraph: Center Forward Backdoor.

headline: Ann McGuiness, Major Fund-Raiser for Women’s Health, Dies at 65
abstract: At Planned Parenthood and other organizations, she worked behind the scenes for reproductive rights and related causes.
lead_paragraph: Ann McGuiness, a behind-the-scenes force in women’s health and reproductive rights who raised vast amounts of money for Planned Parenthood and other groups and then was a founder of the Contraceptive Access Initiative, which seeks to make hormonal birth control more available over the counter, died on Aug. 3 in Albany, N.Y. She was 65.

headline: Lawmakers Demand Social Media Firms Address Threats to Law Enforcement
abstract: The Democrats who lead two House panels also expressed concern about “reckless statements” from Republicans after a surge in online threats following the F.B.I. search of Mar-a-Lago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The leaders of two House panels sent letters on Friday to eight social media companies demanding that they take “immediate action” to address threats on their platforms toward federal law enforcement officials after a surge in right-wing calls for violence following the F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida.

headline: Deshaun Watson’s Apology Undercuts the N.F.L.’s Message
abstract: The league has looked for contrition in determining its discipline of players accused of conduct violations. Deshaun Watson’s insistence that he did nothing wrong undermined its attempt at rehabbing his image.
lead_paragraph: When Roger Goodell became N.F.L. commissioner in 2006, he made it clear that one of his biggest priorities would be to police players whose actions might tarnish the league’s carefully crafted image.

headline: A Former Fox News Insider Spills the Beans
abstract: Chris Stirewalt was part of a pivotal decision to declare Joe Biden the winner of Arizona in 2020. Now he’s speaking out about a network he says incites “black-helicopter-level paranoia and hatred.”
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter is a guest contribution by Jeremy W. Peters, who writes for The Times’s media desk. He got his hands on a forthcoming book by Chris Stirewalt, a former senior journalist at Fox News, and shares its highlights here.

headline: Ukrainian Strikes May Be Slowing Russia’s Advance
abstract: A new strategy of attacks on logistical targets in Russian-held territory is having an impact, analysts say, symbolically as well as militarily.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military extended the fight deeper into Russian-controlled territory on Friday, as it sharpens a strategy of trying to degrade Moscow’s combat capabilities by striking ammunition depots and supply lines in the occupied Crimean Peninsula and other areas the Kremlin had long thought to be safe.

headline: Group Seeks to Block Abortion Vote in Michigan, Citing Typography
abstract: The effort is aimed at keeping a constitutional amendment to guarantee abortion rights off the ballot. A voting access measure is also being challenged.
lead_paragraph: Conservative groups in Michigan filed challenges this week to efforts to put two constitutional amendments on the ballot in November, one that would guarantee abortion rights and the other that would expand voting access.

headline: Big Ten Players Wonder Where They Fit Into a $1 Billion TV Deal
abstract: Student-athletes are excited for the exposure their league will receive, but paying players looms large.
lead_paragraph: Penn State guard Myles Dread felt “important” and “valuable” when he heard that the Big Ten Conference had signed the richest annual television contract in college sports. The Michigan gymnast Sierra Brooks is looking forward to being on television consistently. Ohio State quarterback C.J. Stroud thinks the money should be shared with the student-athletes who generate it.

headline: After Signing Climate Bill, Biden Prepares More Actions to Cut Emissions
abstract: Regulations from the E.P.A. and elsewhere will help the president meet his aggressive climate goals, administration officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh off signing expansive climate legislation, President Biden and his administration are planning a series of executive actions to further reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help keep the planet from warming to dangerous temperatures, senior White House officials said.

headline: A heavyweight rematch is a chance for a surprise champion to get the world to focus on Ukraine.
abstract: When Oleksandr Usyk upset the incumbent heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua in London last September, his win triggered speculation that a rematch could take place in early 2022 in Ukraine, Usyk’s native country.
lead_paragraph: When Oleksandr Usyk upset the incumbent heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua in London last September, his win triggered speculation that a rematch could take place in early 2022 in Ukraine, Usyk’s native country.

headline: Sylvia Fowles Wants to See Who She Can Be Without Basketball
abstract: Fowles, who played through pain in her final season with the Lynx, said she wanted to “step away and debrief a little bit.”
lead_paragraph: It’s kind of funny to Sylvia Fowles that everyone is on the same page about what she should do with her life now that she has retired from the W.N.B.A.

headline: Twitter Tells Employees They Might Get Only Half Their Annual Bonus
abstract: The company blamed its financial performance for the potential bonus cut.
lead_paragraph: Twitter warned its employees on Friday that they might receive only half of their typical annual bonuses as the social media company grapples with economic uncertainty.

headline: Florida Utility Is Fined $500,000 for 2017 Explosion That Killed 5
abstract: Tampa Electric Company pleaded guilty in May to “willfully” violating an OSHA rule that required workers to receive a pre-job briefing about the work they were to perform.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday fined a Florida power company the maximum penalty of $500,000 for violating a federal safety rule and causing a 2017 explosion at a coal-fired power plant near Tampa that killed five people and injured several others, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Lettuce on Wendy’s Sandwiches Potentially Linked to E. Coli Outbreak
abstract: Federal health officials said that while 37 people had been sickened and 10 hospitalized, it was safe to eat at the fast-food chain and to buy romaine lettuce.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials said on Friday that romaine lettuce on sandwiches from Wendy’s restaurants was possibly responsible for the “fast-moving” E. coli outbreak that has sickened dozens and hospitalized 10 people.

headline: It’s Raised by the Best
abstract: Hemant Mehta charges solvers with an energetic challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Saturday themeless grids tend to differentiate themselves in subtle ways. They’re always hard, although we get a wildly difficult swath or two. They’re always artful, though sometimes the grid design is particularly dazzling. Today’s puzzle, Hemant Mehta’s third for The New York Times and third on a Saturday, is notable because every entry longer than eight letters is a debut (with one exception that’s been absent since 1981). That includes the triple center stack and three out of four of the chunky corners. Fortunately, most of these new entries are far from obscure, and they’re all entertaining to uncover.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 20, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about French soldiers pulling out of Mali after nine years misstated the change to Germany’s role in the United Nations’ peacekeeping operation in Mali. Germany has suspended parts of its involvement, not ended it.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Some Colleges Don’t Produce Big Earners. Are They Worth It?
abstract: Many attendees aren’t better off financially than those who have only a high school degree, at least not right away. How should applicants consider these institutions?
lead_paragraph: As the nation’s student debtors enter Month 20 of awaiting word on when or if President Biden will keep his promise to cancel some of their debt, many questions hang in the air.

headline: How the Find My App Became an Accidental Friendship Fixture
abstract: Introduced 10 years ago, the app has slowly become a popular way to keep track of friends. But it comes with considerable privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: In July, Shay Pierre opened Apple’s location-sharing app Find My and noticed a friend at an unfamiliar apartment building in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: How Pharmacy Work Stopped Being So Great
abstract: Two years of economic recovery brought strong gains to workers at the top and the bottom, but headwinds for those in between. Consider the pharmacist.
lead_paragraph: If any group of workers might have expected their pay to rise last year, it would arguably have been pharmacists. With many drugstores dispensing coronavirus tests and vaccines while filling hundreds of prescriptions each day, working as a pharmacist became a sleep-deprived, lunch-skipping frenzy — one in which ornery customers did not hesitate to vent their frustrations over the inevitable backups and bottlenecks.

headline: Where Are All the Manhattan Voters in August? Try the Hamptons.
abstract: A late August congressional primary in New York has candidates scrambling to find far-flung voters who tend to summer in places like the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: AMAGANSETT, N.Y. — In the lush town green here one recent morning, waiting to get her nails done, sat just the kind of Manhattan Democrat whose coveted vote could tip the balance in Tuesday’s blockbuster primary involving two lions of Congress, Jerrold Nadler and Carolyn Maloney.

headline: Germany’s Stony-Faced Chancellor Faces Critics on Nearly Every Side
abstract: After eight months in office, Olaf Scholz is still struggling to find his footing, drawing questions over a tax scandal and criticism of his response to a Holocaust remark made at his side.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — First, he failed to immediately contradict the Palestinian leader who accused Israel of “50 Holocausts” as they stood together in Berlin. Then he was heckled by discontented voters calling him a “liar” and “traitor.” And on Friday, he was summoned to testify in the case of a major tax scam that took place when he was mayor of Hamburg.

headline: Quotation of the Day: When a Key New York Primary Cuts Into Voters’ Beach Time
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Aug. 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not coming in to vote. That’s the problem: Nobody here is going to come in just to vote. It’s insane. What’s this voting in August?”

headline: Coming of Age in 1980s New York
abstract: In his debut, “My Government Means to Kill Me,” Rasheed Newson shines a vivid light onto underappreciated aspects of our history through the life of a gay Black teenager.
lead_paragraph: The book jacket of Rasheed Newson’s extraordinary debut, “My Government Means to Kill Me,” features the title in big, pink, all-caps type, followed by the words “A NOVEL” in the same large font. This is rare. Such labels — “a novel,” “poems,” “a memoir” — are usually sneaked in as surreptitiously as the words “serving suggestion” on the front of a cereal box, and until now, they’ve struck me as equally unnecessary. Beholding a box of frosted flakes, we might confidently project the absence of milk, berries and tigers within; standing in the fiction aisle, we make similar assumptions about the rectangles on the shelves. Once in a while, though, a peculiar book — in this case, a fictional annotated memoir — comes along and scrambles our categories.

headline: A Sweet, Satisfying, Utterly Intoxicating Historical Romance
abstract: Lydia San Andres sets “Compromised Into a Scandalous Marriage” in the Edwardian-era Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Harlequin made such a success of the category romance — those slender paper volumes with straightforward titles — that the publisher name is virtually synonymous with the form. Categories are slender for the same reason a shot glass is small: because what they contain is potent and intoxicating. I’m delighted to report that Lydia San Andres’s first Harlequin Historical, COMPROMISED INTO A SCANDALOUS MARRIAGE (Harlequin, 288 pp., paper, $6.75), has all the delicate world-building of her self-published work, and all the no-holds-barred melodrama category romances are designed for.

headline: Writers Gather to Read Salman Rushdie and Support Free Speech
abstract: Authors including Paul Auster, Gay Talese, Kiran Desai and others reminded the Midtown crowd that without free expression, “literature is nothing but an echo chamber.”
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most appreciative response from the crowd gathered at the New York Public Library in support of Salman Rushdie on Friday came when the writer Hari Kunzru read aloud from Mr. Rushdie’s acclaimed, and infamous, novel “The Satanic Verses.” The book’s publication, in 1988, put a target on its author’s back and led to book bans, violent demonstrations and killings after Iran’s leader, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, issued a fatwa calling for his death.

headline: In the Deep South, a Search for Queer Identity
abstract: Casey Parks’s “Diary of a Misfit” pieces together the elusive history of a Louisiana musician who spent all his life in a community that misgendered him.
lead_paragraph: There was the elementary school gym teacher rumored to have been in a lesbian relationship with the woman who taught science. There was the hair stylist who flicked his wrist when he spoke and only half-hid hints of his nightlife in drag. There was the androgynous ticket-taker at the art museum who gave back a knowing glance, the softball player, the tween poet and painter. There was Matthew Shepard.

headline: The Fried Chicken Inflation Index
abstract: YouTube star Elijah Quashie, of the U.K. hit “The Pengest Munch,” copes with the rising cost of wings.
lead_paragraph: If you are walking anywhere in London and spot Elijah Quashie, a.k.a. The Chicken Connoisseur, he would be grateful if you resist the urge to make a fuss.
