headline: Device for Arachne
abstract: Olivia Mitra Framke and Andrea Carla Michaels weave a fascinating theme.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I knew that I was going to be a fan of Olivia Mitra Framke’s puzzles the moment I finished solving her New York Times debut in 2017. If you haven’t solved that one, I highly recommend it. After you finish reading this column, of course.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Bosses Are Sharing Their Feelings. Their Workers Are Cringing.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Aug. 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “This ‘you don’t know how hard it is for me to fire you all’ vulnerability is something people can stop doing, please.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 25, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Nicaragua’s attacks on church leaders referred incorrectly to the murders of dozens of priests and nuns in the 1980s civil wars in El Salvador and Guatemala. They were killed by security forces and paramilitaries aligned with the government, not both sides.

headline: The Pros and Cons of Congestion Pricing in Manhattan
abstract: It will cut down on cars, but will it turn New Jersey into Manhattan’s A.T.M. and make the Bronx a pollution dump? Also, the likely end of a long congressional career.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll examine two words that transit advocates love and commuters who drive into Manhattan dread — congestion pricing. We’ll also look at takeaways from Tuesday’s primaries and special elections, especially for Democrats.

headline: How China Could Choke Taiwan
abstract: China is honing its ability to blockade Taiwan, giving Beijing the option of cutting off the self-ruled island in its campaign to take control of it.
lead_paragraph: China is honing its ability to blockade Taiwan, giving Beijing the option of cutting off the self-ruled island in its campaign to take control of it.

headline: ​Decades After a ‘Living Hell,’ Korean Victims​ Win a Step Toward Redress
abstract: Brothers Home was supposed to help get people off the streets, but a government commission has confirmed its role in detentions and other abuses was a “grave human rights violation by the state.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — From 1976 to 1987, military dictators in South Korea ​swept roughly ​38,000 people off the streets, corralling them into a welfare center called Brothers Home. The facility was supposed to feed and teach what the government called vagrants — many of them minors — and train them for jobs.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: A fatal attack mars Ukraine’s Independence Day.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, on Ukraine’s Independence Day, a Russian attack killed at least 22 people and wounded 50 at a train station in eastern Ukraine, near Dnipro.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Covering a Disaster That Hasn’t Happened Yet
abstract: Giant rainstorms have ravaged California before. Times journalists combined data, graphics and old-fashioned reporting to explore what the next big one might look like.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, when I heard that California officials were embarking on an ambitious, multiyear effort to study one of the worst natural disasters in the state’s history, I knew there would be a lot of interesting material to cover. There was just one wrinkle: The disaster hadn’t happened yet — it still hasn’t.

headline: Pakistan Court Gives Imran Khan Another Reprieve From Arrest
abstract: The police were ordered not to arrest the former prime minister, who has been charged under Pakistan’s antiterrorism act, before a hearing set for next Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan appeared in court in the Pakistani capital on Thursday after being charged under the country’s antiterrorism act, the latest step in an intensifying crackdown on Mr. Khan and his allies since he was removed from office in April.

headline: As France Swelters, Private Jets Come Under Attack
abstract: Politicians are proposing regulating or banning flights by such planes after a summer of extreme heat and soaring energy prices prompted growing calls to tackle the causes of climate change.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France reels from a summer of extreme temperatures and soaring energy prices, prompting increasingly urgent calls to rein in polluters contributing to global warming, one high-flying culprit is finding itself in the cross hairs: the private jet.

headline: The Score
abstract: Fleeing war, a pianist left her dreams behind. Thirty years later, she returns to her piano.
lead_paragraph: Fleeing war, a pianist left her dreams behind. Thirty years later, she returns to her piano.

headline: U.S. Growth Has Continued, One Official Measure Shows
abstract: Government data shows that gross domestic income rose in the first two quarters, a counterpoint to a decline in G.D.P. The divergence is a mystery.
lead_paragraph: A key measure of economic output continued to grow last spring, easing fears that the United States is entering a recession, but adding to confusion about the state of the economy.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Taking the Chargers
abstract: A family disagrees on whether the electronic accessory should be communal or not.
lead_paragraph: Alissa writes: Please order my husband to keep his hands off our chargers! He frequently leaves his charger somewhere and takes any charger in the house — even if it is labeled with my name or our daughter’s! He argues that chargers belong to everyone.

headline: Poem: Lipstick Elegy
abstract: This poem explores all the distances between mothers and their children, the frayed seams between countries and cultures.
lead_paragraph: This poem explores all the distances between mothers and their children, the frayed seams between countries and cultures. It is also a poem of love and understanding, as if love is a way to the speaker’s freedom as a queer, trans Vietnamese American poet. It is brimming with images as a way to enter the speaker’s intergenerational trauma. The speaker’s mouth is a “pomegranate/split open,” but also a “grenade with a loose pin.” The grandmother is described through imagery only — she is an “immortal bodhisattva/with a thousand hands, chewing a fist of betel root, your teeth black as dawn.” Here, imagery is both the language of survival and the language of escape. Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: After Roe’s End, Women Surged in Signing Up to Vote in Some States
abstract: The rise is particularly notable in states where abortion rights are at risk.
lead_paragraph: The rise is particularly notable in states where abortion rights are at risk.

headline: When Los Angeles Slipped Out of Her Budget, She Looked East for More Space. Which Home Did She Choose?
abstract: Without the funds ‘to get into a bidding war,’ a California buyer fled to Upland, in San Bernardino, focusing on the area’s new developments. Here’s what she found.
lead_paragraph: Without the funds ‘to get into a bidding war,’ a California buyer fled to Upland, in San Bernardino, focusing on the area’s new developments. Here’s what she found.

headline: If You’re Suffering After Being Sick With Covid, It’s Not Just in Your Head
abstract: A major new approach is needed to solve many postviral conditions.
lead_paragraph: When the influenza pandemic of 1918-19 ended, misery continued.

headline: How a Corporate Law Firm Led a Political Revolution
abstract: The untold story of Jones Day’s push to move the American government and courts to the right.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy Saturday night in June, Traci Lovitt hosted a 50th birthday party for her husband, Ara, at their 9,800-square-foot Westchester mansion overlooking Long Island Sound. The couple met while clerking for Supreme Court justices: Traci for Sandra Day O’Connor, Ara for Antonin Scalia. These days, Ara worked in finance. Traci was a top partner at — and a contender to one day run — the international law firm of Jones Day, best known for representing Donald Trump’s presidential campaigns. To serve as M.C. for the event, the Lovitts flew in Richard Blade, the veteran disc jockey Ara listened to while growing up in Southern California. But Blade wasn’t the party’s biggest star. That distinction belonged to Justice Amy Coney Barrett.

headline: Coding and Creative Writing Have More in Common Than You Think
abstract: While other future novelists were discussing iambic pentameter and leitmotifs, Gina Chen immersed herself in computer science.
lead_paragraph: You’ve heard the story of the best-selling novelist who fell in love with reading at a young age, edited the high school literary magazine and majored in English. This is not Gina Chen’s trajectory. The author of “Violet Made of Thorns,” a dark Y.A. fantasy about a lying prophet who gets tangled up with a cursed prince, was a math and science kid who drew Pokémon characters and dabbled in coding. At University of San Diego, she studied computer science — a choice that laid the groundwork for her current career.

headline: N.Y. Medical Marijuana Giants Struggle to Break Into Recreational Market
abstract: Large operators want in on the state’s new retail industry. A potential multimillion-dollar fee stands in the way.
lead_paragraph: When New York State awarded the first of 10 licenses to grow and sell medical marijuana in 2015, the winning bidders rejoiced at the opportunity to control a lucrative, untapped market — but they knew that greater spoils lay ahead.

headline: Pace of Climate Change Sends Economists Back to Drawing Board
abstract: They underestimated the impact of global warming, and their preferred policy solution floundered in the United States.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: War Stole My Mother’s Dream. 30 Years Later, She Returns to It.
abstract: For my mother, music unlocks the past, reminding her of both the joy of her life in Sarajevo and the pain of leaving.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, during the Bosnian war, the siege of Sarajevo began and would last for nearly four years. My mother, Maja Bilic, fled the city with my grandmother, my brother and me, leaving behind her childhood piano and her dream of becoming a composer. She focused her energy on building a new life in Britain for our family, and her hopes for her career as a musician were set aside.

headline: It Costs Nothing to Leave Our Trees as They Are
abstract: Biden should take all steps available to stop commercial logging on federal land.
lead_paragraph: My career as a songwriter began in Manhattan, not far from where I was born. When I moved to Los Angeles in 1968, I became part of the singer-songwriter community that coalesced around Laurel Canyon. I thought California would be wild in the sense of nature. It turned out to be wild in the sense of drugs and parties. I wanted to live close to the kind of wild nature that must exist somewhere on a large scale. Somewhere turned out to be Idaho.

headline: The Front-Runner to Replace Boris Johnson Wants to Be a New Iron Lady
abstract: Campaigning to be Britain’s next prime minister, Liz Truss has modeled herself after Margaret Thatcher and pushed a party orthodoxy of lower taxes, less government and bucking the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — When a British journalist asked Liz Truss on Tuesday to name the character flaw she would most like to fix, she confessed, “I think some of my friends would say I’m a bit relentless.”

headline: Can a Start-Up Help the Film and TV Industry Reduce Their Carbon Footprint?
abstract: The global entertainment industry generates millions of metric tons of carbon dioxide a year. A Spanish director has set up a company to try to cut that number substantially.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Upstart, a series on young companies harnessing new science and technology.

headline: This Manager Might Not Be Anonymous for Long
abstract: Rob Thomson has quietly turned around the Phillies’ season. If he can end the franchise’s playoff drought, people might stop confusing him with other guys.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Rob Thomson has spent 15 years in a major league uniform, but the letters never stop. Some fans still think he is Robby Thompson, an All-Star second baseman in the 1980s and 1990s, and they send him old baseball cards to autograph. Thomson mails them back, unsigned, if they come with a self-addressed stamped envelope.

headline: At the Fed’s Big Conference, Investors Will Grasp for Hints About Rate Path
abstract: The Federal Reserve chair will speak at a key annual economics conference, which is focused on economic constraints. But investors will be listening for clues about the central bank’s path ahead.
lead_paragraph: The most anticipated economic event of the summer is set to happen on Friday, when Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, provides an update on the economic outlook that could detail how the central bank is thinking about inflation and the path ahead for interest rates.

headline: New Faces, New Places, as Boston Gets Revitalized
abstract: In New England’s largest city, there are exciting music venues, a floating oyster bar and newcomers on the arts and restaurant scenes that reflect its diversity.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new face welcoming visitors to Boston. It belongs to a 3-year-old in Velcro sneakers, crouching by a boombox and haloed in gold. She’s the artist Rob Gibbs’s daughter, who stares unflinchingly from a soaring 70-foot mural across from South Station, the city’s biggest train terminal.

headline: In a Small Mountain Town, a Beloved Theater Company Prevails
abstract: After reporting on the Creede Repertory Theater last summer, our writer returned for her vacation and took stock as the company restarted indoor performances.
lead_paragraph: CREEDE, Colo. — Last summer, I stumbled onto one of the most singular — and joyful — experiences of my life: a small community, high in the San Juan Mountains of Colorado, that has been sustaining a thriving professional theater company since 1966. And I did not even see the regular version of Creede Repertory Theater — because of the pandemic, it had put on a smaller season of down-to-basic productions on a makeshift outdoor stage.

headline: Seeking Marriage Equality for People With Disabilities
abstract: When one partner is disabled and the other isn’t, getting married could mean giving up lifesaving health care and benefits from the government.
lead_paragraph: Lori Long and Mark Contreras met on Match.com in November 2015. For Ms. Long, their first date a few weeks later, at Tarpy’s Roadhouse, a restaurant in Monterey, Calif., was a high-stakes proposition.

headline: Harvey Hit 5 Years Ago. Its Floodwaters Did Not Strike Equitably.
abstract: A new study on the catastrophic storm found that up to 50,000 homes would have been spared flooding from Harvey in a world without climate change.
lead_paragraph: Up to 50 percent of the properties that were flooded in Harris County, Texas, during Hurricane Harvey might have escaped that fate in a world without climate change, scientists reported on Thursday.

headline: Making the Rounds on Nashville’s Singer-Songwriter Circuit
abstract: For music fans, songwriters’ nights at often unassuming venues provide an inexpensive and illuminating glimpse into Music City’s most celebrated business.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday night in a Holiday Inn lounge on the fringe of Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Paul Jefferson, a local songwriter with spiky hair and skinny jeans, took the stage to sing a couple of his better-known tunes, popularized in recordings by Keith Urban and Aaron Tippin. Between “You’re Not My God” and “That’s as Close as I’ll Get to Loving You,” he talked about crafting a song, finding inspiration and the hustle it takes to make it, including playing a gig at the airport on the same day he would appear on the country’s longest running radio show.

headline: Brooklyn-Style Tennis: No Celebs, Plenty of Drama, Nothing Like the U.S. Open
abstract: A community of mostly Black players has thrived for decades at Lincoln Terrace Park despite outdated facilities, high crime and little recognition.
lead_paragraph: For two weeks every summer, the elite tennis world convenes in a world-class facility for top competition, celebrity sightings and $32 lobster rolls. For this brief period, Flushing, Queens, is the center of tennis in the world. Then the tour and the players move on to San Diego, London and Seoul.

headline: Before Serena, There Was Althea
abstract: Althea Gibson was the first Black player to win Wimbledon. Soon, the block in Harlem where she grew up will bear her name.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering day in the summer of 1957, a slender young woman from Harlem became the first Black player to win the hallowed Wimbledon tennis tournament in England. After receiving the Venus Rosewater Dish from Queen Elizabeth II, Althea Gibson, 29, attended the Wimbledon Ball that evening, spinning around the dance floor in the arms of the Duke of Devonshire.

headline: Why Is This Colorful Little Wheel Suddenly Everywhere in Japan?
abstract: It’s the logo of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals. And Japan is all in.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A few years ago, a colorful new accessory suddenly began to appear on the lapels of dark-suited salarymen across Japan: a small badge, shaped like a roulette wheel and divided into 17 rainbow-colored sections.

headline: Cecilia Vicuña’s Desire Lines
abstract: After decades on the margins, the 74-year-old Chilean sculptor and poet has improbably become one of this year’s most acclaimed.
lead_paragraph: When Cecilia Vicuña came to Manhattan in 1980, she had no plans to stay — but for Vicuña, an artist in exile from Pinochet’s Chile, plans didn’t matter much. She had been in the city for less than a week when she crossed paths with an Argentine painter and moved into his unfinished loft in TriBeCa. There were few streetlights then, so the block turned black at night, and the ruins of an old overpass sliced through the neighborhood. She could smell the Hudson River — it was so close — but it was cut off by a junkyard of car parts and a wall of barbed wire. Still, she would visit the water every afternoon, peering through a crevice in the hulking mountain of metal. She needed to know the river survived, kept flowing, even though it was polluted, teeming with traffic, almost invisible from where she stood. This elemental friendship sustained her in the foreign city.

headline: At Salzburg Festival, Directing Slow and Fast
abstract: Thorsten Lensing takes years between shows; Ewelina Marciniak puts on several each season. Both theater makers are presenting new work in Austria.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — The German director Thorsten Lensing has astonished and provoked for the past three decades, but he feels like one of theater’s best-kept secrets.

headline: Who Killed Daria Dugina?
abstract: The activist, a rising figure in the ultranationalist milieu in Russia, died in a car bombing that could alter the course of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Daria Dugina and her father, Aleksandr Dugin, have been major figures in the Russian propaganda landscape, advocating Russian imperialism and supporting the invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Biden’s Debt Relief
abstract: The president’s plan focuses on less affluent student borrowers.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than 40 percent of Americans graduate from a four-year college, and these college graduates fare far better than nongraduates on a wide range of measures. College graduates earn much more on average; are less likely to endure unemployment; are more likely to marry; are healthier; live longer; and express greater satisfaction with their lives. These gaps have generally grown in recent decades.

headline: ‘Alienoid’ Review: Sorcerers, Alien Prisoners and Much, Much More
abstract: This bonkers Korean movie could not pick just one cinematic genre, so it went for half a dozen of them at once.
lead_paragraph: This Korean film starts in the 14th century with an alien creature trying to escape from the human body inside which it has been imprisoned. Thankfully, a hole in the sky opens and an SUV materializes, carrying the interstellar lawman Guard (Kim Woo-bin) and his robot sidekick.

headline: ‘Adopting Audrey’ Review: Building a New Home Out of Nothing
abstract: Jena Malone plays a young woman who’s seeking to be adopted by a gruff patriarch. Deep down, he has, you guessed it, a heart of gold.
lead_paragraph: “Adopting Audrey,” the second feature film from the director M. Cahill (“King of California”), resembles many of the quirky domestic dramas that have populated the film festival circuit since “Little Miss Sunshine.” There’s a wayward young woman (Jena Malone) searching for guidance, and a gruff patriarch, Otto (Robert Hunger-Bühler), in need of human connection to soften his heart. There’s an absurd twist to this stock premise, however: The wayward adult, Audrey, would like to be adopted, which is how she meets Otto and his forlorn wife, Sunny (Emily Kuroda).

headline: ‘Breaking’ Review: A Bank Holdup by an Ex-Marine, for Benefits
abstract: John Boyega plays a veteran at the end of his rope in this fact-based story of grievance and hostage-taking.
lead_paragraph: In July, 2017, a former Marine named Brian Easley walked into a Wells Fargo branch in Marietta, Ga., and presented a note saying he was carrying a bomb. Easley had no intention of robbing the bank. Rather, his ill-conceived plan was to air his grievance with the Department of Veterans Affairs. He had come to rely on payments he was due, and they had been withheld.

headline: Former British Ambassador Is Arrested in Myanmar
abstract: Vicky Bowman is among several foreigners who have been arrested in the Southeast Asian nation after the military seized power in a coup last year.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s military regime has arrested a former British ambassador and her Burmese husband, charging them both with violating immigration law, according to two people with knowledge of their situation.

headline: ‘The Good Boss’ Review: Company Man
abstract: As the titular boss of this dark comedy from Spain, Javier Bardem engages in underhanded tactics to win an award for business excellence.
lead_paragraph: Julio Blanco (Javier Bardem), the boss of “The Good Boss,” is introduced giving a pep talk to his factory employees, with his words underlined by a jaunty, clarinet-infused score.

headline: A Room With a View (and Some Fresh Air)
abstract: A study reveals where home buyers have the best chance of finding homes with good views and air quality.
lead_paragraph: Choosing the right home isn’t all about the bedrooms, baths and square footage. What’s outside matters, too, and a good view can make a big difference. If you can open a window and breathe in some fresh air, all the better!

headline: Student Loan Relief Kicks Off Heated Debate
abstract: President Biden’s landmark move to wipe out billions in student loan debt has drawn criticism and praise from all corners.
lead_paragraph: It’s official. President Biden announced yesterday that the federal government would cancel billions in student debt. The move, which promises to offer widespread relief for tens of millions of Americans, has ignited a fiscal debate and raised the possibility of opening a deep political rift that could rival those created by last year’s stimulus check scuffle and the 2008 bank bailouts.

headline: Peloton, struggling to sell its gear, reports a $1.2 billion loss.
abstract: The maker of exercise bikes attributed part of the loss to restructuring charges related to supply chain and inventory problems.
lead_paragraph: Peloton, the exercise bike company that saw huge success in the early days of the pandemic only to flounder as sales slowed, reported a $1.2 billion quarterly loss on Thursday as it struggled to sell excess inventory.

headline: Another Measure of California’s Rising Costs
abstract: In San Jose, the average police officer salary is $189,000, not including benefits. That’s almost as much as the mayor’s.
lead_paragraph: As a measure of how expensive the San Francisco Bay Area has become there is, of course, the million-dollar starter home — the one-story house with a small garden that would go for less than $400,000 in most other parts of the country.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Bebchuk
abstract: Take on Evgeni Bebchuk in a recreation of a Moscow Championship game in Moscow, 1964. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. There are two new puzzles left in this limited series, published each week on Thursdays. Play previous Chess Replay puzzles here.

headline: On Minorca, a Remote Farmhouse Revived as an Upscale Estate
abstract: Plus: men’s wear tailored for a busy New Yorker, new hand care and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Greenwich Village and Harlem.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Greenwich Village and Harlem.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, Harlem and Prospect-Lefferts Gardens.

abstract: This week’s homes are a six-bedroom in Branford, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes are a six-bedroom in Branford, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Laurel Hollow, N.Y.

headline: These Stones Graced the Capitol. They May Soon Be Removed From a Park.
abstract: Unceremoniously abandoned in a national park for decades, they had become an unofficial attraction. There is a plan to relocate them to a storage facility, away from public view.
lead_paragraph: For decades, hundreds of stones that were once part of the United States Capitol Building were abandoned behind a maintenance facility off an unmarked trail at a park in Washington, D.C., delighting visitors.

headline: Winold Reiss, an Immigrant Modernist Way Ahead of His Time
abstract: The German-born artist brought his brand of modernism to the United States and was fascinated by all the different faces he could find here.
lead_paragraph: In 1925, a German immigrant named Winold Reiss was invited to design and illustrate an issue of the journal Survey Graphic devoted to Harlem, the new cultural capital of Black America. So he got together his conté crayons and pastels and went uptown to draw Langston Hughes, Zora Neale Hurston, James Weldon Johnson and other eminences of what would come to be called the Harlem Renaissance, along with various of their less famous neighbors.

headline: Dollar Stores Report Higher Sales as Shoppers Seek Inflation Relief
abstract: American consumers are gravitating toward less expensive stores as inflation drives up rent, food and fuel costs.
lead_paragraph: The two largest chains of dollar stores in the country posted higher sales and profits in their latest quarter, a sign that consumers are flocking to discount retailers as rapid inflation eats into their budgets.

headline: Judge Orders Redacted Affidavit Used in Trump Search Warrant to Be Unsealed
abstract: The document will be unsealed by noon Friday. In its most complete form, it would disclose important details about the government’s justification for searching Mar-a-Lago this month.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the affidavit in the search of Trump’s Mar-a-Lago home.

headline: Bright Lights, Big City, Niche Fame
abstract: As Lower Manhattan’s most infamous publicist, Kaitlin Phillips doesn’t always stay behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: At Lucien, the always crowded art-world-adjacent French restaurant in the East Village, there is a long table right next to the curb that did not exist until Thanksgiving 2021, which is when the publicist Kaitlin Phillips decided that it must.

headline: Why Europe’s Electricity Prices Are Soaring
abstract: Reverberations from the war in Ukraine have “distorted” the market for natural gas, forcing energy prices up.
lead_paragraph: Energy traders in Europe are witnessing price increases that are hard to fathom. Natural gas, which is used to generate electricity and heat, now costs about 10 times more than it did a year ago. Electricity prices, tied to the price of gas, are also several times higher than what used to be considered normal.

headline: Ads Begin in Texas Governor Race, With O’Rourke’s Highlighting Abortion
abstract: Last week, Gov. Greg Abbott released a first ad and, on Thursday, Beto O’Rourke, the former El Paso congressman and perennial Democratic hopeful, countered with two of his own.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With early voting now two months away, the ad competition has begun in the race for Texas governor. Last week, Gov. Greg Abbott released a first ad and, on Thursday, Beto O’Rourke, the former El Paso congressman and perennial Democratic hopeful, countered with two of his own.

headline: Spiders Are Caught in a Global Web of Misinformation
abstract: Researchers looked at thousands of spider news stories to study how sensationalized information spreads. Their findings could be broadly applicable.
lead_paragraph: We live in a world filled with spiders. And fear of spiders. They crawl around our minds as much as they crawl around our closets, reducing the population of insects that would otherwise bug us. Is that one in the corner, unassumingly spinning its web, venomous? Will it attack me? Should I kill it? Could it be — no, it can’t be — but, maybe it is — a black widow?

headline: Spider Facts, Spider Fiction
abstract: It's time to correct the record for some of world's eight-legged creatures.
lead_paragraph: It's time to correct the record for some of world's eight-legged creatures.

headline: U.N. Report on Rights Abuses in Xinjiang May Be Delayed Again
abstract: The high commissioner for human rights has repeatedly postponed its release, reinforcing perceptions that U.N. leadership is reluctant to stand up to China.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations top human rights official, Michelle Bachelet, has signaled that she might not release a long-awaited report about allegations of abuses in China’s far western region of Xinjiang before she leaves office next week, as she had promised. The delay of that report, which Beijing has worked to block, has already exposed her to fierce criticism from human rights groups.

headline: The Kitchen Will Spend Some Creative Time in a Westbeth Loft
abstract: During a renovation of its Chelsea space, the Kitchen will move to Westbeth, which houses artists, the Martha Graham company and much avant-garde history.
lead_paragraph: Two storied New York City arts organizations, both with origins in the early 1970s, will soon share a roof, as the Kitchen temporarily relocates to Westbeth Artist Housing. The Kitchen announced the move on Thursday.

headline: A Children’s Show About Everything, Especially Music
abstract: The creator behind the series “Bluey” on Disney+ says, “I didn’t want the usual kids’ TV scoring.”
lead_paragraph: “Ladies and gentlemen! I will now play for you the ‘Rondo alla Turca.’”

headline: Citigroup’s Consumer Bank in Russia Was for Sale. Now It’s Just Closing.
abstract: The bank will wind down its retail and local commercial banking services in the country by closing branches and laying off workers.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup announced on Thursday that it would wind down the retail and local commercial banking services in Russia that it had earlier hoped to sell.

headline: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant was cut off from Ukraine’s grid, leading to outages, officials say.
abstract: The director of the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog said that the episode underscored the danger at the plant, where shelling has damaged power lines and other infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s largest nuclear power plant was disconnected from the nation’s power grid on Thursday for the first time in its history, Ukrainian officials said, leading to large-scale power outages in nearly all the Russia-occupied cities of southern Ukraine.

headline: Why Aren’t Subway Stations Air-Conditioned?
abstract: A few stations have the ability to cool the platforms. What would it take to avoid the subterranean heat wave?
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon on the Lexington Avenue line’s downtown platform at Grand Central, Ajah Harley waited for his train and did what pretty much all of his fellow subway riders do at this time of year: sweat.

headline: How to Clean Baking Sheets
abstract: You don't actually have to get rid of that dark patina.
lead_paragraph: You don't actually have to get rid of that dark patina.

headline: ‘Out of the Blue’ Review: The Spider and the Fly
abstract: An unhappy wife leads her younger lover down a dangerous path in this sexy, yet predictable drama from Neil LaBute.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Marilyn Chambers (Diane Kruger) sashays from the ocean in “Out of the Blue,” a vision in a sizzling orange swimsuit, we sense she’s bad news. (And not just because her creator is Neil LaBute, a director not known for writing sympathetic characters.) There’s something about the way she appraises the handsome young stranger, Connor Bates (Ray Nicholson), who’s watching her approach with puppyish delight. Like her adult-movie namesake, Marilyn knows how to cultivate male lust.

headline: Will Your Dog Get Dementia? A Large New Study Offers Clues.
abstract: The risk of canine cognitive dysfunction, a.k.a. “doggy dementia,” is far greater in dogs who don’t get enough exercise, researchers found. Their risk factors echo some in humans, whose homes they share.
lead_paragraph: Around the time Dante turned 8, he started to seem a little off. The 70-pound Bernese mountain dog would pace his family’s home in Interlaken, N.Y., like a caged bear. Then he might stand stock still, staring trance-like at the pedals of the family’s organ. Or at a corner of a room. In the middle of the night, he would wake up and begin barking incessantly, for no obvious reason.

headline: Still Unvaccinated, Djokovic Says He Will Miss the U.S. Open
abstract: Djokovic said he wouldn’t be able to travel to New York for the tournament that begins next week. The U.S. has travel restrictions that require foreign visitors to be vaccinated against Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: In January, Novak Djokovic went before a panel of judges in Australia, seeking special permission to play tennis in the country while being unvaccinated against Covid-19. After a last-ditch hearing, he was turned away.

headline: Lords of Silicon Valley, Say No to NIMBY
abstract: Readers discuss the lack of affordable housing in the region. Also: Hudson Valley’s housing crisis; weaponizing nuclear power; congressional races; OB-GYNs’ fears.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Howard Slusher, Sports Agent Known for His Toughness, Dies at 85
abstract: For years, his hardball tactics, including holding out players for as long as a year to win bigger contracts, made him the enemy of team owners.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, when he was seeking a new contract for Randy White, the future Hall of Fame defensive tackle for the Dallas Cowboys, the agent Howard Slusher advised him to hold out — stay away from the team until he got what he wanted — a familiar tactic in Mr. Slusher’s arsenal.

headline: ‘Adieu Godard’ Review: A Poor Imitation
abstract: This limp satire about an Indian villager’s encounter with the movies of Jean-Luc Godard rehashes regressive stereotypes and squanders a potent premise.
lead_paragraph: Amartya Bhattacharyya’s “Adieu Godard,” about a porn-addicted Indian villager who chances upon the French classic “Breathless” (1960), tries to milk comedy from a condescending premise: that uneducated villagers are too dumb to understand the cinema of Jean-Luc Godard. Instead, this limp satire only proves that no one fails to understand Godard as spectacularly as filmmakers who think they do.

headline: ‘Private Desert’ Review: Into the Valley of Repression
abstract: This L.G.B.T.Q. drama from Brazil follows a distraught police academy instructor with a history of violence as he searches for his mysterious online girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: Set in Brazil, where the crime rates against transgender and queer people are among the highest in the world, the L.G.B.T.Q. drama “Private Desert” follows a brawny police academy instructor, Daniel (Antonio Saboia), during a period of intense vulnerability — and, ultimately, transformation.

headline: Morgan Taylor, Inventive Children’s Performer, Dies at 52
abstract: His popular character Gustafer Yellowgold was aimed at youngsters and, more generally, “people who enjoy humor and absurdity and good pop music.”
lead_paragraph: Morgan Taylor, a children’s performer who with fanciful songs and hand-drawn animation drew youngsters into the world of Gustafer Yellowgold, a saffron-colored explorer from the sun who shared a house with an eel and enjoyed music by a rock band made up of bees, died on Aug. 11 in Miamisburg, Ohio, near Dayton. He was 52.
