headline: How to Get Published: A Book’s Journey From ‘Very Messy’ Draft to Best Seller
abstract: The mainstream publishing industry is intimidating. How does a writer break in? Follow Jessamine Chan’s “The School for Good Mothers” through the roller coaster of its creation.
lead_paragraph: Jessamine Chan spent five years drafting her book. It was her first — a novel about a mother who loses custody of her toddler after one “very bad day,” and then, in a surreal twist, is sent to an experimental “school for good mothers.”

headline: Serena Williams Has a Path to Proceed in U.S. Open
abstract: Williams, who has said the Open is most likely her final tournament, will play 80th-ranked Danka Kovinic in the first round on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Unseeded and ranked No. 608, the great Serena Williams could have been drawn to face all manner of opposition in the opening round of her farewell U.S. Open.

headline: Fresh Off a Series of Victories, Biden Steps Back Onto the Campaign Trail
abstract: But embracing the role of the Democratic Party’s top campaigner will mean confronting Republican attacks when nearly three-quarters of voters say the country is heading in the wrong direction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden is preparing for one of the biggest tests of his presidency: Can he save his party?

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’: Who Is Otto Hightower, and Why Does He Matter?
abstract: The King’s Hand in “Dragon” belongs to House Hightower, a minor presence in “Game of Thrones” but a major player in the prequel. Here’s some background.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to read the new characters in HBO’s “House of the Dragon” through a “Game of Thrones” lens, to see the dragon-riding princess Rhaenyra (played as a youth by Milly Alcock) as the new Daenerys (Emilia Clarke). Other parallels between the two shows exist as well, though they are perhaps less obvious.

headline: Sean Hannity and Other Fox Stars Face Depositions in Defamation Suit
abstract: The depositions are one of the clearest indications yet of how aggressively Dominion Voting Systems is moving forward with its suit against the media company.
lead_paragraph: Some of the biggest names at Fox News have been questioned, or are scheduled to be questioned in the coming days, by lawyers representing Dominion Voting Systems in its $1.6 billion defamation suit against the network, as the election technology company presses ahead with a case that First Amendment scholars say is extraordinary in its scope and significance.

headline: At the U.S. Open, 5 Artists Get a Place in the Sun
abstract: Five sculptures, created by artists from underrepresented communities, will find a place in the sun at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens until Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: Sculptures by five artists went on view at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens, Tuesday during Fan Week, six days of festivities and qualifying tournaments. The five works, which will remain on view until Sept. 11, are in collaboration with the Armory Show and the United States Tennis Association and serve as an extension of Armory Off-Site and the tennis association’s Be Open social justice campaign, which first presented paintings in 2020 from 18 Black and Indigenous artists at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Florida Pair Pleads Guilty in Theft of Biden’s Daughter’s Diary
abstract: Aimee Harris and Robert Kurlander admitted to participating in a conspiracy in which Ashley Biden’s diary ended up in the hands of the conservative group Project Veritas near the end of the 2020 campaign.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors presented new evidence on Thursday implicating the conservative group Project Veritas in the theft of a diary and items belonging to Ashley Biden, President Biden’s daughter, laying out in court papers their fullest account yet of how allies of President Donald J. Trump tried to use the diary to undercut Mr. Biden in the final days of the 2020 campaign.

headline: Soups and Stews for Summer
abstract: Recipes for when you need some coziness and comfort on a hot day.
lead_paragraph: I can’t stop thinking about Yewande Komolafe’s delicious version of asaro. She published her recipe for the southern Nigerian dish a couple of years ago, after a trip to Lagos, and its perfect for when you’re craving something with a bit of warmth and substance.

headline: Biden’s Student Loan Forgiveness Plan Divides Democrats
abstract: Democratic candidates had starkly different responses to President Biden’s plan, with splits along racial and generational lines and among those in tight races.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s executive order Wednesday to cancel thousands of dollars in college debt for millions of Americans has divided Democratic candidates like few other policies of his administration, with some Democrats using the plan to distance themselves from a president who could prove to be a heavy burden in their states and districts.

headline: The Russian president signed a decree to add 137,000 service members to the military starting next year.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday ordered a sharp increase in the size of his armed forces, a reversal of years of efforts by the Kremlin to slim down a bloated military and the latest sign that the Russian president, despite heavy battlefield losses, is bracing for a long war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday ordered a sharp increase in the size of his armed forces, a reversal of years of efforts by the Kremlin to slim down a bloated military and the latest sign that the Russian president, despite heavy battlefield losses, is bracing for a long war in Ukraine.

headline: ‘Seoul Vibe’ Review: Grinding Gears
abstract: Set in 1988, this Korean action comedy follows a blithe driving team that goes undercover with holdovers from the old military leadership.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, the Korean action comedy “Seoul Vibe” resembles any studio product getting a kick out of careening cars and snazzy retro gear. But the setting is 1988, when South Korea was transitioning toward freer elections after years of military dictatorship. The heroes of the movie are a driving team with their own custom-car garage, while the baddies hail from the corrupt old regime and have millions stashed away. (Chun Doo-hwan, the era’s ruling general, died last November and was in fact convicted of collecting massive bribes.)

headline: 14 Chicken Recipes Our Readers Can’t Get Enough Of
abstract: Baked, tossed into a salad, served with rice, and more ways to prepare everyone’s favorite poultry.
lead_paragraph: A chicken dinner shouldn’t be a gamble; it should leave you feeling like a winner, winner.

headline: ‘Three Thousand Years of Longing’ Review: Desire, Once Upon a Time
abstract: George Miller directs a visually sumptuous, grown-up fairy tale with Tilda Swinton and Idris Elba. It jumps across time but too often just stumbles.
lead_paragraph: There are storytellers, and then there is Scheherazade, the savvy bride who in “One Thousand and One Nights” entertains her husband, the king of Persia, by telling him stories. The king has a nasty habit of killing his wives, so to keep her head Scheherazade practices narrative interruptus: Each night, she relates wondrous tales without finishing them, keeping him hooked on her cliffhangers so that she can live another day. For her, storytelling is life.

headline: Why Peloton Is Selling on Amazon
abstract: The dream was to sell directly to customers. Now Peloton is on Amazon, Casper is in a furniture shop, and it’s awkward.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, I bought an online mattress — in a boring, conventional store.

headline: Europe’s Elite Learn Their Champions League Opponents
abstract: Manchester City will face Borussia Dortmund, from whom it bought the star striker Erling Haaland.
lead_paragraph: Real Madrid, the defending champion and winner of five of the last 10 Champions Leagues, will face RB Leipzig, Shakhtar Donetsk and Celtic in this year’s competition after the draw was held in Istanbul on Thursday evening.

headline: Scuba Diver Is Fined After Getting Too Close to Killer Whales
abstract: Canadian investigators said the diver “attempted to motor ahead of the whale pod several times” in British Columbia in 2020. He was fined 12,000 Canadian dollars.
lead_paragraph: A scuba diver was fined 12,000 Canadian dollars for swimming too close to a group of killer whales, a threatened species, in British Columbia two years ago, the authorities said this week.

headline: Austin Orders Overhaul to Better Protect Civilians During U.S. Combat Operations
abstract: A Pentagon plan envisions broad changes to military doctrine, planning and training aimed at mitigating the risk of harm to noncombatants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Thursday announced sweeping changes aimed at reducing risks to civilians in U.S. military operations by fostering a culture in which those in the field view preventing such harm as a core part of their missions.

headline: ‘Funny Pages’ Review: Ordinary Life, Complex Stuff
abstract: Owen Kline’s wonderful feature debut about an aspiring comic-book creator delves into a buzzingly alive, if anxious, world of cartooning.
lead_paragraph: The young director Owen Kline packs worlds of cringe into “Funny Pages” — shame, disgust, embarrassment, sweaty sexual panic, acres of pustules — it’s all here in this terrific, tonally flawless feature debut. Scabrous, painful and true, it tracks a high school senior who, in his ambitions to be a comic-book artist of the highest, purest order, steamrollers over nearly everyone in his life. No one is spared in this portrait of a young artist as a pain in the butt.

headline: ‘Samaritan’ Review: Taking Out the Trash
abstract: In this action film from Julius Avery, Sylvester Stallone stars as a sanitation worker who may be a superhero.
lead_paragraph: “Samaritan,” a grouchy time-waster directed by Julius Avery, pounds the sidewalks of a fictitious city where decades ago, the super siblings Samaritan and Nemesis — mortal enemies and twins — dueled to the death, yet continue on as spray-painted symbols of hope and rage. A 13-year-old petty thief named Sam (Javon Walton) yearns to believe that the gallant brother secretly survived, and might even be his neighbor, Joe Smith (Sylvester Stallone), a sanitation worker with a penchant for musty action hero quips. (“Going my way?” he grunts to an elevator of goons.)

headline: The Creep of History
abstract: Too much focus on the sins of the past can distract us from the injustices of the present.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the historian James Sweet found himself in the middle of one of the confusing messes that pop up from time to time in the highest reaches of academia. As the president of the American Historical Association, Sweet writes a monthly address to his colleagues. His September entry, published on Aug. 17, was titled, “Is History History? Identity Politics and Teleologies of the Present.” What followed was a seemingly harmless missive about “presentism,” a phenomenon wherein historians allow the political, identity-based demands of the current day to dictate the focus of their scholarship and inquiry. Paraphrasing one of his predecessors, Sweet asked if students who enter the field with a fixed, identity-first point of view might be better suited to sociology, political science or ethnic studies.

headline: Psilocybin Therapy Sharply Reduces Excessive Drinking, Small Study Shows
abstract: Researchers said the results offered promise to the millions of Americans with alcohol use disorder.
lead_paragraph: A small study on the therapeutic effects of using psychedelics to treat alcohol use disorder found that just two doses of psilocybin magic mushrooms paired with psychotherapy led to an 83 percent decline in heavy drinking among the participants. Those given a placebo reduced their alcohol intake by 51 percent.

headline: Biden’s Student Loan Plan Squarely Targets the Middle Class
abstract: President Biden is offering what independent analysts suggest would be his most targeted assistance yet to middle-class workers — while trying to repair what he casts as a broken bridge to the middle class.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The big winners from President Biden’s plan to forgive hundreds of billions of dollars in student loans are not rich graduates of Harvard and Yale, as many critics claim.

headline: Ingrid Andress, a Nashville Outsider Who Paved Her Own Path In
abstract: The singer-songwriter almost gave up on country music. Instead, her debut earned her a Grammy nod for best new artist. Now she’s back with an LP about the arc of a relationship.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When Ingrid Andress answered the door at her home in her hilly Nashville suburb one afternoon in July, feet bare and hair wet as she gamely played host before hurrying off to a tour date, a shiny Yamaha grand piano was visible behind her.

headline: ‘A Stirring of Democratic Hearts’: Three Writers Discuss a Transformed Midterm Landscape
abstract: In November, Democrats may do much better than anyone once thought possible.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted an online conversation with Molly Jong-Fast, the writer of the “Wait, What?” newsletter for The Atlantic, and Doug Sosnik, a former senior adviser to President Bill Clinton, to discuss whether the Democrats have shifted the narrative of the midterm elections.

headline: A Painter Whose Subjects Are His Siblings
abstract: A look at two of Keith Jackson's works, both featuring his family.
lead_paragraph: A look at two of Keith Jackson's works, both featuring his family.

headline: Biden and Zelensky reaffirm their alliance as the war enters its seventh month.
abstract: WASHINGTON — President Biden talked with President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday, White House officials said, reaffirming U.S. support for Ukraine as Russia’s invasion stretches into its seventh month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden talked with President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday, White House officials said, reaffirming U.S. support for Ukraine as Russia’s invasion stretches into its seventh month.

headline: Georgia Governor Seeks to Keep Distance From Trump Inquiry
abstract: Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican locked in a tight race for re-election against Stacey Abrams, a Democrat, is fighting a subpoena.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Gov. Brian Kemp was one of the Georgia Republican officials who declined to help Donald J. Trump overturn his 2020 election loss in the state — a decision that had him hailed as a hero in some quarters.

headline: We Might Never Know How Much the Internet Is Hiding From Us
abstract: Important information is getting drowned out online by a lot of trollish junk.
lead_paragraph: The internet is the most comprehensive compendium of human knowledge ever assembled, but is its size a feature or a bug? Does its very immensity undermine its utility as a source of information? How often is it burying valuable data under lots of junk? Say you search for some famous or semifamous person — a celebrity, influencer, politician or pundit. Are you getting an accurate picture of that person’s life or a false, manipulated one?

headline: Death of Rep. Tom McClintock’s Wife Tied to White Mulberry Leaf
abstract: The Sacramento County Coroner’s Office said Lori McClintock died in December 2021 of dehydration caused by stomach inflammation from consuming the herbal remedy.
lead_paragraph: The Sacramento County Coroner’s Office determined earlier this year that the 2021 death of Loretta McClintock, the wife of Representative Tom McClintock, Republican of California, was caused by “adverse effects” from ingestion of white mulberry leaf.

headline: Starbucks Illegally Denied Raises to Union Members, Labor Board Says
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board is seeking compensation for workers whom it said the company had shortchanged.
lead_paragraph: Federal labor regulators have accused Starbucks of illegally discriminating against unionized employees by denying them wage and benefit increases that the company put in place for nonunion employees.

headline: Oklahoma Executes Man Despite Clemency Recommendation
abstract: James Coddington, who was convicted of murdering a co-worker with a hammer, is the first of 25 men the state is aiming to execute over the next 28 months.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma executed a man on Thursday for killing a co-worker in 1997, rejecting the recommendation of a state pardon board as it carried out the first in a series of 25 executions scheduled over the next 28 months.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic’s latest recommendations? Three terrific, highly specific comedies.
lead_paragraph: ‘Mo’When to watch: Now, on Netflix.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: U.N. Delays Report on Abuse in Xinjiang
abstract: Plus an expansion of Russia’s armed forces and France’s proposal to ban private jets
lead_paragraph: Michelle Bachelet, the U.N.’s top human rights official, promised in June that she would release a long-awaited report about allegations of abuses in China’s far western region of Xinjiang before she left office. Her tenure ends next week, and yet she signaled on Thursday that she might not meet that deadline.

headline: Remote Scan of Student’s Room Before Test Violated His Privacy, Judge Rules
abstract: A federal judge said Cleveland State University violated the Fourth Amendment when it used software to scan a student’s bedroom, a practice that has grown during the Covid-19 pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said on Monday that it was unconstitutional for a university in Ohio to virtually scan the bedroom of a chemistry student before he took a remote test, a decision that could affect how schools use remote-monitoring software popularized during the Covid-19 pandemic.

headline: What Next
abstract: We look ahead at how the next stage of the war might shape up.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: E. Bryant Crutchfield, 85, Dies; Gave the World the Trapper Keeper
abstract: His ability to blend the fun and the functional with the binder he invented brought order to the chaos of grade-school life in the 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: E. Bryant Crutchfield, a paper-company executive who in the early 1980s brought three-ringed order to the chaos of millions of grade-school backpacks with a plastic-and-cardboard triptych he called the Trapper Keeper, died on Sunday at a hospice center in Marietta, Ga. He was 85.

headline: Authorities Identify Remains Found at Lake Mead
abstract: Two decades ago, a man vanished in the water in front of his children. This week, their DNA samples helped to identify his remains, among several discovered recently amid a drought.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a regular summer outing on Lake Mead for the Erndt family.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The Books desk has a number of avid walkers on its staff, which makes a certain kind of sense: Like reading, walking rewards a leisurely pace, an obsessive focus and a wholesome embrace of the unknown. And if you count audiobooks as reading, you can do both at the same time. (I don’t recommend walking while reading the usual way; that’s how I broke my foot a few years ago.) Lately, though, I’ve fallen out of the audiobook habit because my intrepid colleague Tina Jordan, a walker herself, introduced me to the Merlin bird identification app from Cornell University, and now I stroll with one eye on my phone and one ear to the trees, listening for warbles and coos and trills. As I told Tina: This is the real Twitter app right here.

headline: In Sarah Nurse, a Found Voice for Hockey
abstract: Nurse, 27, is the first Black woman to win Olympic gold in women’s hockey. Before she set the single-tournament points record in Beijing, she faced years of underestimation.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Not even six years ago — before Sarah Nurse’s Olympic medals, before the Olympic record she set, before the Cheerios boxes and Barbie dolls bearing her image — Canada was content to leave her off its national women’s hockey team.

headline: The U.S. State Department and Yale identify 21 detention sites in Russian-controlled territory.
abstract: The sites are sometimes used to deport prisoners. And researchers found evidence of disturbed earth on two recent occasions consistent with mass graves.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. State Department and Yale University researchers said Thursday that they had identified at least 21 sites in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine that the Russian military or Russian-backed Ukrainian separatists are using to detain, interrogate or deport civilians and prisoners of war in ways that violate international humanitarian law. There were signs pointing to possible mass graves in some areas, they said.

headline: Spain Passes Law Requiring ‘Freely Expressed’ Consent for Sex
abstract: The law comes six years after the gang rape of an 18-year-old woman stirred mass protests and a general reckoning over the rights of sexual abuse victims.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, an 18-year-old woman was raped in a building lobby by five men during the bull-running festival in Pamplona, Spain. The men filmed it on a cellphone video, which showed her still and with her eyes shut during the assault.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Creed Taylor, Producer Who Shaped Jazz for Decades, Dies at 93
abstract: He made scores of albums with artists who were well known and others who soon would be. He also founded two important record labels.
lead_paragraph: Creed Taylor, one of the most influential and prolific jazz producers of the second half of the last century, best known for the distinctive work he did for his CTI label in the 1970s, died on Monday in Nuremberg, Germany. He was 93.

headline: Penalized for Misconduct, a Top Official Returns to the U.S. Open
abstract: Soeren Friemel served a one-year suspension and lost a top officiating job for inappropriate communication with an underling. The decision to bring him back has rankled some colleagues.
lead_paragraph: The people who officiate tennis matches are supposed to exist in a quiet corner of the sports world, far from the spotlight. In most cases, if average fans know the name of a tournament referee, supervisor, chair umpire or line judge, something has gone terribly wrong, creating rare noise within an insular club whose members value rules and decorum over all else.

headline: Alex Jones Accused of Hiding Assets From Sandy Hook Families
abstract: The Infowars fabulist has been funneling millions out of his empire while claiming bankruptcy, the Sandy Hook families suing him say.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Hook victims’ families asked a federal bankruptcy court on Thursday to order the Infowars conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones to relinquish control over his company, saying he has “systematically transferred millions of dollars” to himself and his relatives while claiming to be broke.

headline: Howard Rosenthal, Who Quantified Partisanship in Congress, Dies at 83
abstract: He took part in studies that found the widening ideological divide to be the largest since post-Civil War Reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: Prof. Howard Rosenthal, a political scientist whose pioneering research confirmed quantitatively that Congress is more politically polarized than at any point since Reconstruction, died on July 28 at his home in San Francisco. He was 83.

headline: Cluster munitions have killed nearly 700 in Ukraine, a study reports.
abstract: Cluster munitions have killed at least 689 people in Ukraine in the six months since Russia invaded the country, the Cluster Munition Coalition, an international disarmament group, said in its annual report on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Cluster munitions have killed at least 689 people in Ukraine in the six months since Russia invaded the country, the Cluster Munition Coalition, an international disarmament group, said in its annual report on Thursday.

headline: California E.V. Mandate Finds a Receptive Auto Industry
abstract: The move to phase out gasoline-powered cars, with other states expected to follow, matches automakers’ plans. The challenge will be making it happen.
lead_paragraph: For years, as California has moved ahead with ambitious clean-air regulations, the state has had to prod the auto industry to go along. Now, in the push to electrify the nation’s car fleet, it is California that is keeping up with automakers.

headline: Some on the Left Turn Against the Label ‘Progressive’
abstract: Democrats ran away from being called “liberal” in the 1990s. Now, a new breed of intellectuals wants them to ditch the word “progressive,” too.
lead_paragraph: The very word “progress” is embedded in the term “progressive,” a label that has become ubiquitous in recent years as many on the left embrace it over its predecessor, “liberal.”

headline: The Two Big Questions About Student Debt Relief
abstract: No, helping former students won’t cause inflation to explode.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, President Biden announced a plan to reduce most students’ debt by $10,000, with lower-income students eligible for twice that amount. The debt forgiveness was much less generous than many progressives wanted but more generous than many expected. Assuming it survives legal challenges, it will be a big deal for millions of Americans, although the overall economic impact will, as I’ll explain, be limited.

headline: Why Your Social Life Is Not What It Should Be
abstract: You’ll enjoy talking to strangers a lot more than you think you will.
lead_paragraph: One day Nicholas Epley was commuting by train to his office at the University of Chicago. As a behavioral scientist he’s well aware that social connection makes us happier, healthier and more successful and generally contributes to the sweetness of life. Yet he looked around his train car and realized: Nobody is talking to anyone! It was just headphones and newspapers.

headline: Putin Orders a Sharp Expansion of Russia’s Hard-Hit Armed Forces
abstract: The decree suggests that President Vladimir V. Putin expects a prolonged war in Ukraine, but he stopped short of full mobilization, and it was not clear how the military would reach his goal.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday ordered a sharp increase in the size of Russia’s armed forces, a reversal of years of efforts by the Kremlin to slim down a bloated military and the latest sign that he is bracing for a long war in Ukraine, where Russia has suffered heavy losses.

headline: Ghislaine Maxwell’s Own Lawyers Are Now Suing Her
abstract: The law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman has accused Ms. Maxwell and her brother of failing to pay nearly $900,000 in legal fees related to her sex abuse defense.
lead_paragraph: As Ghislaine Maxwell’s conspiracy and sex trafficking trial drew to a close last year, one of her lawyers rose to provide what would be the defense’s final word.

headline: Liberty Reflect on a Season of Changes
abstract: Under a first-year coach, the young team dealt with injuries and inconsistency before losing in the first round of the W.N.B.A. playoffs to the reigning champion Chicago Sky.
lead_paragraph: Two words echoed among the Liberty’s players in the days before the start of the W.N.B.A. season: “defense” and “identity.”

headline: How to Track Down Your Vaccine History
abstract: There are ways to figure out what you’ve been vaccinated for, even if you have no hope of finding the original records.
lead_paragraph: Melinda Wenner Moyer is out this week. I’m Knvul Sheikh, a reporter on the Well desk, filling in today.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Texas Law Barring Adults Under 21 From Carrying Handguns
abstract: The federal judge ruled that the Second Amendment, “as informed by Founding-era history and tradition,” did not exclude 18- to 20-year-olds from the right to carry handguns.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Fort Worth struck down a Texas law on Thursday that prohibits adults under 21 from carrying handguns, on the grounds that the restriction violated the Second Amendment.

headline: White House Pushes Journals to Drop Paywalls on Publicly Funded Research
abstract: The policy, hailed by researchers as “transformational,” will be fully in place by 2026 and make publicly financed research available immediately at no cost.
lead_paragraph: Academic journals will have to provide immediate access to papers that are publicly funded, providing a big win for advocates of open research and ending a policy that had allowed publishers to keep publications behind a paywall for a year, according to a White House directive announced on Thursday.

headline: ‘Me Time’ Review: In Search of Lost Dad Jokes
abstract: Kevin Hart and Mark Wahlberg star in this boys’ night out comedy that fails to find its laughs.
lead_paragraph: The hero of the uneasy comedy “Me Time” begins the movie in a flashback, in free-fall. Sonny (Kevin Hart) has just tried to bail on a day of wingsuit gliding with his longtime friend Huck (Mark Wahlberg), but a burst of propelled air has sent him plummeting down the side of the cliff face. Huck dives after, guiding his friend away from certain death. Sonny is saved, but the movie never shakes off this initial sense of panic.

headline: Christie’s to Sell Paul G. Allen’s $1 Billion Art Collection
abstract: The sale, which is expected to be the biggest in auction history for a private collection, will offer works from the Microsoft co-founder’s impressive cache that ranges from old masters to contemporary giants.
lead_paragraph: In the art world’s latest eye-popping development, Christie’s auction house announced on Thursday that it would sell the impressive art collection of Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who died in 2018. The trove, which includes masterpieces by Renoir and Roy Lichtenstein, has an estimated valued of more than $1 billion.

headline: 50/50 Chance
abstract: You can count on Robert Logan’s Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — What’s this? A theme on a Friday? This must be The Times’s karmic balance to this past Sunday’s themeless tour de force by Brooke Husic and Will Nediger. And as themes go, this one, in a debut by Robert Logan, is so subtle that you could be forgiven for not noticing it at all.

headline: Review: A Faithful ‘Kinky Boots,’ With All Its Pizazz and Pitfalls
abstract: The Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein musical, in which the drag queen Lola saves a provincial shoe factory, makes an Off Broadway return at the spacious Stage 42.
lead_paragraph: You can’t keep a drag queen down, at least not for long. It was only April 2019 that the Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein musical “Kinky Boots” closed on Broadway after a six-year run, and already it’s back in town. The Britain-set show, in which the statuesque performer Lola saves a provincial shoe factory by inspiring a line of toweringly outré footwear, is now running Off Broadway.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Don’t let this tough puzzle make you nervous; Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon can smell fear from miles away.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This unconventional excerpt took me a while to piece together. Just as I was getting frustrated, I learned that its focus was as plain as a prominent feature on one’s face. So was the focus of its source, a 2003 book by Gabrielle Glaser called “The Nose: A Profile of Sex, Beauty and Survival.” I found this funny and interesting — the whole nose angle, I mean — and I loved how quickly my mind started coming up with faint scents of freshly mowed grass and zoo animals, among others.

headline: From the First Date, Looking the Part of Husband and Wife
abstract: Caroline Hubbard and Michael McMillan II met when he ran into her at a bar. On their first date, there were already signs of a future together.
lead_paragraph: On their first date, at a Manhattan wine bar in May 2016, a waiter mistakenly referred to Michael Angelo McMillan II as Caroline Benning Hubbard’s husband.

headline: Lockdown Was Our Romantic Bubble, but Bubbles Burst
abstract: Our connection began behind masks, with eyes only, and grew so deep so fast that I began to dread a return to normal here in Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: During the two months of lockdown last spring in Shanghai, residents were mostly confined to their homes and hallways. For a single woman like me who, at 29, lives alone and is self-employed, my entire life was reduced to me, myself and I.

headline: When a Dating App Didn’t Work, an Old-Fashioned Setup Did
abstract: Shafin Fattah first encountered Luvana Chowdhury on a Muslim dating app, but she never responded when he expressed interest. Months later, at the suggestion of a mutual friend, they had a first date.
lead_paragraph: Shafin Fattah’s chance at a relationship with Luvana Chowdhury didn’t seem too promising when she never responded after he swiped right on her profile on Muzmatch, a Muslim dating app now called Muzz, in late 2020.

headline: At Karaoke and as a Couple, Always in Unison
abstract: Zohar Fuller and Maryse Pearce, who bonded in part over a love of theater, started dating soon after they performed a duet of “Build Me Up Buttercup” at karaoke.
lead_paragraph: Zohar Hannah Fuller spent about a year inviting Maryse Shaina Pearce to events before Ms. Pearce finally attended one.

headline: ‘It Was Magic From the First Second’
abstract: When Chelsea White, a writer and producer, first met Tash Neal, a musician, their attraction was instant. By the end of their first date, he felt “butterflies” and she found her “dream man.”
lead_paragraph: Chelsea White is a whole lot, in the best possible way. She is charming, self-deprecating, engrossing and describes herself on her website as a “host-writer-producer-speaker-comedian-cat enthusiast.” She developed a weekly Instagram live show, “What a Delight! with Chelsea White,” that involved a guest, a sidekick in a mask, and a discussion of weekly events that entranced her. She wanted to share it with whomever is willing to listen.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Rover, Too, May End Up Struggling with Dementia
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Aug. 26, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It turns out that probably the best model for human aging has been aging alongside of us for hundreds and hundreds of years.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 26, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 26, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 19 about a sculptural billboard on Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood designed by the architect Tom Wiscombe referred to Wiscombe as a professor at Southern California Institute of Architecture in downtown Los Angeles; while he remains a professor there, he has been placed on paid leave. The institute declined to comment on Wiscombe’s leave, which came after students’ criticism of internships at his firm.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Vladimir Putin will expand Russia’s military.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin ordered a sharp increase in the size of Russia’s armed forces yesterday, signaling a lengthy commitment to the war in Ukraine.

headline: Retail Marijuana in New York: Where the Goliaths Bolster the Davids
abstract: Medical marijuana companies are required to assist small retailers. Also, why you will continue to swelter on the subway platform.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll get an update on a new New York industry — retail marijuana. And, in the heat of late August, we’ll look into why subway stations aren’t air-conditioned.

headline: Game Face
abstract: The Thai American heroine of Christina Soontornvat’s graphic novel wrestles with anti-Asian racism while auditioning for the cheerleading squad.
lead_paragraph: The perils of early adolescence are often depicted in broad strokes. The Bully. The Crush. The Zit. But in reality these tender years are much more nuanced. Childhood friendships slowly begin to outgrow themselves and change. Cracks begin to emerge in our once-infallible parents, revealing them to be flawed human beings. Questions of self-identity percolate to the surface, demanding answers.

headline: Bills in Britain Will Soar 80% as Energy Crisis Crashes Into Europe
abstract: A regulator detailed the latest increase in gas and electric charges, driven up by the war in Ukraine and expected to further stoke inflation.
lead_paragraph: For months, a tsunami of high energy costs has borne down on Europe. On Friday, the first big waves crashed ashore in Britain, with the news that household gas and electricity bills will nearly double in October.

headline: Soldiering On
abstract: In “The Secret Battle of Evan Pao,” a Chinese American boy and his family feel as if they’re refighting the U.S. Civil War.
lead_paragraph: In 1860, there were approximately 35,000 Chinese people in the United States, about 200 of whom lived in the Eastern part of the country. Of these, 50-60 would go on to fight in the American Civil War. Most were Union soldiers, but there were exceptions, like the two eldest sons of the famous conjoined twins Chang and Eng Bunker — Christopher Bunker, the son of Chang, and Stephen Bunker, the son of Eng, who were both enslavers (like their fathers) and Confederate soldiers.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: China’s Record Drought Is Drying Rivers and Feeding Its Coal Habit
abstract: Dry weather in southwestern China has crippled huge hydroelectric dams, forcing cities to impose rolling blackouts and driving up the country’s use of coal.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Car assembly plants and electronics factories in southwestern China have closed for lack of power. Owners of electric cars are waiting overnight at charging stations to recharge their vehicles. Rivers are so low there that ships can no longer carry supplies.

headline: The Long Tail of Covid-19 Disinformation
abstract: Almost all of Australia and New Zealand’s pandemic restrictions have been lifted. Yet the protests continue.
lead_paragraph: “Two shots, three shots, four shots, five — how many shots will you survive?”

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's roundup includes a gut-wrenching biography of Dostoyevsky’s second wife, a wisecracking history of law-breaking animals and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's roundup includes a gut-wrenching biography of Dostoyevsky’s second wife, a wisecracking history of law-breaking animals and more.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including George Miller's latest film, "3,000 Years of Longing."
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including George Miller's latest film, "3,000 Years of Longing."

headline: Trump Golf Course in New York City Will Host Saudi-Backed Event
abstract: The Aramco Team Series women’s event, separate from the LIV Golf tour that upended the PGA Tour, will be held at Trump Links at Ferry Point in the Bronx in October.
lead_paragraph: A New York City-owned golf course managed by former President Donald J. Trump’s family business is expected to host a Saudi Arabia-backed tournament in October, a city official confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Democrats Gamble With Ads That Highlight Far-Right Candidates
abstract: With the ads, Democrats hope to push out moderate conservatives who may be fiercer competition in November. Critics say the strategy carries risks.
lead_paragraph: With the ads, Democrats hope to push out moderate conservatives who may be fiercer competition in November. Critics say the strategy carries risks.

headline: Democrats Might Get Exceptionally Lucky This Fall, and They Should Be Ready for That
abstract: If Schumer and Pelosi maintain their majorities, what’s the agenda?
lead_paragraph: Republicans are still favored to gain seats in the midterm elections but are not as favored as you might have thought.

headline: A Nuanced History of the Forces Shaping U.S.-Israel Relations
abstract: In “The Arc of a Covenant,” Walter Russell Mead makes the case that U.S. support for the Jewish state has benefited America more than critics allow.
lead_paragraph: For many decades now, a supposed mystery has lurked at the heart of American foreign policy: Why has the United States supported Israel so staunchly and for so long, especially when doing so seems to come at a high cost in blood, treasure and world opinion?

headline: Monkeypox Cases Are Declining in New York City and Globally
abstract: Rising vaccinations rates combined with changes in sexual behavior have shifted the disease’s trajectory, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: Monkeypox cases are declining in New York City and globally as more people get vaccinated and as they change their sexual behavior in response to the outbreak, health officials said this week.

headline: The Sale of a Product Responsible for Bloodshed and Fear Is Still Tied to Our Wildlife
abstract: Hunters are a small slice of gun buyers these days. But they benefit from a windfall from a tax on guns.
lead_paragraph: Regardless of whether they hunt, gun buyers have long underwritten efforts to conserve and restore American landscapes for hunting with an excise tax that manufacturers pay on the guns, ammunition and archery equipment they produce. For the 2022 fiscal year alone, this tax generated a record $1.1 billion, nearly all of it from guns and ammo.

headline: Webb Telescope Sees a Carbon Dioxide Atmosphere Way Out There
abstract: WASP-39b, a distant world with a mass equivalent to Saturn’s, is the first exoplanet known to harbor the gas.
lead_paragraph: The James Webb Space Telescope is having a fantastic rookie season.

headline: Maternal Instinct Is a Myth That Men Created
abstract: The idea that women arrive at motherhood prepared for the job continues to wreak damage. Can new science help us to let it go?
lead_paragraph: Around the time that Mimi Niles became a mother, an upstairs neighbor in her New York City apartment building had twins. When the two women ran into each other in the hallway or on the sidewalk, Ms. Niles would ask the neighbor how she was faring.

headline: Foreign Films, English Titles and the Dilemma Distributors Face
abstract: Leave as is? Translate? Change altogether? A movie’s success doesn’t depend entirely on what we call it, but it can have a big effect.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, international film releases in the United States reached a new pinnacle with the crowning of Bong Joon Ho’s “Parasite” as best picture at the Academy Awards. But before “Parasite” or any other non-English-language film even hits theaters, a basic question has to be settled: the title.

headline: Donald Trump Is Not Above the Law
abstract: Prosecuting a former president is an unprecedented but necessary step to protect American democracy.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: In a Sweltering Texas Jail, Cool Towels but No Air-Conditioners
abstract: Texas is having its second-hottest summer on record, yet most state prisons and jails have little air-conditioning.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURG, Texas — Rashes from heat are common. Metal furniture is hot to the touch. Hyperthermia and dehydration are a constant risk, mitigated with fans, tepid water and wet towels. Deaths, though rare, have occurred.

headline: What Is ‘the Merge’?
abstract: Here’s what to know about a major software upgrade to Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform.
lead_paragraph: Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform, is set to unveil a new technological infrastructure next month that is designed to reduce its energy consumption by more than 99 percent.

headline: How to Tread Lightly in Fragile Places
abstract: Organizing a responsible visit to sensitive areas like the Galápagos Islands or Antarctica involves research, decoding certifications and possibly a travel adviser.
lead_paragraph: Like the 18 other passengers on the ship Origin, from the expedition cruise company Ecoventura, I went to the Galápagos Islands in May to be awed by nature. Swimming with barrel-rolling sea lions, seeing a blue-footed booby chick peeking out from beneath its mother, kayaking with flamingoes and experiencing the meditative pace of a giant tortoise — all exceeded the goal.

headline: The Seeds Strike Back
abstract: Chia seeds are back (again) — and nutritionists and doctors say there are good reasons for it.
lead_paragraph: Chia seeds are making a comeback — again.

headline: ‌A Social Media Star of a Changed Middle East: An Arab From Israel in Dubai
abstract: Nuseir Yassin, a Palestinian citizen of Israel with nearly 60 million followers, has taken advantage of new diplomatic ties to move to the United Arab Emirates — angering many Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — All along the Dubai waterfront, Nuseir Yassin kept bumping into fans. An Egyptian tourist asked for a photograph. A yacht club manager from Zimbabwe stopped for a chat. A group of Filipinos gasped and called after him.

headline: Can Coco Gauff the Tennis Prodigy Become a Tennis Legend?
abstract: Since Coco Gauff went pro at 14, she has played under the weight of high expectations. Now 18, she has her own measures for greatness.
lead_paragraph: When Coco Gauff arrived in Paris in May for the French Open, she did not expect the tournament to be a milestone in her tennis career. It had already been a tough season: At its start, she flew across the globe to Australia, training and competing for four weeks, only to lose in the first round of the Australian Open. Not long before the French Open, she lost in the first round of a tournament on clay, the surface she would be playing on in Paris. Those kinds of early defeats were not what her fans anticipated from Gauff, who, three years earlier, at 15, proceeded, with astonishing grace and composure, to the fourth round of Wimbledon, defeating her idol Venus Williams along the way. Soon after that win, commentators seemed to be competing to hail Gauff’s promise. Chris Evert predicted she would win a Grand Slam championship, even at 18; John McEnroe declared that she would be No. 1. She was now on her fourth year of the tour, and although her skills were steadily improving, she had yet to meet those expectations.

headline: The Crypto World Can’t Wait for ‘the Merge’
abstract: A long-awaited upgrade to Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform, may make the technology more environmentally sustainable. But it comes with risks.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency industry has endured a terrible year. A devastating crash wiped nearly $1 trillion from the market, draining the savings of thousands of people. Several companies filed for bankruptcy.

headline: With Military Attacks and Mockery, Ukraine Pokes the Russian Bear
abstract: Driven by deep anger at Russia and the need to rally support at home and abroad, Ukraine is regularly goading its much more powerful antagonist.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — It was pure performance art, pointedly aimed at irking the Kremlin: a mock parade staged by Ukraine featuring dozens of captured Russian tanks in Kyiv’s central avenue.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 26, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: A ‘Sea Cow’ That Evoked Mermaids Is Extinct in Chinese Waters, Study Finds
abstract: The study said the dugong, a vegetarian mammal that ranges across Asia and Africa, has essentially vanished from the country’s coastline.
lead_paragraph: The dugong, a species of so-called sea cow that roams the ocean floor in Asia and Africa and is said to have inspired ancient legends of mermaids, has been spotted off China’s southern coast for centuries.

headline: A New Plan for Student Loans
abstract: President Biden said he would wipe out significant amounts of debt for millions of Americans. But questions remain about how the proposal will work.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s announcement this week that he would cancel chunks of student loan debt stands to have a major impact for many of the 45 million Americans who owe $1.6 trillion for having gone to college.

headline: Conspiracy Theories
abstract: How more funding for the I.R.S. became a political firestorm.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz has warned that Democrats’ new spending law will create a “shadow army of 87,000 I.R.S. agents.” Kari Lake, the Republican candidate for Arizona governor, tied the increase in agents to the F.B.I. search of Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago home and warned, “Not a single one of us is safe.” Across social media, conservatives have embraced falsehoods about armed agents, saying that they will target Republicans in particular.

headline: ‘When I Come in From the Bullpen, the Other Team’s in Trouble’
abstract: No one is laughing about the Edwin Díaz trade now that he is the best closer in baseball. The former Mets executive who made the deal isn’t gloating. “I’m very happy for him.”
lead_paragraph: That first year, every save chance for Edwin Díaz was like a box of flowers delivered to the Mets’ front door. The Mets would undo the ribbon and lean in for the sweet smell, and the box would blow up in their face.

headline: California Bill Could Restrict the Use of Rap Lyrics in Court
abstract: The bill, which applies more broadly to other forms of creative expression, has unanimously passed the Senate and Assembly and could become law by the end of September.
lead_paragraph: A California bill that would restrict the use of rap lyrics and other creative works as evidence in criminal proceedings has unanimously passed both the State Senate and Assembly, and could soon be signed into law by Gov. Gavin Newsom.

headline: The Finnish National Ballet at 100
abstract: What does style mean for this (or any other) company in an increasingly global ballet world?
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI — What is Finnish about the Finnish National Ballet?

headline: How Well Has Jackson Hole Predicted the Economy?
abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman, Jay Powell, is expected to discuss inflation, interest rates and growth in his annual address from the economic symposium on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Jay Powell, the Federal Reserve chairman, gets a half-hour slot (10 a.m. Eastern) this morning to deliver his annual address at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium. On the agenda: an update on the economic outlook, the inflation picture and the path ahead for interest rates.

headline: How Californians Are Feeling About the Start of the School Year
abstract: On their minds are Covid-19, school safety and learning delays.
lead_paragraph: For a vast majority of California’s roughly six million K-12 students, this month is the beginning of a new school year.

headline: The Fed’s favorite inflation gauge cooled in July.
abstract: The Personal Consumption Expenditures inflation index fell on a monthly basis in July as gas prices swooned. An annual gauge slowed.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of inflation eased in July as gas prices fell following a sharp run-up earlier in the summer, a widely expected moderation that is nevertheless likely to be welcome news for policymakers as they battle the most rapid price gains in decades.

headline: Has the Fight Against Antisemitism Lost Its Way?
abstract: Organizations combating antisemitism used to focus on defending human rights. Now they seem to defend human rights abusers.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 18 months, America’s most prominent Jewish organizations have done something extraordinary. They have accused the world’s leading human rights organizations of promoting hatred of Jews.

headline: Moderna Sues Pfizer and BioNTech Over Covid Vaccine Technology
abstract: Two lawsuits filed in Massachusetts and Germany claim the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine violated Moderna’s mRNA patents.
lead_paragraph: The vaccine manufacturer Moderna sued Pfizer and BioNTech on Friday, claiming that its rivals’ Covid-19 shot copied groundbreaking technology that Moderna had developed years before the pandemic.

headline: U.S. income growth slowed in July, and consumer spending barely grew.
abstract: Personal income, after taxes, rose 0.2 percent, the Commerce Department said. A drop in gasoline prices offered relief.
lead_paragraph: Americans’ incomes rose more slowly last month — but, for once, those gains weren’t swallowed up by higher prices.

headline: What to Do if Market Drops Took a Bite Out of Your College Savings
abstract: As the stock and bond markets have wobbled, 529 plans have taken a tumble. There’s no one-size-fits-all answer, but you have options.
lead_paragraph: Many families saving for college are seeing red — on their 529 plan statements.

headline: Some Monkeys Use Stone Tools for Pleasure, Study Suggests
abstract: Self-pleasure, that is.
lead_paragraph: Many monkeys are skilled stone handlers, using rocks to dig up roots, cut plants and crack open an array of delicacies, including fruits and nuts.

headline: U.S. and China Announce Deal to Share Audits of U.S.-Listed Chinese Firms
abstract: The agreement could prevent Chinese companies from having to depart U.S. stock exchanges, but U.S. officials remain wary of whether China will fulfill its terms.
lead_paragraph: American and Chinese officials said Friday that they had reached an agreement to allow accounting firms in China to share more information with American regulators about the finances of Chinese companies listed on U.S. stock exchanges.

headline: Stocks Plunge After Fed Chair Warns of ‘Pain’ From Inflation Fight
abstract: The S&P 500 fell 3.4 percent, its worst daily showing since mid-June, after the Federal Reserve chair spoke about the path ahead for monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street recoiled on Friday, after the head of the Federal Reserve delivered a stern warning that the central bank’s campaign to lower inflation by raising interest rates is “unconditional” even if it leads to pain for households, businesses and in turn stock prices.

headline: Documents at Mar-a-Lago Could Compromise Human Intelligence Sources, Affidavit Says
abstract: The search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home was spurred by the discovery that he had kept classified material related to the use of human sources in intelligence gathering.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home was spurred by the discovery that he had retained a trove of highly classified material that included documents related to the use of “clandestine human sources” in intelligence gathering, according to a redacted version of the affidavit used to obtain the search warrant.

headline: What Is in a Search Warrant Affidavit?
abstract: Such documents are generally not disclosed while a criminal investigation is continuing because they can provide a road map to the origins of the inquiry and tip off targets.
lead_paragraph: The expected release of the affidavit that accompanied the Justice Department’s application for a warrant to search former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Florida is exceedingly rare.

headline: What the Champions League Is Lacking
abstract: Europe’s richest competition offers the best of what soccer can deliver. But the World Cup still has something it can’t match.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There will be stories, of course. There are always stories. The Champions League delivers them so frequently and so reliably that it is impossible to dismiss the nagging suspicion that all of this might just be scripted, the product of some complex simulation being run from a secret lair in Nyon.

headline: How to Get Heart Patients to Take Their Pills? Give Them Just One.
abstract: Patients given a combination “polypill” after a heart attack were more likely to stick to their regimens, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: Heart disease kills more people than any other condition, but despite advances in treatment and prevention, patients often do not stick to their medication regimens. Now researchers may have found a solution: a so-called polypill that combines three drugs needed to prevent cardiovascular trouble.

headline: Are You Strapped In for ‘The Patient’? The Therapist Is.
abstract: In a new series from the showrunners of “The Americans,” Steve Carell plays a shrink confined to the basement of a killer. They have a lot to talk about.
lead_paragraph: Most actors are attached to their jobs. Steve Carell was padlocked to his.

headline: Watch live: Jerome Powell speaks at the Fed’s Jackson Hole conference.
abstract: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, is speaking at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium, the central bank’s most prominent annual gathering.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, is speaking at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium, the central bank’s most prominent annual gathering.

headline: Fed Chair Signals More Rate Increases Ahead, Shaking Wall Street
abstract: The Federal Reserve chair pledged to resolutely fight rapid price increases, arguing the bigger mistake would be allowing inflation to become entrenched.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Wyo. — Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, delivered a sobering message on Friday, saying the Fed must continue to raise interest rates — and keep them elevated for a while — to bring the fastest inflation in decades back under control.

headline: Zelensky is under pressure over when and how to launch a long-anticipated counteroffensive.
abstract: Both sides are preparing for a protracted war, but Ukraine has an incentive to counterattack this fall, before the rainy season.
lead_paragraph: As the bloody artillery battle in Ukraine’s east settles into a stalemate, the war appears now to be a waiting game for a long-promised Ukrainian counteroffensive.

headline: How to Do Everything
abstract: A guide to life, drawn from seven years of the magazine’s Tip column.
lead_paragraph: A guide to life, drawn from seven years of the magazine’s Tip column.

headline: To Make Money in the Stock Market, Do Nothing
abstract: The bear market endures, yet the S&P 500 index rose more than 17 percent from mid-June to mid-August. Don’t even try to guess what will happen next, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The stock market fell so sharply at the beginning of the year that it felt at times as if it would never come back.

headline: Jared Kushner’s Soulless Memoir and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: A smarter transition to electric vehicles
abstract: E.V.s will bring down emissions, but the materials needed to build them have other environmental costs. We explain why, and talk about ways to limit the harm.
lead_paragraph: We got some big news from California this week: Officials there set into motion a plan that’ll ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035. The decision is expected to accelerate the global transition to electric vehicles.

headline: How British energy prices are set.
abstract: A U.K. regulator determines how much utilities can charge customers. The latest increase is almost entirely due to higher wholesale energy costs.
lead_paragraph: Some 24 million British households received distressing news on Friday: Starting Oct. 1, they will be paying 80 percent more for energy, or a total of 3,549 pounds over the course of a year for a typical British home.

headline: Britney Spears and Elton John’s Mash-up, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Margo Price, Julia Jacklin and Michael Kiwanuka.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: A case for creating an epic spread of salmon kababs, herbed yogurt and salad-e shirazi, and more recipes for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: This is Priya, once again taking over for Sam!

headline: Keeping His Weed Happy
abstract: Rainforest music, Willie Nelson, subterranean greenhouses: A cannabis farmer shares trade secrets.

headline: Trump Lawyers Face a Deadline in Their Request for a Special Master
abstract: In a filing on Monday, the former president’s lawyers said that an independent arbiter was needed to weed out any records taken by investigators that should have been protected by executive privilege.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and his lawyers were due on Friday to file court papers clarifying a request this week seeking an independent arbiter to review the hundreds of pages of sensitive documents that were seized during the search of his Florida residence.

headline: At M.T.A.’s First Congestion Pricing Hearing, Critics Abound
abstract: In a series of hearings this month, the transit authority is seeking public input on a proposal to charge motorists for driving into Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Across almost seven hours Thursday night, the speeches grew in volume and intensity — a cacophony of New Yorkers brought together over Zoom to either praise or denounce one of the city’s most contentious transportation projects.

headline: Steven Hoffenberg, Debt Baron Who Ran a Vast Fraud, Dies at 77
abstract: A onetime business associate of Jeffrey Epstein who briefly controlled The New York Post, he spent 18 years in prison for a $460 million Ponzi scheme.
lead_paragraph: Steven J. headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a Ukrainian documentary, a Mexican thriller and a French-Arab drama about poetry and young love.
lead_paragraph: Early in this documentary from Ukraine, a family in the war-torn region of Donbass sets up a makeshift studio in their living room to shoot some scenes for a film. Against a wall draped with black cloth, each family member — the single mother, Anna, her two teenage daughters and two little boys — takes turns speaking to the camera. When one of the boys slams the clapperboard to start a new scene, we hear, instead of the clap, the sound of a bomb: The screen cuts to Anna and her sons crouched in their basement as a neighbor’s house is shelled by Russian forces. Is this reality? Or another scene from the movie-within-the-movie?

headline: James Hannaham Resists the Very Idea of Literary Genres
abstract: “Wasn’t it Louis Armstrong who said there are only two types of music — good and bad?” says the author and visual artist, whose new novel is “Didn’t Nobody Give a Shit What Happened to Carlotta.” “I feel the same about books. I like good.”
lead_paragraph: I’ve been savoring Blair Fell’s “The Sign for Home” for a long time, because Covid killed my attention span and lately I can only read novels on planes. Blair is an old friend, but I was a fan of his work before I met him. He used to write a soap opera called “Burning Habits” that appeared in East Village gay bars in the ’90s. This book has a lot of the things I’ve always loved about his writing. It’s a hilarious, peculiar and very touching story about a deaf, blind Jehovah’s Witness boy and his gay interpreter (Blair has been a “terp” for 30 years!) who try to find the boy’s long-lost love together. It gets very dramatic! Next up are Airea D. Matthews’s “Simulacra,” Peter Rock’s “Passersthrough,” a couple of Rough Guide travel books and The Anarchist Review of Books.

headline: Affirmative Action Was Banned at Two Top Universities. They Say They Need It.
abstract: As a Supreme Court case on college admissions nears, the California and Michigan university systems say their efforts to build diverse classes have hardly worked.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than 15 years since two of the country’s top public university systems, the University of Michigan and the University of California, were forced to stop using affirmative action in admissions.

headline: Fighting Between U.S. and Iran-Backed Militias Escalates in Syria

lead_paragraph: Militias backed by Iran’s Revolutionary Guards force attacked a U.S. military base in southern Syria with drones recently and on the same day, a different base used by the U.S.-led coalition near Syria’s eastern border with Iraq came under rocket fire.

headline: Wonking Out: Europe and the Economics of Blackmail

lead_paragraph: Four decades ago I spent a year working in the U.S. government, on the staff of the Council of Economic Advisers. (For those wondering: Yes, this was the Reagan administration; no, I wasn’t a Republican.) It was a technocratic job. I was the chief international economist; the chief domestic economist was a guy named Larry Summers. What ever happened to him?

headline: What to Know About White Mulberry Leaf
abstract: A coroner has linked the death of Lori McClintock, the wife of a California Representative, to an herb. But experts say it is generally considered safe.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Loretta McClintock, the wife of Representative Tom McClintock from California, died unexpectedly in her home in California. The cause of death was not released at the time. This week, an investigation by Kaiser Health News revealed that the coroner who performed her autopsy linked her death to white mulberry leaf, a centuries-old herbal remedy which, in recent years, has been marketed as a supplement for weight loss and diabetes management.

headline: Latvia tears down a controversial Soviet-era monument in its capital.

lead_paragraph: The nearly 260-foot-tall obelisk, erected during the Soviet rule of Latvia, had towered in a park in the Baltic nation’s capital for nearly four decades.

headline: Only Connect: Finding a Way Into Kinetic Light’s ‘Wired’
abstract: Audio descriptions are one path into this disability arts ensemble’s show. In some ways, these mirror the critic’s job: putting dance into words.
lead_paragraph: “Am I missing something here?” is a question prompted by many dance performances. In my mind, the thought often has an anxious tone, since I consider it my job as a critic to try to miss as little as possible. When I attended the New York premiere of Kinetic Light’s “Wired” at the Shed on Thursday, the question was especially loud in my head. But even more unusual was the unequivocal clarity of the answer. I was missing something. By design.

Tata, a character actor whose roles in a long television career included henchmen on the original “Batman” series and bit parts on “The Rockford Files,” but who was best known as the good-natured owner of the Peach Pit diner on the hit 1990s teenage drama “Beverly Hills, 90210,” died on Thursday in Woodland Hills, Calif. headline: The Liberal Justice Who Warned Against an Activist Supreme Court
abstract: “Democratic Justice,” Brad Snyder’s comprehensive biography of Felix Frankfurter, aims to reassess the complicated legacy of the judge and political adviser.
lead_paragraph: In his concurring opinion in the Dobbs abortion case, which overturned Roe v. Wade, Chief Justice John Roberts invoked the wisdom of “a thoughtful member of this court” — namely, Felix Frankfurter. Like Frankfurter, who served as a justice from 1939 to 1962, Roberts argued that the Supreme Court should preserve its legitimacy by respecting precedents, deciding cases narrowly rather than broadly, and in most cases deferring to the democratic political process rather than second-guessing Congress and state legislatures.

headline: Confirmation, e.g.

I couldn’t rustle up a thing in the center and top of this puzzle for a long time, until I recalibrated my solving sensibilities to Andrew Linzer’s excellent, humorous wordplay.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Florida, Cautiously Navigating How to Teach

headline: Corrections: Aug. 27, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 27, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about California’s plan to ban the sale of gasoline-powered cars featured a quotation that misstated the distinction of the California measure. While California is the first U.S. state government to mandate zero-emission vehicles, it is not the only government to have done so. (British Columbia has similar rules in place.)

headline: Chris Evert Needs Everyone to Listen
abstract: Since January, the 18-time Grand Slam champion has balanced her work in tennis with the grueling routine of chemotherapy for ovarian cancer. She never would have caught it early, if she hadn’t lost her sister to the same disease.
lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — All the medical advancements that helped save Chris Evert’s life could not save her sister. Jeanne Evert Dubin died of ovarian cancer in February 2020, at age 62, her illness discovered only after it had reached its deadliest stages.

headline: War Brings Ukraine’s Women New Roles and New Dangers
abstract: Women have become an all-important force in the fight. But even as they mobilize, they are increasingly bearing the worst of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: CHERNIHIV, Ukraine — The road to the training site was lined with crumbling homes and damaged buildings, a reminder of how war had consumed the northern Ukrainian city of Chernihiv just months ago.

headline: Back to School in DeSantis’s Florida, as Teachers Look Over Their Shoulders
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis is battling what he calls “indoctrination” in schools. New laws have left many teachers questioning everything from pride flags to “The Great Gatsby.”
lead_paragraph: Erin Brown, a teacher in St. Johns County, Fla., typically keeps a gay pride flag hanging up in her classroom. As the faculty sponsor of a Gay-Straight Alliance club at her high school, she wants her students to know they are safe with her.

headline: Election Data Breach Attracts Georgia Investigators
abstract: The district attorney in Atlanta is seeking to build a broad conspiracy case that encompasses multifaceted efforts by Trump allies to disrupt and overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The day after Donald J. Trump’s supporters stormed the Capitol, a small group working on his behalf traveled to rural Coffee County, Ga., about 200 miles southeast of Atlanta.

headline: How 3 NASA Missions Could Send Astronauts Back to the Moon
abstract: By the end of this decade, humans could walk on the moon once again. Here’s how NASA plans to send them there.
lead_paragraph: By the end of this decade, humans could walk on the moon once again. Here’s how NASA plans to send them there.

headline: Serena Williams at the U.S. Open: How to Watch Her Next Match
abstract: The 23-time Grand Slam champion has a tough challenge in her second-round singles match on Wednesday at 7 p.m. at Arthur Ashe Stadium. She will also play doubles with her sister Venus on Thursday.

headline: Ready for a Night Out? Hire a Disco Nanny.
abstract: In party hot spots around Europe, agencies have popped up to provide child care at all hours of the night and day.
lead_paragraph: Three months before Olga Lopatina and Emiliano Beltrami make their annual August pilgrimage to Mykonos, they start making reservations.

headline: How Do I Time a Move From One Rental Apartment to Another?
abstract: Most New Yorkers give notice at their old apartments without a new one lined up. But that’s OK.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am moving from Connecticut to Manhattan later this year, and I’m concerned about how to time the move. My current landlord requires 60 days’ notice to move out. But from what I have seen, most apartments in New York are not listed until 30 days before they become available, and are rented even faster than that. I’m also considering renting in a co-op or condo, and those approval processes seem long. How do I time this right so I don’t end up paying for two apartments at once, or worse, giving up my apartment without a place to live?

headline: How a Public Tennis Court Attendant Spends His Sundays
abstract: Walter Odom, a fixture in Fort Greene Park, makes sure players respect the hourly schedule and keep their T-shirts on.
lead_paragraph: At exactly 8 o’clock the call went out. “Tennis time!”

headline: The Sixth Love Language Does Not Exist
abstract: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.

headline: The Robber Baron Who Remade Wall Street in His Own Image
abstract: For better or worse, Jay Gould revolutionized the world of finance in the 19th century. In “American Rascal,” Greg Steinmetz tells his story.
lead_paragraph: On April 5, 1882, Theodore Roosevelt stood in the New York State Assembly and demanded an investigation. The indignant 23-year-old accused a clique of “swindlers,” “wealthy stock gamblers,” “men whose financial dishonesty is a matter of common notoriety,” of corruptly monopolizing New York City’s elevated railroads. The plot’s mastermind, he implied, was Jay Gould.

headline: New York City Sets a High Bar for Lifeguards. That Could Be a Problem.
abstract: The city requires its pool lifeguards to meet standards similar to those set for ocean lifeguards, beyond what the state sets.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures climbed into the high 80s on a sunny afternoon this week, dozens of people trying to cool off at the public pool in McCarren Park in Williamsburg had only half the usual space, as the other side sat empty, blocked by traffic cones and caution tape.

headline: Octopuses Don’t Have Backbones — or Rights
abstract: As cephalopods become more important in neuroscience and other fields, scientists and welfare advocates seek to give the smart animals the same protections as mice and monkeys.
lead_paragraph: Lab rats have rights. Before researchers in the United States can experiment on the animals, they need approval from committees that ensure they follow federal regulations for housing and handling the creatures humanely. The same is true of scientists working with mice, monkeys, fish or finches.

headline: Does Watching College Football on TV Have to Be So Miserable?
abstract: The corporations that control these broadcasts know: It can still be hugely lucrative to provide an experience that fans come to despise.
lead_paragraph: It is, let’s say, 8:43 p.m. on a Saturday. You are watching a college football game that is taking place at this hour despite being played in the Midwest in November, and the people in the stadium, which is not entirely full, look very cold and a little put off. The season schedule said kickoff was at 8 p.m., but it didn’t actually take place until 8:18. In the 25 minutes that have elapsed, play has been interrupted for three commercial breaks. Each advertisement shown during these breaks has been for pickup trucks.

headline: ‘The Best Tool We Have’ for Self-Harming and Suicidal Teens
abstract: Studies indicate that dialectical behavior therapy offers greater benefits than more generalized therapy. But treatment is intensive, and expensive.
lead_paragraph: Parents seeking therapy for teenagers who self-harm or suffer from anxiety, depression or suicidal thoughts face an imposing thicket of treatment options and acronyms: cognitive behavioral therapy (C.B.T.), parent management training (P.M.T.), collaborative assessment and management of suicidality (CAMS), acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) and others.

headline: Planning for Your Retirement, and for a Child’s Special Needs, All at Once
abstract: People with children who cannot support themselves need to think well past their own lifetime and figure out how to provide for children after they are gone.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Nagler, 39, has worked part time since she was 22, but she will never be financially independent, according to her father. She is legally blind with a seizure disorder and mild cognitive impairment, the result of birth trauma.

headline: Come for the Golden Gate Bridge and Cable Cars. Stay for the Summer Shivers.
abstract: San Franciscans are done apologizing for their cold Julys and Augusts. In a time of punishing heat waves, the city likes being a place to chill out.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — While Americans from Seattle to Memphis to New York sweated their way through the swampy summer of 2022, here was the scene on an August afternoon at Fisherman’s Wharf, on the northern tip of San Francisco: Among a group of friends from Germany gawking at dozens of barking sea lions splayed on floating docks, one was bundled in a down jacket and another in a sweatshirt, and a third was shivering despite a red checkered scarf worn like a shawl.

headline: This Teen Was Prescribed 10 Psychiatric Drugs. She’s Not Alone.
abstract: Increasingly, anxious and depressed teens are using multiple, powerful psychiatric drugs, many of them untested in adolescents or for use in tandem.
lead_paragraph: One morning in the fall of 2017, Renae Smith, a high school freshman on Long Island, N.Y., could not get out of bed, overwhelmed at the prospect of going to school. In the following days, her anxiety mounted into despair.

headline: In Finland, a Partying Prime Minister Draws Tuts, and Cheers
abstract: Leaked videos featuring Sanna Marin dancing have raised the question of whether she is held to a different standard than older, male leaders are.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — Last fall, Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland, a 36-year-old leather-jacket-wearing regular at rock festivals, vowed that she wanted to “live like a person my age” and “shake up” the highest office in the government.

headline: At One of Canada’s Top Destinations, Tourists Are Back but Much Has Changed
abstract: The towns in and around Banff National Park are teeming again, but overseas visitors are scarce, as are hotel and restaurant workers.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year had passed since my last visits to the Alberta mountain towns of Banff and Canmore, and the contrast was startling. After a protracted pandemic-induced absence, tourists were back.

headline: The 5 Love Languages at 30
abstract: Why have they endured as a self-help phenomenon?
lead_paragraph: The pastor Gary Chapman created the concept of “love languages” 30 years ago. In his hugely popular book, “The 5 Love Languages,” he proposed that the ways people prefer to have love communicated to them fall into five categories, or “languages”: acts of service, words of affirmation, quality time, receiving gifts and physical touch.
