headline: The Toss
abstract: A detailed look at a critical element of elite serving that can determine who wins each point in a tennis match.
lead_paragraph: A detailed look at a critical element of elite serving that can determine who wins each point in a tennis match.

headline: Counting the Population Has Always Been Political
abstract: In the deft and surprisingly lively “Democracy’s Data,” Dan Bouk explores the uses, misuses and failures of the U.S. Census.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. census has inspired a surprising amount of poetry, Dan Bouk notes in his endearingly nerdy new book, “Democracy’s Data.” And I doubt this is because “census” rhymes with so many relevant words: fences, defenses, Mike Pence’s.

headline: After 20 Years in a Men’s Prison, a Trans Woman Returns Home
abstract: James Hannaham’s new novel imagines a convict’s fateful re-entry into a much-changed Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody Black knows how to react to a tragedy,” James Hannaham wrote in his 2015 novel “Delicious Foods.” “Just bring out a wheelbarrow full of the Same Old Anger, dump it all over the Usual Frustration and water it with Somebody Oughtas. … Mention the Holy Spirit whenever possible.” In his new novel, “Didn’t Nobody Give a Shit What Happened to Carlotta,” the plot converges on a wake, and its cast of characters gleefully adhere to that pronouncement. We may understand its mechanisms, but Hannaham’s bumper-car narrative still astonishes.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: In New Hampshire, Republicans Weigh Another Hard-Right Candidate
abstract: Don Bolduc, a retired Army general, has played to the Republican base and is leading in polls to take on Senator Maggie Hassan, who is viewed as vulnerable in November.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — He has said the state’s popular Republican governor is “a Chinese Communist sympathizer,” called for the repeal of the 17th Amendment allowing direct popular election of senators and raised the possibility of abolishing the F.B.I.

headline: The Office’s Last Stand
abstract: It’s either the end of the era of flexibility around where work takes place — or the beginning of outright rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Colleen McCreary recently gave managers at Credit Karma a message that could seem more apt for rising sixth graders than personal finance executives.

headline: One Man’s Dream of Fusing A.I. With Common Sense
abstract: Artificial intelligence systems can process vast amounts of data in seconds, but they can’t make sense of the world or explain their decisions. David Ferrucci wants to change that.
lead_paragraph: David Ferrucci, who led the team that built IBM’s famed Watson computer, was elated when it beat the best-ever human “Jeopardy!” players in 2011, in a televised triumph for artificial intelligence.

headline: Trying to Keep Americans Camping With Treehouses and Yurts
abstract: Interest in camping soared in the pandemic, and now, as social-distancing restrictions are winding down, the sector is showing signs that it may maintain its popularity.
lead_paragraph: Some families plan annual summer trips in a quest to eventually visit every major-league ballpark across America. Over the past two years, Patty Lin Growden and her family have taken up a similar pursuit: campgrounds.

headline: Referendum Seeks to Mend the Open Wound at Australia’s Heart
abstract: The new prime minister is seeking support for an Aboriginal Voice to Parliament, even enlisting the backing of Shaquille O’Neal. Here’s what it would entail, and why it faces an uncertain path.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Capt. James Cook sailed to Australia in 1768, he did so with instructions that he should “show every kind of civility and regard” to the land’s Indigenous people and get their consent before possessing their land. He did neither.

headline: Cloud Wars: Mideast Rivalries Rise Along a New Front
abstract: As climate change makes the region hotter and drier, the U.A.E. is leading the effort to squeeze more rain out of the clouds, and other countries are rushing to keep up.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Iranian officials have worried for years that other nations have been depriving them of one of their vital water sources. But it was not an upstream dam that they were worrying about, or an aquifer being bled dry.

headline: ‘Wood Is Life’: A Hong Kong Sawmill’s Last Days
abstract: Chi Kee Sawmill and Timber, in business since the 1940s, will soon make way for a vast development project. But it is still bringing new life to old wood.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — From the brine-soaked docks of a ferry pier to the red-painted pillars of a Buddhist temple, many an aging wooden structure in Hong Kong has found new purpose in the hands of Wong Hung-kuen.

headline: ‘We’ll Teach Out of Anywhere’: In Flooded Kentucky, Schools Race to Rebuild
abstract: This school year was, finally, supposed to be a return to normal. But after floodwaters wrecked homes and schools across the region, simply getting started will be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: COMBS, Ky. — Robin Combs has been teaching math for more than three decades, muscle memory guiding her as she reaches for the right lesson plans, confident in what works and how best to reach her middle school students. But when floodwaters surged through Robinson Elementary School last month, the roof collapsed on her classroom and three decades’ worth of curriculum materials were destroyed.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘She’s at Brown. Her Heart’s Still in Kabul.’
abstract: In their first year at U.S. universities, women who escaped the Taliban are struggling to adjust — and to reckon with what they left behind.
lead_paragraph: Going to college can be a shock to most: Leaving the comfort of friends and family for a leap into the unknown, a fresh start. But what is the university experience like as a refugee?

headline: What’s With All the Fluff About a New Civil War, Anyway?
abstract: Why the idea of two new, separate blue and red countries is absurd.
lead_paragraph: BOZEMAN, Mont. — The idea was to be permanently chastened by the Civil War, that the relief of emancipation and reunification would always be tempered by the shock of 600,000 corpses. And yet “civil war” has lately become one of those zeitgeist phrases that rattle around the internet, like “quiet quitting” or “Pete Davidson.”

headline: Haven’t We Seen These Characters Before?
abstract: Summer sequels are back and worse than ever.
lead_paragraph: Summer has always loved a sequel. So why do this year’s comebacks and next chapters feel somehow worse? Not just mildly disappointing but also a little disquieting?

headline: In Track and Field, Money Flows to the Flashy and Stylish
abstract: Winning is important when it comes to making a living in the sport. But so is finishing in style.
lead_paragraph: Raven Saunders watched Usain Bolt’s rise closely.

headline: Ron DeSantis’s Florida
abstract: How the Republican governor is turning the swing state into a right-wing laboratory.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who appears to be preparing to run for president in 2024, has achieved a national platform by leaning into cultural battles. He signed laws limiting what teachers can teach about race, sexual orientation and gender identity, and he recently suspended an elected prosecutor who said he would refuse to enforce the state’s anti-abortion laws.

headline: The Week in Business: Changing Consumer Habits
abstract: Peloton struggles to emerge from the pandemic. The Federal Reserve chair issues a warning from Jackson Hole. Economists await August’s jobs report.
lead_paragraph: As consumers’ whims continue to evolve in the pandemic recovery, many companies that once enjoyed high-highs are feeling the sting of low-lows. That is especially true for the exercise bike company Peloton, which reported a $1.2 billion quarterly loss on Thursday — its sixth straight quarter of losses. After a pandemic boom, Peloton is now among the many retailers struggling to sell excess inventory. But its stationary bikes, priced at $1,445 and now available on Amazon, may still be a hard sell: Other earnings reports, like those from Dollar General and Dollar Tree this week, pointed to more cautious consumer spending. The two companies, the largest dollar-store chains in the country, posted higher sales and profits in their latest quarter as inflation eats into Americans’ budgets. In the past year, a majority of new customers shopping at Dollar Tree earned at least $80,000 annually, according to the company’s chief executive — a sign that even higher earners are looking for bargains.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Herb-marinated swordfish, browned halloumi, silken tofu dishes and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons to keep a block of silken tofu in your fridge at all times. Raw or steamed, whole or cubed, seasoned lightly or aggressively, silken tofu means dinner, fast.

headline: Rick Reed, G.O.P. Adman of ‘Swift Boat’ Campaign, Dies at 69
abstract: In helping to create a series of ads attacking the Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry’s military record, he added a new term to the political lexicon.
lead_paragraph: Rick Reed, a Republican advertising executive whose work in the 2004 presidential race tarnished Senator John Kerry, the Democratic nominee, by attacking his record as a Swift boat commander during the Vietnam War — giving rise to the term “swift boating” as a synonym for making ad hominem attacks, typically unfair, on a public figure — died on Aug. 17 at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 69.

headline: Why Pastors Are Burning Out
abstract: “I just started associating ministry with having to learn new computer programs and having embarrassing, anxious moments around technology.”
lead_paragraph: If you are part of a church, there’s a good chance that your pastor is not all right.

headline: Possible Scenarios to Deal With the ‘Trump Problem’
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay saying there are “no unambivalently good options.” Also: Arctic warming; driverless cars; who gets published.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bullying and Sex Abuse Scandal Engulfs Elite Danish School
abstract: Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark and his wife, Princess Mary, pulled their son from the institution, saying that they were “deeply shaken by the reports.”
lead_paragraph: Denmark, like most of Scandinavia, likes to see itself as a fair and equal society, with a nonhierarchical structure, high levels of happiness and trustworthy institutions dedicated to everyone’s well-being.

headline: Over Caves and Over Budget, Mexico’s Train Project Barrels Toward Disaster
abstract: Pitched as a way to develop the country’s poorest region, the Maya Train is threatened by a ballooning budget and rushed construction over fragile terrain. But Mexico’s president has refused to slow it down.
lead_paragraph: PLAYA DEL CARMEN, Mexico — Twisted tree trunks were plowed into high piles along a slash of freshly cut jungle, like thousands of discarded matchsticks as far as the eye could see. This path of deforestation in southern Mexico was recently cleared to make way for an ambitious government project: the Maya Train railway.

headline: Jaimie Branch, Trumpeter Who Crossed Genre Lines, Dies at 39
abstract: One of the most dynamic trumpet players in contemporary music, she forged a direct emotional, and even spiritual, connection with her listeners.
lead_paragraph: Jaimie Branch, an innovative avant-garde trumpet player and composer whose punk-rock intensity and commitment to experimentation and to dissolving the distinctions between genres invigorated the music scenes of New York and Chicago, died on Aug. 22 at her home in Red Hook, Brooklyn. She was 39.

headline: Clashes Between Rival Militias in Libya Kill at Least 32
abstract: The worst fighting in two years rocked Tripoli on Saturday, as residents feared a return to war.
lead_paragraph: Some of the fiercest clashes in two years in Libya’s capital between militias loyal to rival political leaders have left nearly three dozen people dead, as neighborhoods became battlefields and residents hunkered down in their homes, fearing a return to war in the country.

headline: A Festival That Conjures the Magic of H.P. Lovecraft and Beyond
abstract: At the Rhode Island event, revelers danced to murder ballads and celebrated all things weird. They even found time to reckon with the writer’s racism.
lead_paragraph: There’s bacon and eggs, and then there’s bacon and eggs at the Cthulhu Prayer Breakfast. Named after the cosmically malevolent and abundantly tentacled entity dreamed up by Howard Phillips Lovecraft, the event, among the most popular at NecronomiCon Providence 2022, filled a vast hotel ballroom at 8 a.m. on a recent Sunday.

headline: Central Mississippi Spared Feared Flooding From Heavy Rains, Officials Say
abstract: In Jackson, Miss., officials had warned that up to 150 homes could be affected and evacuations, but the Pearl River crested lower than expected on Monday morning, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Shelters remained open on Monday as emergency crews assessed the impact of flooding on neighborhoods in central Mississippi, including in Jackson, an official said, after days of heavy rain had prompted the authorities to urge residents to evacuate over the weekend.

headline: Biden Becomes a Boon for Democrats
abstract: His successes are building momentum.
lead_paragraph: The coattail effect in politics is the theory that the popularity of a candidate at the top of the ticket redounds to the benefit of those in the same party down ballot.

headline: Devastating Floods in Pakistan Kill More Than a Thousand People
abstract: More than 33 million people have been affected by record rainfall this summer, according to Pakistan’s National Disaster Management Authority.
lead_paragraph: More than 33 million people have been affected by record rainfall this summer, according to Pakistan’s National Disaster Management Authority.

headline: The ‘MacGyvered’ Weapons in Ukraine’s Arsenal
abstract: The Ukrainian military has battled Russia with retrofitted equipment, including missiles and rocket systems mounted on trucks and speedboats, experts and officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The billions of dollars in military aid the United States has sent Ukraine includes some of the most advanced and lethal weapons systems in the world. But Ukraine has also scored big successes in the war by employing the weapons and equipment in unexpected ways, and jury-rigging some on the fly, according to military experts.

headline: Leaving Los Angeles
abstract: Hollywood wasn’t exactly the Hollywood you see in movies.
lead_paragraph: It was early in the morning when I first ate toilet paper. My mother and my brother were still asleep. It tasted bad. I cried. I went for another bite. I needed the memory. I was 7 years old, and I knew I needed the memory.

headline: American Real Estate Was a Money Launderer’s Dream. That’s Changing.
abstract: How Cleveland became a poster child for the need for more transparency in the U.S. real estate industry.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When a young man from Florida barely old enough to enter a bar began buying up office buildings in downtown Cleveland, many in the real estate industry here were eager to do business with him. Even though Chaim Schochet wasn’t forthcoming about who his financial backers were or the particulars of his employer, Optima, he had deep pockets, and his company apparently was able to pay in cash.

headline: Serena Williams Dominated Her Generation, Then the Next One, Too
abstract: Williams started her career as a teenager taking on seasoned veterans. She spent more than two decades fending off similar challenges from up-and-comers.
lead_paragraph: Williams started her career as a teenager taking on seasoned veterans. She spent more than two decades fending off similar challenges from up-and-comers.

headline: Baseball Card Sold for $12.6 Million, Breaking Record
abstract: The 1952 Topps Mickey Mantle baseball card is the most valuable piece of sports memorabilia ever to be sold at auction.
lead_paragraph: A mint condition Mickey Mantle baseball card became the most valuable piece of sports memorabilia to be sold at auction, notching $12.6 million early Sunday morning.

headline: Shelling Near Ukraine Nuclear Plant Strikes Towns, Heightening Concern
abstract: Neither Russia nor Ukraine appeared to be pausing attacks in the south, even as talks continued over allowing international inspectors to visit the Zaporizhzhia power plant.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — For weeks, Russia and Ukraine have blamed each other for firing artillery at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in southern Ukraine, the largest power station in Europe, in a series of attacks that imperil not just the region, but also the whole world.

headline: How and When to Watch NASA’s Giant Rocket Launch to the Moon
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about Artemis I and the launch of the Space Launch System and Orion capsule.
lead_paragraph: Before NASA can send astronauts back to the moon, it needs a successful test flight of the Space Launch System, a giant rocket built for the agency with lunar missions in mind. On Monday, we’ll get to see the first attempt at launching this massive rocket to orbit, this time with no astronauts aboard the Orion capsule it will send to space.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Record Heat Disrupts China
abstract: Plus Pakistan is hit by deadly floods and Australia weighs Indigenous recognition
lead_paragraph: A record-setting drought and an 11-week heat wave are causing broad disruption in southwestern China, a region that depends on dams for more than three-quarters of its electricity generation.

headline: Well, Look at That!
abstract: Chase Dittrich and Jeff Chen pay homage to a classic love song.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Hello, solvers, and happy Monday! Today’s puzzle was created by two veteran constructors, Jeff Chen and Chase Dittrich; this is their second collaboration, following an impressive Sunday puzzle from last year.

headline: Republicans Signal Worries About Trump and the Midterms
abstract: Few Republicans appeared on the major Sunday talk shows to defend the former president. Those who did indicated that they would rather be talking about almost anything else.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Headed into 2022, Republicans were confident that a red wave would sweep them into control of Congress based on the conventional political wisdom that the midterm elections would produce a backlash against President Biden, who has struggled with low approval ratings.

headline: A Triple-Bogey Start Vanquished, Rory McIlroy Captures the FedEx Cup
abstract: McIlroy edged out Scottie Scheffler, who had held the lead in Atlanta for almost the entire Tour Championship. Sungjae Im and Scheffler finished tied for second, a stroke behind.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On Thursday, his scorecard a shambles after only two holes at the Tour Championship, Rory McIlroy did not find himself thinking about golf’s comeback magicians or his fellow major champions.

headline: Trump’s Legal Team Scrambles to Find an Argument
abstract: The lawyers representing the former president in the investigation into his handling of classified documents have tried out an array of defenses as they seek to hold off the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: On May 25, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers sent a letter to a top Justice Department official, laying out the argument that his client had done nothing illegal by holding onto a trove of government materials when he left the White House.

headline: Inmate Who Was Pregnant Settles Suit Over Stop at Starbucks en Route to a Hospital
abstract: The woman, who lost her pregnancy, won a $480,000 settlement arising from a suit that said jail employees did not respond for two hours to requests for help after her water broke.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Quinones, six months pregnant, was at a jail in Orange County, Calif., when her water broke in March 2016, according to court records.

headline: Beto O’Rourke Sidelined With Bacterial Infection Amid Texas Run
abstract: The Democrat, who is trying to unseat Republican Gov. Greg Abbott, said that although his symptoms had improved, he would be resting at home on doctors’ orders.
lead_paragraph: Beto O’Rourke, the former congressman and 2020 Democratic presidential candidate who is running to unseat Greg Abbott in the tightening race for Texas governor, said on Sunday that he would be sidelined from campaigning because of a bacterial infection.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon,’ Season 1, Episode 2: A Happy Announcement
abstract: Rhaenyra receives some surprising news, and Viserys likely sets into motion the thing he’s been trying to avoid.
lead_paragraph: A couple of centuries in Westeros’s future, in the same garden (I think) where King Viserys went on a blind date with a child on Sunday, Cersei Lannister will tell the soon-to-be-splooshed Oberyn Martell one of the saddest things anyone has ever heard.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Flood-Ravaged Kentucky, Schools Improvise in a Race to Reopen
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I just want our kids back together and for eight hours a day, be normal — just normal. They’re cool, they’ve got a seat, they’ve got food. I don’t have to worry for eight hours a day.”

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 29, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: QAnon Accounts Found a Home, and Trump’s Support, on Truth Social
abstract: Researchers identified 88 users promoting the conspiracy theory on Donald Trump’s platform, and said he had reposted messages 65 times.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of QAnon-boosting accounts decamped to Truth Social this year after they were banned by other social networks and have found support from the platform’s creator, former President Donald J. Trump, according to a report released on Monday.

headline: More Vital Than Ever, Ukraine’s Trains Bind a Land Fractured by War
abstract: With the skies and ports closed, Ukraine’s railroads have been crucial to efforts to flee, to return, to keep the country going or to simply reclaim some semblance of normal life.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A Polish friend offered some advice about taking the Ukrainian National Railways express train to Kyiv from Warsaw: Close the blinds before you go to bed, and sleep with your head by the door and away from the window. Better protection if an explosion blows it out.

headline: Serena Williams: 23 Grand Slam Titles, in the Books
abstract: The New York Times’s coverage of Williams’s 23 Grand Slam singles titles reflects more than two decades of greatness, and some surprises along the way.
lead_paragraph: How long has Serena Williams been a champion? She won her first Grand Slam singles title in the 20th century.

headline: In Comebacks, Serena Williams Showed ‘You Can Never Underestimate Her’
abstract: Big moments on the biggest stages cemented Williams’s reputation as the queen of comebacks.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: It’s Tough to Become a Lifeguard in New York City
abstract: As the city and country grapple with a lifeguard shortage, some who do the job say the requirements are too demanding here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s the final Monday of August. With summer pool season nearing its end, we consider the reasons for the city’s lifeguard shortage. And we take a quick look at the U.S. Open, which starts in Queens today.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: More attacks near a Ukrainian nuclear plant.
lead_paragraph: Russian artillery strikes continued near the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in Ukraine yesterday as negotiations continued over allowing international inspectors to visit the complex.

headline: Mississippi Residents Brace for Flooding
abstract: Residents in Jackson, Miss., removed valuables from their homes, and workers prepared sandbags in anticipation of flooding after heavy rains in the region.
lead_paragraph: Residents in Jackson, Miss., removed valuables from their homes, and workers prepared sandbags in anticipation of flooding after heavy rains in the region.

headline: U.N. experts head to the Zaporizhzhia facility on a risky mission after weeks of talks.
abstract: Both Russia and Ukraine welcomed the news, even as they repeated accusations that the other side was responsible for shelling the area around the plant.
lead_paragraph: The International Atomic Energy Agency said on Monday that it was dispatching a team of experts to inspect a nuclear complex in southern Ukraine that has been imperiled by shelling, launching a crucial but highly risky mission to ease global fears of a nuclear catastrophe.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Race for the Championship’ and ‘Stargirl’
abstract: USA Network airs its NASCAR documentary series. And the third season of the CW show based on the DC Comics character premieres.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 29 — Sept. 4. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: 2 Killed in Shooting at Oregon Shopping Center, Police Say
abstract: The 20-year-old gunman, who fired multiple times inside a grocery store, was also found dead. At least two people were wounded.
lead_paragraph: Two people were shot and killed and two others were wounded at a shopping center in Bend, Ore., on Sunday evening, prompting law enforcement agencies to flood the area and enter a grocery store, where officers found the gunman dead from a gunshot wound, the authorities said.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Should I Try to Hide My Large Bandage at Work?
abstract: A reader wonders how to dress after a recent medical procedure.
lead_paragraph: This is the sort of question that sounds simple — what’s the big deal about a bandage? — but actually touches on all sorts of complicated workplace issues and personal psychology. I’ve been in casts twice in the office because of ankle injuries, and I can attest that this kind of accessory becomes an unavoidable talking point in any conversation. In a world where we are constantly, if subconsciously, judging one another on what we wear, any form of adornment, even if it’s medical, is part of the equation.

headline: Deep-Sea Riches: Mining a Remote Ecosystem
abstract: Miles below the surface, harvesting metallic nodules on the ocean floor may speed the green energy revolution but threaten animals found nowhere else on the planet.
lead_paragraph: Miles below the surface, harvesting metallic nodules on the ocean floor may speed the green energy revolution but threaten animals found nowhere else on the planet.

headline: Document Inquiry Poses Unparalleled Test for Justice Dept.
abstract: What had started as an effort to retrieve national security documents has now been transformed into one of the most challenging and complicated criminal investigations in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Justice Department officials haggled for months this year with former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers and aides over the return of government documents at his Florida home, federal prosecutors became convinced that they were not being told the whole truth.

headline: What Serena Williams Means to You
abstract: “She did things on her own terms and propelled herself to greatness, doing so in a sport that felt by design that it was off limits to Black people.”
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to say what is more potent: Serena Williams’s howitzer serves, or the deep and powerful passions she provokes from fans watching those shots — particularly those who have been cast as outsiders in tennis.

headline: Is Serena Williams the GOAT? Yes. No. Probably. Maybe. Without a Doubt.
abstract: Proclaiming the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion the greatest women’s tennis player of all time is a worthwhile debate, but not a straightforward one. First, define greatness.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: In Algeria, Macron Seeks to Reshape a Traumatic Relationship With France
abstract: On a three-day visit, the French president said he was seeking “truth and acknowledgment” over the war and colonialism.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Past the graves and elaborate Christian mausoleums of Saint Eugene Cemetery, President Emmanuel Macron of France made his way, before laying a wreath at a monument to those “who died for France.” For a moment, France in Algeria, most painful of subjects, was palpable in the ghosts of those who populated “that France on the other side of the Mediterranean,” as Mr. Macron called it this year.

headline: ‘The Eye of the Storm’: Taiwan Is Caught in a Great Game Over Microchips
abstract: Worried about the Chinese threat to Taiwan, the U.S. and others have tried to expand their piece of the island’s semiconductor production.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As Chinese warships rehearsed a blockade of Taiwan this month, they simulated a scenario global leaders and policymakers have been busy worrying about: not war, but a grinding halt to the electronic supply chains that make the modern world run.

headline: An Investigation Leads to the Bottom of the Pacific
abstract: To understand seabed mining, which may be the next great resource rush, Eric Lipton boarded a fishing boat and headed out to sea.
lead_paragraph: Our journey began in the Pacific Ocean, off the coast of Mexico, where a New York Times photographer and I met the Maersk Launcher, a giant former offshore oil drilling supply ship that had been repurposed for a very unusual task: collecting potato-size rocks from the ocean floor.

headline: Xi Jinping’s Vision for Tech Self-Reliance in China Runs Into Reality
abstract: After heavy national investment in semiconductors to break a dependence on global chips, Mr. Xi seems unhappy with the results.
lead_paragraph: Wearing a laboratory coat, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, inspected a subsidiary of Yangtze Memory Technologies Company, a national semiconductor company based in Wuhan. It was April 2018, shortly after the U.S. government had barred the Chinese telecommunications firm ZTE from doing business with American suppliers.

headline: Revenge of the Founders: A Generational Struggle on Wall Street
abstract: The abrupt departure of Kewsong Lee as Carlyle Group’s chief executive followed conflicts over how to run the financial firm.
lead_paragraph: In early August, Kewsong Lee, the chief executive of the Carlyle Group, got on a videoconference call with two of the private equity firm’s board members. They told him that Carlyle’s septuagenarian founders were planning to play a more active role managing the firm.

headline: Penn Station Plan Makes a High-Stakes Bet on the Future of Office Work
abstract: Despite near record-high office vacancies, Gov. Kathy Hochul has backed a real estate project at the New York transit hub that would be one of the largest in American history.
lead_paragraph: In a bid to reshape Midtown Manhattan, Gov. Kathy Hochul and New York State officials are pushing ahead with one of the largest real estate development projects in American history: 10 towers of mostly offices around Penn Station, the busiest transit center in the country.

headline: Secret Data, Tiny Islands and a Quest for Treasure on the Ocean Floor
abstract: Mining in parts of the Pacific Ocean was meant to benefit poor countries, but an international agency gave a Canadian company access to prized seabed sites with metals crucial to the green energy revolution.
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica — As demand grows globally for metals needed to make batteries for electric vehicles, one of the richest untapped sources of the raw materials lies two and a half miles beneath the surface of the Pacific Ocean.

headline: A Catholic Podcasting Star Says Theocracy Is Not the Way
abstract: “All of us get a say,” says Father Mike Schmitz. “From the deeply religious to the convicted atheist and everyone in between.”
lead_paragraph: “All of us get a say,” says Father Mike Schmitz. “From the deeply religious to the convicted atheist and everyone in between.”

headline: Summers End, but Our Desires Last a Lifetime
abstract: We all want to be touched, to be chosen, even at an age when our culture tells us that we are in no way desirable.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — By the calendar and by the thermometer, autumn feels impossibly distant, the figment of a fever dream. Here in Tennessee, temperatures still push into the 90s nearly every day, and the humidity is thick enough to steam press a blouse. This is insect weather.

headline: The G.O.P. Is in a Grand Old Pickle
abstract: Republicans seem to feel less feisty than when they were cruising into the summer.
lead_paragraph: As today’s politicians go, Senator Michael Bennet is kind of boring. Ideologically moderate. Dispositionally low-key. Scandal-free. A sensible technocrat rather than a charismatic ideologue. Heck, when Mr. Bennet, a Colorado Democrat, ran for president in 2020, he joked that a perk of electing him would be that people could simply forget about him for days on end.

headline: Did Biden Just School the Republicans, or His Own Party?
abstract: The complicated ethical question of student loan forgiveness is only one part of the problem with higher education.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Depending on whom you ask, Joe Biden’s decision to forgive hundreds of billions of dollars in student loans is either the Democrats’ political masterstroke or a major political gift to Republicans. What’s your take?

headline: To Edward Enninful, Fashion is ‘Borderless’
abstract: The British Vogue editor wants to make the media — and the world — a more welcoming place.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since Edward Enninful became the editor-in-chief of British Vogue, a pattern has emerged: Whenever a new issue of the magazine comes out, it instantly becomes a part of the zeitgest — the cover often goes viral, and the inside images are shared and re-shared across social media.

headline: Fentanyl Test Strips Are ‘Catching On’ Among Cocaine Users
abstract: A rise in overdoses has prompted some drug users to make testing a party ritual.
lead_paragraph: A 29-year-old mental health worker in Brooklyn sometimes spends his weeknights singing at karaoke dive bars with friends, where he snorts cocaine before singing.

headline: A Retiree Finds Somewhere to Call Home in Brooklyn
abstract: A New Yorker found himself in a precarious housing situation after retirement. He finally moved into his own furnished one-bedroom apartment in East New York.
lead_paragraph: For Randall King, finding safe and affordable housing has been a pursuit since childhood.

headline: ‘Little Venice’ Finally Gets its Moment
abstract: With a ban on large cruise ships in the waters surrounding Venice, nearby Chioggia is one of the new go-to ports. While many welcome the new visitors, some worry that the tourism boom could turn sour.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 4, the Viking Sea, a 930-passenger cruise ship, docked in Italy’s Venetian Lagoon. At first sight, the scene looked familiar: a towering white vessel, loaded with tourists, most of them from North America, making its way past centuries-old buildings and narrow canals. But this time the destination wasn’t Venice, but Chioggia, a smaller, lesser-known city built on a separate cluster of islands about 15 miles away, in the same lagoon.

headline: Billie Jean King: What Makes Serena Williams So Watchable
abstract: When the champion, who helped professionalize women’s tennis, watches Williams play, she says, she thanks God: “Serena is living our dream.”
lead_paragraph: I’ve seen many generations come and go in tennis, and every time you see a great player retire, it’s really difficult. But the news that Serena Williams is moving on from tennis is particularly hard because of what she represents.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Elite Get Dragged Into Musk-Twitter Trial
abstract: More than 100 subpoenas have been issued to techies like Jack Dorsey and Marc Andreessen as Twitter tries to force Elon Musk to complete a $44 billion deal. Law firms are stoked.
lead_paragraph: Jack Dorsey, a founder of Twitter, got a subpoena. So did Marc Andreessen, a prominent venture capitalist. Larry Ellison, Oracle’s chairman, and the investors David Sacks and Joe Lonsdale received them, too.

headline: How Serena Williams Won the Fashion Game
abstract: The game-changing tennis player used her clothes as a statement of self and a weapon of change.
lead_paragraph: When Serena Williams steps out onto the hard courts of the U.S. Open on Monday for what may be her last tournament, she will do so in a little black (tennis) dress with long sheer sleeves, a six-layer skirt — one tier for every U.S. Open title she has won — and a bodice sparkling with a galaxy of stars. It is a dress made for a supernova’s farewell. It is fitting, in more ways than one. If you’re not paying attention to the symbolism, you’re whiffing the point.

headline: How Quitting a Job Changed My Relationships
abstract: We asked people who quit during the “Great Resignation” how it helped them reconnect with their loved ones. This is what they told us.
lead_paragraph: This has been a summer of laughter in Ana del Rocío’s home.

headline: How Bad Is the Teacher Shortage? Depends Where You Live.
abstract: Urgently needed: teachers in struggling districts, certified in math or special education. Perks: maybe a pay raise, or how about a four-day week?
lead_paragraph: The new fall semester has just begun in Mesa, Ariz., and Westwood High School is short on math teachers.

headline: Wolfgang Tillmans: Older, Wiser, Cooler
abstract: In a 35-year career celebrated at MoMA this fall, the artist has concerned himself with “the poetry of looking,” blurring the line between party and protest. But, increasingly, it’s politics on his mind.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was shortly after 11 a.m., and Wolfgang Tillmans’s studio was coming to life. Assistants had gathered in a corner of the huge, light-filled space and were running Tillmans through their plans. Hundreds of artworks were packed and ready to go, but there were a few busy days still ahead.

headline: What You Get for $2.6 Million in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern retreat in Los Angeles, a 1922 home in Oakland and a 1971 ranch house in Laguna Niguel.
lead_paragraph: A midcentury-modern retreat in Los Angeles, a 1922 home in Oakland and a 1971 ranch house in Laguna Niguel.

headline: $2.6 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern retreat in Los Angeles, a 1922 home in Oakland and a 1971 ranch house in Laguna Niguel.
lead_paragraph: The sellers, who bought this house in 2017, meticulously restored it to its original state and incorporated sustainable upgrades, including landscaping the property with native plants and installing a low-waste irrigation system.

headline: Is a Local Prosecutor Making the Strongest Case Against Trump?
abstract: A look at a sprawling inquiry into election interference and the Georgia prosecutor at the heart of it.
lead_paragraph: Since he left office, former President Donald J. Trump has been facing several investigations.

headline: Americans Who Stutter
abstract: President Biden’s approach to his own stutter highlights the stigma that the condition still brings.
lead_paragraph: About three million Americans — or almost 1 percent of the population — speak with a stutter.

headline: The Fed’s inflation warning reverberates in global markets.
abstract: Stocks slipped across Asia and Europe, and futures pointed to a downward opening on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Markets around the world fell on Monday, extending the previous week’s declines, as comments from officials at the Federal Reserve and other central banks on their determination to rein in rising prices continued to reverberate.

headline: Political Chaos Grips Iraq, With at Least 12 Killed in Street Clashes
abstract: The violence erupted after the powerful Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr said he is leaving politics. Protesters supporting Mr. Sadr took to the streets of the capital, Baghdad, and security forces opened fire.
lead_paragraph: Iraq sank deeper into political chaos on Monday after the influential Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr announced he was retiring from politics and at least 12 of his supporters were shot and killed by government security forces while protesting in the capital, Baghdad.

headline: Low Water Levels Disrupt European River Cruises, a Favorite of U.S. Tourists
abstract: As the continent faces a severe drought, companies have had to use buses to transport passengers along parts of the Rhine and the Danube, where water levels have become too low for riverboats.
lead_paragraph: Mark Farmer’s two-week river cruise from Amsterdam to Budapest got off to a bad start. For the first four days, there were no luxurious dinners overlooking the Rhine River or views from the top-deck balcony room that he and his wife had booked.

headline: The Escape Fantasies of Maurice Sendak
abstract: A new book collects six decades’ worth of the artist’s work.
lead_paragraph: “Where is far away?” Martin asks his preoccupied mother at the start of the 1957 children’s book “Very Far Away.” Its 28-year-old author and illustrator, Maurice Sendak, would spend his life searching for an answer.

headline: Nebraska School Shuts Down Student Newspaper After L.G.B.T.Q. Publication
abstract: In its final edition, the paper at a high school in Grand Island, Neb., published two opinion columns focused on L.G.B.T.Q. issues.
lead_paragraph: On March 31, the first period bell at Northwest High School in Grand Island, Neb., had just rung when the principal walked into a journalism classroom adorned with punctuation posters to deliver a new rule directly from administrators.

headline: How a Whistleblower Could Help Elon Musk in His Case Against Twitter
abstract: Twitter’s former security chief could loom large in Mr. Musk’s legal efforts to undo his $44 billion acquisition of the social network.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Twitter’s former security chief, Peiter Zatko, leveled serious allegations that Twitter had misled the public about its security practices. Twitter executives strongly reject the claims. But it’s becoming increasingly likely that Zatko’s accusations will take center stage in Elon Musk’s legal battle to extricate himself from buying Twitter, as Musk’s legal team foreshadowed late last week.

headline: NASA, and Space Fans, Await Decision on Next Chance to Launch Artemis Moon Rocket.
abstract: The mission’s managers will complete assessments before announcing whether the rocket could try to launch again this weekend.
lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — Thousands of people had packed the beaches, roadsides, rooftops and waterways. Some even camped overnight in hopes of seeing NASA’s giant new moon rocket launch for the first time, rising upward with a thunderous boom and jets of fire from its engines.

headline: Ukraine announces offensive operations across the south.
abstract: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military announced on Monday that it had launched offensive operations in multiple areas along the front line in the Kherson region in southern Ukraine, perhaps signaling the start of a broad and long anticipated counteroffensive aimed at retaking territory seized by Russia.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military announced on Monday that it had launched offensive operations in multiple areas along the front line in the Kherson region in southern Ukraine, perhaps signaling the start of a broad and long anticipated counteroffensive aimed at retaking territory seized by Russia.

headline: Lawmakers seek information on ‘buy now, pay later’ gun sales.
abstract: Eighteen Democrats in Congress are demanding answers from Credova Financial about its no-interest loans for gun and ammunition purchases.
lead_paragraph: Some members of Congress are demanding answers from a small Montana financial firm that has emerged as a major player providing no-interest financing to online gun buyers.

headline: What to Know About California’s Ban on New Gasoline-Powered Cars
abstract: By 2035, California shoppers looking for new vehicles will have to buy electric.
lead_paragraph: California made history late last week when its regulators approved an ambitious plan to phase out the sale of new gasoline-powered vehicles in the state.

headline: On a Busy First Day at the U.S. Open, All Eyes Are on Serena Williams
abstract: There are 63 other matches on opening day, but they have been relegated to the background as Williams prepares to play what could be her final singles match.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: China Charges 28 People, Months After Brutal Beating of Women
abstract: The attack at a restaurant, captured on video, prompted outraged discussion about misogyny. The government sought to change the topic to gangs.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A group of men caught on camera violently beating several women at a barbecue restaurant in June were charged on Monday, part of a wider investigation into the criminal activities of a local gang in the Chinese city of Tangshan.

headline: Taylor Swift Announces ‘Midnights,’ a New Album Written After Dark
abstract: The LP, described by Swift as “the story of 13 sleepless nights,” is due Oct. 21. It will be her 10th studio album, and her fifth release in just over two years.
lead_paragraph: We already knew that Taylor Swift was a restless creative force. Now we know that she is also an insomniac one.

headline: As Rome Burns (or at Least Its Garbage), a Mayor Dares to Dream
abstract: Could a solution to Rome’s perpetual trash crisis really be in sight? Mayor Roberto Gualtieri would like to think so.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For years now, nothing has symbolized the fall of Rome more than its garbage crisis. A trash menagerie of wild boars, violent sea gulls and rats convene to feast on the capital’s overflowing debris. Early this summer, a spate of suspicious blazes at garbage plants and scrapyards — literal dumpster fires — darkened the skies, choked the air, and raised the specter of arson and organized crime.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’: Steve Toussaint on Playing Lord Corlys, Boat Guy
abstract: One of the most powerful people in Westeros made his reputation as a fearless sailor. The actor who plays him does better on land.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the first two episodes of “House of the Dragon.”

headline: Honda and LG will jointly build a U.S. battery plant.
abstract: The announcement comes as the auto industry ramps up its efforts to switch to electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Honda and LG Energy Solution said on Monday that they would jointly build a battery plant in the United States for a slate of new electric cars the automaker is working on.

headline: Kenji’s New Guacamole Is Divine
abstract: His recipe takes inspiration from a Mexican restaurant in Bogotá, Colombia.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt recently brought us his recipe for guacamole with grilled corn (above), based on “esquimole” — a mash-up of guacamole and esquites, the corn-mayonnaise-cheese dish — that he tried at a Mexican restaurant in Bogotá, Colombia.

headline: Trump Request for Special Master Could Open Door for Delays to Investigation
abstract: The former president, who used the slow pace of litigation to run out the clock on congressional oversight, is seeking intervention that could lead to appeals and slow the documents inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As president, Donald J. Trump employed a consistent and largely successful strategy for fending off congressional oversight investigations: stonewall until the fight reached the courts. Even if judges eventually rejected his legal claims, he could use the slow pace of litigation to run out the clock.

headline: Elon Musk’s Lawyers Subpoena Twitter Whistle-Blower
abstract: Peiter Zatko’s accusations of false statements and security shortcomings at Twitter may be used by Mr. Musk in the legal battle over a $44 billion acquisition of the company.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s lawyers have subpoenaed Twitter’s former security chief, Peiter Zatko, they disclosed in a court filing Monday, signaling that Mr. Musk may try to use Mr. Zatko’s accusations of false statements and security shortcomings at Twitter as part of his attempt to break off an agreement he made to buy the social media company for $44 billion.

headline: Air France Under Scrutiny Over Safety Incidents
abstract: Two pilots have recently been suspended after a cockpit fight, bringing to light new concerns over poorly observed safety protocols at the French airline.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Air France pilots are under scrutiny after a series of incidents that have raised concerns over safety protocols on flights operated by the French flagship carrier, prompting aviation investigators to reprimand the airline last week.

headline: Did My Cat Just Hit On Me? An Adventure in Pet Translation
abstract: Entrepreneurs are aiming to put A.I.-powered pet translation tools into our pockets.
lead_paragraph: My cat is a bona fide chatterbox. Momo will meow when she is hungry and when she is full, when she wants to be picked up and when she wants to be put down, when I leave the room or when I enter it, or sometimes for what appears to be no real reason at all.

headline: Restaurant Review: Evelia’s Tamales, a Sidewalk Standby, Comes in From the Streets
abstract: The celebrated Queens food cart finds a storefront space, and the food is still just as good.
lead_paragraph: By 7 a.m. on most weekdays, when Evelia’s Tamales in North Corona, Queens, is in the thick of the morning rush, there is a good chance that all the tables will be empty.

headline: Bad Bunny’s Album Ties ‘Encanto’ for Most Weeks at No. 1 This Year
abstract: “Un Verano Sin Ti,” a streaming blockbuster, notches its ninth time at the top of Billboard’s chart. Rod Wave’s “Beautiful Mind,” last week’s No. 1, drops to second place.
lead_paragraph: Is Bad Bunny the new Bruno?

headline: More Children Are Swallowing Batteries and Landing in the E.R.
abstract: Twice as many kids needed treatment after putting button batteries in their mouths, noses and ears compared with the previous decade, a new study says. Here’s how to prevent it, and what to do if it happens.
lead_paragraph: Button batteries and lithium coin batteries power many electronic devices that families tend to have in their homes: TV remotes, key fobs, thermometers, scales, toys, flame-free candles — even singing greeting cards.

headline: Georgia Governor Must Testify in Trump Inquiry After Election
abstract: Gov. Brian P. Kemp, a Republican, unsuccessfully fought a subpoena to appear before a special grand jury in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A judge ruled on Monday that Gov. Brian P. Kemp of Georgia must appear before a special grand jury investigating election interference by former President Donald J. Trump, but will not be compelled to do so until after the Nov. 8 election.

headline: Is the Constitution Obstructing American Democracy?
abstract: Readers agree that U.S. democracy is broken, but disagree on how to fix it and whether the Constitution is to blame. Also: Books for prisoners; student activists; Philip Galanes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mets-Dodgers: ‘You Play This Game to Face the Best’
abstract: A three-game series against Los Angeles will give the Mets a chance to size themselves up. It could also create an opportunity for Atlanta to make up some ground.
lead_paragraph: In a season where they are on pace for 103 wins, the Mets have shaken off a lot of doubts about their sustainability, seemingly getting stronger as they go. They will get a crucial test of that strength against the Los Angeles Dodgers, the best team in baseball by a fairly wide margin.

headline: It’s Not Just You — Blank Street Coffee Is Suddenly Inescapable
abstract: Built around high-volume automated espresso systems, the rapidly expanding coffee shop has caught the attention of skeptical New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: In August 2020, a tiny, seafoam-green, electric-powered coffee cart opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, advertising local pastries and bagels and coffee beans. On Wythe Avenue, in the heart of one of New York City’s most coffee-saturated neighborhoods, another cute spot to buy an iced latte wasn’t cause for commotion.

headline: Jordan Peele Says There May Be More ‘Nope’ Stories to Come
abstract: We asked the writer-director about that standing shoe, a character called Nobody and fan theories about his flying-saucer movie. This is what he told us.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Peele has made only three feature films. But he seems to have packed a dozen movies’ worth of ideas into each.

headline: Be ‘Less Squeamish’ About Drinking Recycled Wastewater, British Official Says
abstract: As droughts become more frequent, drinking water that has been reprocessed from sewage treatment is the future, the head of Britain’s Environment Agency said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The head of Britain’s Environment Agency said this week that people need to be “less squeamish” about where their drinking water comes from since part of the response to prolonged droughts is reprocessing water from sewage treatment for use in residential taps.

headline: Carl Croneberg, Explorer of Deaf Culture, Dies at 92
abstract: He helped write the first comprehensive dictionary of American Sign Language and later identified the deaf as a part of society worth examining.
lead_paragraph: Carl Croneberg, a deaf Swedish immigrant who helped write the first comprehensive dictionary of American Sign Language and was the first to outline the idea of Deaf culture as a distinct part of society and one worth studying, died on Aug. 7. He was 92.

headline: Would You Take Out a Loan to Buy This Week’s Groceries?
abstract: Americans are increasingly turning to “buy now, pay later” services for food and other everyday essentials. And there are signs that the practice is putting some in deep debt.
lead_paragraph: Josh Roberts didn’t think twice about taking out a loan to pay for groceries. It was early in the pandemic, and he was making $16.50 an hour working for a technology company in Cincinnati while supporting his sister and her girlfriend.

headline: Julien Boulangerie Is Expanding With a New Bistro
abstract: A new Upper East Side location of Julien Khalaf’s bakery will add a 40-seat restaurant with waiter service in September.
lead_paragraph: The fourth and largest iteration of Julien Boulangerie, the native French baker Julien Khalaf’s bakery, has opened on the Upper East Side. Mr. Khalaf, who was an executive chef for François Payard, established two other nearby locations after the success of his original store in Park Slope, Brooklyn, which opened in 2020. What distinguishes the new bakery is its size, with an expanded kitchen and, coming on Sept. 22, a 40-seat bistro with waiter service, a full menu of salads, soups, hot dishes, beer, wine and, of course, desserts and pastries. The pastry and bread counters are already in full flourish, selling Mr. Khalaf’s specialty croissants, among many other items, and prepared sandwiches and salads.

headline: The New York City Wine and Food Festival Celebrates 15 Years
abstract: The annual citywide event is back with a Champagne dim sum brunch and a lavish vegan dinner.
lead_paragraph: This fall, the New York City Wine and Food Festival will mark its 15th year. Four days of events — from Oct. 13 to 16 — will involve restaurants and chefs for tastings, demos, lunches, dinners and so forth. New this year is a Champagne dim sum brunch led by the writer Molly Yeh, whose book “Home Is Where the Eggs Are” is included in the $225 ticket price. It will be on Sunday, Oct. 16, at 12:30 p.m., at Hutong, the high-end Chinese restaurant on East 58th Street. Another highlight is a lavish vegan dinner prepared by Lauren Von Der Pool, a chef to celebrities, with the chef and restaurateur JJ Johnson at the SoHo headquarters of God’s Love We Deliver, the festival’s charity partner, $295.

headline: Turn Out Fresh Baguettes With This Kit From Manresa Bread
abstract: The box comes with measured ingredients, a baking stone, a heavy linen couche and everything else you’ll need.
lead_paragraph: Avery Ruzicka, the co-founder and a partner in Manresa Bread, the sister bakeries to the Michelin three-star restaurant, Manresa, in Los Gatos, Calif., has assembled a kit for baking baguettes at home. The results, eight modestly sized loaves with properly crackling crusts, nice crumb and good flavor, are worth the two days of effort, much of it untended. In addition to premixed and measured flours, yeast and salt, the kit contains a baking stone, a heavy linen couche, a board for moving the loaves, and a razor and holder for slashing. The printed directions take you through the basics, but it pays to tune into Ms. Ruzicka’s exclusive video for necessary details like how to handle the dough and the fact that you’ll need additional flour. With the printed recipe, you’ll also have the measurements you need to obtain your own ingredients and replenish your breadbox.

headline: It’s a New Semester of Culinary Classes at DeGustibus
abstract: The cooking and dining sessions with professional chefs have been held at Macy’s for decades, and more recently in restaurants.
lead_paragraph: It’s back to school at DeGustibus, the cooking and dining sessions with professional chefs held for more than 40 years at Macy’s and in restaurants. Among the options on this fall’s lineup is a class covering the cooking of the Greek island of Crete, taught by Nick Poulmentis on Sept. 24 at 9:30 a.m. at his TriBeCa restaurant, Marathi — 200 Church Street (Duane Street), $300. A demonstration of seasonal recipes by Bryce Shuman of Sweetbriar in NoMad will be held Sept. 29 at 6 p.m., $135, at the De Gustibus Cooking School by Miele at Macy’s Herald Square.

headline: Make More Room on Your Charcuterie Board
abstract: The company Brooklyn Cured has released a black truffle salami, cured beef bresaola and a Tuscan red wine salami.
lead_paragraph: Founded in 2010, Brooklyn Cured, a local charcuterie producer, has remained true to its mission of using only pasture-raised meats from family farms. It recently introduced a line of pâtés under the Gilbert & Bernard label, and  has now added an earthy black truffle salami, cured beef bresaola spiked with Calabrian chiles and a rich Tuscan red wine salami made with beef, not the more typical pork. They’re sold on the company’s website and in a number of local markets.

headline: This Nonalcoholic Aperitivo Is More Bitter Than Sweet
abstract: The new offering from Wilderton, a nonalcoholic spirits company in Portland, Ore., is perfect for cocktail hour.
lead_paragraph: With a nod to vermouth and other bitter Italian drinks, Bittersweet Aperitivo, a new  contender from Wilderton, a nonalcoholic spirits company in Portland, Ore., is a cocktail hour success. It’s the company’s third such product in its two-year history and its best by a long shot. The reddish drink, long on the botanical components with a touch of chardonnay juice, delivers a boldly herbal aroma and a sharp edge, more bitter than sweet. Pour it on the rocks with a smidgen of fresh orange juice and a swipe of the peel on the rim of the glass. (The other two drinks from the company, Earthen and Lustre, are rather sour.)

headline: After Deadly Fires and Disastrous Floods, a Canadian City Moves to Sue Big Oil
abstract: A potential lawsuit by Vancouver would be the first in Canada to target the fossil fuel industry’s role in climate change.
lead_paragraph: LYTTON, British Columbia — Nothing has been rebuilt since flames devoured the tiny village of Lytton last year, turning it into a national symbol of climate change. It was in Lytton, about 90 miles northeast of Vancouver, that temperatures set a national record of 49.6 degrees Celsius — 121.3 Fahrenheit in Canada! — before the deadly fire erupted.

headline: Democrats in Georgia, Buoyed by Recent Wins, Seek to Keep Up Momentum
abstract: Policy victories for Democrats in Washington were made possible by the state’s Senate winners in 2020. “That work is not yet done,” Senator Raphael Warnock said at a convention.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga. — As President Biden and Democrats in Congress have notched some wins in Washington lately, Democrats in Georgia have been happily accepting the credit.

headline: ‘The Patient’ Review: The Doctor Is In. In the Basement.
abstract: The team behind “The Americans” returns with a darkly comic tale starring Steve Carell as a psychotherapist in chains.
lead_paragraph: Alan Strauss is an ideal therapist, kind, attentive, levelheaded. Gene is a problem patient who lies (his real name is Sam) and refuses to take off his sunglasses during sessions. When Alan regretfully says that things aren’t working because Gene won’t open up, Sam takes the logical next step: He kidnaps Alan, takes him to a place where Sam can open up — Sam’s nicely finished basement — and chains Alan to a hook in the floor so that they can finish the therapy. Oh, and the first thing Sam gets off his chest is that he’s a serial killer.

headline: Are You Ready for Your Fall Booster?
abstract: Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: A new booster campaign is just around the corner. Moderna and Pfizer’s vaccines, which have been updated to target the Omicron variants, will go through the final steps for approval later this week with the F.D.A. and the C.D.C. If greenlighted, these new shots could be offered as early as next week.

headline: F.T.C. sues over tracking data that could expose visits to abortion clinics.
abstract: Federal regulators said the sale of geolocation information on tens of millions of smartphones could expose people’s visits to private places.
lead_paragraph: Smartphone location tracking, a multibillion-dollar business in the United States, can reveal intimate details about Americans’ daily routines — including where they go for medical treatments, religious services or mental health counseling.

headline: Back at the U.S. Open, Leylah Fernandez Tries to Be ‘the Best Version of Myself’
abstract: After a foot injury sidelined her for much of the summer, Fernandez returns to Flushing Meadows with high expectations.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Emma Raducanu and Leylah Fernandez stood side by side on the platform to receive their United States Open trophies last year the two teenagers found themselves together in a nearly empty locker room beneath Arthur Ashe Stadium. By chance, their lockers were located right next to each other.

headline: An Orlando Museum’s Disputed Basquiats Are Gone. Its Leadership Is, Too.
abstract: In the wake of an F.B.I. raid, the crisis at the Orlando Museum of Art deepened amid upheaval on its board and the resignation of its interim director.
lead_paragraph: Since the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the Orlando Museum of Art in June and seized 25 paintings that the museum had attributed to Jean-Michel Basquiat but whose authenticity has been questioned, a cascading wave of departures has roiled the leadership of the embattled museum.

headline: Deshaun Watson and the Failed Politics of Personal Choices
abstract: We can boycott the N.F.L., but there won’t be enough of us to matter.
lead_paragraph: The numbers speak for themselves.

headline: Angola’s Ruling Party Retains Power in Tightest Election Yet
abstract: The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola won in the general election with the lowest margin since coming to power in 1975.
lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola — Angola’s ruling party on Monday was declared the winner of the general election, but it was its weakest showing in the five elections that have taken place since the country gained independence.

headline: San Francisco’s Art Market Struggles in the Shadow of Los Angeles
abstract: Though some small galleries are opening or expanding, the mega dealers have closed shop, a blow to an area with a vibrant artistic history.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The San Francisco art world has long been a vibrant center of experimentation and tradition, thriving in a city that has been a platform for literature, music, social activism and intellectual ferment.

headline: What Is the Jellyfish Haircut?
abstract: A Nicole Kidman photo shoot renewed interest in a hairstyle that looks like an avant-garde cousin of the mullet.
lead_paragraph: Pop quiz: What lives in the ocean, sports a mushroom top, radiates a trail of angel-hair tentacles and lends its name to a trendy internet haircut?

headline: The Day Rosa Santana Got Her Big Break
abstract: The entrepreneur, originally from Mexico, owns a company that assembles truck beds for Toyota in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: It was 2014 and Rosa Santana was running a successful staffing business. She had immigrated to the United States from Mexico at age 5 with her mother and four older siblings. She learned the staffing trade in 17 years at Kelly Services and three at Westaff, then built her own company that supplied workers to Dell, Johnson Controls, Ryder System and others. She staffed many of the suppliers to Toyota’s auto plant in San Antonio but hadn’t managed to get work from Toyota itself.

headline: Graham Predicts ‘Riots in the Streets’ if Trump Is Prosecuted
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham drew a comparison between the investigation of former President Donald J. Trump and a decision not to prosecute Hillary Clinton over using a private server.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham’s prediction on Sunday that a prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump would lead to “riots in the streets” added an element of menace to the fraught decisions facing Justice Department officials as they consider next steps in the investigation of Mr. Trump’s handling of classified material.

headline: Blake Masters, a G.O.P. Senate Candidate, Links Fed Diversity to Economic Woes
abstract: The sarcastic barb from Mr. Masters, which was widely condemned, was in response to a report of increased diversity at the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Blake Masters, the Republican nominee challenging Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, suggested in a sarcastic Twitter post late Sunday that the nation’s economic struggles were connected to increased gender and racial diversity in Federal Reserve leadership.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Charges 28 People in Beating of Women
abstract: Plus the controversy over seabed mining and the geopolitical drama surrounding Taiwan’s microchips
lead_paragraph: In June, four women in the Chinese city of Tangshan were beaten with chairs, kicked and dragged at a restaurant after one woman appeared to rebuff a man who had approached and touched her. Security camera footage of the event unleashed a torrent of outrage over violence against women in China.

headline: New Research Forecasts More Dire Sea Level Rise as Greenland’s Ice Melts
abstract: The study reached a more drastic conclusion than earlier assessments in part because it used a different method to gauge ice loss.
lead_paragraph: The melting of the Greenland ice sheet could eventually raise global sea levels by at least 10 inches even if humans immediately stop burning the fossil fuels that are warming the planet to dangerous levels, according to a new study published on Monday.

headline: For the Fourth Time, a Trooper Is Cleared in a Fatal Shooting
abstract: A Pennsylvania district attorney said no charges would be filed in the most recent shooting by Jay Splain, a state trooper who has killed four people in separate incidents.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania state trooper who has killed four people in separate on-the-job encounters over the past 15 years was cleared on Monday of any criminal charges in his most recent shooting.

headline: Ukraine Says It’s on the Attack
abstract: The military announced that it had launched operations in multiple areas in the south.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
abstract: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
lead_paragraph: Across Pakistan, torrents of floodwater have ripped away mountainsides, swept buildings off their foundations and roared through the countryside, turning whole districts into inland seas. More than 1,100 people have died so far, and more than one million homes have been damaged or destroyed.

headline: M.L.B. Players Association Working to Unionize the Minors
abstract: Authorization cards were sent to around 5,000 minor leaguers in hopes of creating a bargaining unit within the larger union.
lead_paragraph: In a significant shift, the Major League Baseball Players Association took a step toward organizing minor league players, sending them authorization cards on Sunday that would allow them to vote on becoming members of the union.

headline: As N.Y.C. Trash Problem Mounts, Garbage Will Be Picked Up on Labor Day
abstract: The Adams administration will pay Sanitation Department volunteers overtime to collect residential trash on the holiday this year.
lead_paragraph: Labor Day weekend is often about beach trips and cookouts, the air tinged with the smell of sunscreen and barbecue. But on the olfactory flip side, another tradition follows: hot, putrid mountains of trash.

headline: California Senate Passes Bill to Regulate Fast-Food Industry
abstract: If signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom, the measure would create a state council to establish minimum pay and safety conditions on an industrywide basis.
lead_paragraph: The California State Senate passed a bill on Monday that could transform the way the service sector is regulated by creating a council to set wages and improve working conditions for fast-food workers.

headline: A Ukrainian player upset Simona Halep in the first round of the U.S. Open.
abstract: Daria Snigur, a 20-year-old ranked 124th in the world, burst into tears after beating Halep, a two-time major singles champion.
lead_paragraph: Daria Snigur, 20, burst into tears after defeating Simona Halep of Romania, a two-time Grand Slam singles champion, in three sets on Monday in the first round of the U.S. Open.

headline: One Man Dies, and an Entire Uncontacted Tribe Vanishes in Brazil
abstract: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When officials from Brazil’s Indigenous protection agency approached the hut in the middle of the Amazon rainforest, their fears were confirmed: They were witnessing the first recorded disappearance of an uncontacted tribe in the country’s history.

headline: The Book That Explains Our Cultural Stagnation
abstract: Art has gotten so boring. W. David Marx knows why.
lead_paragraph: In May the literary critic Christian Lorentzen published a Substack newsletter about being bored. “Hollywood movies are boring. Television is boring. Pop music is boring. The art world is boring. Broadway is boring. Books from big publishing are boring,” he wrote.

headline: Uma Pemmaraju, an Original Fox News Channel Anchor, Dies at 64
abstract: She convinced her Indian parents to allow her to pursue journalism as a career, then went on to win three Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Uma Pemmaraju, an Indian American television journalist whose success on a local station in Boston led to her hiring in 1996 as one of the founding anchors at Fox News Channel, where she worked for nearly 20 years, died on Aug. 7 at her home in Ossining, N.Y. She was 64.

headline: Why Student Debt Relief Isn’t Elitist
abstract: No, it isn’t a bailout for slacker baristas.
lead_paragraph: Embarrassing admission: I have been watching the TV show “She-Hulk: Attorney at Law.” I’m not, in general, a fan of the superhero genre, but after “Orphan Black” I’ll watch anything starring Tatiana Maslany.

headline: Ukraine Launches Southern Offensive, as Inspectors Head to Nuclear Plant
abstract: The scale of Ukraine’s push in the Kherson region was unclear, but it has vowed for months to mount a counteroffensive to retake territory seized by Russia.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces launched ground assaults on Monday in multiple areas along the front in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine, apparently stepping up a counteroffensive aimed at recapturing territory seized by Russia.

abstract: “I am not a member of any organized party,” the humorist Will Rogers famously once quipped. “I am a Democrat.”
lead_paragraph: “I am not a member of any organized party,” the humorist Will Rogers famously once quipped. “I am a Democrat.”

lead_paragraph: The pastor of a prominent evangelical megachurch near Dallas abruptly announced an indefinite leave of absence on Sunday, effective immediately, because of an online relationship he had with a woman who is not his wife.

lead_paragraph: A former president, A-list actors and professional athletes were among the fans who packed into Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday to watch Serena Williams in the first round of the U.S. Open.

abstract: Floodwaters have swept buildings off their foundations, washed away bridges and roads and inundated the country’s farmland.

abstract: Olympia watched her mother in the first round of the U.S. Open from the stands of Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams won the Australian Open in 2017 when she was pregnant. Her daughter, Olympia, is now 4 (she turns 5 on Thursday), and was at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday night to watch her mother compete.

lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

abstract: Russia could deploy the drones in its war against Ukraine to conduct air-to-surface attacks, carry out electronic warfare and identify targets, according to U.S. officials.
lead_paragraph: Iran delivered to Russia the first batch of two types of military drones this month as part of a larger order totaling hundreds of the aerial war machines, according to an Iranian adviser to the government and two U.S. administration officials who were not authorized to speak on the record.

headline: Biden to Focus on ‘Battle for the Soul of the Nation’ in Prime-Time Speech
abstract: The president is set to return to his campaign theme of democracy in peril as his party fights to retain its hold on Congress in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will travel to Pennsylvania on Thursday to deliver a rare prime-time speech on what the White House called the “battle for the soul of the nation,” returning to the theme of democracy in peril that he used in the 2020 presidential campaign as his party fights to hold onto control of Congress in the looming midterm elections.

headline: Serena Williams Keeps Focus Amid the Fanfare
abstract: A star-studded crowd inside Arthur Ashe Stadium was joined by throngs of fans outside during Williams’s first-round U.S. Open match.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: Cheese That’s ‘Not Badda’
abstract: Hop into Emily Carroll’s Tuesday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a new day in the New York Times Crossword, and we have a grid art puzzle from Emily Carroll to welcome it. This is Ms. Carroll’s 15th crossword for The Times, and her fourth to make use of circles.

headline: Aspiring Proud Boy Who Encountered Schumer on Jan. 6 Gets 55 Months in Prison
abstract: Joshua Pruitt, 40, came face to face with the senator’s group as it fled to safety during the attack, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: During the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, Joshua Pruitt, a bartender, personal trainer and aspiring Proud Boys member from Silver Spring, Md., wore a tactical glove and an ankle monitor from a recent offense and climbed a makeshift ladder into the building, according to prosecutors, “seeking to overturn the election.”

headline: Tomatoes Spill Onto Interstate, Causing Crashes, Quips and Confusion
abstract: A crash involving a big-rig truck caused 150,000 tomatoes to scatter across Interstate 80 in Vacaville, Calif. Passing vehicles ground them into a slippery red pulp.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes in Solano County, Calif., where more than half the land is used for agriculture, residents can smell the earthy odor of tomatoes as big-rig trucks carry the product south to the Bay Area. Those trucks typically hold about 50,000 pounds of tomatoes in a hulking pile of red. A few are occasionally lost over the side thanks to sharp turns or bumps on the road.

headline: California Approves Bill to Punish Doctors Who Spread False Information
abstract: Weighing into the fierce national debate over Covid-19 prevention and treatments, the state would be the first to try a legal remedy for vaccine disinformation.
lead_paragraph: Trying to strike a balance between free speech and public health, California’s Legislature on Monday approved a bill that would allow regulators to punish doctors for spreading false information about Covid-19 vaccinations and treatments.

headline: Jill Biden Tests Negative for Coronavirus After Rebound Case
abstract: The first lady plans to return to the Washington area after isolating in Delaware.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jill Biden, the first lady, tested negative for the coronavirus on Monday after a rebound case had forced her back into isolation, according to the White House.

headline: The Real Insanity Exposed by ‘Gorilla Milk’
abstract: An experimental video about a gorilla yields insight into the violence of motherhood.
lead_paragraph: The collective mind-set in which I first saw the German-Danish artist Liesel Burisch’s 2020 short video “Gorilla Milk,” alone on a laptop screen, was one of strategic delusion.
