Online life under Covid’s early lockdowns was often a practice of suspended disbelief: Feel-good acts of togetherness like simultaneous remote streaming of movies were ways to distract from the pandemic’s violent divisions. Perhaps this is why a film about people heaping love on a gorilla appealed to me. It seemed soothing, even if its setting was a carceral institution like a zoo. “Gorilla Milk,” however, did not meet my need for comfort. It demanded I look directly at that which so often goes undescribed: the limits of love in confinement, including the cruelties we impose on women in the guise of “motherhood.”

headline: Thousands in Michigan Without Power After Midwest Storms Kill 3
abstract: A line of storms produced wind gusts from 60 to 80 miles per hour in some areas and knocked out power to thousands of customers in Michigan and Indiana.
lead_paragraph: Severe thunderstorms rolled through southern Michigan and northwest Ohio on Monday, leaving hundreds of thousands of customers without power in the region and killing three people, including an 11-year-old boy who was swept into a drain as the storm system stretched into Arkansas, the authorities said.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine launches a southern offensive.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces launched ground assaults yesterday in multiple areas along the front in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine, apparently stepping up a counteroffensive aimed at recapturing territory seized by Russia.

headline: Quotation of the Day: On the Nation’s Trains, the Rhythm of Life Comforts the Passengers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 30, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Trains are made from iron. So are the people who work on them.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 30, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 30, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the sale of the art collection of the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen omitted a material used for “Small False Start.” It was encaustic, acrylic and paper collage, not just acrylic and paper collage.

headline: Are You a U.S. Open Fan? This Test Will Tell.
abstract: Tennis and trivia go together. So let’s see if you have the brain power to finesse your way through the 2022 edition of our U.S. Open quiz.
lead_paragraph: Tennis and trivia go together. So let’s see if you have the brain power to finesse your way through the 2022 edition of our U.S. Open quiz.

headline: I’m a Ukrainian Soldier, and I’ve Accepted My Death
abstract: So it must be for those who tread the path of war.
lead_paragraph: IVANKIV, Ukraine — Recently, one of the companies in our battalion returned from a mission in eastern Ukraine. When we saw our comrades a month earlier, they were smiling and cheerful. Now they don’t even talk to one another, never take off their bulletproof vests and don’t smile at all. Their eyes are empty and dark like dry wells. These fighters lost a third of their personnel, and one of them said that he would rather be dead because now he is afraid to live.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Skirting Ethics Order, Hochul Seeks Donations From Cuomo Appointees
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s campaign says contributions from board and commission members and their families are fair game because she did not appoint them.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — On the road to building one of the largest campaign war chests the state of New York has ever seen, Gov. Kathy Hochul has been taking money from appointees of the governor — despite an executive order designed to prevent it.

headline: Serena Williams Rises to the Occasion, Like So Many Times Before
abstract: Williams met a valedictory night at the U.S. Open with a win that was fitting, and with a second-round match on Wednesday, the farewell party at Arthur Ashe Stadium continues.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: Biden’s Student Loan Plan Sets Off Fierce Debate Among Economists
abstract: Liberals and more moderate Democrats are arguing over the impact on inflation, the federal budget deficit and high earners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s plan to forgive some student debt has sharply divided liberal economists and pitted the White House economic team against both independent analysts and veterans of past Democratic administrations.

headline: A Surprise Senate Race Rises Out West
abstract: Senator Michael Bennet, a Democrat seeking re-election in Colorado, faces a challenge from Joe O’Dea, a novice Republican emphasizing more moderate positions in a break with his party.
lead_paragraph: GRANBY, Colo. — It was a bit tense for a groundbreaking ceremony.

headline: The Animal Translators
abstract: Scientists are using machine learning to eavesdrop on naked mole rats, fruit bats, crows and whales — and to communicate back.
lead_paragraph: The naked mole rat may not be much to look at, but it has much to say. The wrinkled, whiskered rodents, which live, like many ants do, in large, underground colonies, have an elaborate vocal repertoire. They whistle, trill and twitter; grunt, hiccup and hiss.

headline: Death in Navy SEAL Training Exposes a Culture of Brutality, Cheating and Drugs
abstract: The elite force’s selection course is so punishing that few make it through, and many of those who do resort to illicit tactics.
lead_paragraph: CORONADO, Calif. — Kyle Mullen always had the natural drive and talent that made success look easy. Until he tried out for the Navy SEALs.

headline: How ‘the Most Vicious, Horrible Animal Alive’ Became a YouTube Star
abstract: Joseph Carter, known to his online followers as the Mink Man, trains feisty carnivores to rid canals and urban river banks of midsize pests.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — It was late in the day for muskrats to be out on Mill Creek, or at least the stretch that runs between a parking lot and a playground near the southern limits of the city. But there they were, two of them, one big and one small, paddling back and forth past each other like furry ships in the afternoon, seemingly unaware they were being filmed.

headline: Towering Over Midtown: The Penn Station Super-Talls
abstract: The proposed project would include buildings in the West 30s that would be among the tallest worldwide, with one tower that could surpass One World Trade.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the massive real estate project that New York State wants to build around Pennsylvania Station and where those buildings would rank among the city’s tallest. Also, we examine a source of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s campaign donations.

headline: I Have Face Blindness. This Is How I Recognize You.
abstract: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.
lead_paragraph: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Factions Turn Their Guns on Each Other in a Deadly New Phase
abstract: With no functioning government and no common ground, tensions among Shiite political factions have become a deadly matter in Baghdad this week.
lead_paragraph: After years of harsh repression under Saddam Hussein, Iraq’s majority Shiites finally came to political power in the wake of the 2003 U.S. invasion, and have largely held on to it through wrenching chapters of sectarian civil war, terrorist uprisings and internal tensions.

headline: Sweeping Children’s Online Safety Bill Is Passed in California
abstract: The new rules, which would require many online services to increase protections for children, could change how popular social media and game platforms treat minors.
lead_paragraph: Social media and game platforms often use recommendation algorithms, find-a-friend tools, smartphone notices and other enticements to keep people glued online. But the same techniques may pose risks to scores of children who have flocked to online services that were not specifically designed for them.

headline: By the Numbers: Electric Vehicle Minerals
abstract: There's a dirty side to creating clean cars.
lead_paragraph: There's a dirty side to creating clean cars.

headline: Historical Novels With Hints of Spirituality and Magic
abstract: In three journeys to the past, characters find themselves on quests that have nothing to do with the calendar or geography.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the oldest plot devices going: what Mark Twain called “lighting out for the territory.” But a character’s disappearing act can be effected in any number of original ways — and for any number of reasons. Small wonder, then, that it’s turned up in the work of three very different writers as they make their own excursions into the past.

headline: The Elderly Man I’ve Been Helping Turns Out to Be a Bigot. What Do I Do?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on helping someone whose views you find repugnant.
lead_paragraph: I have been visiting and helping out a solitary older gentleman through a mutual-aid organization. He clearly values our time together. But on a recent visit he revealed repugnant beliefs — that Jews control the world and Black people are genetically inferior to whites. My attempts to disabuse him went nowhere. Does my ethical obligation to help this person override a desire to reject those ideas? Does it even matter if an isolated person believes terrible things? Name Withheld

headline: A Grammy-Nominated Singer Performs and Explores Music’s Deep Power Over Us
abstract: Allison Russell discusses — and demonstrates — the craft of songwriting and how to find ‘survivor’s joy’ through music.
lead_paragraph: In times of deep sorrow or joy, humans have always turned to music. Archaeologists have found evidence of instruments among very early civilizations. Spiritual communities have centered on music for centuries. We teach our children their ABCs and how to brush their teeth with songs. We dance out our feelings and cry along with sad tunes. What is it about music that enables it to work so powerfully on our bodies, minds and emotions?

headline: 3 Essay Collections Offer Guides to Great Art and Literature
abstract: Cultural criticism from Gary Indiana, David Collard and Charles Baxter.
lead_paragraph: It requires no genius to be disgusted with our culture these days, but Gary Indiana expresses his own disdain with a rare intelligence. The essays collected in FIRE SEASON: Selected Essays 1984-2021 (352 pp., Seven Stories, paper, $23.95) are erudite, discomforting and often caustic — and almost always spot on, which is a little sad because they tell us such ugly true things.

headline: I Have Face Blindness. This Is How I Recognize You.
abstract: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all been there: You run into people on the street, and you suspect you’ve met them before — they certainly seem to know you. But you can’t locate them in the complicated tapestry of memory. Frustration and embarrassment well up inside you, putting recall farther out of reach. So you fake it and beat a hasty retreat.

headline: Ted Cruz Would Like to Put Some Words in Your Mouth
abstract: The idea that student loan relief is a handout to a small minority of affluent college graduates is simply a myth.
lead_paragraph: Critics of President Biden’s plan to relieve the debt of millions of Americans with federal student loans have made a considered choice to put their words in the mouths of an imagined group of working-class and blue-collar voters, angry and aggrieved at debt forgiveness for upper-income college graduates.

headline: Why I Changed My Mind on Student Debt Forgiveness
abstract: Our current system of student loans and college funding is at odds with what we hope to achieve by encouraging people to go to college.
lead_paragraph: As an economist who studies education, I long thought that forgiving student loans was a crude and inequitable tool for fixing student aid. College graduates, after all, are the winners in our society. College certainly changed my life: My father was a high school dropout, but his daughter is a Harvard professor. My student loans (which I paid off just a few years ago) were absolutely worth it. A bachelor’s degree, on average, puts graduates on a path to economic security.

headline: With This Sequel, the World of ‘The Miniaturist’ Gets Bigger
abstract: In “The House of Fortune,” Jessie Burton’s characters are 18 years older and much has changed.
lead_paragraph: Sequels, according to the economic laws of publishing, are not necessities but calculations. They mean simply that something you’ve written has done well enough out of the gate that your publisher has moved the gate down the road. The vast majority of authors will never have their gate moved — not forward — but they will at least be spared the hard question of how to carry a story past its natural endpoint. Push down the same lane? Hack out a new road? Or, upon further thought, engage in white-hot panic?

headline: Bill Barr Made the Decision to Clear Trump, and That Should Still Frighten Us
abstract: The ability to investigate future high-level wrongdoing in the executive branch is at stake.
lead_paragraph: The Trump-era memo released last week by the Justice Department closing the book on the report of the special counsel Robert Mueller and his inquiry into Russian interference in the 2016 election is a frightening document. Critics have rightly focused on its substance, slipshod legal analysis and omission of damning facts.

headline: From Red Lobster to Running Some of New York’s Marquee Restaurants
abstract: Chip Wade takes over Danny Meyer’s role in running Union Square Hospitality Group, a move that signals a growing conversation between two sides of the industry.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who witnessed the rise of fine dining in New York City during the 1980s and ’90s would hardly have bet that Danny Meyer — whose personal touch, food sensibility and laser focus on hospitality has influenced a generation of American restaurants — would pick a Red Lobster executive to replace him as the head of his restaurant group.

headline: The Allure of the Lurid? Elementary, My Dear Reader!
abstract: In “The Life of Crime,” Martin Edwards takes on the colorful history of the detective novel, and its enduring fascination.
lead_paragraph: In the 1920s, the author (and priest) Ronald Knox came up with what became known as the “Ten Commandments” for writing a mystery. Among them: The character who is the criminal must be mentioned early on; the detective isn’t the culprit, and can’t be helped by accident or unaccountable intuition; only one secret room or passage per story; no supernatural agencies, Chinamen or doubles. These rules made fun of the more outlandish tropes of the genre while also reflecting a particular conception of detective fiction.

headline: Does CBD Help With Insomnia?
abstract: The research is sparse, experts say, but there are some hints about how it could soothe you to sleep.
lead_paragraph: Q. Does CBD alleviate insomnia?

headline: Introducing ‘The Run-Up’
abstract: The midterm elections are usually a referendum on the party in power. This year, they’re about so much more.
lead_paragraph: First launched in August 2016, three months before the election of Donald Trump, “The Run-Up” is back.

headline: ‘Not My Choice.’ A TV Anchor Is Ousted, and Viewers Ask: Was Sexism to Blame?
abstract: The chief executive of a Canadian news network pushed back against allegations that sex, age or gray hair were factors in the abrupt dismissal of the veteran journalist, Lisa LaFlamme.
lead_paragraph: From a makeshift studio and with a news anchor’s measured tones, one of Canada’s most familiar faces shocked viewers, created a PR disaster at a national broadcaster and set off intense conversations about how employers treat women as they age.

headline: How German Companies Are Staring Down Putin’s Threat to Cut Off Gas
abstract: Industrial producers across Germany are coming up with unique ways to cut their dependence on natural gas as Russia’s war in Ukraine keeps prices high.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after Russia invaded Ukraine, German lawmakers cautiously proposed ways to cut their country’s ties to Russian natural gas. The heads of some of Germany’s leading industrial companies, long reliant on Russian gas, wanted no part of it.

headline: Maggie O’Farrell Looks for Stories Hiding in Plain Sight
abstract: Her latest book, “The Marriage Portrait,” imagines the life of the girl who is thought to have inspired Robert Browning’s famous poem “My Last Duchess.”
lead_paragraph: When the author Maggie O’Farrell was 6 or 7 years old, she loved writing secret messages in lemon juice and revealing them by toasting the paper over a candle. Then one day, she set the front of her hair on fire.

headline: For Singapore’s Gay Men, Repeal of Sex Ban Brings Hope After Years of Pain
abstract: The government confirmed that it would get rid of the colonial-era law, but said it would also move to protect the definition of marriage from being challenged in court.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Roy Tan remembers the fear of being a gay man in Singapore in the 1980s and 1990s. Having consensual sex with another man was punishable by imprisonment. Undercover police officers would chat up unsuspecting gay men in quiet parks and beaches, wait for them to suggest sex, then swoop in and make an arrest.

headline: Ayo Edebiri and Her Dog Gromit Go to the Bookstore
abstract: A morning out in Los Angeles with the surprise star of “The Bear” and her Chihuahua mix.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ayo Edebiri has an arresting screen presence because she doesn’t look like she’s acting. In “The Bear,” the frenetic restaurant drama that has been one of the most talked-about shows of the summer, she is usually the calm at the center of the storm.

headline: This Remote Mine Could Foretell the Future of America’s Electric Car Industry
abstract: Hiding a thousand feet below the earth’s surface in this patch of northern Minnesota wetlands are ancient mineral deposits that some view as critical to fueling America’s clean energy future.
lead_paragraph: TAMARACK, Minn. — In this isolated town of about 100 people, dozens of employees are at work for Talon Metals, drawing long cylinders of rock from deep in the earth and analyzing their contents. They liken their work to a game of Battleship — each hole drilled allows them to better map out where a massive and long-hidden mineral deposit is lurking below.

headline: Lockdowns in China, and North Korea, Deal Double Blow to Bridge City
abstract: Shenyang, in China’s northeast, was a hub for North Korean workers and a launchpad for visits to Pyongyang. Covid restrictions have battered its economy.
lead_paragraph: SHENYANG, China — There are plenty of reasons that business has been lousy recently at Steven Wen’s clothing store in Shenyang, the largest city in northeastern China.

headline: Jonathan Majors Is More Than a Marvel Supervillain
abstract: Inside​ ​the​ ​captivating​ ​mind​ ​of​ ​a new Hollywood star.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Majors started his day — as he usually does — at 4:30 a.m. He likes the solitude of morning: the quiet, the clean slate. London had come to feel more than ever like home, but on this October day, well before dawn, he found himself in a hotel room on the Sunset Strip. He hadn’t slept well, and this quick business trip back to Los Angeles left his mind in multiple places. But he was used to that by now, so what was bothering him? Jet lag no longer fazed him. Neither did nerves. His appearance on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” had gone well — “Boy, you’ve had some year, haven’t you?” Kimmel asked him, though both of them knew it was more statement than question. The N.F.L. promo shoot for Fox was flawless — one take. The Screen Actors Guild screening of Netflix’s Black cowboy adventure, “The Harder They Fall,” and the Q. and A. afterward, had been successful enough, he guessed. So, what was it?

headline: The Enduring Echoes of Moorish Spain
abstract: Exploring the country’s Arab influence is an impossibly romantic journey, involving palaces with intricate geometric designs, castles and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.
lead_paragraph: There is a way through Spain that is all horseshoe arches, keyhole windows and bronze doors carved in Arabic script. It meanders into crenelated forts, Moorish castles overlooking the Mediterranean and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.

headline: Government Will Cancel $1.5 Billion in Loans for Westwood College Students
abstract: The Education Department intends to wipe out the federal debt of those who attended the for-profit school from 2002 until it closed in 2016 without requiring them to apply.
lead_paragraph: Federal student loans totaling $1.5 billion will automatically be canceled for nearly 80,000 borrowers who went to Westwood College, a for-profit trade school that shut down in 2016, the Education Department said on Tuesday.

headline: Inside the Adolescent Mental Health Crisis
abstract: Young people in the United States are facing a new set of risks. Why has the situation caught so many people off guard?
lead_paragraph: This episode contains discussions about suicide, self-harm and mental health issues.

headline: At Home With Sarah Steele, in Brooklyn Heights
abstract: The actress, who plays Marissa Gold on “The Good Fight,” fell hard for her new two-bedroom co-op — and for her new partner, a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: The actress, who plays Marissa Gold on “The Good Fight,” fell hard for her new two-bedroom co-op — and for her new partner, a lawyer.

headline: Sarah Steele, of ‘The Good Fight,’ on Finding Love in Brooklyn
abstract: The actress, who plays Marissa Gold on the legal drama, fell hard for her new Brooklyn Heights co-op — and for her new partner, a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: During her 20s, like countless other New Yorkers in that age group, Sarah Steele “bopped around apartments that mostly, you know, weren’t so nice,” she said.

headline: Elon Musk Cites Whistle-Blower Report as Reason to Scrap Twitter Deal
abstract: The billionaire said in a letter to Twitter that allegations made by a whistle-blower have had a “material, if not existential” effect on the company.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s lawyers argued that the recent whistle-blower report by Pieter Zatko, Twitter’s former security chief, provided additional reasons for Mr. Musk to walk away from his agreement to buy Twitter for $44 billion and asked to postpone his legal battle with the company while the claims were investigated.

headline: A Poorer Generation
abstract: Americans under 40 have had to cope with a worse economy than earlier generations. How should it affect the debate over Biden’s debt-relief plan?
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to find a signature example of somebody who did not need to have his student loans forgiven, you might want to consider me.

headline: Venice Film Festival 2022: What to Watch For
abstract: The event fires the award-season starting pistol with some of the most anticipated films of the year — including “White Noise,” “The Whale” and “Don’t Worry Darling.”
lead_paragraph: Though Sundance debuted last year’s Academy Award best-picture winner, “CODA,” and Cannes can be counted on to launch major international films like “Parasite” and “Drive My Car,” when it comes to the real kickoff for Oscar season — the mad crush of prestige films, A-list cocktail parties and awards-show buzz that churns all fall and winter — it’s the Venice Film Festival that fires the starting pistol.

headline: Mississippi’s Capital Loses Water as a Troubled System Faces a Fresh Crisis
abstract: In Jackson, residents have long contended with boil-water notices and service disruptions. But now, officials say, the system has been pushed to the brink.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — More than 150,000 people in Mississippi’s capital were without access to safe drinking water on Tuesday, forcing officials to tackle what they described as the “massively complicated task” of distributing bottled water and devising a plan to restore service without a firm sense of how long that would take.

headline: Mississippi Water Declared ‘Not Safe to Drink’ as Treatment Plant Fails
abstract: Officials in Jackson, Miss., said the city’s largest water treatment plant was failing. Jackson’s water system was already in poor repair, and days of torrential rainfall have disrupted water treatment operations.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Jackson, Miss., said the city’s largest water treatment plant was failing. Jackson’s water system was already in poor repair, and days of torrential rainfall have disrupted water treatment operations.

headline: China Sets Key Communist Party Congress for Mid-October
abstract: Xi Jinping is poised to win five more years in power at the congress, a choreographed ritual that will offer a glimpse of China’s broad policy direction.
lead_paragraph: A Communist Party congress that is poised to anoint Xi Jinping as China’s top leader for another five years will open in Beijing on Oct. 16, officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Nuclear inspectors are in Ukraine for a high-stakes visit to the Zaporizhzhia plant.
abstract: As artillery strikes continued near the complex, the inspectors could reach the nuclear plant as soon as Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A team of international nuclear inspectors was in Ukraine on Tuesday as part of a risky trip to assess the safety of a nuclear power plant that has been repeatedly struck by artillery shells, hoping to provide the world a first impartial glimpse of the threat.

headline: A Frontline Shadow Economy: Ukrainian Units Swap Tanks and Artillery
abstract: Most of the bartering involves items captured from Russian troops, which are exchanged for urgently needed supplies. “Let’s just call it a simplification of bureaucracy,” one soldier said.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — The Ukrainian sergeant slid the captured Russian rocket launcher into the center of a small room. He was pleased. The weapon was practically brand-new. It had been built in 2020, and its thermobaric warhead was deadly against troops and armored vehicles.

headline: California Bids for Tighter Rein on Fast-Food Chains
abstract: The bill, which would create a state council to establish minimum pay and safety conditions, was the subject of a giant lobbying battle.
lead_paragraph: California’s State Senate yesterday passed a bill that would create a council to set wages and working conditions for the fast-food industry, after furious lobbying from both unions and the industry.

headline: Google Employee Who Played Key Role in Protest of Contract With Israel Quits
abstract: The worker said the company had tried to retaliate against her activism opposing a deal with the Israeli military, while co-workers argued the company had an anti-Palestinian bias.
lead_paragraph: A Google employee who became the most visible opponent of a company contract with the Israeli military said on Tuesday that she would resign after claiming Google had tried to retaliate against her for her activism.

headline: The Vatican, for the first time, calls Russia the aggressor in the war.
abstract: Condemning the invasion as “unacceptable,” the Vatican sought to calm a controversy caused by earlier remarks by Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican on Tuesday for the first time said that Russia was the aggressor in the Ukraine war, condemning Moscow’s invasion in strong terms after earlier comments by Pope Francis prompted criticism from Kyiv.

headline: Chris Dawson, Subject of ‘Teacher’s Pet’ Podcast, Is Found Guilty of Wife’s Murder
abstract: Mr. Dawson was on trial in Australia. His wife, Lynette Dawson, went missing in 1982, and a popular podcast brought new attention to the cold case.
lead_paragraph: Chris Dawson, who was arrested in 2018 after the true-crime podcast “The Teacher’s Pet” shed new light on the disappearance of his wife in 1982, was found guilty of her murder on Tuesday in an Australian court.

headline: Brutal Heat Wave Expected in California This Week
abstract: A scorcher will bring triple-digit temperatures to much of Central and Southern California through Labor Day, weather officials say.
lead_paragraph: While much of the country has suffered extreme heat waves this summer, California has in large part been spared. But that reprieve is over.

headline: A Leading Choreographer Joins the War Effort, With Classical Ballet
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky, one of the most important figures in ballet, is supporting Ukraine by staging “Giselle” with a company made up of Ukrainian refugees.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky was leading a newly formed ballet company of Ukrainian dancers who have fled the war in a run-through of “Giselle,” a 19th-century classic, in a repurposed conservatory here where the dancers have been rehearsing, and some living, since April.

headline: Gabriel Byrne’s ‘Walking With Ghosts’ Is Heading to Broadway
abstract: The play, adapted from his memoir of the same name, will run for 75 performances starting in October.
lead_paragraph: To Gabriel Byrne, his play “Walking With Ghosts,” adapted from his memoir of the same name, doesn’t refer to haunting phantoms but the lost people and places that we carry within us.

headline: Dancing Up a Political Storm
abstract: The prime minister of Finland was caught on the dance floor. This is a bad thing?
lead_paragraph: After the release of videos this month showing Sanna Marin, the prime minister of Finland, dancing and posing with friends at a private gathering, some in Finland suggested that Ms. Marin had created a security risk by drinking alcohol, and called for a police investigation. The head of the opposition party pushed the 36-year-old prime minister to take a drug test, which Ms. Marin agreed to do. The test came back negative.

headline: Serena Williams Fans, Unite
abstract: Serena Williams fans are gathering across the city to watch the champion play.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams fans are gathering across the city to watch the champion play.

headline: With ‘Tár,’ Todd Field Returns to Directing. Where Has He Been?
abstract: Sixteen years after “In the Bedroom” and “Little Children” made waves, he’s nervous about stepping back into the limelight with a hot-button story.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Todd Field isn’t ready to reappear just yet.

headline: Laura Linney to Return to Broadway in New David Auburn Play
abstract: “Summer, 1976,” about a friendship between two women in Ohio, will open next spring at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
lead_paragraph: Laura Linney will return to Broadway next spring, in a new play by David Auburn about a friendship that arises between two women during America’s bicentennial.

headline: The ’90s Partisans Who Fueled the Rise of Grievance Conservatism
abstract: A new book by the historian Nicole Hemmer charts the demise of Reagan-style optimism and the birth of a rage-and-fear-based politics on the right.
lead_paragraph: Even for those of us who remember them all too well, the 1990s were something of a muddle. The decade was like a long transitional moment between the casually rapacious spirit that preceded it and the War on Terror that came after.

headline: ‘What Do I Want to Do With My Life?’
abstract: Readers discuss the decisions facing college graduates. Also: Lindsey Graham’s prediction; housing discrimination; babies and minimalism.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Pakistan was hit so hard
abstract: Floods have killed at least 1,100 and submerged about a third of the country. We explain the factors making it so bad.
lead_paragraph: After a spring of deadly heat waves, summer floods have killed more than 1,100 people in Pakistan. Since June, rains have washed away buildings, submerged homes and destroyed roads. One-third of the country is underwater.

headline: Daniel Vogelbach Stays Ready. For the Mets or Any Other Team.
abstract: Vogelbach, a left-handed power hitter, has bounced around, but he has loved his stint in Queens — even when his manager gets him warmed up but leaves him on the bench.
lead_paragraph: Manager Buck Showalter of the Mets has been coaching in professional baseball since 1985, and he has learned there are some lines you don’t want to cross.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Widens Definition of ‘Family’
abstract: The court declared that same-sex parents, single parents and blended families deserve equal treatment, the latest in a series of rulings pushing back on conservative social norms.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court has ruled that family benefits under the law must be extended to blended families, same-sex couples and other households the court considers “atypical,” widening its definition of family. It is the latest in a series of court decisions to challenge the country’s conservative mores, and it could have major implications for the rights of women and gay people.

headline: After a Quiet August, Hurricane Forecasters Are Watching Potential Storms
abstract: Meteorologists were monitoring three disturbances, after the first August in 25 years without a named storm in the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: After the first August in 25 years in which there has not been a named storm in the Atlantic Ocean, meteorologists were monitoring three disturbances that could bring an end to what has so far been an unusually quiet hurricane season.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 10: On ‘How to Fall Out of Love With Your Lawn’
abstract: As our 13th Summer Reading Contest ends, we congratulate this week’s winner and thank the thousands of students who participated.
lead_paragraph: Our Summer Reading Contest is our longest-running challenge and perhaps our simplest: To participate, all you have to do is answer the questions, What got your attention in The Times this week? Why?

headline: Frustrations Mount at Washington Post as Its Business Struggles
abstract: With digital subscriptions and digital advertising revenue stagnating, the company is on a pace to lose money this year.
lead_paragraph: In the years after Jeff Bezos bought The Washington Post in 2013, business boomed. Droves of readers bought digital subscriptions, and the newsroom roughly doubled in size, adding hundreds more journalists.

headline: How Did ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Get Those Dogfight Scenes? Joseph Kosinski Explains.
abstract: The director behind the biggest movie of 2022 so far discusses trying to make a movie that can’t be traced to any particular year and the meaning of Dad Cinema.
lead_paragraph: The WhatsApp message arrived on May 10. “I got my call sign,” was all it read, signed “Strike.” And in the weeks that followed, leading up to the release of “Top Gun: Maverick” and after it finally opened, every message from my dad was also signed Strike.

headline: Europe’s Gonna Party Like It’s 1979
abstract: Sometimes you just can’t let markets rip.
lead_paragraph: You probably have to be a senior citizen to remember the gasoline shortages of 1979. I am, and I do. I also remember how demoralizing they were. Then as now, outside a few big cities, America was a highly car-dependent nation, and waiting in long lines, not knowing whether you would be able to fill up, was deeply disconcerting.

headline: First Solar says it will spend up to $1.2 billion to expand U.S. production.
abstract: The solar panel maker will build a factory in the Southeast and expand three Ohio plants, creating nearly 1,000 jobs.
lead_paragraph: First Solar, a big solar panel manufacturer, said on Tuesday that it would invest up to $1.2 billion to build its fourth factory in the United States, in large part because Congress this month passed a major energy and climate bill that expands incentives for renewable energy.

headline: Flex Mussels, an Upper East Side Fixture, Relocates Nearby
abstract: A Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, chop house from the owners of Popina, an East Village bar deeply influenced by Japan and Thailand, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: After 15 years in the East 80s, Flex Mussels has moved. A Feb. 14 fire and the availability of a nearby space, which the owners of Flex Mussels, Bobby Shapiro; his wife, Laura; and daughter Alexandra, had been eyeing for some time, generated the change. “We’re a neighborhood restaurant, and we wanted to stay in the neighborhood, to support it, especially after Covid,” Alexandra Shapiro said. With 160 seats on two floors, its new headquarters is larger than the original (and its West Village branch). The Shapiros have also taken the menu in a few different directions. “We’re emphasizing more crudos and ceviches made with local fish,” Ms. Shapiro said. They are expanding the oyster varieties they’re serving and, to oversee the raw bar offerings, including razor clams and shrimp, they have hired Patrick McMurray, a Canadian expert who is said to hold a world record for his shucking speed. Now running the kitchen, which prepares mussels 10 ways, is a New York City veteran chef, Wolfgang Ban. The restaurant conveys its nautical approach without overdoing it.

headline: Cameron Smith, Winner of This Year’s British Open, Joins LIV Golf
abstract: Smith’s defection had been expected, but Rory McIlroy tried to stave it off back in July.
lead_paragraph: Cameron Smith, the world’s second-ranked golfer and a player whose exceptional final-round putting carried him to this year’s British Open title, will join LIV Golf, the breakaway series financed with money from Saudi Arabia.

headline: When Japan Surrendered, Wars Broke Out
abstract: In “A Continent Erupts,” Ronald H. Spector chronicles the violent, internecine conflicts that overwhelmed Asia in the decade after World War II.
lead_paragraph: A CONTINENT ERUPTS: Decolonization, Civil War, and Massacre in Postwar Asia, 1945-1955, by Ronald H. Spector

headline: Trump Hires Former Florida Solicitor General as Lawyer in Documents Case
abstract: The former president has brought Christopher M. Kise onto his legal team after struggling to find high-profile lawyers willing to work for him on the investigation into his handling of classified material.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has hired a high-profile lawyer to help him with the aftermath of the F.B.I. search of his club and home in Florida and the criminal investigation into his handling of sensitive government documents.

headline: Hard Right Stokes Outrage After Search of Mar-a-Lago
abstract: As they did before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the former president and his allies are fueling anger among supporters.
lead_paragraph: One week after a team of F.B.I. agents descended on his private club and residence in Florida, former President Donald J. Trump warned that his followers were enraged by the search — and that things could get out of hand if the Justice Department kept the heat on him.

headline: Katie Gregson-MacLeod Sang About a ‘Complex’ Love. TikTok Responded.
abstract: The 21-year-old Scottish folk singer-songwriter found a sudden hit by tapping into the platform’s appetite for melancholy with a striking, sorrowful chorus.
lead_paragraph: If TikTok has made you cry sometime this month, it’s likely thanks to Katie Gregson-MacLeod.

headline: French Tax Collectors Use A.I. to Spot Thousands of Undeclared Pools
abstract: Algorithms combing through satellite photos found over 20,000 unreported swimming pools in a few regions, yielding an expected $10 million in taxes, and the system will soon go nationwide.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For those trying to offset France’s increasingly sweltering summers by building swimming pools, the tax authorities have a message: If you’re thinking of saving money by keeping your pool hidden from property tax collectors, we’re watching — from above.

headline: The European Union plans to give 5.5 million iodine tablets to Ukraine.
abstract: BRUSSELS — The European Union is set to donate 5.5 million potassium iodide tablets to Ukraine, the bloc’s executive arm said on Tuesday, amid growing concerns about the shelling around the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant and the threat of a radiation leak.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union is set to donate 5.5 million potassium iodide tablets to Ukraine, the bloc’s executive arm said on Tuesday, amid growing concerns about the shelling around the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant and the threat of a radiation leak.

headline: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Deaths Among Older People, Israeli Study Finds
abstract: Among patients under 65, however, the drug made little difference in hospitalization or death rates.
lead_paragraph: Paxlovid, the Covid-19 treatment made by Pfizer, reduced hospitalizations and deaths in older patients during the Omicron surge in Israel earlier this year, but made no difference for patients under 65 at high risk for severe disease, new research has found.

headline: Job Openings Picked Up in July, Showing the Labor Market Remains Hot
abstract: Even with the Fed raising interest rates, employers are still eager to hire.
lead_paragraph: Demand for workers remained strong in July, a sign that the U.S. labor market remains vibrant even as the Federal Reserve tries to cool the economy by raising interest rates.

headline: A Star Maestro, Fighting Brain Cancer, Finds Peace in Music
abstract: Michael Tilson Thomas, who returned to Tanglewood, where his career first took off, refuses to be confined by his illness.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — The conductor Michael Tilson Thomas, during his half-century career in music, has led many performances of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, with its rousing “Ode to Joy” finale.

headline: A Utica Sculpture Studio Is Ransacked, and 5 Children Are Arrested
abstract: Sculpture Space, a residency program, was vandalized over the weekend. The police said Tuesday they had charged five juveniles between the ages of 8 and 11 in connection with the crime.
lead_paragraph: When Tom Montan, the executive director of Sculpture Space, which has offered a residency program for artists for nearly half a century, arrived at its studio in a former factory in Utica, N.Y., on Sunday morning, he grew frightened. The doors were ajar. The space was flooded. Broken glass was scattered across the floor.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Show with Allison Russell
abstract: The August 30, 2022 episode of The Ezra Klein Show
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest hosted by our associate producer, Annie Galvin, with Allison Russell. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Biden Calls Out Republicans on Guns and Crime in Pennsylvania Speech
abstract: President Biden took what have been political vulnerabilities for the White House — policing and rising crime — and portrayed them as strengths ahead of the congressional elections in November.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden gave a forceful defense of the F.B.I. during a speech in Pennsylvania on Tuesday and called out allies of former President Donald J. Trump for failing to condemn those who attacked law enforcement during the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol.

headline: Daniel Barenboim, Star Conductor, Withdraws from ‘Ring’ Cycle in Berlin
abstract: “I must now give priority to my health and concentrate on my complete recovery,” the conductor said.
lead_paragraph: A new production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle at the Berlin State Opera, featuring the eminent conductor Daniel Barenboim, was one of the most highly anticipated events on the classical music calendar this season.

headline: U.N. Race Panel Sounds the Alarm on Abortion Access in the U.S.
abstract: The influential committee called on the Biden administration to safeguard access for minorities and to address a host of issues on race relations.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — An influential United Nations panel that examined the state of race relations in the United States called on the Biden administration on Tuesday to address a host of concerns, including imperiled abortion access for minorities, curbs on voting rights and the country’s “increasingly militarized approach” to immigration.

headline: Why Many Americans Turned on Anthony Fauci
abstract: A science worth following must lead.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Anthony Fauci was seen as a charming but no-nonsense doctor who had served the public for five decades‌. He’d been cited as a hero by the first President Bush and awarded the nation’s highest civilian honor by the second. So how by 2022 did Dr. Fauci become, to so many, a villain?

headline: Jenifer Lewis, in High Gear
abstract: With a new Showtime series and book of essays, the veteran actress, who relishes her real-life role as everybody’s auntie, is enjoying her flowers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jenifer Lewis was sitting in her white Mercedes-Benz parked at her home in the Sherman Oaks neighborhood, preparing to have lunch at Petit Trois, a chic French restaurant nearby.

headline: Complaint About Biden From Americans for Public Trust to the Federal Election Commission
abstract: A conservative group filed a complaint against President Biden that accused him of violating federal election law by not officially informing the F.E.C. that he planned to run again in 2024.
lead_paragraph: A conservative group filed a complaint against President Biden that accused him of violating federal election law by not officially informing the F.E.C. that he planned to run again in 2024.

headline: Justice Dept. Adds Limits on Political Activity of Staff
abstract: The department imposed new restrictions on appointees attending political events, a policy change that comes ahead of the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Tuesday imposed new restrictions on partisan activity by political appointees at the Justice Department, a policy change that comes ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: First, a Complaint to the F.E.C. About Trump in 2024. Now One for Biden, Too.
abstract: Both parties have now lodged complaints saying the opposing party’s leader ran afoul of election law in not officially declaring 2024 presidential runs.
lead_paragraph: A conservative group has filed a complaint against President Biden accusing him of violating federal election law by not officially informing the Federal Election Commission that he plans to run again in 2024.

headline: Scenes from the Devastating Flooding in Pakistan
abstract: Months of rain has swollen rivers and inundated communities across Pakistan, killing more than 1,100 people.
lead_paragraph: The deadly rain has hardly stopped for three months in Pakistan.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: China Plans the Communist Party’s 20th Congress
abstract: Plus India’s Supreme Court widens its definition of family and floods devastate Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: China announced that the Communist Party’s 20th congress would be held in Beijing on Oct. 16.

headline: A Long-Lost Branch of the Nile Helped in Building Egypt’s Pyramids
abstract: A new study confirms a long-held theory that builders used the river to transport the heavy blocks that make up the ancient wonders.
lead_paragraph: For 4,500 years, the pyramids of Giza have loomed over the western bank of the Nile River as a geometric mountain chain. The Great Pyramid, built to commemorate the reign of Pharaoh Khufu, the second king of Egypt’s fourth dynasty, covers 13 acres and stood more than 480 feet upon its completion around 2560 B.C. Remarkably, ancient architects somehow transported 2.3 million limestone and granite blocks, each weighing an average of more than two tons, across miles of desert from the banks of the Nile to the pyramid site on the Giza Plateau.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Was the World’s Best Kisser’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: He left the bar of soap upside down in its dish, melting; played the car radio too loud; lost his phone hourly; ignored the closet and piled his shoes by the front door; hogged the coat rack with his jackets; ran the dishwasher with three plates in it; filled the driveway with derelict boats and cars. He brought me coffee in bed every morning, whispering, “Buongiorno, principessa.” He said I was the world’s best kisser, tolerated weekly ballroom dance classes, mimicked the cardinal’s song so well that I sometimes think he is still here. His ashes are. — Marze Murphy

headline: Russia Halts Natural Gas Flows to Germany Again
abstract: Gazprom said the Nord Stream 1 pipeline would undergo three days of maintenance, raising worries about a complete shutdown of Russian gas deliveries to Germany.
lead_paragraph: Gazprom, Russia’s government-owned energy giant, shut off natural gas flows early Wednesday through Nord Stream 1, the critical pipeline that connects Russia to Germany, raising fresh worries about European energy supplies.

headline: It’s Your Party and You’ll Dine Out if You Want To
abstract: Here’s where to host a group birthday dinner, whether it’s a park hang or an all-out fete.
lead_paragraph: Hello, it’s Becky again, filling in for our fearless leader, Nikita. (Come home, Nikita, we miss you.)

headline: Main Target of Russian Mercenaries in Africa Is Civilians, Report Says
abstract: Newly released data seen by The New York Times suggests that the Kremlin-affiliated Wagner Group plays a central role in violence against civilians in the Central African Republic and Mali.
lead_paragraph: As Russian mercenaries from the private military group Wagner have been operating in Ukraine, their counterparts in Africa have received little scrutiny and have made civilian populations their primary targets, according to a newly released report on their activities in two of the continent’s most fragile countries.

headline: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Reformist Soviet Leader, Is Dead at 91
abstract: Adopting principles of glasnost and perestroika, he weighed the legacy of seven decades of Communist rule and set a new course, presiding over the end of the Cold War and the dissolution of the U.S.S.R.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose rise to power in the Soviet Union set in motion a series of revolutionary changes that transformed the map of Europe and ended the Cold War that had threatened the world with nuclear annihilation, has died in Moscow. He was 91.

headline: Man Gets 3 Years in Scheme to Sell Bogus Tom Brady Super Bowl Rings
abstract: A New Jersey man cheated an unidentified Patriots player out of his championship ring and then posed as him to order three more engraved with Tom Brady’s last name, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: When the New England Patriots roared back from a 28-3 deficit to stun the Atlanta Falcons in overtime in the Super Bowl in 2017, it set off a frenzy among fans and collectors for memorabilia from the championship game.

headline: Another ship earmarked for humanitarian aid has left Ukraine.
abstract: When Ukrainian grain exports by sea resumed last month, officials predicted the deal would bring five million tons of food to the world market each month, enough to slowly but surely chip away at the 20 million tons stuck in the nation’s silos.
lead_paragraph: When Ukrainian grain exports by sea resumed last month, officials predicted the deal would bring five million tons of food to the world market each month, enough to slowly but surely chip away at the 20 million tons stuck in the nation’s silos.

headline: Google Says Trump’s Truth Social Must Scrub Violent Content to Join Play Store
abstract: The social media app is not available on Google’s app store, and the former president’s company and Google are publicly disagreeing about why.
lead_paragraph: Google said on Tuesday that it would not distribute Truth Social on its Play app store until Truth Social, the social media platform founded by former President Donald J. Trump, removed content that incites violence.

headline: Arizona’s Supreme Court blocks an election reform ballot measure, voiding over 238,000 petition signatures.
abstract: The Arizona Free and Fair Elections Act would have established same-day voter registration and prohibited the state Legislature from overturning federal election results.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s ballot in November will exclude a sweeping election reform proposition after the state Supreme Court upheld a decision to throw out the majority of the nearly half-million petition signatures collected.

headline: Complaint About Trump From American Bridge to the Federal Election Commission
abstract: A Democratic super PAC filed a complaint against former President Donald J. Trump that accused him of violating federal election law by not officially informing the F.E.C. that he planned to run again in 2024.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic super PAC filed a complaint against former President Donald J. Trump that accused him of violating federal election law by not officially informing the F.E.C. that he planned to run again in 2024.

headline: Ruby C. Williams, Folk Artist With a Produce Stand, Dies at 94
abstract: Her colorful paintings started out as advertisements for her farm stand in Florida. Before long, her works found their way to art galleries.
lead_paragraph: At a produce stand in a rural part of Florida east of Tampa, Ruby C. Williams would sell you some squash or collard greens for a few bucks. At galleries in Florida and beyond, some of her vibrant, quirky paintings have fetched hundreds.

headline: Russia’s Occupation of Nuclear Plant Gives Moscow a New Way to Intimidate
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appears to be using the facility to scare Ukraine’s leaders and warn the West to stay out of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: As international nuclear inspectors head toward Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia power plant, they face a situation that few had ever envisioned: a vast nuclear power plant that could be deliberately turned into a potential dirty bomb, with Russia using it to intimidate its enemy and the world.

headline: Biden Says He Is ‘Determined’ to Ban Assault Weapons
abstract: During a trip to Pennsylvania, President Biden promoted the passage of a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms, and he vowed to ban assault weapons in the United States.
lead_paragraph: During a trip to Pennsylvania, President Biden promoted the passage of a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms, and he vowed to ban assault weapons in the United States.

headline: Roland Mesnier, Pastry Chef to Five Presidents, Dies at 78
abstract: French born and French trained, he served up inventive and ambrosial desserts in the White House for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: Roland Mesnier, the inventive White House pastry chef whose ambrosial and whimsical desserts briefly shifted the weight of office from the minds to the stomachs of beleaguered presidents, recalcitrant congressmen and balky diplomats, died on Friday at an assisted living home in Burke, Va. He was 78.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Plaque Bearing Image of Hooded K.K.K. Figure Hangs at West Point
abstract: A special congressional commission that recommends the removal of Confederate symbols at U.S. military sites flagged the image, which appears above the words “Ku Klux Klan,” in a new report.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the students at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in New York have walked past a panel of three large bronze plaques mounted at the entrance of Bartlett Hall Science Center that includes an image of a hooded figure and the words “Ku Klux Klan” written below it, according to findings in a report released by a congressional panel on Monday.

headline: A reporter’s Siberian memories of Gorbachev, and that Pizza Hut commercial.
abstract: Anatoly Kurmanaev, a New York Times reporter, recalls a childhood forever changed by a man with a distinctive birthmark.
lead_paragraph: I was 6 when the Soviet Union broke up.

headline: Solomon Islands Suspends Visits by Foreign Military Ships, Raising Concerns in U.S.
abstract: The move comes after top U.S. officials visited the Pacific nation to bolster ties and deliver warnings over its new security agreement with China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Solomon Islands has suspended visits by U.S. and other foreign military vessels, American officials said Tuesday, raising concerns in Washington that the Pacific nation is turning away from engagement with the United States in favor of working with China.

headline: Experts Arrive to Inspect Nuclear Plant, but Ukraine Warns of Pitfalls
abstract: A senior adviser to Ukraine’s president said that key aspects of the negotiations between the international team, Ukraine and Russia were in question, including a safe route to the plant itself.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A team of international nuclear experts departed from Ukraine’s capital on Wednesday morning hoping to ensure the safety of an imperiled nuclear plant, though a senior Ukrainian official had warned that many challenges remained to the team’s mission, not least finding safe passage through an active battlefield to the Russian-occupied facility.

headline: This Is the Other Way That History Ends
abstract: A once-scholarly discipline courts irrelevance in its desperate bid for relevance.
lead_paragraph: The End of History was supposed to have happened back in 1989, the year the Berlin Wall fell and Francis Fukuyama announced the conclusive triumph of liberal democracy. We know how that thesis worked out. But what happens when the other kind of History — academic, not Hegelian — starts to collapse?

headline: Humpback Whales Pass Their Songs Across Oceans
abstract: Whales share songs from Australia to Ecuador, scientists have found, suggesting a remarkably fast cultural evolution.
lead_paragraph: One of the most remarkable things about our species is how fast human culture can change. New words can spread from continent to continent, while technologies such as cellphones and drones change the way people live around the world.

headline: U.S. Will Set Aside Monkeypox Vaccines in New Equity Program
abstract: White House officials said an “equity intervention pilot” will get more doses to communities that have been left behind in the nation’s inoculation campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced a new plan on Tuesday to send extra doses of monkeypox vaccine to states for use at events or sites that can reach more people of color and others who have lacked access to shots.

headline: In his own words: Gorbachev’s essays in The Times.
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev wrote often about issues including world affairs and climate change. He also mourned former President Ronald Reagan and the former British prime minister, Margaret Thatcher.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three decades after he stepped down as the leader of the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev remained a potent voice in geopolitics, warning of the dangers of nuclear weapons, musing about European unity, calling for action on the climate and remembering those who were once Cold War foes.

headline: NASA Plans to Retry Its Moon Rocket Launch on Saturday
abstract: After scrubbing its launch of the Artemis I mission on Monday, NASA said it hoped to resolve an engine problem by a second launch window this weekend.
lead_paragraph: For now, NASA will press ahead with preparations for a second launch attempt on Saturday of its new moon rocket, NASA officials said during a news conference on Tuesday,

headline: Putin sees the Ukraine war as part of his battle to undo Gorbachev’s legacy.
abstract: For Mr. Putin, the end of the Soviet Union was the “greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the century,” caused by the weak nerves of a leader too willing to appease the treacherous West.
lead_paragraph: The day that Russia invaded Ukraine, Feb. 24, the legacy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev loomed over President Vladimir V. Putin’s predawn speech.

headline: Pastor Arrested While Watering Neighbor’s Yard, Footage Shows
abstract: Police body camera footage shows the arrest of Michael Jennings, a Black pastor in Alabama who claims that he was wrongly arrested while watering his neighbor’s flowers.
lead_paragraph: Police body camera footage shows the arrest of Michael Jennings, a Black pastor in Alabama who claims that he was wrongly arrested while watering his neighbor’s flowers.

headline: L. Lin Wood, a Trump Ally, Is Called to Testify in Election-Meddling Inquiry
abstract: Mr. Wood said he would appear before the special grand jury in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — L. Lin Wood, a trial lawyer and an ardent supporter of Donald J. Trump who pushed a number of falsehoods about election fraud after the 2020 presidential contest, has been asked to give testimony in the criminal investigation into efforts to overturn the Georgia election, he confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Toxic Red Tide Kills ‘Uncountable’ Numbers of Fish in the Bay Area
abstract: A harmful algal bloom in the San Francisco Bay is killing fish, sharks and stingrays. Some are washing ashore.
lead_paragraph: A harmful algal bloom known as a red tide is killing off “uncountable” numbers of fish in the San Francisco Bay Area, with residents reporting rust-colored waters, and piles of stinking fish corpses washing ashore.

headline: How Reagan and Bush overcame skepticism to collaborate with Gorbachev.
abstract: Mr. Gorbachev was charming and presented himself as a reformer, but neither Ronald Reagan nor George Bush was convinced he was for real. They would both be proved wrong.
lead_paragraph: For his first four years in office, President Ronald Reagan had a tough time forging any kind of relationship with his counterparts in the Soviet Union. “They kept dying on me,” he later explained. It fell to his vice president, George Bush, to attend the funerals. “You die, I fly” became Bush’s wry motto.

headline: How Gorbachev’s ‘perestroika’ vanished.
abstract: His vision of a “common European home” stretching from Vladivostok to Lisbon has been replaced by a Russia increasingly isolated from the rest of Europe.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, lionized in the West, idolized by protesting Chinese students in Tiananmen Square but despised by many Russians for what they saw as his destroying their country, had fallen far from grace and could barely contain his fury when I first met him in 1992, soon after arriving in Moscow as a correspondent.

headline: Man Held at Rikers Dies From Razor Wound After Guards Fail to Intervene
abstract: A captain and two correction officers were suspended last week after failing to help a man for 10 minutes after he slit his throat. He was taken off life support on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Two correction officers and a captain failed to act for at least 10 minutes when a mentally ill man slit his throat with a razor at the Rikers Island jail complex last week, with the guards looking on as the man bled, according to five people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Something to Think About
abstract: Pick up Joe Deeney’s puzzle before it’s too late!
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hope you’re hungry, solvers! Today’s puzzle comes to us from Joe Deeney, who is making his 12th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Mr. Deeney’s puzzle is stuffed with theme content, which we’ll dig into in a moment, as well as a delicious blend of trivia and wordplay clues.

headline: Review: Finding Community in ‘As You Like It’
abstract: This shimmering Shakespeare adaptation at the Delacorte Theater retains the outline of the original, while making space for songs. You don’t have to sing along, though you may want to.
lead_paragraph: The Forest of Arden is where you head when the city won’t hold you. When laws are unjust, when custom constricts, when institutions squeeze and shrink you, here, at last, is space to breathe and to be. Manhattan razed its woodlands long ago, of course. (A lone stand of trees, in Inwood Hill Park, remains.) But on a summer night, in Central Park, squint a little and you can imagine a forest here — the refuge, the bounty, the hush.

headline: Defending U.S. Open Champion Emma Raducanu Loses in the First Round
abstract: Raducanu, who won the U.S. Open women’s singles title as a qualifier without dropping a set last year, fell to Alizé Cornet in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: Emma Raducanu, who won last year’s U.S. Open as a little-known 18-year-old qualifier without losing a single set, will not defend her title this year after losing in the first round to Alizé Cornet on Tuesday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day: French Tax Collectors Scan Satellite Images to Spot Pools Hidden From View
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Aug. 31, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “We have to be sure that the software can find buildings with large footprints, not the doghouse or the children’s playhouse.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 31, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 31, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a potential protracted standoff between Ukraine and Russia referred imprecisely to Ukraine’s military attacks on Russia. While Ukraine is using long-range, precision-guided rockets provided by the United States against Russian forces, there is no evidence that they have been used to strike Crimea.

headline: For Venus and Serena Williams at the U.S. Open, Day and Night Experiences
abstract: Unlike her sister, Venus was not prepared to deal with questions about her tennis future after a loss in the first round of the singles tournament. “I’m just focused on the doubles,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: With Upset Over Taylor Fritz, Brandon Holt Is Making a Name for Himself
abstract: Holt, a qualifier who inherited tennis skills from his mother, the U.S. Open winner Tracy Austin, and his other pastime — music — from his father, is putting together a tidy run at the tournament.
lead_paragraph: As the son of a famous tennis champion, Brandon Holt is often asked what he has taken from his mother, Tracy Austin, who won the United States Open twice. Did he inherit his service return from her? Did she bequeath her court savvy to her son?

headline: U.S. Life Expectancy Falls Again in ‘Historic’ Setback
abstract: The decline during the pandemic is the sharpest in nearly 100 years, hitting Native American and Alaska Native communities particularly hard.
lead_paragraph: The average life expectancy of Americans fell precipitously in 2020 and 2021, the sharpest two-year decline in nearly 100 years and a stark reminder of the toll exacted on the nation by the continuing coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Teenage Baller Behind the ‘Super Fly’ Brittney Griner Hoodies
abstract: Isabella Escribano, 14, is popular on Instagram for her basketball skills. She’s using her design skills in the public campaign to free the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner.
lead_paragraph: For more hours now than she can remember, Isabella Escribano sat on the orange couch inside her garage, iPad in hand, crafting clothing designs that she hoped would aid one of her favorite basketball players.

headline: As Apartment Prices Climb, Renters Look for Deals in the Outer Boroughs
abstract: An analysis by the listing site StreetEasy found that many apartment hunters have moved on from the hottest neighborhoods in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at how rising apartment prices are pushing renters to expand where they look for units in New York City, and how they have given up searching Manhattan’s hottest neighborhoods. Also, we’ll look at the severe drought that has taken hold across the region.

headline: Documents at Mar-a-Lago Were Moved and Hidden as U.S. Sought Them, Filing Suggests
abstract: The filing by the Justice Department paints the clearest picture to date of its efforts to retrieve documents from the former president’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sought a search warrant for former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Florida after obtaining evidence that highly classified documents were likely concealed and that Mr. Trump’s representatives had falsely claimed all sensitive material had been returned, according to a court filing by the department on Tuesday.

headline: The experts’ convoy of armored S.U.V.s traveled toward an active battlefield.
abstract: KYIV, Ukraine — Experts from the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency are expected to visit the imperiled Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on Thursday, a day after they embarked on one of the most complicated missions in the agency’s history.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Experts from the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency are expected to visit the imperiled Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on Thursday, a day after they embarked on one of the most complicated missions in the agency’s history.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Mikhail Gorbachev is dead at 91.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail Gorbachev, a reformist leader who oversaw the end of the Soviet Union, has died at 91.

headline: Bashar al-Assad Has a Syria He’d Like the World to See
abstract: The only trouble is, it’s not the real one.
lead_paragraph: At first the image didn’t make much sense: tanks bunched together, red flags flying and a line of soldiers in Yemeni-style red berets. The scene was set in the shadows of bombed-out apartment buildings that, confusingly, didn’t look much like Yemen.

headline: U.N. Experts to Inspect Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine
abstract: A group of experts with the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations nuclear watchdog, departed from Kyiv, Ukraine, headed to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. The team intends to establish a permanent monitoring mission at the Russian-occupied nuclear facility.
lead_paragraph: A group of experts with the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations nuclear watchdog, departed from Kyiv, Ukraine, headed to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. The team intends to establish a permanent monitoring mission at the Russian-occupied nuclear facility.

headline: California Algal Bloom Kills ‘Unprecedented’ Numbers of Fish
abstract: A harmful algal bloom in the San Francisco Bay Area has killed numerous fish, sharks and stingrays.
lead_paragraph: A harmful algal bloom in the San Francisco Bay Area has killed numerous fish, sharks and stingrays.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Wait … Is This Times Square?
abstract: New York City considers far-flung boundaries for the Crossroads of the World as it decides where to ban guns.
lead_paragraph: Adam Alkindi was behind a deli counter near the intersection of 48th Street and Ninth Avenue on Tuesday when he confronted an unexpected question: Did he consider his workplace a part of Times Square?

headline: Serena Williams’s Next Opponent Is a Struggling Anett Kontaveit
abstract: They will face off in a packed Arthur Ashe Stadium on Wednesday, a venue that feels like home to Williams even if it has not always been a haven.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: Mike Tyson Was the Boxer Hollywood Taught Us to Love. What Happened?
abstract: Just like American culture as a whole, Hulu’s new mini-series doesn’t know whether to condemn violence or glorify it.
lead_paragraph: It might be hard for younger sports fans to believe, but in the 1980s Mike Tyson was arguably the most famous athlete in the world named Mike. It’s hard to believe in large part because Tyson was a boxer, the last practitioner of the sport to command the American cultural imagination as so many others had throughout the 20th century. In 2022, when most Americans would be hard-pressed to tell you who the current heavyweight champion of the world is, it’s safe to say we will probably never see another like Tyson again.

headline: In A.M. Homes’s New Novel, the Political is Personal
abstract: “The Unfolding” takes readers inside the homes and meeting rooms of a dyed-in-the-wool conservative with big plans for change.
lead_paragraph: We are living in fractious times. Two decades into the new century, our nation is bitterly divided and our political institutions have never seemed more fragile. The genesis of these fissures in the American body politic is the central concern of “The Unfolding,” a sharply observed, wickedly funny political satire by the reliably brilliant A.M. Homes.

headline: Ron DeSantis Is a Test Case
abstract: The DeSantis governorship provides insight into what our national life might look like if in 2024 the Republicans make a clean sweep.
lead_paragraph: The fact that Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, is favored to win re-election is a clear warning to those worried about declining support for democratic institutions and values in the United States.

headline: Ashley Judd: The Right to Keep Private Pain Private
abstract: I could not help my mother, Naomi Judd, who lost a long battle against mental illness. I can, however, do something about how she is remembered.
lead_paragraph: April 30, 2022, was the most shattering day of my life. My beloved mother, Naomi Judd, who had come to believe that her mental illness would only get worse, never better, took her own life that day. The trauma of discovering and then holding her laboring body haunts my nights. As my family and I continue to mourn our loss, the rampant and cruel misinformation that has spread about her death, and about our relationships with her, stalks my days. The horror of it will only worsen if the details surrounding her death are disclosed by the Tennessee law that generally allows police reports, including family interviews, from closed investigations to be made public.

headline: Read Your Way Through Mexico City
abstract: Juan Villoro, who spent over two decades perfecting one book about Mexico City, recommends reading on the city he loves. “Mexico is too complex,” a visitor said. “It needs to be read.”
lead_paragraph: Álvaro Pombo, a Spanish author, came to Mexico City in 2004. He’d written a novel that took place during the religious revolts of early 20th century Mexico, and wanted to know what the country he’d studied in books was like, he said.

headline: This Vietnamese Dish Is Comforting, Luminous and Striking. It’s Also Forgiving.
abstract: The first taste of bánh cuốn led to a yearslong project of culinary discovery.
lead_paragraph: My first bites of bánh cuốn were hardly intentional — they came from a banh mi shop tucked in Houston’s Third Ward. I’d been working at a day care, and also a stadium’s parking company, and most of what I ate came from this tiny Vietnamese spot. It stood between a print shop and a busted bus bench, but the mother and son who ran it always welcomed me, running a full operation with one stove, a coffee press and a toaster oven. For my first week of patronage, I was “Sir.” A month later, I became “Bryan.” Thereafter, it was, lovingly, “Hey, fat guy.” I always ordered the same thing (“an egg banh mi with extra pâté, please!”) with a cà phê sữa đá to go.

headline: Don’t Get Dressed Without Reading This Book
abstract: Claire McCardell helped create American fashion. She was also a writer whose words on style still resonate today.
lead_paragraph: Claire McCardell, the midcentury designer who is one of the founding mothers of American sportswear, did many things first.

headline: Naomi Osaka, Serena Williams and One Last Shared U.S. Open
abstract: Osaka lost in the first round Tuesday to Danielle Collins, but would remember the final Grand Slam of the year for the front-row seat she had to her idol’s farewell party.
lead_paragraph: Follow live as Serena Williams plays Anett Kontaveit at the U.S. Open.

headline: Some Carmakers Say Recycling Car Parts Is the Future. But Is It Realistic?
abstract: “Circular manufacturing” has the promise to reduce waste by reusing parts to make new cars. There are glimmers of hope, but they are currently outweighed by challenges.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our series on the Future of Transportation, which is exploring innovations and challenges that affect how we move about the world.

headline: The Next Step in the Anti-Abortion Playbook Is Becoming Clear
abstract: Despite clear political headwinds, the movement has embraced a push for fetal personhood.
lead_paragraph: Two months after the fall of Roe v. Wade, abortion has been banned or severely restricted in at least 14 states, energizing leaders of the anti-abortion movement but also activating voters who are opposed to many of these measures. With so much at stake in the next few election cycles — and women’s lives hanging in the balance — both sides of this fight are strategizing their next moves.

headline: To Prevent a Martian Plague, NASA Needs to Build a Very Special Lab
abstract: The likelihood is low that bringing rocks to Earth from the red planet will make us sick, but the space agency isn’t taking any chances.
lead_paragraph: When Carl Sagan imagined sending humans to Mars in his book “The Cosmic Connection,” published in 1973, he posed a problem beyond such a mission’s cost and complexity: the possibility that life already existed on the red planet and that it might not play nice.

headline: Life Expectancy Is Falling. Here’s How to Change That.
abstract: Public health is at a crossroads.
lead_paragraph: Life expectancy in the United States continued to decline in 2021, according to data released by the federal government. Is there a more fundamental barometer of the health of our nation? The stagnation in life expectancy reflects deep‌‌ societal challenges — not just in our health system but also in our economic and political systems.

headline: Reminder: ‘Africa Is Not a Country’
abstract: Dipo Faloyin is tired of Western stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: What do you remember about the film “Independence Day”? Will Smith looking cute in a jump suit? The autopsy scene where the squid-like alien kills the scientists? The warm, mindless surge of patriotism it generated?

headline: Silicon Valley Discovers an Age-Old Child Care Hack: The Neighbors
abstract: Otter, a new child care platform, is attracting millions of dollars in venture capital. But can it fix a broken industry?
