lead_paragraph: It was an enticing new option for pandemic-era child care, and almost infuriatingly simple: What if stay-at-home parents watched the children of parents who had to work?

headline: John Adams, an American Master at 75
abstract: Adams, arguably our greatest living composer, has done operas inspired by recent history. In “Antony and Cleopatra,” he turns to Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — “I have to apologize,” the composer John Adams said as he approached his car. “The front seat was torn up by a bear.”

headline: ‘Monarch’ Heralds a New Family Empire, This One With a Texas Twang
abstract: Starring Trace Adkins, Anna Friel and Susan Sarandon, the new Fox musical series brings “Empire”-style dynastic drama to the world of country music.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the writer Melissa London Hilfers was having lunch with her friend Gail Berman, the TV and movie producer. Berman mentioned that Fox was looking into doing a dramatic series based in the country music world.

headline: Why Totino’s Needs 25 Ways to Make Pizza Rolls
abstract: As supply chain delays and rising costs made individual ingredients harder to procure, food companies had to become very flexible.
lead_paragraph: It takes about 21 ingredients to make a Totino’s pizza roll, the bite-size snack that soared in popularity during the pandemic as people sought easy-to-make meals.

headline: To Meet a New Generation, Legacy Black-Owned Businesses Get a Reboot
abstract: Brands like Fashion Fair and Madam, founded with the goal of serving Black communities, faded at the end of the last century. Now, they’re being revived with similar missions in mind.
lead_paragraph: When the cosmetics brand Fashion Fair’s top-selling lipstick, Chocolate Raspberry, disappeared from makeup counters, many Black women despaired. The vibrant magenta shade popped against brown skin tones, and it had been a mainstay on vanities and in bathroom cabinets for decades until the company fell into bankruptcy in 2018.

headline: The Extremely Online Rise of Doug Mastriano
abstract: The G.O.P. candidate for governor of Pennsylvania deftly used Facebook to build a loyal right-wing fan base at the height of the pandemic. Will it be enough to win a competitive general election?
lead_paragraph: BLOOMSBURG, Pa. — In the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic, Diane Fisher, a nurse from Weatherly, Pa., was surfing through videos on Facebook when she came across a livestream from Doug Mastriano, a Pennsylvania state senator.

headline: How Justin Tucker Became the Greatest Kicker in N.F.L. History
abstract: The confidence, persistence, and all-out obsession required to play the least understood position on the field.
lead_paragraph: Justin Tucker felt off. It was Sept. 26, 2021, and he was standing on his home field for the third game of his 10th season as a place-kicker for the Baltimore Ravens. The game was almost over, and the Ravens had all but lost. Unless, with three seconds left on the clock, Tucker could boot the ball through the yellow uprights 66 yards downfield — a longer field goal than anyone had ever kicked in the N.F.L.

headline: After a Long, Starring Run, Will Racism at Last Get the Hook?
abstract: We can no longer ignore the theater’s systemic inequities. But leaving them behind may remake the industry in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: Severed from the rest of New Haven by Metro-North tracks on one side and I-95 on the other, the Long Wharf Theater shares a patch of industrial bleakness with a busy food terminal and a chicken processing plant. The only convenient way to get there is by car, which is one reason the Tony Award-winning company, despite decades of excellent work, has had no trouble attracting visitors from the suburbs and exurbs. For many Black and Latino New Haveners, that seemed to be the point; according to a local joke, the initials L.W.T. stood for “lily-white theater.”

headline: In TriBeCa, a Farm Stand Where Celebrities and Tomatoes Mingle
abstract: Open only on Tuesdays, the restaurant One White Street’s seasonal farm stand has become a reliable place to spot famous faces.
lead_paragraph: Austin Johnson was fretting over a pile of heirloom tomatoes.

headline: Pain, Fear, Stigma: What People Who Survived Monkeypox Want You to Know
abstract: Seven patients share their stories of devastating symptoms, their frustration over finding care and their efforts to help each other when doctors and officials have failed.
lead_paragraph: It began as an odd-looking pimple, or perhaps as a weird rash, or maybe as a sudden wave of fatigue in the middle of a hot summer day. The doctor was stumped, or said it was not a big deal, or — just maybe — identified it right away: monkeypox.

headline: Heat, Water, Fire: How Climate Change Is Transforming the Pacific Crest Trail
abstract: The already grueling 2,600-mile hike now includes the added challenges of global warming, which can mean a lack of shade and exposure to smoke and fire.
lead_paragraph: In the desert near Agua Dulce, north of Los Angeles, hikers along the Pacific Crest Trail who reached mile marker 502 encountered a cistern of water that smelled bad and tasted worse, with a dead rat floating inside. They got out their filters and refilled their bottles anyway. “Will update if I get sick,” one wrote on a message board to those coming up behind.

headline: ‘Absolute Warfare’: Cartels Terrorize Mexico as Security Forces Fall Short
abstract: The president disbanded the Federal Police and created the National Guard to tackle soaring violence, but three years later, criminal cartels have expanded their reach.
lead_paragraph: CELAYA, Mexico — The butcher had been killed and no one knew why. The execution occurred in broad daylight as he worked in a family-owned restaurant, one of many murders that go unsolved every week in Celaya, among Mexico’s most dangerous cities.

headline: What You Get for $650,000
abstract: A 1960 house in Statesboro, Ga.; a two-bedroom condominium in Boston; and a Colonial Revival home in Madison, Wis.
lead_paragraph: A 1960 house in Statesboro, Ga.; a two-bedroom condominium in Boston; and a Colonial Revival home in Madison, Wis.

headline: $650,000 Homes in Georgia, Massachusetts and Wisconsin
abstract: A 1960 house in Statesboro, a two-bedroom condominium on Beacon Hill in Boston and a Colonial Revival home in Madison.
lead_paragraph: The owners bought this house in 2020 and have carefully updated it, using texture and color to create cohesion: The front doors, for example, are painted the same bright orange as the range in the kitchen.

headline: Steps (and a Slide) Down to the Ocean in Maldives
abstract: This three-bedroom villa with a water slide, built over a lagoon off the resort island of Medhufaru, in Maldives, is on the market for $7 million.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom villa with a water slide, built over a lagoon off the resort island of Medhufaru, in Maldives, is on the market for $7 million.

headline: What to Plant for a Colorful Fall
abstract: Your garden may not be looking Instagram ready at the moment, but don’t give up: There’s time for more color before the first frost.
lead_paragraph: Your garden may not be looking Instagram ready at the moment, but don’t give up: There’s time for more color before the first frost.

headline: Why ‘September Is the New May’ When It Comes to Planting Flowers
abstract: Your garden may not be looking Instagram ready at the moment, but don’t give up: There’s time for more color before the first frost.
lead_paragraph: On the cusp of fall, the direction a flower garden is headed may not be the stuff of viral social media images. And it may not inspire a weary gardener’s delight.

headline: A Water Slide (Plus a House) in the Ocean: House Hunting in Maldives
abstract: Homes in the archipelagic state are often handed down from generation to generation, while foreigners are limited to vacation villa packages on resort islands.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom villa stands over a turquoise lagoon off the island of Medhufaru in Maldives, the archipelagic state comprising almost 1,200 islands in the north-central Indian Ocean.

headline: The Keeper
abstract: How an Afghan soccer player and her teammates fled their homes, outran a murderous regime and forged the uncertain beginnings of a new life.
lead_paragraph: To begin her goodbye, Fatima stood inside her family’s walled-in courtyard in Kabul, Afghanistan, shovel in hand, and pierced a patch of soil with the tip of its sharp blade.

headline: Alabama Pastor Is Arrested While Watering Neighbor’s Flowers, Video Shows
abstract: The Rev. Michael Jennings, a pastor of 31 years, had been watering petunias and hydrangeas when a neighbor called the police to report suspicious activity, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: It was starting to get dark in Childersburg, Ala., on May 22, so the Rev. Michael Jennings figured it was a good time to water the purple petunias and hydrangeas for his neighbor up the street, who was vacationing in the mountains up north.

headline: Inflation Tightens Its Grip on Europe
abstract: Price rises in the eurozone hit another record in August, with Estonia reaching 25 percent and eight other countries registering double-digit annual inflation.
lead_paragraph: At the Saku beer factory in Estonia, the mammoth copper brew kettles sit side by side like household sink plungers stored on a shelf in a manor house for giants. The brewery has been around for 200 years, but this is the first time in memory that the company has planned two price rises — of 10 percent each — in a single year.

headline: With War in Ukraine, Putin Tries to Unravel Gorbachev’s Legacy
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin calls the end of the Soviet Union a “genuine tragedy” for Russia, and he blamed Mikhail S. Gorbachev for bending to the demands of a treacherous and duplicitous West.
lead_paragraph: The day that Russia invaded Ukraine, Feb. 24, the legacy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev loomed over President Vladimir V. Putin’s predawn speech.

headline: The Parkland Students, Four Years Later
abstract: We look back at conversations with some of the survivors of the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains detailed descriptions of a mass shooting that some listeners may find disturbing.

headline: Living In ... Bedford, N.Y.
abstract: The wealthy Westchester town has a rural feel, with old stone walls, more than 30 miles of dirt roads and occasionally spotty cellphone service.
lead_paragraph: The wealthy Westchester town has a rural feel, with old stone walls, more than 30 miles of dirt roads and occasionally spotty cellphone service.

headline: Bedford, N.Y.: History, Horse Farms and Sprawling Estates
abstract: The wealthy Westchester town has a rural feel, with old stone walls, more than 30 miles of dirt roads and occasionally spotty cellphone service.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Yu and Evan Goldstein had long sensed that their 10-year-old twin sons would thrive outside New York City. For several years they looked at real estate — in Bronxville and Rye, N.Y., and in Greenwich, Conn. — but, as Dr. Goldstein put it, “we couldn’t find a neighborhood that fit our modern family.”

headline: Our Latest Covid Poll
abstract: Americans on the left end of the political spectrum have become less anxious about Covid.
lead_paragraph: Almost six months ago, when my Morning colleagues and I released our last poll about Covid, the deep anxiety among Americans identifying as “very liberal” was one of the main findings.

headline: An Orchestra Brings Harmony to a Region of Discord
abstract: The Pan-Caucasian Youth Orchestra unites players from Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Russia, Turkey and Ukraine with a message of peace and dialogue.
lead_paragraph: In February, Grigory Ambartsumyan, a 22-year-old Ukrainian violinist of Armenian descent, awoke in Kyiv to the sound of bombs. It was the beginning of Russia’s assault on his country, and the coming days and weeks were a blur of restless nights in bomb shelters.

headline: Typhoon Hinnamnor Brings High Winds to Japanese Islands
abstract: Forecasters say the storm is the Northern Hemisphere’s strongest tropical cyclone of the year. It was expected to bypass Taiwan and head toward the Korean Peninsula later this week.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Hinnamnor was bringing high winds to islands south of mainland Japan on Wednesday, a day after forecasters said it was the Northern Hemisphere’s strongest tropical cyclone of the year so far.

headline: Bed Bath & Beyond Secures a Financial Lifeline
abstract: The retailer confirmed that it has taken out more than $500 million in new financing as it seeks to shore up its struggling business.
lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond confirmed today that it has taken out more than $500 million in new financing, including a $375 million loan from Sixth Street, sorely needed cash to help drive the retailer’s turnaround. Its fall from grace has been spectacular: The company was worth around $17 billion in 2013; today, it’s worth less than $1 billion, with roughly $100 million in cash. (Its shares dropped more than 26 percent in premarket trading this morning after the company disclosed plans to issue new stock, seeking to take advantage of a meme-stock frenzy.) This isn’t its first attempt at a turnaround.

headline: Summer’s Last Gasp Has Arrived
abstract: Our last newsletter edition of the season focuses on summer missions accomplished and those still on the to-do list.
lead_paragraph: There’s still time.

headline: The Many Violations of the Violent Birth Scene
abstract: Does the gory surprise C-section in “House of the Dragon” represent a grim historical reality, an urgent political statement or a worn cultural cliché?
lead_paragraph: “Are you sure you want to watch this?” my husband asked as we cued up the “House of the Dragon” premiere last week.

headline: Mahathir, Malaysia’s Former Premier, Is Hospitalized With Covid
abstract: A towering figure in his country’s politics, Mahathir Mohamad was admitted to the hospital for monitoring, and says he’s contemplating another election run at age 97.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Mahathir Mohamad, who served twice as Malaysia’s prime minister for a total of 24 years, was hospitalized on Wednesday after testing positive for the coronavirus. In an interview, Mr. Mahathir, 97, confirmed that he is considering a bid in the upcoming election.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Sets the Stage for Another Big Rate Increase
abstract: The European Central Bank, when it meets next week, is expected to raise interest rates again to curb eurozone inflation, which just set a record.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday’s eurozone inflation data, showing that consumer prices rose 9.1 percent in August compared to a year ago, will maintain the pressure on the European Central Bank to impose another large interest rate increase when it meets next week.

headline: Bed Bath & Beyond Tries to Turn Itself Around, Again
abstract: The beleaguered retailer’s latest rescue plan embraces a “back-to-basics philosophy,” its chief said, an effort to reverse falling sales, negative cash flow and supply chain woes.
lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond on Wednesday laid out an aggressive plan of store closures, cost cuts and layoffs that the home-goods retailer hopes will return it to the relevance it enjoyed in its heyday.

headline: Why Did My Ex-Husband Catfish Me on a Dating App?
abstract: A reader wading back into the dating pool is angered to have been duped by her ex, who chatted with her using a false identity for weeks.
lead_paragraph: My ex-husband and I divorced 18 months ago. I tried to wait until our teenage daughter left for college, but I couldn’t. Recently, I decided to try the dating apps and met a nice man online. We texted for a few weeks; he was sweet and good-looking. But when we set a date to meet in person, he didn’t show up. That seemed odd, so I wrote to him again. No response. I was disappointed — then angry when my daughter told me that my ex-husband had created a fake profile and was pretending to be the man I was talking to the whole time. When I confronted him, he said it was a joke. I am really upset. What should I do?

headline: These Contentious Bills Are Awaiting Newsom’s Signature, or Veto
abstract: The California governor must decide about labor bills and a sweeping measure to seal criminal records, matters that have drawn intense lobbying from both sides.
lead_paragraph: The countdown has begun.

headline: Moosewood, the Beloved Vegetarian Restaurant, Prepares for Its Second Act
abstract: The Ithaca, N.Y., destination was revolutionary because of its menu and its collective ownership model. Recently, the new owners hosted a dinner to celebrate its past and future.
lead_paragraph: ON A WARM evening earlier this summer, 16 of the 19 former owners of the Moosewood Restaurant in downtown Ithaca, N.Y. — widely acknowledged to be the country’s longest-running vegetarian restaurant — sat around three tables in its newly renovated main dining room and feasted on a flurry of family-style dishes. To start, there were boards loaded with local cheeses, pickles, Bing cherries and housemade crackers, bites from which were enjoyed with glasses of cold sparkling wine from Lakewood, a local vineyard. Wafting from the kitchen was the smell of sautéed onions, saffron and tomatoes, the makings of a chickpea stew that was served over seared panisses along with plates of white bean and fresh pea hummus garnished with edible flowers. The energy was jubilant — while most of those in attendance had been working together for decades, they hadn’t gathered as a group like this in years — and the music, “The Bowie Variations” (2011) by the pianist Mike Garson, was just right.

headline: A Draft for Russia’s Army? Putin Opts for Domestic Stability Instead.
abstract: Western officials are puzzled by the Russian leader’s decision to avoid mass conscription. But analysts say he is intent on maintaining a sense of normalcy to prevent any public backlash.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin says Russia is fighting for its very existence in Ukraine, taking on a country that is conspiring with the West to destroy his nation. In high-octane talk shows on state television, the war is presented as a continuation of the Soviet Union’s fight for survival against Nazi Germany.

headline: Snap Cuts 20% of Employees and Restructures
abstract: The maker of Snapchat discontinued some of its products and appointed a chief operating officer, amid financial struggles.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the maker of the ephemeral messaging app Snapchat, is laying off 20 percent of its employees, discontinuing at least six products and appointing its first chief operating officer in seven years, the financially struggling social media company said on Wednesday.

headline: Read the Justice Department’s Response to Trump’s Request for a Special Master
abstract: The Justice Department rebuffed the former president’s request for an independent arbiter, arguing that one was “unnecessary and would significantly harm important governmental interests, including national security interests.”
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department rebuffed the former president’s request for an independent arbiter, arguing that one was “unnecessary and would significantly harm important governmental interests, including national security interests.”

headline: F.D.A. Authorizes Updated Covid Booster Shots Targeting Omicron Subvariants
abstract: The agency cleared two options aimed at subvariants that are now dominant, hoping to curtail a fall or winter surge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday authorized the first redesign of coronavirus vaccines since they were rolled out in late 2020, setting up millions of Americans to receive new booster doses targeting Omicron subvariants as soon as next week.

headline: A Pair of Ahmad Jamal Live Albums Capture an Innovator in His Prime
abstract: The pianist, 92, has been hesitant to glance back: “I’m still evolving, whenever I sit down at the piano.”
lead_paragraph: The first time Ahmad Jamal put out a live recording with his trio, it was an unexpected smash. “At the Pershing: But Not for Me,” from 1958, became one of the best-selling instrumental records of its time. Since then, in an extraordinary career spanning more than 75 years, this piano eminence has released dozens more live albums, a catalog sprinkled with gems.

headline: Zach Sang, the Ryan Seacrest of the Youth, Wants to Save Radio
abstract: The former syndication star and top-flight interviewer is rebuilding his daily show on Amazon’s new app, Amp.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One afternoon in June, Zach Sang was curled into an improvised studio nook at the top of a staircase in a warehouse in Hollywood. The setup was ramshackle — right downstairs was the fallow set for Hailey Bieber’s YouTube series “Who’s in My Bathroom?” — but Sang didn’t let the scrappy conditions get to him.

headline: Many Developed Countries View Online Misinformation as ‘Major Threat’
abstract: New research from the Pew Research Center shows nearly three-quarters of respondents are very concerned about the spread of false information online.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three-quarters of people across 19 countries believe that the spread of false information online is a “major threat,” according to a survey released on Wednesday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: With ‘House of the Dragon’ and ‘The Rings of Power,’ We’ve Entered the Age of Blockbuster TV
abstract: To truly rule the television world, the two fantasy series need to borrow from one another’s strengths.
lead_paragraph: The past 25 years of American television, like the history of J.R.R. Tolkien’s Middle-earth, can be usefully divided into several ages. First came the age of Prestige TV, dominated by auteurs and antiheroes, 1970s-style reimaginings of classic cinematic genres, think pieces about Dickensian storytelling, Sunday-night appointments with HBO. It was succeeded by the age of Peak TV, in which proliferating streaming platforms competed to produce as much content as possible, in a repetitive churn dominated by B+ knockoffs of the prestige era’s biggest hits.

headline: Where Did Those Hot Dog Fingers Come From? Daniels Explain
abstract: The directors of “Everything Everywhere All at Once” have found the reaction to their film “humbling and inspiring and confusing.”
lead_paragraph: When “Everything Everywhere All at Once” opened in March in a handful of theaters, its creators, the directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, weren’t sure what to expect. The film had stars — “I thought we could bill it as ‘Michelle Yeoh fights Jamie Lee Curtis,’” Scheinert said — but was otherwise tough to pigeonhole. It was a multiverse picture, sure, but instead of superheroes and spaceships, there were fights with fanny packs, cinematic shout-outs to Wong Kar-wai and Stanley Kubrick, and a singing raccoon. And then there was the pandemic, and who knew what that might do to box office numbers? “I went in with very low expectations, because there were a lot of unknowns,” Kwan said.

headline: Show ID to Buy Whipped Cream? N.Y. Law Stirs Confusion at Checkout
abstract: A law intended to curb the inhalation of nitrous oxide among teenagers was interpreted by some to be an all-out ban on whipped-cream canisters.
lead_paragraph: Stewart’s Shops in New York are known for their pints and half-gallons of ice cream in flavors like black raspberry, “Adirondack bear paw” and “blueberry pie in the sky.” But try to add a can of whipped cream to your grocery cart and you may be stopped at checkout.

headline: The First A.P. African American Studies Class Is Coming This Fall
abstract: The new course will undergo a pilot program in 60 schools, as the debate over how to teach history becomes ever more divisive.
lead_paragraph: The College Board is jumping into the fray over how to teach the history of race in the United States with a new Advanced Placement course and exam on African American studies that will be tried out in about 60 high schools this fall.

headline: Cooking With the Three Sisters
abstract: As I sat down to write this, I saw a crinkly beige leaf float from the London Plane tree outside my window. This shocks me every summer — that there are a few rogue leaves falling weeks ahead of any autumnal chill. It always makes me want to eat as many tomatoes, watermelons, ears of corn and drippy cones of soft serve as I possibly can before the arrival of Labor Day clicks our brains into Fall Mode. Only a few days to go!
lead_paragraph: As I sat down to write this, I saw a crinkly beige leaf float from the London Plane tree outside my window. This shocks me every summer — that there are a few rogue leaves falling weeks ahead of any autumnal chill. It always makes me want to eat as many tomatoes, watermelons, ears of corn and drippy cones of soft serve as I possibly can before the arrival of Labor Day clicks our brains into Fall Mode. Only a few days to go!

headline: The European Union moves to restrict visas to Russians, but does not ban them.
abstract: The suspension of a 2007 agreement with Russia will make visas cost more, require more paperwork and involve longer delays.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After a heated debate, European foreign ministers agreed on Wednesday to suspend a 2007 agreement with Russia that makes it easier for Russians to get visas to travel to the European Union.

headline: What to Know About the New Booster Shots
abstract: The F.D.A. just cleared new shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
lead_paragraph: With fall and winter looming, along with an anticipated seasonal surge in Covid cases, the Food and Drug Administration has authorized a new tool for battling the pandemic: updated booster shots.

headline: Our Best Labor Day Recipes
abstract: Potato salad, grilled zucchini, a plum torte: all the dishes to make the summer’s last long weekend great.
lead_paragraph: You’ve worked hard all year, and maybe even all summer. So why not take the unofficial last weekend of the season off to honor workers — and yourself? Or maybe you’d rather not think of work at all, and just spend the time surrounded by loved ones?

headline: A Looming Sale and Another Losing Season Complicate Ohtani’s Future
abstract: “I think it’s all up in the air,” Mike Trout said of the Angels’ attempts to persuade Shohei Ohtani, their two-way superstar, to stay beyond next season.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Spirited chants of “M-V-P! M-V-P!” filled the warm night air here this week. Pinstriped Yankees fans dominated the crowd in appreciation of Aaron Judge and what might be coming for the slugging outfielder. With considerably less gusto, beleaguered Angels fans answered those M.V.P. calls in favor of Shohei Ohtani as a respite from their grim reality.

headline: Breaching Dams ‘Must Be an Option’ to Save Salmon, Washington Democrats Say
abstract: The state relies heavily on hydroelectric power generated by four dams, which have contributed to the depletion of the salmon population that is critical to the region’s ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two top Democrats in Washington State have come out in favor of eventually breaching four hydroelectric dams in the lower Snake River to try to save endangered salmon runs, a contentious option that environmentalists, tribes and business groups in the region have argued over for decades.

headline: Do You Use Wordle in Your Classroom? Tell Us How!
abstract: We’d love to include your ideas in a forthcoming lesson plan.
lead_paragraph: We know teachers are as obsessed with Wordle as everyone else, and we’re working on a comprehensive lesson plan that will explore ways to experiment with the game and all that it can teach. We’d love your help.

headline: California is in for extreme heat through the Labor Day weekend.
abstract: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in much of California, with elevated fire risk and strains on the state’s power grid.
lead_paragraph: After a relatively mild summer, California faces a long and possibly record-setting heat wave through Labor Day weekend, with triple-digit temperatures expected across some parts of the state.

headline: After Truck Spills on Highway, ‘Alfredo Sauce Is Everywhere’
abstract: An overturned truck in Memphis covered the road in Alfredo sauce. It reportedly smelled great — at first.
lead_paragraph: The Alfredo sauce was everywhere.

headline: Gorbachev Freed the Soviet Union but Could Not Save It
abstract: He was a rock star for a nation at rock bottom.
lead_paragraph: Back in the old Soviet Union, the political joke was the principal underground conduit of political opinion. One that made the rounds soon after Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985 posed this question: “Who supports Gorbachev in the Politburo?” The answer: “Nobody has to. He can move around on his own.”

headline: 10 Ideas for Building Community at the Start of the School Year
abstract: Inspired by lighthearted New York Times features from across sections, these exercises can help students get to know one another.
lead_paragraph: Happy school year 2022-23! To celebrate, we’re reminding you of a few favorite New York Times and Learning Network features that might offer your students fun ways to get to know one another and to practice working together.

headline: Yankees Plant Flag in European Soccer (Again) With Stake in A.C. Milan
abstract: Milan, a seven-time European champion, was acquired by RedBird Capital for $1.2 billion. The investment firm has ties to both the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: A.C. Milan, the storied Italian soccer team, is teaming up with another storied franchise: the New York Yankees.

headline: How the Picture of Top Secret Folders at Mar-a-Lago Came About
abstract: Federal agents arrayed classified materials on a floor at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida residence for a photograph as a standard part of their evidence-gathering procedures.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department used 35 pages of type in a court filing on Tuesday to provide new details of its investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of hundreds of classified documents that were taken from the White House at the end of his term.

headline: When Fetterman Declined to Debate, Oz Made His Stroke an Issue
abstract: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the Republican nominee for Senate in Pennsylvania, has taunted his Democratic rival, Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, about his recovery.
lead_paragraph: It began with a spat over crudités. It has escalated, with one Senate hopeful openly mocking another’s health after a stroke.

headline: Trump’s Lawyers May Become Witnesses or Targets in Documents Investigation
abstract: Two lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump are under increased scrutiny after new details emerged about a failure to fully comply with a subpoena for documents marked as classified.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump are likely to become witnesses or targets in the investigation into how he hoarded documents marked as classified at his Florida estate — and secretly held onto some even after they claimed all sensitive materials had been returned, legal specialists said.

headline: Romeo Santos Reveals Another Volume of Boundary-Crossing Bachata
abstract: “Fórmula Vol. 3” soars when it expands the scope of the genre and the singer’s own approaches to its trademarks, but falls flat when it relies on backward-looking tropes.
lead_paragraph: Ever since he left the Bronx boy band Aventura a decade ago to go solo, the bachata luminary Romeo Santos has been teaching a graduate seminar in melodrama. He is a disciplined thespian, especially across his “Fórmula” series, a collection of albums driven by audacious, genre-crossing collaborations and intrepid experiments with pop, hip-hop and reggaeton.

headline: Toyota adds $2.5 billion to its investment in a North Carolina battery plant.
abstract: The plan is part of a global push by the automaker to develop and produce electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Toyota Motor said on Wednesday that it was more than doubling its investment in a battery plant in North Carolina as part of a broader effort to catch up to rivals in fielding electric vehicles.

headline: Is Harry Styles Co-opting a Queer Identity?
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay about the singer’s use of queer symbols. Also: Gorbachev’s death; filling empty theater seats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ars Nova Introduces a Name Your Price Ticketing Model
abstract: For its upcoming season, audiences can pay what they wish. Tickets will start at $5 and increase in $5 increments up to $100 per ticket.
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway incubator Ars Nova will allow audience members to pay what they wish for theater tickets in a new initiative called “What’s Ars Is Yours: Name Your Price,” the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: In His Twilight, a Conductor Revisits Where His Career Dawned
abstract: Michael Tilson Thomas, in the face of an aggressive brain cancer, returned to his roots to conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Michael Tilson Thomas had just brought the first movement of Copland’s Symphony No. 3 to a radiant close here at Tanglewood on Saturday night when applause broke out at the back of the Shed.

headline: Conservative Lawyer a Likely Target in Atlanta Trump Investigation, His Lawyer Says
abstract: John Eastman, who developed strategies to block certification of the 2020 election, appeared before a grand jury in Atlanta on Wednesday and invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — John Eastman, the lawyer who developed strategies to block certification of the 2020 election, is “probably a target” in the criminal investigation into efforts to overturn Donald J. Trump’s election loss in Georgia, one of Mr. Eastman’s lawyers said on Wednesday. Mr. Eastman spent the morning appearing before an Atlanta special grand jury looking into the matter.

headline: As New York’s Gun Law Goes Into Effect, Demand for Permits Spikes
abstract: Those who want to carry concealed weapons will have to undertake 16 hours of classroom training and provide character references.
lead_paragraph: By the time the Niagara County Courthouse opened on Wednesday morning, 150 people were lined up to apply for permits that would let them carry concealed handguns in public. Nearly 100 had camped out overnight, some staying awake in folding chairs and taking regular walks to keep warm.

headline: Families of Israelis Killed at Munich Olympics Reach Compensation Deal
abstract: The Israeli and German governments announced an agreement after the families said they would boycott a memorial observing the 1972 attack over what they called insufficient recompense.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — The German government has reached an agreement with the families of 11 Israeli athletes killed by Palestinian militants at the Munich Olympics in 1972, the Israeli and German governments announced on Wednesday.

headline: Virginia Judge Dismisses Case That Sought to Limit Book Sales
abstract: Two petitions sought to block Barnes & Noble and independent booksellers from selling “Gender Queer” and “A Court of Mist and Fury” to minors in Virginia because of the books’ sexual content.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Virginia on Tuesday dismissed an attempt to prevent bookstores in the state, including Barnes & Noble, from selling two books to minors that they said were obscene because of their sexual content.

headline: The Wing Shuts Down
abstract: The well-financed women’s club came to represent an Instagram-friendly, for-profit feminism. Then its lofty flight crashed.
lead_paragraph: The Wing, the women’s-only social club and co-working space that opened in New York in 2016, has been shut down by its parent company. For many professional women, the Wing, which grew to have locations in San Francisco, Chicago and Los Angeles, came to represent an empowerment movement following the election of Donald Trump.

headline: Gov. Jay Inslee Is Taking a Well-Earned Climate Victory Lap
abstract: “I didn’t end up in the White House, but I do believe that my policies have, which is a thrill.”
lead_paragraph: The landmark Inflation Reduction Act isn’t even a month old, and though internecine fights continue about its estimated value and likely impact, at the policy level the climate saga appears to have already moved on. Last week, California announced a ban on new gasoline-powered car sales by 2035. The White House has declared it is planning a series of executive actions to add to the gains of the new legislation and bring the country as a whole closer to its stated targets: a 50 to 52 percent reduction of carbon emissions from those close-to-peak levels observed in 2005.

headline: Court Rules for Germany in Nazi-Era Dispute Over the Guelph Treasure
abstract: The Jewish heirs of German art dealers had argued that their ancestors were forced to sell the works, now valued at $250 million, at a discount because of persecution by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. federal court has ruled against the heirs of Jewish art dealers who sought to sue Germany in America over a trove of valuable medieval relics that the heirs said were sold under duress and at a drastic discount in Nazi-era Frankfurt.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Rehearsal’ and More
abstract: I am the Times’s assistant TV editor. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and reading lately.
lead_paragraph: I am the Times’s assistant TV editor. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and reading lately.

headline: ‘Publishing error’ delays Dinesh D’Souza’s book ‘2000 Mules.’
abstract: The publication date was postponed by almost two months, until Oct. 25.
lead_paragraph: Citing “a publishing error,” the publisher of a book version of “2000 Mules” — a documentary film by the conservative commentator Dinesh D’Souza that used dubious evidence and logical leaps to claim widespread ballot box fraud — said the book would be delayed until the fall.

headline: ‘A Decade of Fruitless Searching’: The Toll of Dating App Burnout
abstract: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
lead_paragraph: Abby, 28, has been on dating apps for eight years, bouncing between OkCupid, Bumble, Tinder, eHarmony, Match, WooPlus, Coffee Meets Bagel and Hinge. A committed user, she can easily spend two or more hours a day piling up matches, messaging back and forth, and planning dates with men who seem promising.

headline: What Is a ‘Fake’ Artist in 2022?
abstract: Firestorms over the “virtual rapper” FN Meka and faceless artists on Spotify have sparked conversations about alienation and creative agency.
lead_paragraph: Here’s one sort of simulated artist: This month, a virtual rapper called FN Meka became the center of a critical storm involving digital blackface and the ethics of using artificial intelligence to (re)create cultural production. As a result of the backlash, FN Meka was dropped from Capitol, the major label that had signed the project, though it was debatable exactly how much of the rapper’s music was algorithmically derived at all.

headline: Robert Kime, Decorator for Nobility and Other Notables, Dies at 76
abstract: A celebrated antiques lover with an understated, old-guard approach, his clients included Prince Charles and Andrew Lloyd Webber.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Robert Kime redecorated Clarence House, long the London home of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother — or “Queen Mum” — for Prince Charles, a friend of hers came by to survey his work. “But I don’t understand what all the fuss is about!” she was quoted as saying in The Financial Times in 2015. “Nothing has changed at all.”

headline: The West’s Illusions About Gorbachev and the Victory of Liberalism
abstract: As the Soviet Union’s final leader, Mikhail Gorbachev dreamed of a “common European home,” but three decades later that tantalizing idea remains out of reach.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Mikhail S. Gorbachev believed the Soviet Union could be preserved without recourse to violence. This proved to be a misunderstanding of the nature of the repressive empire he ruled. The Soviet imperium collapsed in 1991, its ending embraced by the West as a victory for freedom and liberal democracy.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: How Authoritarians See Mikhail Gorbachev
abstract: Plus the decline in American life expectancy and the latest on Typhoon Hinnamnor.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader whose death was announced on Tuesday, is hailed in much of the West as a visionary who brought the Cold War to a peaceful conclusion. But in other parts of the world, his legacy stands as an example of power discarded quickly and cavalierly.

headline: Matty Matheson Makes It Big
abstract: The chef, who plays a handyman on “The Bear,” has launched Rosa Rugosa, a clothing line that fits him well.
lead_paragraph: Matty Matheson has fed the world. Now he wants to dress it.

headline: World-Class Lessons on Zero-Waste
abstract: Designers from around the world find inspiration in traditional garment making in their quest to eliminate fabric waste.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: What to Know: Updated Covid Boosters
abstract: The F.D.A. on Wednesday authorized updated coronavirus boosters, the first time it has done so since the original vaccines were rolled out nearly two years ago.
lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. on Wednesday authorized updated coronavirus boosters, the first time it has done so since the original vaccines were rolled out nearly two years ago.

headline: Esther Cooper Jackson, Civil Rights Pioneer, Dies at 105
abstract: A feminist and a self-proclaimed revolutionary, she was in the forefront of the fledgling movement for economic and political equality in the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: Esther Cooper Jackson, whose voice for racial equality in the 1940s would elevate her into the vanguard of the civil rights revolution of the mid-20th century, died in Boston on Aug. 23, two days after her 105th birthday.

headline: From Gorbachev to Putin
abstract: The Russian president has spent years trying to unravel the legacy of the last Soviet leader.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: In This Energy Crisis, What’s Stocking Up? What’s Hoarding?
abstract: Winter is coming.
lead_paragraph: There are two things you don’t want to do when there’s an energy crisis. One is to suppress prices, which makes the shortage of energy even worse because consumers have less incentive to conserve and producers have less incentive to produce. The other is to hoard the limited supply of energy so you have plenty but others are left dry. Unfortunately, we’re seeing signs of both behaviors, in capitals ranging from Athens to Oslo and Washington, D.C.

headline: Omicron Boosters
abstract: The F.D.A. authorized coronavirus vaccines targeting the recent subvariants.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Virus Briefing, your comprehensive guide to the latest news and expert analysis on the coronavirus pandemic and other outbreaks.

headline: Bitter Race to Lead U.K. Is Ending With Little to Offer for Economic Ills
abstract: The contest to succeed Boris Johnson as Conservative Party leader and prime minister has often seemed divorced from Britain’s fast-growing problems.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Exhausted rather than exuberant, the two candidates to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson held their last scheduled joint campaign appearance on Wednesday, trading final jabs in a contest that has often seemed to have little to do with the economic storm clouds gathering over Britain.

headline: Michigan Board Says Abortion Referendum Should Not Go to Voters
abstract: Abortion rights supporters gathered more than 750,000 signatures, but the petitions they circulated had formatting problems.
lead_paragraph: A state board in Michigan refused on Wednesday to place an abortion rights referendum on the November ballot because of a dispute over word spacing on the petition, an embarrassing blow to abortion rights supporters who had gathered more than 750,000 signatures.

headline: Charlbi Dean, Star of Top Winner at Cannes, Dies at 32
abstract: A South African-born actress and model, she had a breakout role in the satirical “Triangle of Sadness,” due in theaters in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Charlbi Dean, an actress and model who plays a lead role in the film satire “Triangle of Sadness,” which won the top award at the Cannes Film Festival this year and will be released in the fall, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 32.

headline: Could the Courts Block Biden’s Student Loan Relief Plan?
abstract: Just last year, President Biden himself cast doubt on whether he had the authority to cancel student loan debt on such a broad basis.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.N. Says China May Have Committed ‘Crimes Against Humanity’ in Xinjiang
abstract: The organization’s human rights office delivered its much-delayed report minutes before Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, was to leave office.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In a long-awaited report released on Wednesday, the United Nations’ human rights office accused China of actions that “may constitute international crimes, in particular crimes against humanity,” in its mass detention of Uyghurs and other predominantly Muslim groups in its far western region of Xinjiang.

headline: Commuter Tunnel Under the Hudson Won’t Be Finished Until 2035
abstract: The crucial Gateway transit link from New Jersey to New York will now open three years later than expected and is likely to cost $2 billion more to construct.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, the head of Amtrak warned that the century-old rail tunnel connecting New Jersey to Midtown Manhattan would have to be shut down in some form by 2034 to address the ravages of age and Hurricane Sandy.

headline: As Republicans Turn to Fall Races, Their Sites Downplay Trump and Abortion
abstract: At least 10 Republican candidates in competitive races have updated their websites to minimize their ties to the former president or to adjust their stances on abortion.
lead_paragraph: For months, the campaign website for Adam Laxalt, the Republican Senate nominee in Nevada, greeted visitors with a huge banner exalting his endorsement from former President Donald J. Trump in all capital letters. Now, that information is nowhere on his home page.

headline: Robert LuPone, Actor Who Became a Behind-the-Scenes Force, Dies at 76
abstract: After playing a critical Broadway role in “A Chorus Line,” he helped start the vibrant Off Broadway MCC Theater. TV watchers knew him from “The Sopranos” and “Law and Order.”
lead_paragraph: Robert LuPone, an actor and dancer who originated the role of the driven director-choreographer in the musical “A Chorus Line” on Broadway and later helped run a vibrant Off Broadway theater company known for thought-provoking new works, died on Saturday in Albany, N.Y. He was 76.

headline: Columbus Police Release Body Camera Footage of Fatal Shooting
abstract: The video shows a Black man, Donovan Lewis, sitting up in bed and raising his hand before an officer fires. The police chief said the authorities had found a vape pen cartridge on the bed.
lead_paragraph: A police officer fatally shot an unarmed Black man in an apartment in Columbus, Ohio, early Tuesday morning, moments after encountering him during an attempt to serve a felony warrant, body camera footage released hours after the shooting shows.

headline: Disney Considers a Membership Plan to Leverage Its Empire for Disney+
abstract: Seeking to fulfill a promise to make Disney+ profitable by 2024, the company is weighing stepping up its efforts to cross-sell its offerings.
lead_paragraph: Disney has been looking for ways to link its flagship streaming service more closely with other parts of its empire, including theme parks, cruise vacations and stores, as it works to fulfill a promise to make Disney+ profitable by 2024. On Wednesday, the company confirmed that one idea involves a membership program that would offer companywide discounts or special perks.

headline: ‘Los Otros’ Review: A Slow-Burning Tale of Melancholy
abstract: Michael John LaChiusa’s delicate new musical starts in Depression-era California and follows two people across six decades.
lead_paragraph: There are musicals that hit you over the head with the instant familiarity of pop songs, or with the thrill of anthems belted to the back of the rear mezzanine. Michael John LaChiusa does not go for any of that, though he came close in 2000 with the jaggedly jazzy, underestimated “The Wild Party,” his most recent Broadway outing as a composer and lyricist.

headline: In ‘Once Upon a (korean) Time,’ Bedtime Stories to Keep You Up at Night
abstract: Daniel K. Isaac’s stylistically daring play at La MaMa doesn’t quite fulfill its promise, but it suggests the playwright has more stories to tell.
lead_paragraph: Korean fairy tales can trend macabre; a few skew more grisly than even the Brothers Grimm. In the Korean version of “Cinderella,” for instance, Cinderella dies. (For a while, anyway.) Murder, starvation, and sacrifice form the dark heart of this folk tradition, at least in the tales that Daniel K. Isaac tells in “Once Upon a (korean) Time,” a production from Ma-Yi Theater Company that opened on Wednesday at La MaMa.

headline: U.N. Experts Plan Perilous Visit to Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Thursday
abstract: The international team prepared to cross the front lines to inspect the embattled, Russian-held Zaporizhzhia plant, but it was not clear how long the Russians would let them stay.
lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — An international team of nuclear experts on Wednesday approached the combat zone in Russia’s war on Ukraine, preparing to cross over the front lines on Thursday to inspect the imperiled, Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, in one of the most complex and perilous missions of its kind ever attempted.

headline: The Man Who Did the Math on America’s Partisan Divisions
abstract: Howard Rosenthal, a political scientist who died last week, had keen insights into the rise of Donald Trump, and he helped develop a formula to quantify roll-call votes in Congress and give them a partisan score.
lead_paragraph: When Howard Rosenthal died last week, he left behind an important body of work that will live on well after he is forgotten.

headline: Trump’s Legal Jab Left Him Open to Justice Dept. Strike
abstract: A legal back-and-forth produced a straightforward narrative of how Mr. Trump and his lawyers repeatedly dodged the government’s attempts to recover sensitive documents for more than a year.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump may have thought that he was playing offense when he asked a federal judge last week for an independent review of documents seized from his residence in Florida — a move that, at best, could delay but not derail an investigation into his handling of the records.

headline: How the Pandemic Shortened Life Expectancy in Indigenous Communities
abstract: New federal data outline the scale of suffering among Native Americans and Alaska Natives.
lead_paragraph: Carol Schumacher, 56, who was raised in the remote community of Chilchinbeto in the Navajo Nation, has lost 42 family members to Covid-19 over the last two years. The dead included two brothers aged 55 and 54, and cousins as young as 18 and 19.

headline: Tiger Woods among the celebrities who show up to see Serena Williams in the U.S. Open.
abstract: Tiger Woods was among the celebrities at Arthur Ashe Stadium, along with Zendaya and Dionne Warwick.
lead_paragraph: Two nights after a number of politicians, A-list actors and professional athletes came to see Serena Williams play in the first round of the U.S. Open, the stars aligned again.

headline: Reported Sexual Assaults in Military Rose 13% in 2021, Officials Say
abstract: The easing of coronavirus restrictions may have contributed to the increase.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Reports of sexual assaults in the military rose sharply in 2021, once again defying efforts by the Pentagon to address a problem that has long bedeviled the men and women who serve in the country’s armed forces, two U.S. officials said Wednesday.

headline: Newly Aggressive Biden Shifts From Compromise to Combat
abstract: President Biden is spending less time hailing the virtues of unity and more time calling out Republicans and dangers to democracy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden likes to say there is nothing America cannot do if the country is united and its rival parties are willing to work together.

headline: Brazilian Officials Reach Truce on Voting Machines Targeted by Bolsonaro
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro has claimed that Brazil’s voting machines are vulnerable to fraud, with little evidence. Election officials agreed to explore changes to security tests before the October election.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — President Jair Bolsonaro has made Brazil’s electronic voting machines the center of his attacks on the country’s electoral system, despite little evidence that the machines are at risk, raising concerns he will contest the presidential election results if he loses in October.

headline: Coco Gauff Warms Up the Court for Serena Williams, and Gets a Win
abstract: The 18-year-old American beat Elena-Gabriela Ruse of Romania, 6-2, 7-6 (4), to advance to the third round at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: A few hours before Serena Williams would walk into Arthur Ashe Stadium on Wednesday night for the second-round match everyone was waiting for, Coco Gauff warmed up the hardcourt with a win.
